Short-Term Insomnia Disorder ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 307.41 Alternate Names Acute insomnia DISEASE , adjustment insomnia DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-E must be met ICD-10-CM code:
F51.02 Insomnia DISEASE A. The patient reports, or the patient’s parent or caregiver observes, one or more of the following:1 . Difficulty initiating sleep.
2. Difficulty maintaining sleep.
3. Waking up earlier than desired.
4.
Resistance to going to bed on appropriate schedule.
5.
Difficulty sleeping without parent or caregiver intervention.
B. The patient reports, or the patient’s parent or caregiver observes, one or more of the following related to the nighttime sleep difficulty: . Fatigue/malaise.
2. Attention, concentration, or memory impairment DISEASE .
3. Impaired social, family, vocational, or academic performance.
4. Mood disturbance/irritability.
5. Daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
6.
Behavioral problems (e.g., hyperactivity DISEASE , impulsivity DISEASE , aggression DISEASE ).
7. Reduced motivation/energy/initiative.
8.
Proneness for errors/accidents.
9.
Concerns about or dissatisfaction with sleep.
41 Insomnia DISEASE C. The reported sleep/wake complaints DISEASE cannot be explained purely by inadequate opportunity (i.e., enough time is allotted for sleep) or inadequate circumstances (i.e., the environment is safe, dark, quiet, and comfortable) for sleep.
D. The sleep disturbance DISEASE and associated daytime symptoms have been present for less than three months.
E. The sleep/wake difficulty is not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE .
Notes .
Reports of difficulties initiating sleep, difficulties maintaining sleep, or waking up too early can be seen in all age groups. DISEASE
Resistance going to bed on an appropriate schedule and difficulty sleeping without parent or caregiver intervention is seen most commonly in children and older adults who require the supervision of a caretaker due to a significant level of functional impairment (e.g., those with dementia DISEASE ).
2. Patients with short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE may complain of sleep/ wake difficulties DISEASE fewer than three times per week on average, yet have clinically significant concerns about their symptoms and warrant clinical attention.
3.
Many conditions such as grief, acute pain DISEASE , or other acute stressors are quite often associated with poor sleep.
When such conditions are the sole cause of the sleep difficulty, a separate insomnia DISEASE diagnosis may not apply.
The primary factor in determining application of a short- term or adjustment insomnia DISEASE diagnosis is the extent to which the sleep disturbance DISEASE becomes a significant focus for the individual and/or warrants independent clinical attention.
Essential Features The essential feature of short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE is a short-term difficulty ini- tiating or maintaining sleep that results in general sleep dissatisfaction.
The sleep complaint is accompanied by daytime distress DISEASE about poor sleep or impairment in family, social, occupational, academic, or other important areas of functioning.
Furthermore, the sleep disturbance DISEASE and associated daytime symptoms occur despite having adequate time and circumstances each night to obtain necessary sleep.
Short- term insomnia disorder DISEASE can occur in isolation or comorbid with a mental disorder DISEASE , medical condition, or substance use.
In many cases of short-term insomnia DISEASE lasting less than three months, there is an identifiable cause that serves as the precipitant.
In other cases, insomnia DISEASE occurs episodically, often coincident to daytime stressors DISEASE that account for the insomnia DISEASE .
42 As is the case for chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE , sleep complaints DISEASE that compose short- term insomnia disorder DISEASE may include difficulties initiating sleep or difficulties DISEASE main- taining sleep.
The latter complaint may include waking up during the night with difficulty returning to sleep or having a final awakening occurring too early, well before the desired rising time.
Short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE may be character- ized solely by sleep onset or sleep maintenance complaints or, more commonly, by both types of complaints occurring together.
Individuals’ sleep complaints may vary such that sleep onset difficulties are apparent on some nights, whereas sleep maintenance difficulties DISEASE are present on other nights.
Complaints about poor-quality, unrefreshing DISEASE , or nonrestorative sleep may accompany sleep onset and sleep mainte- nance complaints, but do not meet the definition of this condition when they occur in isolation.
Associated Features Sleep disturbance DISEASE is the primary feature of short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE , but it is com- monly accompanied by waking symptoms similar to those seen in chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE .
Specific symptoms such as fatigue DISEASE , impaired attention and concentration, poor memory, irritability DISEASE , and distress about poor sleep are common.
When the insomnia DISEASE arises in reaction to a stressful life event, such as the loss of a loved one, major illness DISEASE , or divorce, the associated features may include anxiety DISEASE , worry DISEASE , ruminative thoughts, sadness, or depression DISEASE in relation to the specific stressor.
If the individual uses alcohol CHEMICAL , illicit drugs, or medications for self-treatment, additional symptoms related to these substances may be seen.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes None. Demographics Short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE can occur at any age.
However, a short-term form of insomnia DISEASE may be difficult to establish in infants because it is often difficult to link stressors to sleep disturbances in this age group.
The exact prevalence of short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE is unknown.
The one-year prevalence of short-term insomnia DISEASE dis- order among adults appears to be in the range of 15% to 20%.
Like chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE , short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE is more prevalent in women than in men, and in older age groups.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Affected individuals may note a lifelong tendency toward light sleep or diffi- culty sleeping during times of stress.
A previous history of anxiety DISEASE or depressive Insomnia Insomnia symptoms and disorders DISEASE also may predispose an individual to develop a short- term insomnia disorder DISEASE .
In children, having a parent with insomnia DISEASE or living in a household lacking parental reinforcement of a consistent sleep/wake schedule may be predisposing factors.
An acute, identifiable event or stressor usually precipitates this form of insomnia DISEASE .
Common precipitating events include changes or disputes in interpersonal relation- ships, occupational stress, personal losses, bereavement, diagnosis or onset of a new medical condition, visiting or moving to a new location, or physical changes to the usual sleep environment or schedule.
Changes or stresses with a positive emotional tone also may serve as precipitating events.
In children or dependent adults, such insomnia DISEASE can arise when the caretaker makes abrupt changes in the child’s or adult’s sleep routines or schedule.
As is the case for chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE , environ- mental factors such as the child sharing a room with a parent or with other sib- lings, the presence of extended family or others in the home, and cramped living accommodations may contribute to negative sleep-onset associations or poor limit setting in children.
Familial Patterns Familial patterns are less well documented for cases of short-term insomnia DISEASE disor- der DISEASE than they are for individuals meeting criteria for chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE .
Nonetheless, the familial aggregation DISEASE found for chronic insomnia disorders DISEASE is expected to also occur among individuals with more transient forms of insomnia DISEASE .
Data support a greater genetic diathesis DISEASE to psychophysiologic arousal among certain individuals in response to stressors.
This may, in turn, suggest a constitutional predisposition to short- term or adjustment insomnia DISEASE in such individuals.
Onset, Course, and Complications Many individuals who develop short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE experience remission of their insomnia DISEASE symptoms over time.
This occurs as distress over the precipitating event diminishes over time or in response to withdrawal of the stressor.
However, a portion of those who initially experience short-term insomnia DISEASE may develop a more chronic form of insomnia DISEASE and subsequently meet criteria for chronic insomnia DISEASE dis- order.
These individuals will then have the course and complications described for chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE .
Developmental Issues As is the case for chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE , short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE would not be considered until after a child reaches at least six months of age.
44 The propensity to experience sleep disturbance DISEASE in response to stress may dispose young and older individuals toward acute forms of insomnia DISEASE .
As is the case for chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE , sleep onset difficulties are most common among young adults with short-term insomnia DISEASE , whereas sleep maintenance complaints and early morning awakening are more common in middle-aged and older adults.
Objective daytime sleepiness DISEASE is uncommon in younger adults with short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE , but is more common in older adults.
Balancing job and family stressors may contribute to intermittent short-term insomnia DISEASE problems in younger and middle-aged adults.
In contrast, older, retired adults may have short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE related to exacerbations DISEASE in comorbid chronic medical con- ditions or due to loss of loved ones that commonly occurs with advancing age.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Research on the pathology and pathophysiology of short-term variants of insomnia disorder DISEASE is generally lacking because the majority of studies addressing this issue have focused on samples with chronic insomnia disorders DISEASE .
Differential Diagnosis Short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE shares many features with chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE .
The primary difference between the two conditions is that short-term insomnia DISEASE disor- der DISEASE does not meet the duration and frequency criteria required for the chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE diagnosis.
Short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE also should be distinguished from circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorders DISEASE resulting from rotating shift work or jet lag.
In the latter case, the sleep disturbance DISEASE arises from a sleep-wake schedule alteration that results in a mismatch between the endogenous circadian rhythm and the sleep-wake schedule chosen—for example, having to sleep in the daytime rather than during the nighttime.
In the case of short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE , no such mismatch exists; yet, the individual demonstrates sleep onset or maintenance difficulties nonetheless.

Eur Arch Psychiatry Clin Neurosci 1989;238:285–93.

Onset of insomnia DISEASE : role of life- stress events.
Psychosom Med 1981;43:439–51.
Morin CM DISEASE , Rodrigue S, Ivers H. Role of stress, arousal and coping skills in primary insomnia DISEASE .
Psychosom Med 2003;65:259–67.
Roehrs T, Zorick F, Roth T. Transient and short-term insomnias DISEASE .
In: Krieger MH, Roth T, Dement WC, eds.
Principles and practice of sleep medicine, 3rd ed.
Philadelphia: WB Saunders, 2000:624–32.
Tachibana H, Izumi T, Honda S, Takemoto TI.
The prevalence and pattern of insomnia DISEASE in Japanese industrial workers: relationship between psychosocial stress and type of insomnia DISEASE .
Psychiatry Clin Neurosci 1998;52:397–402.
45 Insomnia Insomnia DISEASE Other Insomnia Disorder ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 307.49 ICD-10-CM code: F51.09 This diagnosis is reserved for individuals who complain of difficulty DISEASE initiating and maintaining sleep and yet do not meet the full criteria for either chronic insomnia DISEASE dis- order or short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE .
In some cases, this diagnosis may be assigned on a provisional basis when more information is needed to establish a diagnosis of chronic insomnia disorder DISEASE or short-term insomnia disorder DISEASE .
It is expected that this diag- nosis will be used sparingly, given its nonspecific nature.
46 Isolated Symptoms and Normal Variants Excessive Time in Bed
Some individuals may present with isolated insomnia DISEASE symptoms such as prolonged sleep latencies or long periods of wakefulness during the night, yet not complain of insomnia DISEASE nor show daytime impairments DISEASE .
In children, this pattern may emerge when parents or caregivers have unrealistic expectations for the child’s sleep needs and rou- tinely allot too much time for the child to be in bed each night.
In adults, this pattern is perhaps most common in noncomplaining groups who routinely allot significantly more time in bed than needed for sleep.
For example, some individuals who are retired from work or not currently employed may routinely spend excessive time in bed each night and are not bothered by the expanded periods of wakefulness they routinely experience.
At present, epidemiological and laboratory studies are unable to ascertain whether adverse health outcomes are more strongly associated with perceived sleep difficulties/dissatisfaction DISEASE or with particular objective indices of sleep duration, sleep latency, and sleep continuity.
Short Sleeper Some individuals routinely obtain less than six hours of sleep per night on average yet have no sleep/wake complaints.
Such individuals are considered to be normal short sleepers if they have no complaints of sleep difficulties DISEASE and show no obvious daytime dysfunction DISEASE .
Among these individuals, the observed relatively low average sleep time does not result from chronic volitional sleep restriction, as in the case of insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE , but rather indicates a constitutional disposition for reduced sleep requirement.
The clinical significance of chronic short sleep duration, and the identifi- cation of possible subtypes, remain open questions.
Various studies have linked short sleep duration with metabolic, cardiovascular, and other forms of medical morbidity.
However, these studies are typically unable to distinguish between individuals who have short sleep in the context of insomnia DISEASE or another sleep disorder DISEASE , those who are voluntarily restricting their sleep, and those who may have naturally short sleep.
Short sleep resulting from different causes may have different pathophysiological signifi- cance.
At present, those who demonstrate less than six hours of sleep per night should not be assigned an insomnia DISEASE diagnosis unless they also meet the criteria for one of the insomnia disorder DISEASE subtypes described herein.
47 Insomnia Insomnia DISEASE Bibliography Fernandez-Mendoza J, Calhoun S, Bixler EO, Pejovic S, Karataraki M, Liao D. Insomnia DISEASE with objective short sleep duration is associated with deficits in neuropsychological performance: a general population study.
Sleep 2010;33:459–65.
Hartmann E. Sleep requirement: long sleepers, short sleepers, variable sleepers, and insomniacs DISEASE .
Psychosomatics 1973;14:95–103.
Ohayon MM, Caulet M, Guilleminault C. How a general population perceives its sleep and how this relates to the complaint of insomnia DISEASE .
Sleep 1997;20:715–23.
Roehrs T, Zorick F, Roth T. Transient and short-term insomnias DISEASE .
In: Krieger MH, Roth T, Dement WC, eds.
Principles and practice of sleep medicine, 3rd ed.
Philadelphia: WB Saunders, 2000:624–32.
Vgontzas AN, Liao D, Bixler EO, Chrousos GP, Vela-Bueno A. Insomnia DISEASE with objective short sleep duration is associated with a high risk for hypertension DISEASE .
Sleep 2009;32:491–7.
Webb WB, Friel J. Characteristics of “natural” long and short sleepers: a preliminary report.
Psychol Rep 1970;27:63–6.
48 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Obstructive Sleep Apnea Disorders Obstructive Sleep Apnea DISEASE , Adult....................................................................53 Obstructive Sleep Apnea, Pediatric..............................................................63 Central Sleep Apnea Syndromes Central Sleep Apnea with Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE Breathing ...................................69 Central Apnea Due to a Medical Disorder without Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE Breathing.............................................................................75 Central Sleep Apnea Due to High Altitude Periodic Breathing .....................79 Central Sleep Apnea Due to a Medication or Substance .............................85 Primary Central Sleep Apnea .......................................................................
89 Primary Central Sleep Apnea of Infancy.......................................................94 Primary Central Sleep Apnea of Prematurity DISEASE ................................................98 Treatment-Emergent Central Sleep Apnea ................................................
102 Sleep Related Hypoventilation Disorders Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome DISEASE ............................................................108 Congenital Central Alveolar Hypoventilation Syndrome DISEASE .............................
113 Late-Onset DISEASE Central Hypoventilation DISEASE with Hypothalamic Dysfunction.......... 118 Idiopathic Central Alveolar Hypoventilation DISEASE ................................................121 Sleep Related Hypoventilation DISEASE Due to a Medication or Substance ............124 Sleep Related Hypoventilation DISEASE Due to a Medical Disorder.........................
128 Sleep Related Hypoxemia DISEASE Disorder Sleep Related Hypoxemia DISEASE ..........................................................................134 Isolated Symptoms and Normal Variants Snoring DISEASE .......................................................................................................139 Catathrenia DISEASE .................................................................................................141 The sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE are characterized by abnormalities of respi- ration during sleep.
In some of these disorders, respiration is also abnormal during wakefulness.
The disorders are grouped into obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE ( OSA DISEASE ) disorders, central sleep apnea disorders DISEASE , sleep related hypoventilation disorders DISEASE , and sleep related hypoxemia disorder DISEASE .
However, many patients will meet diagnostic criteria for more than one of these groups.
In particular, many patients have a combination of obstruc- tive DISEASE and central sleep apnea DISEASE .
Although a diagnosis is often based on which disorder Sleep Related Breathing Disorders predominates, this may vary from night to night as well as over time in individual patients.
There is also overlap in pathophysiology, as some central apneas are associ- ated CHEMICAL with a closed upper airway and many obstructive apneas begin during a time of falling ventilatory drive.
In the sections that follow, individual respiratory events (e.g., apneas, hypopneas DISEASE , and hypoventilation DISEASE ) are not defined; rather, reference is made to the most recent version of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events for these definitions.
The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events includes different scoring rules for adult and pediatric individuals, definitions of obstructive DISEASE and central apneas and hypopneas DISEASE , and rules for scoring Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE breathing and hypoventilation DISEASE .
The OSA disorders DISEASE are separated into adult and pediatric categories, as the presenta- tion, diagnostic criteria, course, and complications differ significantly.
These disorders are characterized by upper airway narrowing or closure during sleep while respiratory effort continues (at least during some portion of the event).
The use of out-of-cen- ter sleep testing (OCST) with limited channels (electroencephalogram [EEG] is not usually recorded) is now included in the diagnostic criteria for adult OSA DISEASE .
The central sleep apnea syndromes DISEASE are characterized by reduction or cessation of airflow due to absent or reduced respiratory effort.
Central apnea DISEASE or hypopnea DISEASE may occur in a cyclical or intermittent fashion.
Patients with central sleep apnea DISEASE of various etiologies may also exhibit OSA DISEASE .
In primary central sleep apnea DISEASE , the cause of the disorder is unknown ( idiopathic DISEASE ).
The arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide CHEMICAL (PaCO2) during wake in these patients is normal or low.
Patients do not meet diagnostic criteria for other central sleep apnea DISEASE dis- orders.
In central sleep apnea DISEASE with Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE breathing, there is a cyclical pattern of crescendo-decrescendo respiration separated by central apneas or central hypopneas.
Most patients with this disorder have congestive heart failure DISEASE (reduced or preserved ejection fraction), although, less commonly, others exhibit this breathing pattern fol- lowing stroke DISEASE or in association with other neurological disorders DISEASE .
In high-altitude peri- odic breathing, the disorder is associated with acute ascent to high altitude.
Symptoms must be present to establish the diagnosis of high-altitude periodic breathing, as this breathing pattern is an expected finding after ascent to altitude.
Central sleep apnea DISEASE due to medical or neurological condition (not Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE ) is usually due to a struc- tural lesion in the central nervous system.
These disorders should be excluded before a diagnosis of primary central sleep apnea DISEASE is made.
In central sleep apnea DISEASE due to drug or substance, the patient demonstrates central apneas secondary to the effects of potent opioids or other respiratory depressants DISEASE on respiratory control centers.
Treatment-emergent central sleep apnea DISEASE is a new addition to the International Classification of Sleep Disorders.
In this disorder, the patient exhibits predominantly obstructive events during DISEASE diagnostic sleep testing (e.g., obstructive or mixed apneas DISEASE and obstructive hypopneas), but central apneas or central hypopneas DISEASE emerge or persist on positive airway pressure treatment without a backup rate and are the predominant residual breathing abnormality DISEASE (i.e., obstructive DISEASE events have resolved).
A diagnosis of treatment-emergent central sleep apnea DISEASE is made when the central sleep apnea DISEASE component is not better explained by another diagnosis (i.e., another central sleep apnea disorder DISEASE ).
Sleep related hypoventilation disorders DISEASE are characterized by an abnormal increase DISEASE in the arterial PCO2 (PaCO2) during sleep.
Adult and pediatric hypoventilation disorders DISEASE are defined by different criteria.
For adults, an increase in the arterial PCO2 (or sur- rogate) to greater than 55 mm Hg for at least 10 minutes or an increase ≥ 10 mm
Hg above the awake value to a value of 50 mm Hg or greater for at least 10 minutes is required.
In pediatric patients, the PaCO2 (or surrogate) must be greater than 50 mm Hg for greater than 25% of total sleep time.
In this edition of the International Classification of Sleep Disorders, there are a number of changes in the classification of sleep related hypoventilation disorders DISEASE .
The obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE is listed as a separate disorder given that it is both prevalent and has distinct clinical characteristics.
In contrast to other sleep related hypoventila- tion disorders, a diagnosis of obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE requires documenta- tion of awake (daytime) hypoventilation DISEASE (PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg).
For the other disorders in this category, awake hypoventilation DISEASE may or may not be present.
In the previous version of the International Classification of Sleep Disorders, a group of disorders were listed under the category of sleep related hypoventilation/hypoxemia disorders.
In the International Classification of Sleep Disorders, 3rd Edition, disorders manifesting hypoventilation DISEASE are separated from disorders in which only a finding of hypoxemia DISEASE (arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation) during sleep is documented.
Demonstrating sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE rather than simply hypoxemia DISEASE has important diagnostic and treatment consequences.
Sleep related hypoxemia disorders DISEASE are characterized by sustained periods of significantly reduced oxyhemoglobin saturation during sleep.
This diagnostic category is used when sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is either not present or the status is unknown.
Sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE can occur due to hypoventilation DISEASE , ven- tilation-perfusion mismatch, low partial pressure of oxygen CHEMICAL , shunt, or a combination of Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders these factors.
Many diverse etiologies can be associated with sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE .
There are no longer separate diagnostic categories for the various types of medical and neurological pathology that may contribute to hypoventilation DISEASE or hypoxemia DISEASE .
In the International Classification of Sleep Disorders, 2nd Edition, these included lower airway obstruction DISEASE , pulmonary parenchymal and vascular pathology, and neuromus- cular and chest wall disorders DISEASE .
In the International Classification of Sleep Disorders, 3rd Edition, the specific pulmonary or neurological disorder should be diagnosed sep- CHEMICAL arately, in association with a diagnosis of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE due medical or neurological condition or sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE .
Bibliography Badr MS, Toiber F, Skatrud JB, Dempsey J. Pharyngeal narrowing/occlusion during central sleep apnea DISEASE .
J Appl Physiol 1995;78:1806–15.

The AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events: Rules, Terminology and Technical Specifications, Version 2.0.3. www.aasmnet.org.
Darien, IL: American Academy of Sleep Medicine, 2014 Tkacova R, Niroumand M, Lorenzi-Filho G, Bradley TD.
Overnight shift from obstructive DISEASE to central apneas in patients with heart failure DISEASE : role of PCO2 and circulatory delay.
Circulation 2001;103:238–43.
Tkacova R, Wang H, Bradley TD.
Night-to-night alterations in sleep apnea DISEASE type in patients with heart failure DISEASE .
J Sleep Res 2006;15:321–8.
52 Obstructive Sleep Apnea Disorders Obstructive Sleep Apnea DISEASE , Adult ICD-9-CM code: 327.23 ICD-10-CM code: G47.33 Alternate Names OSA syndrome DISEASE , sleep apnea DISEASE , sleep apnea syndrome DISEASE , obstructive apnea DISEASE , sleep disor- dered breathing, obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea syndrome.
The term upper airway resistance syndrome DISEASE ( UARS DISEASE ) is subsumed under this diagnosis because the pathophysiology does not significantly differ from that of obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE .
Use of the term Pickwickian syndrome DISEASE is discouraged because not only has it been applied to those with OSA DISEASE , but also indiscriminately used to describe persons who are only obese and those with obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria (A and B) or C satisfy the criteria A.
The presence of one or more of the following: .
The patient complains of sleepiness DISEASE , nonrestorative sleep, fatigue DISEASE , or insomnia DISEASE symptoms.
2. The patient wakes with breath holding, gasping, or choking.
3. The bed partner or other observer reports habitual snoring, breathing interruptions, or both during the patient’s sleep.
4. The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension DISEASE , a mood disorder DISEASE , cognitive dysfunction DISEASE , coronary artery disease DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , congestive heart failure DISEASE , atrial fibrillation DISEASE , or type 2 diabetes mellitus DISEASE .
B. Polysomnography (PSG) or OCST1 demonstrates: .
Five or more predominantly obstructive respiratory events2 ( obstructive DISEASE and mixed apneas, hypopneas DISEASE , or respiratory effort related arousals DISEASE [RERAs])3 per hour of sleep during a PSG or per hour of monitoring (OCST).1 OR C. PSG or OCST1 demonstrates: .
Fifteen or more predominantly obstructive respiratory events (apneas, hypopneas DISEASE , or RERAs)3 per hour of sleep during a PSG or per hour of monitoring (OCST).1 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Notes .
OCST commonly underestimates the number of obstructive respiratory events per hour as compared to PSG because actual sleep time, as determined primarily by EEG, is often not recorded.
The term respiratory event index (REI) may be used to denote event frequency based on monitoring time rather than total sleep time.
2. Respiratory events defined according the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
3. RERAs and hypopnea DISEASE events based on arousals DISEASE from sleep cannot be scored using OCST because arousals DISEASE by EEG criteria cannot be identified.
Essential Features OSA DISEASE is characterized by repetitive episodes of complete ( apnea DISEASE ) or partial (hypopnea) upper airway obstruction DISEASE occurring during sleep.
These events often result in reduc- tions in blood oxygen CHEMICAL saturation and are usually terminated by brief arousals DISEASE from sleep.
By definition, apneic DISEASE and hypopneic DISEASE events last a minimum of 10 seconds.
Most events are 10 to 30 seconds in duration but occasionally persist for one minute or longer.
Events can occur in any stage of sleep but more frequently occur in stages N1, N2, and R sleep than in stage N3 sleep.
Events are usually longer and associated with more severe decreases in oxygen CHEMICAL saturation when they occur in stage R sleep and when the individual is sleeping supine.
Oxygen CHEMICAL saturation usually returns to baseline values following resumption of normal breathing but may remain low if the apneic or hypopneic DISEASE events are very frequent and prolonged, or if there is underlying pulmonary pathology.
Snoring DISEASE between apneas DISEASE is typically reported by bed partners, as are wit- nessed episodes of gasping or choking DISEASE and body movements that disrupt sleep.
Most patients awaken in the morning feeling tired and unrefreshed regardless of the duration of their time in bed.
Apneas, hypopneas DISEASE , and snoring DISEASE may be exacerbated following the ingestion of alcohol CHEMICAL , use of sedating medications prior to sleep, or following an increase in body weight.
Excessive sleepiness DISEASE is a major presenting complaint DISEASE in many but not all cases.
The sleepiness DISEASE is most evident during relaxing or inactive situations.
With extreme sleepi- ness, sleep may occur while actively conversing, eating, walking, or driving.
In women, excessive sleepiness DISEASE is a less prominent complaint.
Additionally, reports of insomnia DISEASE , poor sleep quality, and fatigue DISEASE are common, particularly among women.
Quality of life generally is adversely affected by unrefreshing sleep, sleepiness, and fatigue DISEASE .
Bed part- ners may also report sleep disruption and associated consequences.
The frequency of apneas DISEASE and hypopneas DISEASE during sleep correlates poorly with daytime symptom severity and impact on quality of life.
In some cases, affected individuals will not endorse any symptoms or confirm any bed partner observations.
Associated Features Systemic hypertension DISEASE is a common finding in patients with OSA DISEASE .
There is substan- tial clinical and epidemiologic evidence implicating OSA DISEASE as a significant risk factor for development of systemic hypertension DISEASE independent of other conditions such as obesity DISEASE and smoking.
Additionally, OSA DISEASE is frequently observed in patients with cor- onary artery disease DISEASE , atrial fibrillation DISEASE , and stroke DISEASE , and it may be an independent risk factor for these conditions.
OSA DISEASE is also associated with type 2 diabetes DISEASE , and there are accumulating data to suggest that it is a risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes DISEASE .
Patients with severe disease may be at risk for developing pulmo- DISEASE nary hypertension DISEASE and cor pulmonale DISEASE , although this is usually seen only in patients with daytime hypercapnia DISEASE due to comorbid conditions such as morbid obesity DISEASE or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease DISEASE ( COPD DISEASE ).
When OSA DISEASE coexists with dilated cardiomyopathy DISEASE or ischemic heart disease DISEASE , there may be worsening of the underly- ing heart disease DISEASE and predisposition to congestive heart failure DISEASE .
Gastroesophageal reflux symptoms, nocturia DISEASE , mood disturbance DISEASE , and erectile dysfunction DISEASE are some- times reported in patients with OSA DISEASE .
The disorder can also be associated with the following motor parasomnias DISEASE : OSA-induced arousals DISEASE from non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep mimicking a primary disorder of arousal ( confusional DISEASE arousal, sleep- walking, or sleep terrors DISEASE ); OSA-induced arousals DISEASE from REM sleep mimicking REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE ; disorders of arousal from NREM associated with slow wave sleep rebound during initiation of nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy of OSA DISEASE ; OSA-induced arousals DISEASE linked with sleep related eating disorder DISEASE ; and OSA-induced nocturnal seizures DISEASE or cerebral anoxic DISEASE attacks with prominent motor activity.
Severity of OSA DISEASE as determined by the frequency of apneas DISEASE and hypopneas DISEASE and/or degree of oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation correlates poorly with symptomatic sleepiness.
Different measures of sleepiness DISEASE , including self-reported severity of sleepiness DISEASE , commonly used indices such as the Epworth Sleepiness Scale, and objective measures such as the Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT), are not strongly correlated and, thus, assessment of sleepiness DISEASE can be difficult and relatively unreliable.
In addition, patients may adapt to any level of sleepiness DISEASE over time and fail to view it as a reportable problem.
Bed partner-observed breathing pauses and disruptive snoring DISEASE may not always be accompa- nied by patient complaints of sleepiness.
Finally, it is important to note that sleepiness DISEASE is a condition with a number of possible etiologies DISEASE and a range of manifestations (see Differential Diagnosis).
55 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Apneas and hypopneas DISEASE are believed to have similar pathophysiology and consequences.
Therefore, from a clinical perspective, there is little importance in distinguishing patients who have predominantly apnea DISEASE from those who have predominantly hypopnea DISEASE .
Occasionally, patients may demonstrate only REM-related apneas DISEASE or hypopneas DISEASE , but there is no consensus to suggest that this is a distinct clinical or pathophysiological subtype.
Some patients have relatively few arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturations but a significant number of respiratory events characterized by narrowing of the upper airway result- ing in brief arousals DISEASE from sleep.
Depending on the definition of hypopnea DISEASE employed, these events typically meet criteria for either hypopneas DISEASE associated with arousal but no desaturation, or for RERAs.
When initially described, this latter group was said to have UARS.
Current data suggest that this condition represents simply a variant of OSA DISEASE in which obstructive DISEASE events result in arousal but minimal arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
Patients with this condition commonly snore and report daytime sleepiness DISEASE or fatigue DISEASE .
However, there are some reports of patients with frequent respiratory arousals DISEASE in the absence of snoring DISEASE .
They tend to be less obese than individuals who have respiratory event-associated arterial oxygen CHEMICAL saturation.
The prevalence of this group of patients is unknown.
When advanced technology is used to detect changes in airflow (as described in the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events), most of these patients will be diagnosed as having OSA DISEASE , as defined by the criteria listed above.
COPD DISEASE and OSA DISEASE frequently coexist, but there is no common pathophysiologic rela- tionship.
Nevertheless, individuals with both disorders have greater nocturnal oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation and daytime hypercapnia DISEASE for the same degree of bronchial airflow obstruc- tion, and greater risk of developing pulmonary hypertension DISEASE and right heart failure.
The prevalence rate for having both conditions has been estimated to be 1%.
Demographics OSA DISEASE can occur in any age group.
Estimates of prevalence are very dependent on how sleep related respiratory events are defined, as well as their frequency and other criteria used to define disease.
Nevertheless, general population-based studies from a number of countries indicate that OSA DISEASE associated with daytime sleepiness DISEASE occurs in 3% to 7% of adult men and 2% to 5% of adult women.
However, because many individuals with OSA DISEASE do not endorse daytime sleepiness DISEASE , the prevalence of the disease is likely much higher.
A major study yielded prevalence rates as high as 24% in men and 9% in women using only an apnea-hypopnea DISEASE index (AHI) criterion of ≥ 5/hour, although addition of a daytime sleepiness DISEASE criterion reduced these estimates to 4% in males and 2% in females.
56 The prevalence of OSA DISEASE increases with age, although it appears to plateau in the elderly.
The ratio of OSA DISEASE in men compared to women is approximately two to one.
This dispar- ity may decline in middle to older age as a result of a greater risk for OSA DISEASE in women after menopause.
OSA DISEASE occurs in all racial and ethnic groups.
In younger and elderly groups, but not in middle-aged groups, OSA DISEASE has been reported to be more prevalent in blacks than whites.
The prevalence of OSA DISEASE in Asian patients is comparable to that of whites, despite having a generally lower body mass index (BMI).
Differences in craniofacial features that predispose Asians to developing OSA DISEASE are the likely explanation.
Data comparing OSA DISEASE prevalence rates among Hispanics and Native Americans to other racial/ethnic groups are sparse, although it is clear that OSA DISEASE occurs commonly in these groups.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors The major predisposing factor for OSA DISEASE is excess body weight.
It has been estimated that ~60% of moderate to severe OSA DISEASE is attributable to obesity.
The risk of OSA DISEASE increases as the degree of additional weight increases, with an extremely high preva- lence of OSA DISEASE in people with morbid obesity DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE patients with normal or below-nor- mal body weight are more likely to have upper airway obstruction DISEASE due to a localized structural abnormality such as a maxillomandibular malformation DISEASE or adenotonsillar enlargement.
Increasing neck circumference predicts higher AHIs; it is not, however, independent of BMI.
Instability in ventilatory control appears to increase risk of OSA DISEASE .
Those patients with an exaggerated ventilatory response to a respiratory disturbance DISEASE have a greater propensity for obstructive events.
Menopause is a risk factor for this disorder in women, even after adjustment for age and BMI.
However, use of hormone replacement therapy may be protective.
There are conflicting data concerning smoking as a risk factor for OSA DISEASE .
Various abnormalities of the bony and soft tissue structures of the head and neck may predispose the individual to having OSA DISEASE .
These may be hereditary DISEASE (e.g., mandibular size, mandibular position, palatal height) or acquired (e.g., enlarged adenoids and tonsils).
Endocrine disorders DISEASE such as acromegaly DISEASE and hypothy- roidism are risk factors for OSA DISEASE .
Adults and children with Down syndrome DISEASE also have a high prevalence of OSA DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE is common in patients with some neurologic disorders DISEASE that affect peripheral muscles, such as myotonic dystrophy DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE is likely made worse following alcohol CHEMICAL consumption or use of sedating medications before sleep and by nocturnal nasal restriction or congestion DISEASE due to abnormal morphology, rhinitis DISEASE , or both.
Familial Patterns OSA DISEASE is a heritable condition as demonstrated by familial clustering of OSA DISEASE patients.
First-degree relatives of OSA DISEASE patients are twice as likely to have OSA DISEASE in comparison Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders to those not affected.
Clustering of symptoms that are associated with OSA DISEASE such as snoring DISEASE , daytime sleepiness DISEASE , and snorting or gasping also occurs.
Heritability explains approximately one third of the variation in the AHI, with a substantial proportion of the heritability explained by obesity DISEASE .
Other inherited traits that might predispose an indi- vidual to developing OSA DISEASE include craniofacial morphology and ventilatory control.
Familial environmental factors such as physical activity and eating habits may play a role as well.
Nevertheless, genetic studies to date have not identified a unique gene or genes responsible for OSA DISEASE heritability.
Onset, Course, and Complications As documented in longitudinal population studies, the severity of untreated OSA DISEASE mea- sured by the AHI tends to slowly progress over time.
OSA DISEASE becomes more severe in patients whose BMI increases, but may improve with weight reduction.
However, the effect of weight gain DISEASE on increasing OSA DISEASE severity is greater than the impact of weight loss DISEASE on decreasing OSA DISEASE severity.
Moreover, the consequences of weight change are more evident in men than women.
Substantial evidence implicates OSA DISEASE as a risk factor for incident systemic hyper- tension, coronary artery disease DISEASE , congestive heart failure DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , and premature mortality.
Data suggest that these effects are more evident in men and middle-aged individuals.
In addition, there is accumulating evidence to suggest that OSA DISEASE is a risk factor for the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus DISEASE independent of obesity DISEASE .
Various arrhythmias DISEASE are commonly observed in association with OSA DISEASE .
Evidence suggests that OSA DISEASE is particularly related to the onset and recurrence of atrial fibrillation DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE may increase the severity of depression DISEASE .
Because of daytime sleepiness DISEASE , func- tional impairment occurs commonly as manifested by poor job performance, loss of employment, impaired family relationships, and reduction in overall quality of life.
The risk of motor vehicle accidents DISEASE is significantly increased among those with OSA DISEASE .
Developmental Issues OSA DISEASE can occur in any age group, but in adults, prevalence accelerates between young adulthood and middle age, with a plateau reached after approximately age 65 years.
Although OSA DISEASE occurs in the elderly, it is commonly observed with few symptoms.
In addition, some evidence suggests that risk of cardiovascular disease DISEASE related to OSA DISEASE may be less important in the elderly.
This has raised the possibility that its presence in this age group represents a distinct clinical variant.
Pediatric OSA DISEASE is discussed in a separate section (below).
58 Pathology and Pathophysiology The pathophysiology underlying upper airway narrowing during sleep is multifactorial.
Patients with OSA DISEASE commonly have reduced cross-sectional area of the upper airway lumen due to either excessive bulk of soft tissues (tongue, soft palate DISEASE , and lateral pha- ryngeal walls) or craniofacial anatomy, or both.
During inspiration, negative pressure is generated in the lumen of the upper airway, promoting closure.
However, pharyngeal dilating muscles act to maintain patency.
The activity of these muscles decreases with sleep onset, but is normally adequate to maintain an open airway.
In persons with OSA DISEASE , the activity of the pharyngeal dilating muscles becomes insufficient to prevent narrow- ing and/or closure of the upper airway.
This state-dependent change is the major con- tributing factor leading to an obstructed upper airway.
There is a further reduction in tone and phasic activity of pharyngeal dilating muscles during REM sleep, particularly in phasic REM, which likely contributes to apneas and hypopneas DISEASE that are longer and more pronounced.
Decreased end-expiratory lung volume and falling ventilatory drive associated with hypocapnia DISEASE also predispose to upper airway narrowing or closure.
In the breaths leading up to obstructive apnea DISEASE , end-expiratory upper airway caliber pro-
gressively decreases.
Smaller end-expiratory lung volume may result in smaller upper airway size due to decreased downward traction (tracheal tug).
Some patients have unstable ventilatory control (high loop gain DISEASE ) with resulting periods of hypocapnia DISEASE that may also contribute to upper airway narrowing.
The mechanisms of apnea/hypopnea DISEASE termination are controversial.
Event termination may occur with or without an associated arousal.
Some events may resolve with aug- mentation of upper airway muscle tone from chemical (low PaO2, high PaCO2) and mechanical (upper airway mechanoreceptors) stimuli, whereas others may depend on a change of sleep state (arousal) at either a cortical or subcortical level.
Cortical arous- als are associated with changes detectable by EEG, whereas other changes of state may be detectable only by direct or indirect measures of sympathetic tone.
Even if arousals DISEASE are not required for termination of all obstructive DISEASE events, sleep fragmentation from arousals DISEASE is nevertheless believed to be a significant cause of excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
Apneas and hypopneas DISEASE typically last considerably longer in REM and, in some patients, are only present in this sleep stage.
The explanation for this finding is unknown.
As an apnea DISEASE or hypopnea DISEASE event progresses, the patient gradually becomes more hypox- emic; the degree of oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation is dependent not only on the duration of the event, but also on the patient’s baseline oxygen CHEMICAL saturation and lung volume and the presence of comorbid lung conditions.
Slight hypercarbia DISEASE also occurs during apneas and hypopneas DISEASE and is worse during REM sleep.
59 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Accumulating evidence indicates that persons with OSA DISEASE have elevated levels of circu- lating inflammatory mediators related to repetitive episodes of oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation and increased sympathetic nervous system activity.
Both of these findings may be import- ant in the pathogenesis of hypertension DISEASE and cardiovascular disease DISEASE related to OSA DISEASE .
Objective Findings Obstructive apneas are documented by a cessation of airflow with ongoing respiratory efforts during PSG or an OCST.
When breathing effort is recorded with respiratory inductance plethysmography, it typically shows paradoxical movement of the rib cage and abdomen.
If esophageal manometry is used, increasingly large swings between inspiratory and expiratory efforts are observed.
Obstructive hypopneas DISEASE are a reduction rather than a cessation of airflow with ongoing respiratory effort.
Increasing respira- tory effort with constant or reduced flow is indicative of increased upper airway resis- tance.
This state is most accurately identified with a quantitative measurement of flow and esophageal manometry, although it can be inferred when there is obvious inspira- tory airflow limitation (flattening of the inspiratory flow) on a nasal pressure recording.
Although patients with OSA DISEASE have predominantly obstructive DISEASE events, they may also have variable amounts of central apneas.
In some patients, these resolve with admin- istration of positive airway pressure, whereas in others frequent central apneas either persist or emerge, at least during the initial night of positive airway pressure treatment.
Oxygen CHEMICAL saturation typically declines for a variable period of time following the onset of an event ( apnea DISEASE or hypopnea DISEASE ), with the nadir usually occurring after normal breath- ing resumes.
The degree of oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation may range from as little as 1% to 2%, up to 30% to 40% or greater.
If the baseline oxygen CHEMICAL saturation is normal, there may be no discernible drop in oxygen CHEMICAL saturation despite evidence of airflow limitation fol- DISEASE lowed by arousal.
As a result, some events associated with evidence of increased respi- ratory effort (and/or flattening of inspiratory flow) and an arousal at event termination may not meet diagnostic criteria for apnea DISEASE or hypopnea DISEASE .
These events are defined as RERAs.
These events are presumed to have the same underlying pathophysiology as obstructive apneas and hypopneas DISEASE (upper airway obstruction DISEASE ) and are considered to be as much of a risk factor for symptoms of unrefreshing DISEASE sleep, daytime somnolence DISEASE , and fatigue DISEASE as frank apnea DISEASE or hypopnea DISEASE .
The EEG may provide evidence of a brief arousal from sleep, and the submental electro- myogram may demonstrate a burst of activity indicating upper airway dilating muscle activation immediately preceding the resumption of normal breathing.
Microphones may record a sudden resumption of loud snoring.
Obstructive apneas and hypopneas DISEASE may be accompanied by bradyarrhythmias DISEASE , tachyarrhythmias DISEASE , or both; however, the prevalence of this finding in patients varies widely.
At the time of arousals DISEASE , there is often a surge in both sympathetic nervous system activity and systemic blood pressure.
Differential Diagnosis In contrast to patients with OSA DISEASE , those with isolated snoring DISEASE will not exhibit obstruc- tive apneas DISEASE , hypopneas DISEASE , or RERAs on PSG or OCST and do not have other sleep symp- toms attributable to breathing disturbance DISEASE .
However, because arousal-based hypopneas DISEASE and RERAs cannot be identified with OCST, OSA DISEASE cannot be excluded if the OCST is negative.
Patients with central sleep apnea DISEASE have predominantly central rather than obstruc- tive apneas DISEASE , hypopneas DISEASE , or RERAs as the primary finding on PSG or OCST.
If mixed apneas are predominant, a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE should be made.
Patients with obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE will demonstrate daytime hypercap- CHEMICAL nia.
Snoring DISEASE may not be a prominent feature, although daytime sleepiness DISEASE can occur.
Patients with sleep related hypoventilation disorders DISEASE may show episodes of oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation without evidence of airflow obstruction DISEASE on PSG or OCST.
Confirmation of nocturnal hypercapnia DISEASE will be diagnostic.
However, if obstructive apneas DISEASE or hypo- pneas are evident, a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE should be made instead of, or in addition to, the diagnosis of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE must be differentiated from other causes of sleepiness DISEASE such as narcolepsy DISEASE , idio- pathic hypersomnia DISEASE , and insufficient sleep.
These conditions often can be identified on the basis of history, but PSG and/or MSLT may be required to confirm the diagnosis.
OSA DISEASE should be distinguished from other causes of nocturnal dyspnea DISEASE , such as noc- turnal panic DISEASE attacks, nocturnal gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , asthma DISEASE , paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea DISEASE from congestive heart failure DISEASE , and nocturnal angina pectoris DISEASE .
In many cases, absence of snoring DISEASE and daytime sleepiness DISEASE will be highly suggestive of etiologies other than OSA DISEASE .
However, the absence of obstructive apneas, hypopneas DISEASE , or RERAs on PSG will definitively exclude OSA DISEASE as the diagnosis.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions
Although substantial evidence implicates OSA DISEASE as a risk factor for coronary artery disease DISEASE and stroke DISEASE , it has not been clearly demonstrated that treatment mitigates this risk.
This is especially a concern for patients with mild OSA DISEASE who are not hypersom- nolent.
The pathophysiologic mechanisms linking OSA DISEASE to increased risk of coronary artery disease DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , and hypertension DISEASE require further investigation.
Although there Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders is a clear association between OSA DISEASE and type 2 diabetes mellitus DISEASE , further studies are needed to determine whether OSA DISEASE is an independent risk factor and what mechanisms are involved.

Pamidi S, Aronsohn RS DISEASE , Tasali E. Obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE : role in the risk and severity of diabetes DISEASE .

62 Obstructive Sleep Apnea, Pediatric ICD-9-CM code: 327.23 ICD-10-CM code: G47.33 Alternate Names Obstructive sleep apnea syndrome DISEASE , sleep apnea DISEASE , sleep apnea syndrome DISEASE , obstructive apnea DISEASE , sleep disordered breathing DISEASE , sleep hypopnea syndrome DISEASE , obstructive hypoventila- tion, and upper airway obstruction DISEASE .
The term upper airway resistance syndrome DISEASE ( UARS DISEASE ) is subsumed under this diagnosis because the pathophysiology does not significantly differ from that of OSA DISEASE .
Use of the term Pickwickian syndrome DISEASE is discouraged, as this term has been used loosely to cover a constellation of conditions including OSA DISEASE and central hypoventilation DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A and B must be met A.
The presence of one or more of the following: .
Snoring DISEASE .
2. Labored DISEASE , paradoxical, or obstructed breathing during the child’s sleep.
3. Sleepiness, hyperactivity DISEASE , behavioral problems, or learning problems.
B. PSG demonstrates one or both of the following: .
One or more obstructive apneas, mixed apneas, or hypopneas DISEASE , per hour of sleep.1 OR .
A pattern of obstructive hypoventilation DISEASE , defined as at least 25% of total sleep time with hypercapnia DISEASE (PaCO2 >
50 mm Hg) in association with one or more of the following:
a. Snoring DISEASE .
b. Flattening of the inspiratory nasal pressure waveform.
c. Paradoxical thoracoabdominal motion.
Notes .
Respiratory events defined according to the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
Essential Features Pediatric criteria for OSA DISEASE apply to patients younger than 18 years.
However, for the purpose of PSG scoring, the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events states that adult diagnostic criteria may be used for patients aged 13 to 18 years.
Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Pediatric OSA DISEASE is characterized by intermittent complete or partial obstruction (obstruc- tive apnea DISEASE or hypopnea DISEASE ); prolonged partial upper airway obstruction DISEASE ; or both prolonged and intermittent obstructions DISEASE that disrupt normal ventilation during sleep, normal sleep patterns, or both.
Children with OSA DISEASE may demonstrate several breathing patterns during sleep.
Some children have cyclic episodes of obstructive apnea DISEASE , similar to that of adults with the syndrome.
However, some patients, particularly younger children, have a pattern of obstructive hypoventilation DISEASE , which consists of long periods of persistent partial upper airway obstruction DISEASE associated with hypercapnia DISEASE , arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desatu- ration, or both.
Some children may manifest a pattern of UARS DISEASE similar to that seen in adults, including snoring DISEASE without identifiable airflow obstruction DISEASE and increasingly negative esophageal pressure swings and cyclic arousals DISEASE .
In children, upper airway obstruction DISEASE occurs predominantly during REM sleep.
Children often do not have cor- tical arousals DISEASE in response to the upper airway obstruction DISEASE , although they may have movement or autonomic arousals DISEASE .
Perhaps as a result of this higher arousal threshold, sleep architecture is usually normal, with normal amounts of slow wave sleep.
Even short obstructive apneas may be associated with severe hypoxemia DISEASE because children have a lower functional residual capacity and a higher metabolic rate than adults.
Most children with OSA DISEASE present with a history of snoring DISEASE and difficulty breathing during sleep.
Snoring DISEASE is usually loud and may be punctuated by pauses and gasps, with associated movements or arousal from sleep.
However, some patients, particu- larly infants and those with neuromuscular weakness DISEASE , may not snore.
Patients with obstructive hypoventilation DISEASE often have continuous snoring DISEASE without pauses or arous- als.
Children have a very compliant rib cage.
As a result, paradoxical breathing is a prominent sign in these patients (note that paradoxical breathing during REM sleep is a normal phenomenon in young children up to at least age three years).
A pectus DISEASE excavatum may be present.
Thoracic retractions may be present.
Children may sleep in unusual positions, such as seated or with their neck hyperextended.
Diaphoresis DISEASE may be observed.
Morning headaches DISEASE may also occur.
Many parents of children with OSA DISEASE are so concerned about their child’s breathing that they sleep with their child or stimu- late their child to terminate the apneas.
Excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE may be present, especially in older children and adoles- cents, but is seen less commonly in children than in adults with OSA DISEASE .
Developmental, behavioral, and learning issues are frequently present.
These may include attention problems, hyperactivity DISEASE , moodiness DISEASE , irritability DISEASE , and impaired academic performance.
64 Associated Features Hypoxemia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE are often present during sleep and may be severe.
A prom- inent sinus arrhythmia DISEASE is often seen, although other arrhythmias DISEASE are rare.
Secondary enuresis DISEASE may occur.
Breathing during wakefulness is normal, although mouth breath- ing secondary to adenoidal hypertrophy DISEASE may be present.
Other nonspecific daytime symptoms related to adenotonsillar hypertrophy DISEASE , such as frequent upper respiratory tract infections DISEASE or dysphagia DISEASE , may occur.
Although studies have shown that children with OSA DISEASE generally have larger tonsils and adenoidal tissue than do other children, the size of the tonsils and adenoidal tissue does not predict disease in individual patients.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Clinical presentations include OSA DISEASE , obstructive hypoventilation DISEASE , and recurrent arousal associated with increased respiratory effort (RERAs).
Demographics The prevalence in children has been estimated at 1% to 4%, but the prevalence may currently be higher due to the pediatric obesity DISEASE epidemic.
The prevalence in infants and adolescents is unknown.
In prepubertal children, the disease occurs equally among boys and girls; in adolescents, data suggest the prevalence may be higher in males.
There appears to be a higher prevalence in black children than white children; the prev- alence in other ethnic groups is unknown.
The disease can occur at any age, from the neonatal period to adolescence, but in otherwise healthy children it is most common in the preschool age (in association with adenotonsillar hypertrophy DISEASE ) and in adolescents (in association with obesity DISEASE ).
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Adenotonsillar hypertrophy DISEASE and obesity DISEASE are the most common predisposing/precip- itating factors.
Children with craniofacial abnormalities DISEASE , particularly micrognathia DISEASE or midfacial hypoplasia, are at risk.
Those with Down syndrome DISEASE are particularly at risk for having OSA DISEASE .
Children with neuromuscular diseases DISEASE often have upper airway muscle weakness DISEASE , which predisposes to airway collapse.
Children with cerebral palsy DISEASE may be predisposed to OSA DISEASE because of spasticity DISEASE , weakness DISEASE , or incoordination DISEASE of the upper airway muscles.
Infants with gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE may develop OSA DISEASE due to upper airway edema DISEASE or laryngospasm DISEASE .
Other medical conditions such as mucopoly- saccharidosis and sickle cell disease DISEASE may predispose to OSA DISEASE .
Pharyngeal flap oper- ations, typically performed to improve speech quality in patients with cleft palate DISEASE , can result in OSA DISEASE .
Environmental tobacco smoke CHEMICAL exposure has been associated with snoring DISEASE and OSA DISEASE .
65 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Familial Patterns There is evidence for an increased risk of OSA DISEASE in children with affected family members.
Potential mechanisms for familial aggregation DISEASE include heritability of pre- disposing skeletal, soft tissue, body habitus, or respiratory control characteristics.
However, the relative roles of genetic factors versus environmental factors have not been determined.
Onset, Course, and Complications The exact course of pediatric OSA DISEASE has not been well studied.
Symptoms typically begin within the first few years of life, although the disease may not be diagnosed until many years later.
The natural course of untreated OSA DISEASE is not known.
A few short-term studies suggest that some children with mild disease may improve, or conversely, have worsening of the condition; long-term studies are not available.
Complications are frequent and may be severe.
In early childhood, OSA DISEASE can cause growth failure, especially when associated with a comorbid genetic or craniofacial disorder DISEASE .
Cognitive and behavioral complications are common and may include developmental delay, poor school performance, attention deficit hyperactivity DISEASE dis- order, inattention and impairment in concentration, and aggressive behavior.
Rarely, cases of severe asphyxial brain damage DISEASE , seizures DISEASE , and coma DISEASE have been reported.
Cardiovascular complications DISEASE include pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , cor pulmonale DISEASE , and systemic hypertension DISEASE .
Developmental Issues Developmental issues are reviewed within individual sections.
Pathology and Pathophysiology In children, as in adults, OSA DISEASE results from a combination of abnormal neuromuscular control and anatomical narrowing of the collapsible (supracartilaginous) portion of the upper airway.
During wakefulness, the patient with OSA DISEASE compensates by augmenting upper airway muscle tone to dilate the upper airway; thus, obstructive apnea DISEASE does not occur.
During sleep, there is a decrease in ventilatory drive and in neuromuscular tone, facilitating upper airway collapse.
The resultant recurrent hypoxemia DISEASE , hypercapnia DISEASE , and sleep disruption may lead to neurobehavioral, cardiovascular, and growth abnor- malities.
Childhood OSA DISEASE has also been associated with metabolic and inflammatory abnormalities.
In most children who are otherwise healthy, upper airway narrowing is primarily due to adenotonsillar hypertrophy DISEASE .
Pediatric OSA DISEASE also occurs in association with obesity DISEASE , which is becoming increasingly prevalent.
Other causes for upper airway narrowing include craniofacial anomalies DISEASE , particularly those involving midface hypoplasia DISEASE or micrognathia/retrognathia.
In addition, children with decreased upper airway muscle tone or abnormal upper airway muscle function, such as children with muscular dys- DISEASE trophy or cerebral palsy DISEASE , are at increased risk for OSA DISEASE .
Objective Findings PSG demonstrates obstructive and mixed apneas, hypopneas DISEASE , or periods of obstructive hypoventilation DISEASE .
In children, obstructive apneas lasting two respiratory cycles or longer are scored.
In contrast to adults with OSA DISEASE , EEG arousals DISEASE may or may not be present fol- lowing apneas, especially in young children, although subcortical/autonomic arousals DISEASE (as manifested by body movements, tachycardia DISEASE , or measurements of pulse transit time or arterial tonometry) may occur.
Possibly as a result of the higher arousal threshold, sleep architecture is usually preserved.
Apneas and hypopneas DISEASE occur primarily during REM sleep, and breathing may be totally normal during NREM sleep.
Obstructive DISEASE events are frequently associated with desaturation DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE .
Evaluation of the upper airway by endoscopy, radiography, computed tomographic scans, or magnetic resonance imaging studies may show large tonsils and adenoidal tissue and a narrow upper airway, although these tests are not performed routinely.
Echocardiography may show evidence of right, left, or biventricular hypertrophy.
Differential Diagnosis Pediatric OSA DISEASE must be differentiated from isolated snoring DISEASE .
Children with snoring DISEASE but without observed apnea DISEASE , labored breathing during sleep, daytime behavioral issues, sleepiness DISEASE , or other symptoms of OSA DISEASE may not require further laboratory investigation.
However, children who have snoring DISEASE and symptoms of OSA DISEASE need evaluation to deter- mine whether they have isolated snoring DISEASE or OSA DISEASE (N.B. this distinction cannot reliably be made clinically but should be based on PSG).
Children with primary snoring DISEASE do not have apneas, gas exchange abnormalities, or frequent arousals DISEASE on PSG.
Central sleep apnea DISEASE can be differentiated from OSA DISEASE by the lack of chest or abdominal wall move- ment associated with the central apneas.
Mixed apneas may be seen and are included in the diagnosis of OSA DISEASE .
Children with fixed upper airway obstruction DISEASE due to struc- tural abnormalities DISEASE tend to obstruct both awake and asleep, and have stridor rather than snoring DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE in children must be distinguished from nonobstructive alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE .
Children with lung or chest wall disease DISEASE may have desaturation DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE during sleep.
It may be difficult to separate nonobstructive hypoventila- tion and desaturation DISEASE from OSA DISEASE , especially because the two conditions may coexist.
In general, children with nonobstructive hypoventilation DISEASE will not snore and will not have paradoxical inward rib cage motion during inspiration, although the latter may be present in children with neuromuscular disease DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE must be differentiated from Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders other causes of sleepiness DISEASE such as narcolepsy DISEASE , idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE , and insufficient sleep.
Sleep related epilepsy DISEASE may mimic obstructive apnea DISEASE during sleep and may be indistinguishable from OSA DISEASE without the appropriate EEG monitoring, especially in infants who may have only subtle motor components of seizures DISEASE .
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions There is a need for further research in many aspects of pediatric OSA DISEASE .
Although studies of prevalence have been performed in the past, the prevalence has probably increased in recent years due to the increasing prevalence of childhood obesity DISEASE .
Further data regarding the prevalence in infants and adolescents is needed.
The natural course of the disease, the optimal techniques for monitoring patients during PSG, the effects of mild OSA DISEASE , and the threshold necessitating treatment require further study.
The role of genetic, ethnic, and anatomic factors in the pathophysiology of childhood OSA DISEASE also requires further study.

Redline S, Tishler PV, Schluchter M, Aylor J, Clark K CHEMICAL ,
