68 Central Sleep Apnea Syndromes Central Sleep Apnea with Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE Breathing ICD-9-CM code: 786.04 Alternate Names Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE respiration.
Diagnostic Criteria (A or B) + C + D satisfy the criteria A.
The presence of one or more of the following: 1. Sleepiness.
ICD-10-CM code: R06.3 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders .
Difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, frequent awakenings, or nonrestorative sleep.
3. Awakening short of breath.
4.
Snoring DISEASE .
5. Witnessed apneas.
B. The presence of atrial fibrillation/flutter DISEASE , congestive heart failure DISEASE , or a neurological disorder DISEASE .
C. PSG (during diagnostic or positive airway pressure titration) shows all of the following:
1. Five or more central apneas and/or central hypopneas per hour of sleep.1 .
The total number of central apneas and/or central hypopneas DISEASE is > 50% of the total number of apneas DISEASE and hypopneas.2 .
The pattern of ventilation meets criteria for Cheyne-Stokes breathing (CSB).1 D.
The disorder is not better explained by another current sleep disorder DISEASE , medication use (e.g., opioids), or substance use disorder.
Notes .
As defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
2.
If criterion C2 is not met, CSB can be listed as a polysomnographic finding.
3.
A diagnosis of central sleep apnea DISEASE (CSA) with CSB does not exclude a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE .
69 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Essential Features CSA-CSB is characterized by recurrent central apneas or central hypopneas DISEASE
alternat- ing with a respiratory phase exhibiting a crescendo-decrescendo pattern of flow (or tidal volume).
The longer cycle length (> 40 seconds; typically 45 to 60 seconds) distinguishes CSB from other central sleep apnea DISEASE types.
The vast majority of patients with CSA-CSB have either systolic or diastolic heart failure.
In systolic heart failure DISEASE the cycle length is longer (longer respiratory phase) than in patients with diastolic heart failure DISEASE , and there is often a delay in the nadir of the associated oxygen CHEMICAL desatu- ration.
Patients with CSA-CSB have normal or low daytime arterial PCO2 (PaCO2).
Some patients with heart failure DISEASE have a mixture of obstructive DISEASE and central apneas with more central apneas in the later part of the night or when the patient is placed on posi- tive DISEASE airway pressure (PAP).
A diagnosis of CSA-CSB requires that events be predom- inantly central apneas and hypopneas DISEASE with an average frequency of at least 5/hour during a diagnostic PSG or either the diagnostic or therapeutic portion of a split-night study.
For patients with a mixture of OSA DISEASE and CSA-CSB, the central apneas may appear only after elimination of obstruction DISEASE on positive airway pressure.
In patient with CSA-CSB, arousal from sleep tends to occur at the zenith of respiratory effort between contiguous central apneas or hypopneas DISEASE .
This can result in sleep fragmen- tation.
However, patients may complain of disturbed nocturnal sleep or nocturnal dyspnea DISEASE rather than daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
Associated Features Presenting features of CSB pattern during sleep may include excessive daytime sleep- iness, insomnia DISEASE , or nocturnal dyspnea DISEASE .
Because many patients with CSA-CSB have known heart failure DISEASE , their complaints of frequent awakenings or disturbed sleep may be falsely assumed to be entirely secondary to heart failure DISEASE .
Because studies have shown that approximately 60% of patients with heart failure DISEASE have some form of sleep apnea DISEASE , a high index of suspicion is indicated.
A CSB pattern can also occur during wakefulness and can be observed at bedside or in the clinic.
Some studies suggest that the pres- ence of CSA-CSB during wakefulness is associated with a worse prognosis.
Although heart failure DISEASE is the major cause of CSA-CSB, recent studies suggest that it can be noted after stroke DISEASE .
CSA-CSB can rarely present in an idiopathic DISEASE form or be associated with renal failure DISEASE .
As in other forms of CSA, apneas and hypopneas DISEASE are associated with absent or reduced ventilatory effort, respectively, due to diminished central respiratory drive.
Of inter- est, a longer respiratory phase between apneas DISEASE is associated with a longer circulation time and delay in the saturation nadir.
The CSB breathing pattern is characteristically observed during stages N1 and N2 and usually resolves or is attenuated during REM sleep.
In patients with both OSA DISEASE and CSA-CSB, the relative amount of central and obstructive apnea DISEASE can vary over time or even within the same night.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes
Some patients have combined OSA DISEASE and CSA, and the CSA-CSB may not manifest until the patient is placed on positive airway pressure treatment.
These patients are considered to have both OSA DISEASE and CSA with CSB.
Patients with systolic or diastolic heart failure may have CSB, but the cycle length is longer in those with systolic dys- DISEASE function.
Patients with neurological disorders DISEASE may have CSB, but the characteristic cycle length is less well described.
Demographics CSA with CSB generally is seen in subjects older than 60 years.
The prevalence of this breathing disorder DISEASE in the setting of chronic congestive heart failure has been reported to be 25% to 40%, depending on how patients are divided into those with predomi- nant OSA DISEASE and those with CSA.
In patients with heart failure DISEASE there is a striking male predominance in the occurrence of CSA-CSB.
Of interest, the use of β-blockers and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors for treatment of congestive heart failure DISEASE has not decreased the prevalence of CSA-CSB.
Some form of sleep apnea DISEASE is reported in 50% to 70% of patients following stroke DISEASE , depending on the AHI cutoff used for diagno- sis.
Although OSA DISEASE predominates, central sleep apnea DISEASE is also common especially in the first few days following stroke DISEASE .
CSA-CSB has been reported to occur in 26% to 50% of patients in the acute period following stroke DISEASE .
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors The most important predisposing factors are the presence of congestive heart failure DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , and possibly renal failure DISEASE .
Within the heart failure DISEASE population, risk factors for CSB pattern during sleep include male sex, age older than 60 years, the presence of atrial fibrillation DISEASE , and daytime hypocapnia DISEASE (i.e., awake PaCO2 of 38 mm Hg or less).
In general, greater pulmonary congestion DISEASE (higher left ventricular end-diastolic pressure) predicts lower PaCO2.
Some studies suggest that CSA-CSB occurs more commonly in the supine position.
Although renal failure DISEASE is often listed as a possible cause of CSA- CSB, there is scant literature documenting this association.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
71 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Onset, Course, and Complications There are no definitive data concerning the onset.
However, because it is seen in the setting of congestive heart failure DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , and possibly renal failure DISEASE , CSA with CSB most likely has its onset following the development of one of these illnesses.
In the setting of systolic congestive heart failure DISEASE , it is associated with a poor prognosis, as indicated by a greater adjusted relative risk for mortality-cardiac transplantation com- pared to patients without CSB.
These data suggest that CSB pattern during sleep par- ticipates in the pathophysiology and progression of heart failure DISEASE .
Its clinical signifi- cance in the setting of stroke DISEASE or other neurological disorders DISEASE remains less certain.
In some patients with CSA CHEMICAL after stroke DISEASE , the pattern can transition to one of OSA DISEASE .
The presence of obstructive apnea DISEASE following stroke DISEASE has been found to be associated with a worse prognosis.
Developmental Issues Although there are reports of CSB in children, the condition is extremely rare in this age group.
Of interest, one study of patients with congestive heart failure DISEASE across all age groups found CSB to be absent in children but present in 40% of the adult patients with congestive heart failure DISEASE .
A limitation of the study was that only ten children with congestive heart failure DISEASE were studied.
Pathology and Pathophysiology CSA with CSB generally arises because of instability in the respiratory control system.
A high ventilatory drive and delay in chemoreceptor response to changes of PaCO2 and PaO2 (due to increased circulation time) are likely the major factors.
This breathing disorder DISEASE tends to occur in individuals with a chronically low PaCO2 when awake and asleep.
Hyperventilation DISEASE occurs due to an increase in the responsiveness of the periph- eral and central chemoreceptors.
The increased responsiveness is believed to be due to both increased sympathetic tone and stimulation of vagal irritant receptors in the lungs by pulmonary congestion DISEASE .
The PaCO2 in individuals with CSB pattern and heart failure DISEASE is closer to their apneic threshold than in those without CSB pattern (primarily due to a smaller sleep related rise in PaCO2 in those with CSB), so that even modest increases in ventilation can drive PaCO2 below the apneic threshold.
The most common trigger factor for central apnea DISEASE is an arousal from sleep, which abruptly augments ventilation and drives PaCO2 below the apneic threshold.
The crescendo-decrescendo pattern of tidal volume results from prolonged lung-to-che- moreceptor circulatory delay, such that changes in PaCO2 in the lung are trans- CHEMICAL mitted only very slowly to the chemoreceptors, resulting in a gradual buildup and falloff of ventilatory stimulation.
The length of the cycle is directly proportional to lung-to-chemoreceptor circulation time and inversely proportional to cardiac output.
Accordingly, whereas the length of the ventilatory-apneic cycle in primary CSA CHEMICAL is typically shorter than 40 seconds, in CSB pattern it is almost invariably longer than 40 seconds (usually 45-90 seconds).
One study of patients with varying degrees of heart failure DISEASE found a considerably shorter cycle time in patients with normal ejection frac- tion (e.g., diastolic heart failure DISEASE ).
The pathophysiology of CSB pattern in the setting of stroke DISEASE and renal failure DISEASE has not been examined in any detail.
However, apneas in association with these medical disorders are believed to be due to a reduction in PaCO2 below the apneic threshold.
In individuals with renal failure DISEASE , pulmonary congestion DISEASE ( volume overload DISEASE ) may play a role in stimulating hyperventilation DISEASE .
Objective Findings The polysomnographic hallmarks of CSB pattern are recurrent central apneas and central hypopneas DISEASE alternating with ventilatory periods having a prolonged crescen- do-decrescendo pattern of airflow (tidal volume).
CSB pattern typically occurs at the transition from wakefulness to NREM sleep and during stages N1 and N2.
It tends to dissipate in stages N3 and R.
In stage N3 sleep the sleeping PaCO2 is higher (further above the apneic threshold).
During REM sleep the hypoxic and hypercapnic ventila- tory responses are lower, thereby reducing the tendency for an overshoot in ventilation which may drive PaCO2 below the apneic threshold.
Arousals DISEASE are frequently seen in association with CSB and are typically noted at or near the zenith in respiratory effort (or airflow), although can occur at or near the onset of the respiratory phase pattern.
In contrast, arousals DISEASE tend to occur at apnea DISEASE termination in other CSA disorders DISEASE .
As noted above, a longer respiratory phase (and cycle length) is associated with lower cardiac output and longer circulation time.
Central hypopnea DISEASE , rather than apnea DISEASE , can occur at the nadir in respiratory effort in patients with CSB and have been included in calculation of the central AHI in a sub- stantial number of investigations.
Central hypopneas DISEASE are characterized by the absence of snoring DISEASE , flattening in the nasal pressure or PAP device flow signal, and thoracoab- dominal paradox.
Central apneas and central hypopneas DISEASE are usually accompanied by modest oxyhemo- globin desaturation DISEASE ; arterial oxygen CHEMICAL saturation seldom falls below 80% to 85%.
The combination of oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation and arousals DISEASE from sleep leads to sleep fragmenta- tion with reduced amounts of stage N3 sleep.
Additionally, PaCO2 less than 40
mm Hg is typically observed during wakefulness.
In patients with both obstructive and central apneas DISEASE , the proportion of central apneas tends to increase over the night, and this is Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders associated with a fall in the sleeping PaCO2.
The lower sleeping PaCO2 is thought to be due to an increase in pulmonary congestion DISEASE during the night with stimulation of juxta- capillary (J) receptors in the lung interstitium and a subsequent increase in ventilatory drive.
As noted above, some patients have more CSA-CSB in the supine position.
Differential Diagnosis Primary CSA CHEMICAL can usually be distinguished from CSB pattern by the absence of a history of heart failure DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , or renal failure DISEASE and by the absence of a crescendo-decrescendo breathing pattern between central apneas.
The cycle length ( apnea DISEASE + ventilatory phase) in primary CSA CHEMICAL is typically less than 40 seconds.
High-altitude periodic breathing only occurs at high altitude and is not associated with heart failure DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , or renal failure DISEASE .
Patients with CSA CHEMICAL due to drug or substance have a history of use of this type of medication, and an ataxic breathing pattern may be present.
If patients with CSA CHEMICAL asso- ciated with opioids manifest periodic breathing, the respiratory phase does not have a crescendo-decrescendo pattern and the cycle length is shorter.
Patients with CSA CHEMICAL due to a medical or neurological disease DISEASE without Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE will have central apnea DISEASE that does not have Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE morphology, as the name implies.
Sleep related hypoven- tilation and hypoxemic syndromes can be readily distinguished from CSA-CSB by documentation of an awake PaCO2 >
45 mm
Hg and/or sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
Patients with CSA-CSB usually have an awake PaCO2 <
40 mm Hg.
In patients with sleep related hypoventilation disorders DISEASE , some central apneas may be present, but these events do not have a Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE morphology.
Additionally, oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation in sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE syndromes is generally more pronounced during REM sleep.
OSA DISEASE is distinguished by the presence of respiratory efforts during apneas.
A few central apneas or hypopneas DISEASE at sleep onset or during REM sleep are normal, especially in elderly subjects.
These cease once sleep becomes stable.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions The pathophysiology and clinical significance of CSB pattern have not yet been eluci- dated in the setting of stroke DISEASE and renal failure DISEASE .
Less is also known about the importance of CSB in patients with heart failure DISEASE with a normal ejection fraction.

Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2002;165:1245–50.
Central Apnea Due to a Medical Disorder without Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE Breathing ICD-9-CM code: 327.27 Alternate Names Not applicable or known.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A.
The presence of one or more of the following1: 1. Sleepiness.
ICD-10-CM code: G47.37 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders .
Difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, frequent awakenings, or nonrestorative sleep.
3. Awakening short of breath.
4.
Snoring DISEASE .
5. Witnessed apneas.
B. PSG shows all of the following:
1. Five or more central apneas and/or central hypopneas per hour of sleep.2 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders .
The number of central apneas and/or central hypopneas DISEASE is > 50% of the total number of apneas DISEASE and hypopneas DISEASE .
3. Absence of CSB.2 C. The disorder occurs as a consequence of a medical or neurological disorder DISEASE but is not due to medication use or substance use.
Notes .
In infants and young children, symptoms are supportive but not required.
2. As defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
3.
Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is not required but may be present.
If the patient meets criteria for both sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL due to medical or neurological condition not Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE , both diagnoses can be made.
4.
In some patients other abnormalities of breathing such as ataxic breathing may be prominent.
5.
A diagnosis of central apnea DISEASE due to a medical disorder without CSB does not exclude a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE .
Essential Features CSA CHEMICAL that is attributed to a medical or neurological condition (and does not have the pattern of CSB) is classified here.
The majority of these patients have brainstem lesions of developmental, vascular, neoplastic, degenerative, demyelinating, or traumatic DISEASE origin.
Associated Features Patients generally present with sleep fragmentation, excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE , or insomnia DISEASE .
Other signs and symptoms that are often, but not invariably, present include snoring DISEASE , witnessed apnea DISEASE , and awakening with shortness of breath DISEASE .
The presentation varies with the cause of central apnea DISEASE and may include neurological findings.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes None.
Some of the common medical and neurological disorders DISEASE causing central apnea DISEASE not associated with CSB are listed in Pathology and Pathophysiology (below).
Demographics The prevalence and demographics of this disorder vary with the underlying etiology.
Patients with Chiari malformation DISEASE ( CM DISEASE ) can present in infancy or childhood, but the most common age of presentation is 20 to 40 years.
Patients with stroke DISEASE tend to be older.
76 Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Because of the heterogeneity of etiologies in this type of CSA, predisposing and pre- cipitating factors are variable.
In CM DISEASE there is herniation of a portion of the brainstem through the foramen magnum.
In CM DISEASE type 1, a portion of the cerebellar tonsils herni- DISEASE ate.
CSA in these patients is believed to occur due to impaired function of ventilatory control centers in the brainstem.
Familial Patterns None known.
Onset, Course, and Complications These factors vary as well with the different etiologies.
In CM DISEASE the presentation is typi- cally age 20 to 40 years of age but can occur in infants and children.
With the increased use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), cases are often diagnosed before symptoms are severe.
The CSA following a cerebrovascular accident ( CVA CHEMICAL ) is abrupt in onset.
In patients exhibiting both central and obstructive apnea DISEASE , the central apneas tend to resolve with time.
Some post-CVA DISEASE patients with central apneas have central apnea DISEASE with CSB, whereas in others the CSA does not have a pattern consistent with CSB.
The central apneas can lead to sleep fragmentation, yielding either hypersomnolence DISEASE or insomnia DISEASE or both.
There is little evidence that these apneas or their associated hypoxia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE lead to pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , cor pulmonale DISEASE , or other adverse car- diovascular consequences.
Developmental Issues Not known.
Pathology and Pathophysiology CSA CHEMICAL is caused by failure of the ventilatory control centers to initiate ventilatory effort.
The abnormality is due to dysfunction of central ventilatory control centers.
The pres- ence of sleep may unmask ventilatory control abnormalities with the loss of the wake- fulness stimulus.
Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE and/or daytime hypoventilation DISEASE may coexist with CSA CHEMICAL due to medical or neurological disorder DISEASE , not CSB, in which case both diagnoses can be made.
A number of causes of CSA CHEMICAL due to medical or neurological disorders DISEASE –not Cheyne- Stokes—have been described.
Patients with CM DISEASE exhibit obstructive DISEASE , central, or a mixture of obstructive DISEASE and central apneas.
Some patient exhibit nocturnal hypoventi- lation DISEASE but rarely daytime hypoventilation DISEASE .
CSA and/or OSA DISEASE can be the initial presenta- tion of the disorder.
Symptoms include headache DISEASE (especially with laughter, coughing, Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders or exertion), neck pain DISEASE , and vertigo DISEASE .
An MRI is diagnostic of the condition and should be considered as part of the evaluation of all patients without an obvious cause of central apnea DISEASE .
Brainstem neoplasm DISEASE can present with central apnea DISEASE not of the Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE type.
Patients with a recent cerebrovascular accident show a high incidence of sleep disor- dered breathing.
Although obstructive apnea DISEASE is more common, central apnea DISEASE may be noted initially after a cerebrovascular accident.
Some patients exhibit a pattern of CSB, whereas in others periodic breathing without the characteristic CSB pattern is present.
Patients with multiple system atrophy DISEASE may also present with CSA CHEMICAL that does not have a CSB pattern.
Objective Findings The polysomnogram of the patient with CSA CHEMICAL due to medical or neurological condi- tion—not CSB—demonstrate recurrent (five or more per hour) central apneas and/or central hypopneas.
The central apneas and hypopneas DISEASE meet criteria for these events as defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
Runs of recurrent central apneas separated by periods of ventilation may occur.
The interevent respiratory phase is typically brief with a maximum of five breaths.
The central apneas do not have the pattern of CSB.
Differential Diagnosis Patients with CSA CHEMICAL due to medical or neurological disorder DISEASE —not CSB—should be dif- ferentiated from primary CSA, in which no known cause is identified.
As the name implies, patients with a pattern of CSB should be classified as such.
Patients with central nervous system neoplasms DISEASE may have a central hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE with sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE with or without an increase in daytime PaCO2.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions With the possible exception of poststroke DISEASE central apnea DISEASE , the disorders classified here are thought to be relatively rare.
The presenting symptoms may not be a sleep related complaint.
Except for those associated with CM DISEASE and poststroke DISEASE CSA, the disorders are not well characterized.

Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2000;161:375–80.

Central Sleep Apnea Due to High Altitude Periodic ICD-10-CM code: G47.32 Breathing ICD-9-CM code: 327.22 Alternate Names None.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-D must be met A. Recent ascent to high altitude.1 B.
The presence of one or more of the following:2 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders . Sleepiness.
2. Difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, frequent awakenings, or nonrestorative sleep.
3. Awakening with shortness of breath DISEASE or morning headache DISEASE .
4. Witnessed apnea DISEASE .
C.
The symptoms are clinically attributable to high-altitude periodic breathing or PSG, if performed, demonstrates recurrent central apneas or hypopneas DISEASE primarily during NREM sleep at a frequency of ≥ 5/hour.
D.
The disorder is not better explained by another current sleep disorder DISEASE , medical or neurological disorder DISEASE , medication use (e.g., narcotics), or substance use disorders.
Notes .
Typically at least 2,500 meters (8,202 feet), although some individuals may exhibit the disorder at altitudes as low as 1,500 meters.
2. Periodic breathing is a common response to altitude.
Associated symptoms are required to make the diagnosis of a disorder.
There is no level of the central AHI separating a normal and abnormal response to high altitude.
3.
A diagnosis of CSA CHEMICAL due to high-altitude period breathing does not exclude a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE .
79 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Essential Features High-altitude periodic breathing is characterized by alternating periods of central apnea DISEASE and hyperpnea DISEASE associated with recent ascent to high altitude.
The pattern of periodic breathing is an expected response to ascent to elevation.
Only those individuals who manifest related symptoms, as described below, are diagnosed with this disorder.
The cycle length of this respiratory pattern is commonly less than 40 seconds and often as short as 12 to 20 seconds.
The percentage of individuals exhibiting periodic breathing during sleep increases at higher altitudes.
Approximately 25% exhibit periodic breath- ing at 2,500 meters (8,202 feet), and virtually 100% demonstrate periodic breathing at 4,000 m (13,123 feet).
Periodic breathing has been described at altitudes as low as 1,500 meters (4,900 feet).
Chronic exposure to altitude above 2,500 meters has also been associated with periodic breathing in some studies.
Associated Features At altitude, individuals may complain of frequent awakenings, poor-quality sleep, and a sense of dyspnea DISEASE .
These symptoms will often improve with time at moderate altitude but may persist at extreme altitude.
Alterations in sleep associated with ascent to alti- tude include a reduction in stage N3 sleep and increased arousal frequency.
Total sleep time and the amount of REM sleep are either unchanged or decreased.
Of note, the degree of both subjective and objective impairment of sleep quality was not correlated with the severity of periodic breathing in a number of studies.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes None known.
Demographics The demographics of high-altitude periodic breathing are not known.
High-altitude periodic breathing tends to occur in individuals with a high hypoxic and probably hypercapnic ventilatory response.
Because men generally have higher chemorespon- siveness than women, high-altitude periodic breathing may be more common in men than in women.
As stated above, periodic breathing will occur in virtually anyone ascending to higher than 4,000 meters and in some individuals at lower altitudes.
The latter group probably comprises individuals with increased hypoxic chemoresponsive-
ness.
In one study, individuals both with and without periodic breathing at altitude had alterations in sleep architecture.
Those with periodic breathing had a greater arousal index, although their sleep architecture was otherwise not significantly different from individuals who did not develop periodic breathing.
80 Predisposing and Precipitating Factors The only known predisposing factor for the development of high-altitude periodic breathing is increased ventilatory chemoresponsiveness, primarily hypoxic ventila- tory responsiveness.
A high hypoxic ventilatory response will lead to increased hyper- ventilation on ascent to altitude.
This hyperventilation DISEASE leads to hypocapnic alkalosis DISEASE that, during sleep, inhibits ventilation.
Thus, repetitive cycles of apnea DISEASE and hyperpnea DISEASE develop during NREM sleep.
The obvious precipitating factor for the development of this periodic breathing is ascent to altitude.
The more rapid the ascent, the more likely periodic breathing is to develop.
Familial Patterns Some data suggest that ventilatory chemoresponsiveness is directly inherited.
Because elevated hypoxic responsiveness is a predisposing variable in the development of high-altitude periodic breathing, it would seem likely that there would be a familial pattern in the development of this respiratory abnormality DISEASE .
However, there are no data addressing this issue.
Onset, Course, and Complications This respiratory pattern will generally be evident during sleep immediately after ascent to altitude.
This depends to some extent on the rapidity of the ascent, the elevation, and individual predisposition.
However, it will be present most often on the first night at altitude.
At moderate altitude, the breathing pattern may become more regular over time, although at extreme altitude it is likely to persist.
One recent study found that the amount of periodic breathing continued to increase over three days to two weeks of acclimatization.
Studies of adaptation to altitude suggest that sleep quality may improve despite further increases in periodic breathing.
It has been hypothesized that hypoxia DISEASE itself may have an important role in disturbing sleep architecture.
Thus, sleep and symptoms may improve during acclimatization to altitude even if the amount of periodic breathing actually increases.
The complications of high-altitude periodic breathing, which are generally limited to disrupted sleep on the initial nights at altitude, include frequent awakenings, often with shortness of breath DISEASE or a sensation of suffocation DISEASE that may lead to fatigue DISEASE or sleep- iness on the following day.
There is no clear association between periodic breathing and other altitude syndromes (high-altitude pulmonary edema DISEASE , acute mountain sick-
ness, and high-altitude cerebral edema DISEASE ).
In fact, periodic breathing is a marker of high hypoxic responsiveness, which generally yields improved oxygenation at altitude and a reduced frequency of the maladaptive syndromes.
81 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Developmental Issues Relatively little is known about differences between children and adults concerning periodic breathing at altitude.
One study did compare breathing in children and their fathers.
The children revealed reduced nocturnal oxygen CHEMICAL saturation and associated hyperventilation DISEASE at high altitude similar to the adults, but their breathing pattern was more stable.
The investigators hypothesized that children may have a lower apnea DISEASE threshold for CO2 CHEMICAL than adults.
Pathology and Pathophysiology High-altitude periodic breathing is believed to be a product of the hyperventilation DISEASE induced by the hypobaric hypoxia DISEASE encountered at altitude.
At 2,500 meters the atmo- spheric pressure is approximately 570 mm Hg and the ideal alveolar PO2 CHEMICAL around 55 mm Hg (depending on the level of PaCO2).
Actual arterial PO2 CHEMICAL values will be lower, especially during sleep.
The hypoxic ventilatory response shows a steep increase in ventilation when the arterial PO2 CHEMICAL level drops below 55 mm Hg.
The increases in venti- lation associated with hypoxemia DISEASE result in hypocapnic alkalosis DISEASE .
Because PaCO2 is the principal stimulus to respiration during NREM sleep, a low PaCO2 can yield a loss or reduction in respiratory drive, resulting in central apnea DISEASE or hypopnea DISEASE .
The greater the ventilatory response to hypoxia DISEASE , the greater the fall in PaCO2.
Thus, individuals with brisk hypoxic responses more commonly tend to demonstrate this respiratory pattern.
Over the course of the apnea DISEASE , the PaO2 falls and PaCO2 rises, eventually stimulating a resumption of ventilation.
However, after several large breaths, the PaCO2 again falls below the apnea DISEASE threshold, initiating another pause in breathing.
This cycle is then repeated over the course of the night.
Of note, the respiratory pattern is often improved during REM sleep with reduced cycling.
This is likely due to the decreased hypoxic and hypercapnic responsiveness characteristic of REM sleep.
Of interest, in one study the hypoxic ventilatory response continued to increase up to seven days after ascent to altitude.
This resulted in a lower PaCO2 and higher PaO2.
The reduction in peri- odic breathing in some individuals with adaptation to altitude despite a greater venti- latory response to hypoxemia DISEASE may be due to a lowering of the apneic threshold.
Other studies have found that the amount of periodic breathing continues to increase over three days to two weeks of acclimatization despite improvements in oxygen CHEMICAL saturation.
The increase in both periodic breathing and oxygen CHEMICAL saturation is thought to be due to increased controller gain of the respiratory system.
A number of studies have found that the impairment of sleep architecture does not correlate with the degree of periodic breathing.
One study found that the amount of periodic breathing was greater on the third night at altitude compared to the first night.
However, both the nocturnal oxygen CHEMICAL saturation and amount of stage N3 also increased on the third night compared to the first night.
It has been hypothesized that hypoxia DISEASE rather than periodic breathing might be the major factor disturbing sleep.
Objective Findings The PSG of individuals with high-altitude periodic breathing demonstrates recur- rent central apneas with a cycle time of less than 40 seconds, and typically around 20 seconds.
There is some degree of associated arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
The apneas are short, generally 8 to 10 seconds in duration.
In one study, the apnea DISEASE duration was around 8 seconds (7 to 9 seconds) in children and approximately 12 seconds (10-14 seconds) in adults.
The cycle length is commonly less than 40 seconds.
This breathing pattern occurs only during NREM sleep with more rhythmic respiration during REM sleep.
Because this breathing pattern is a physiologic adaptation to altitude, there is no specific number of apneas per hour of sleep that is considered normal or abnormal.
The apneas and associated hyperpnea DISEASE can lead to recurrent arousals DISEASE from sleep, which often increase stages N1 and N2 sleep while reducing stage N3 sleep.
REM sleep (stage R) duration is generally preserved, as is total sleep time.
As noted above, some studies have found a reduction in total sleep time and stage R as well as stage N3.
Of interest, the arousal index was only around 25% of the AHI in some investigations.
Differential Diagnosis High-altitude periodic breathing should be distinguished from other SRBDs DISEASE .
The major distinguishing factor is, of course, recent ascent to high altitude.
An individual with OSA DISEASE will likely continue to have this nocturnal respiratory problem at altitude.
Altitude might even exacerbate the OSA DISEASE .
Patients with chronic mountain sickness DISEASE demonstrate relative hypoventilation DISEASE at altitude (i.e., breathe less than is encoun- tered in normal individuals at similar altitude) such that they are more hypoxic than normal individuals who have a greater ventilatory response to the same ambient hypoxia DISEASE .
During sleep, these individuals often demonstrate further arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
Some of the individuals will demonstrate apneas or periodic breathing.
A diagnosis of chronic mountain sickness does not imply that periodic breathing is present.
However, periodic breathing may be more common in these patients than previously appreciated.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Recent studies suggest that hypoxemia DISEASE rather than the amount of periodic breathing may be the major factor impairing sleep quality.
Further studies relating changes in sleep and periodic breathing at altitude are needed.
83 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Bibliography Anholm J, Powles A, Downey R, et al.

J Sleep Res 2006;15:445–54.
Nussbaumer-Ochsner Y, Ursprung J, Siebenmann C, Maggiorini M, Bloch KE.
Effect of short-term acclimatization to high altitude on sleep and nocturnal breathing.
Sleep 2012;35:419–23.
Schoene R. Control of ventilation in climbers to extreme altitude.
J Appl Physiol 1982;53:886–90.
Waggener TB DISEASE , Brusil PJ, Kronauer RE, Gabel RA, Inbar GF.
Strength and cycle time of high-altitude ventilatory patterns in unacclimatized humans.
J Appl Physiol 1984;56:576–81.
White D, Gleeson K CHEMICAL , Pickett C, Rannels A, Cymerman A, Weil J. Altitude acclimatization: influence on periodic breathing and chemoresponsiveness during sleep.
J Appl Physiol 1987;63:401–12.
84 Central Sleep Apnea Due to a Medication or ICD-10-CM code: G47.39 Substance ICD-9-CM code: 327.29 Alternate Names Narcotic or opioid induced central sleep apnea DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-E must be met Sleep Related Breathing Disorders A.
The patient is taking an opioid or other respiratory depressant.
B. The presence of one or more of the following: . Sleepiness.
2. Difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, frequent awakenings, or nonrestorative sleep.
3. Awakening short of breath.
4.
Snoring DISEASE .
5. Witnessed apneas.
C. PSG (diagnostic or on positive airway pressure) shows all of the following:
1. Five or more central apneas and/or central hypopneas1 per hour of sleep (PSG).
2. The number of central apneas and/or central hypopneas DISEASE is > 50% of the total number of apneas DISEASE and hypopneas DISEASE .
3. Absence of CSB.1 D. The disorder occurs as a consequence of an opioid or other respiratory depressant.
E.
The disorder is not better explained by another current sleep disorder DISEASE .
Notes .
As defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
2. Ataxic breathing (irregular variations in respiratory cycle time and tidal volume) may be noted.
3. Nocturnal and/or daytime hypoventilation DISEASE may be present but are not required.
If sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is present, a diagnosis of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE due to medication or substance use can be made as well as a diagnosis of central sleep apnea DISEASE due to a medication or substance.
4.
A diagnosis of CSA CHEMICAL due to a medicationor substance does not exclude a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE . Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Essential Features Users of potent long-acting opioids may have central apneas during sleep.
The most common offending drug is methadone CHEMICAL .
However, the condition has also been described in patients taking long-acting forms of morphine CHEMICAL or oxycodone CHEMICAL as well as individu- als being treated with fentanyl CHEMICAL patches or continuous narcotic infusions.
Suboxone CHEMICAL (a combination of buprenorphine CHEMICAL and naloxone CHEMICAL ) is often used for treatment of patients with narcotic dependence DISEASE and pain DISEASE and can also cause drug-induced central apnea DISEASE .
The description of this population is complicated by the fact that many of the affected indi- viduals may be using multiple drugs (prescribed or illicit) that affect sleep and breathing.
Associated Features Breathing abnormalities DISEASE associated with these drugs are not restricted to central apneas and may also include hypoventilation DISEASE and OSA DISEASE with prolonged respiratory events.
In fact, many patients present with a combination of both OSA DISEASE and CSA.
Patients who have nocturnal hypoventilation DISEASE may have normal or increased daytime PaCO2.
In most patients with daytime hypoventilation DISEASE , the PaCO2 is only mildly increased (46-50 mm Hg).
Patients with drug-induced central apnea DISEASE who are being treated for chronic pain DISEASE often report significant daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
Due to the sedating effects of opioid medications, the sleepiness DISEASE may not substantially improve even if the central apnea DISEASE is treated successfully.
However, one study of patients on chronic methadone CHEMICAL mainte- nance found the average Epworth Sleepiness Scale score to be within normal range.
In these patients, who manifested only mild to moderate OSA DISEASE (average AHI about 18/ hour), the degree of sleepiness DISEASE correlated with a depression DISEASE index.
A case series of patients treated with opioids for chronic pain DISEASE found AHI values above 30/hour (up to 100/hour) and moderate to severe sleepiness DISEASE .
In this group, 50% to 80% of respiratory events were central apneas.
Sleepiness that is disproportionately high in comparison to the severity of the AHI (and in some cases, at least partially unresponsive to treatment) is likely due to the direct sedative effects of the narcotic medication itself.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes None known.
Demographics There are no known sex, racial, or ethnic differences.
The prevalence of this disorder is not known, although limited data suggest that it occurs commonly in those being treated with opioids for chronic pain DISEASE .
86 Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Use of a potent long-acting narcotic is the major causative factor.
If patients are suc- cessfully withdrawn from the offending medication, the central apnea DISEASE may resolve.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications
This disorder is typically seen after opioids have been used for at least two months.
An increased risk of death DISEASE has been reported with the use of potent narcotics.
There has been a large increase in deaths DISEASE associated with methadone CHEMICAL due to the increasing use of this medication for chronic pain DISEASE .
Many of these deaths DISEASE occur during sleep.
Developmental Issues Information regarding the presentation of this disorder in children is limited.
CSA CHEMICAL due to opioid medications has been described in children being treated for pain DISEASE due to cancer DISEASE .
Pathology and Pathophysiology The presumed pathophysiology for the development of these varied breathing abnor- DISEASE malities during sleep is the respiratory depression DISEASE that occurs through action of the drugs on the μ-receptors on the ventral surface of the medulla.
Studies have demon- CHEMICAL strated depression DISEASE of the awake hypercapnic ventilatory drive; however, it often improves after five to eight months of continued drug use.
In one study the hypoxic ventilatory drive never fully normalized.
Another study of patients on chronic meth- adone DISEASE maintenance found that the hypoxic ventilatory drive is increased compared to that of control subjects.
In this study the hypercapnic ventilatory response was reduced in comparison with that of controls who were not taking opioids.
The difference was not due to a lower tidal volume but rather reduced respiratory rate.
Differences in technique or patient population may explain the divergent findings.
The cause of the ataxic breathing in patients on opiates is not known.
However, one study of patients on chronic opioids found that the incidence of ataxic breathing increased with the total narcotic dose.
Objective Findings The drug-induced central apneas may occur as a form of periodic breathing with runs of central apneas separated by a short ventilatory phase (2 to 4 breaths) or intermittent and sporadic central apneas.
The underlying breathing pattern may show a slow respi- ratory rate or an ataxic breathing pattern.
The term ataxic breathing is sometimes used as a synonym of Biot breathing, although definitions of the latter term vary widely.
87 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Ataxic breathing DISEASE is characterized by an irregular breathing rhythm as well as irregular depth of breathing (tidal volume).
Obstructive breathing events are also common in patients taking potent opioids and a diagnosis of both OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL is often appro- priate.
Prolonged obstructive apneas with severe arterial desaturation may be noted.
The drug-induced central apneas occur mainly during NREM sleep and, in patients without coexistent obstructive apnea DISEASE , the AHI may be much lower during REM than during NREM sleep.
Patients also tend to have a low arousal index and increased stage N3 sleep.
Unlike other forms of central apnea DISEASE , drug-induced central apneas may occur during stage N3 sleep.
Differential Diagnosis This condition is best distinguished from other types of central sleep apnea DISEASE by the patient’s ongoing use of long-acting opioids.
Other SRBDs DISEASE may be present and may complicate PSG findings.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Further study is needed to determine risk factors and pathogenesis for development of these sleep disordered breathing patterns in users of long-acting opioids.
It has been hypothesized that these sleep disordered breathing patterns may play a role in the unex- plained increased mortality in this population.
This also requires further study.

Opioid-associated central sleep apnea DISEASE : a case series.

Primary Central Sleep Apnea ICD-9-CM code: 327.21 Alternate Names Idiopathic central sleep apnea DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-D must be met A.
The presence of at least one of the following1: 1. Sleepiness.
ICD-10-CM code: G47.31 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders .
Difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep, frequent awakenings, or nonrestorative sleep.
3. Awakening short of breath.
4.
Snoring DISEASE .
5. Witnessed apneas.
B. PSG demonstrates all of the following: . Five or more central apneas and/or central hypopneas2 per hour of sleep (PSG).
2. The number of central apneas and/or central hypopneas DISEASE is > 50% of the total number of apneas DISEASE and hypopneas DISEASE .
3.
Absence of CSB.2 C. There is no evidence of daytime or nocturnal hypoventilation DISEASE .
D.
The disorder is not better explained by another current sleep disorder DISEASE , medical or neurologic disorder DISEASE , medication use, or substance use disorder.
Notes .
In children, daytime symptoms may not be evident.
2. As defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
Essential Features Primary CSA CHEMICAL is of unknown etiology ( idiopathic DISEASE ) and is characterized by recurrent central apneas, defined as a cessation of airflow during sleep associated with an absence of respiratory effort.
Airflow and respiratory effort cease simultaneously in a repetitive Sleep Related Breathing Disorders fashion over the course of the night.
This recurrent cessation and resumption of venti- lation can lead to sleep fragmentation, yielding excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE , frequent nocturnal awakenings DISEASE , or both.
Thus, patients may present with symptoms of hyper- somnolence DISEASE or insomnia DISEASE .
Patients with primary CSA CHEMICAL tend to have low normal arterial PaCO2 during wakefulness (less than 40 mm Hg).
Patients with a known medical or neurological disorder DISEASE that is believed to cause central apneas are classified elsewhere.
Associated Features Patients generally present with excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE , sleep fragmentation, or insomnia DISEASE .
Other signs and symptoms that are often, but not invariably, present include snoring DISEASE , witnessed apnea DISEASE , and awakening with shortness of breath DISEASE .
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes The disorder is rare, precluding identification of any definite subtypes.
Demographics Not known.
Most studies suggest this disorder is rare, most common in middle-aged to elderly individuals, and more frequent in men than women, although not all studies support this sex bias.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors CSA CHEMICAL in these patients occurs because the arterial PCO2 (PaCO2) drops below the hypo- capnic apnea DISEASE threshold (HAT).
During wakefulness, drops in PaCO2 do not result in apnea DISEASE .
However, during sleep, when the PaCO2 drops below the HAT, respiratory effort ceases.
For most patients, the HAT DISEASE is within a few mm Hg of the awake PaCO2.
Any factors that narrow the gap between the sleeping PaCO2 and the HAT DISEASE predispose to central apnea DISEASE .
A high ventilatory response to CO2 CHEMICAL seems to be a major predisposing factor in the development of primary CSA.
This can lead to the instability in venti- latory control that characterizes the disorder.
Frequent arousal from sleep can also predispose to the development of central apneas, as ventilatory control is somewhat unstable at sleep-wake transitions.
Increased ventilation associated with arousal can result in a PaCO2 below the HAT after the return to sleep.
Because ventilatory drive is lower during REM than NREM sleep, hypocapnic central apnea DISEASE is much less common during that sleep stage.
Two other variables have been discussed as possible predispos- ing factors, although their true role in the development of this syndrome is uncertain.
First, frequent arousal or awakening due to low arousal threshold or sleep maintenance insomnia DISEASE have been reported to lead to an increase in central apneas.
Because ventila- tory control can be somewhat unstable in the normal wake-sleep transition with occa- sional central apneas being observed in otherwise normal individuals, any disorder that interrupts sleep may worsen CSA.
Some studies have suggested a worsening of primary CSA in the supine position, but this has been more clearly documented in patients with CSB.
Familial Patterns Some data suggest that ventilatory chemoresponsiveness is directly inherited.
Because elevated CO2 CHEMICAL responsiveness is a predisposing variable in the development of idio- pathic CSA, it would seem likely that there would be a familial pattern in the develop- ment of this respiratory abnormality DISEASE .
However, there are no data addressing this issue.
Onset, Course, and Complications Not known.
The apneas can lead to sleep fragmentation, yielding either hypersomno- lence or insomnia DISEASE .
There is little evidence that these apneas or their associated hypoxia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE lead to pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , cor pulmonale DISEASE , or other adverse car- diovascular consequences.
Developmental Issues Criteria for apnea DISEASE of infancy and apnea DISEASE of prematurity DISEASE are detailed elsewhere and it should be noted that central apnea DISEASE is defined somewhat differently in infants and chil- dren than in adults.
Central apneas that are brief (< 20 seconds in duration) and not associated with desaturation DISEASE or arousal are commonly observed in both premature and term infants.
In adults, population studies report an increase in the occurrence of central apnea DISEASE with increasing age, especially in men.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Primary CSA CHEMICAL is caused by instability of the respiratory control system in the transition from wakefulness to sleep and less commonly during stable NREM sleep.
Central apnea DISEASE in patients with primary CSA most often occurs during stages N1 and N2 sleep and is rare during stages
N3 and R sleep.
Central apneas tend to occur in individuals with a high or increased ventilatory responsiveness to CO2 CHEMICAL .
Arterial PCO2 levels below the hypocapnic apnea DISEASE threshold lead to a cessation in ventilatory effort and, therefore, a central apnea DISEASE .
Individuals with high CO2 CHEMICAL ventilatory responsiveness tend to have lower PaCO2 levels (both daytime and sleep) and a lower gradient between the sleep- ing PaCO2 and the apneic threshold.
Hence, a smaller increase in ventilation is required to reach this apnea DISEASE threshold and inhibit ventilation.
Individuals with high chemore- sponsiveness also hyperventilate DISEASE more in response to small changes in arterial PaCO2.
This again often drives the PaCO2 below the apnea DISEASE threshold, yielding a cessation Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders of ventilation.
However, not all factors that cause greater ventilatory drive have the same effect.
Studies suggest that although hypoxemia DISEASE increases chemoresponsiveness to PaCO2, the gap between the PaCO2 and the apneic threshold is smaller (predispos- ing to central apnea DISEASE ).
Metabolic acidosis DISEASE and nonhypoxic DISEASE chemoreceptor stimulants CHEMICAL tend to decrease HAT more than they decrease the sleeping PaCO2, resulting in a larger gap between the HAT and the sleeping PaCO2 and lower likelihood of central apnea DISEASE .
Metabolic alkalosis DISEASE tends to increase HAT DISEASE as well as decrease ventilatory responsive- ness, yielding a smaller gap between the HAT and sleeping PaCO2.
Objective Findings The PSG of the patient with primary CSA CHEMICAL demonstrates more than five central apneas and/or central hypopneas per hour of sleep.
The central apneas and central hypopneas DISEASE meet criteria for these respiratory events in adults or children as defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
Published studies of patients with primary CSA CHEMICAL have required that > 50% to 85% of respiratory events be central apneas.
Periodic breathing characterized by episodes of recurrent central apneas separated by periods of ventilation may occur.
The inter- event respiratory phase is typically brief with a maximum of five breaths.
The venti- latory phase between central apneas does not have the crescendo-decrescendo pattern of CSB breathing.
Central apneas commonly lead to mild arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation, although more severe desaturation DISEASE can occur.
Central apneas may also lead to arousal from sleep, causing fragmentation and yielding increased stages N1 and N2 sleep at the expense of stage N3 sleep.
As noted above, central apneas in these patients are less common during REM sleep.
In summary, respiration, arterial oxygenation, and sleep architecture are affected by this disorder.
Additionally, an arterial PaCO2
less than 40 mm
Hg is typically observed during wakefulness.
These patients do not exhibit sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
Differential Diagnosis Normal individuals may have a few central apneas in the wake-sleep transition.
However, once stable sleep is achieved, these apneas should cease.
Normal individuals should not have more than five central apneas per hour of sleep.
Primary CSA must be distinguished from other sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE .
Some patients with predominantly OSA DISEASE will have central apneas during diagnostic or positive airway pressure titration studies.
These apneas tend to resolve immediately or over time on positive airway pressure treatment.
The pattern of central apneas in primary CSA CHEMICAL differs from that of CSA with CSB.
Primary CSA lacks the crescendo-decrescendo pattern of respiration between contiguous central apneas noted in patients with CSA with CSB.
The cycle length is longer in CSB (greater than 40 seconds and typically 45 to 90 seconds).
The longer cycle length in CSB versus primary CSA CHEMICAL is due to a longer respiratory phase between central apneas.
In primary CSA, the apnea DISEASE is often terminated abruptly by a large breath, and there are usually no more that 4 to 5 breaths between apneas.
Furthermore, most patients with Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE respiration will have a history of congestive heart failure DISEASE or a neurological disorder DISEASE .
Patients with central apnea DISEASE due to substance use, particularly potent long-acting narcotics, may exhibit periodic breathing with central apneas, but the pattern of ventilation between apneas does not have a crescendo-decrescendo pattern and the cycle length is shorter than 40 seconds.
In addition, the underlying pattern of breathing is often ataxic DISEASE (irregular varia- tions in cycle length and tidal volume) and a low respiratory rate may be noted.
Unlike primary CSA, central apneas can occur during stage N3 in patients taking opioids.
Patients with CSA CHEMICAL due to medical or neurological conditions not of the Cheyne-Stokes DISEASE pattern often have a history of a known neurological disorder DISEASE (recent cerebrovascular accident) but in others a high index of suspicion for an underlying disorder DISEASE is indi- cated.
For example, patients with Chiari malformation DISEASE may present in adulthood with unexplained central apneas and relatively few other symptoms.
Thus, primary CSA CHEMICAL is a diagnosis based on careful exclusion of other causes of CSA.
In sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE and hypoxemic syndromes, patients have normal or increased daytime arterial PCO2 (PaCO2) with the onset or worsening of hypoven- tilation during sleep.
Daytime hypoventilation DISEASE is defined as a PaCO2 > 45 mm
Hg.
Patient with primary CSA CHEMICAL usually have an awake PaCO2 <
40 mm Hg.
The causes of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE include abnormalities in ventilatory control, neuro- muscular disease DISEASE , parenchymal lung disease DISEASE , or restrictive chest wall disorders DISEASE .
PSG in these patients may reveal a few central apneas, but the predominant pattern is one of reduced tidal volume (shallow pattern of breathing), often without a compensatory increase in respiratory rate.
There is usually significant oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation secondary to hypoventilation DISEASE and/or ventilation perfusion mismatch.
Patients with parenchymal lung disease DISEASE , neuromuscular disease DISEASE , or chest wall disorders DISEASE typically have abnormal pulmonary function tests and the most severe arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation typically occurs during REM sleep.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions
Although primary CSA CHEMICAL is believed to be a relatively rare disorder, additional prevalence data are needed.
The pathophysiology of this disorder remains unclear.
Specifically, the relative roles of instability in sleep state (low arousal threshold, delayed transition from wake to stable sleep) and respiratory control instability (elevated hypercapnic ventila- tory response) require further elucidation.
93 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Bibliography Bixler EO, Vgontzas AN, Lin HM, Ten Have T, Rein J, Vela-Bueno A, Kales A. Prevalence of sleep- disordered breathing DISEASE in women: effects of gender.
Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2001;163:608–13.
Bradley T, McNicholas W, Rutherford R, Popkin J, Zamel N, Phillipson E. Clinical and physiological heterogeneity of the central sleep apnea syndrome DISEASE .
Am Rev Respir Dis 1986;134:217–21.

J Physiol 2004;560:1–11.

Chest 2007;131:595–607.

Cycle length of periodic breathing in patients with and without heart failure DISEASE .
Am J Respir Crit Care Med 1996;154:376–81.
White D, Zwillich C, Pickett C, Douglas N, Findley L, Weil J. Central sleep apnea DISEASE : improvement with acetazolamide CHEMICAL therapy.
Arch Intern Med 1982;142:1816–9.

Effects of inhaled CO2 CHEMICAL and added dead space on idiopathic central sleep apnea DISEASE .
J Appl Physiol 1997;82:918–26.
Xie A, Rutherford R, Rankin F, Wong B, Bradley T. Hypocapnia DISEASE and increased ventilatory responsiveness in patients with idiopathic central sleep apnea DISEASE .
Am J Respir Crit Care Med 1995;152:1950–5.

Am J Respir Crit Care Med 1994;150:489–95.
Primary Central Sleep Apnea of Infancy ICD-9-CM code: 770.81 ICD-10-CM code:
P28.3 Alternate Names Infant sleep apnea DISEASE , apnea DISEASE of infancy, primary sleep apnea DISEASE of the newborn.
Inappropriate terms for primary central sleep apnea DISEASE of the newborn include near-miss sudden infant death DISEASE syndrome ( SIDS DISEASE ),
near-SIDS, aborted SIDS DISEASE , and aborted crib death DISEASE ; these terms imply a causal relationship between apnea DISEASE and SIDS DISEASE that is not supported by extensive research.
Likewise, the term “apparent life-threatening event ( ALTE DISEASE )” should not be used.
Although some infants with primary sleep apnea DISEASE present with an ALTE DISEASE , there are many other causes of ALTE DISEASE , and some children with sleep apnea DISEASE do not have ALTE.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-D must be met A. Apnea or cyanosis DISEASE is noted by an observer or an episode of sleep related central apnea DISEASE or desaturation DISEASE is detected by monitoring.
B. The infant has a conceptional age of at least 37 weeks.
94 C. PSG or alternative monitoring such as hospital or home apnea DISEASE monitoring shows either: .
Recurrent, prolonged (> 20 seconds duration) central apneas.1 .
Periodic breathing2 for ≥ 5% of total sleep time.
D.
The disorder is not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE , medical or neurological disorder DISEASE , or medication.
Notes .
Normative data concerning the number of prolonged central apneas per hour are not well established.
2. As defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
3. Short (< 20 seconds) central apneas associated with significant desaturation DISEASE are more likely to be a sign of decreased pulmonary reserve than of central nervous system pathology.
4. Definitive determination of the central nature of apneas requires simultaneous monitoring of airflow and respiratory effort.
Obstructive DISEASE and mixed apneas may also be present, but central apneas are predominant.
Essential Features Primary CSA of infancy DISEASE is characterized by prolonged, predominantly central apneas in children of at least 37 weeks conceptional age.
These events are typically associated with physiological compromise ( hypoxemia DISEASE , bradycardia DISEASE ), or the need for intervention such as stimulation or resuscitation.
Obstructive DISEASE and/or mixed apneas or hypopneas DISEASE may also be seen, although central events are the predominant finding.
It is a disorder of respira- tory control that can be either a developmental problem associated with immaturity of the brainstem respiratory centers or secondary to other medical conditions that produce apnea DISEASE by mechanisms such as direct depression DISEASE of central respiratory control.
Apnea in the neonate or infant may be exacerbated or precipitated by a variety of medical condi- tions, such as anemia DISEASE , infection DISEASE , hypoxemia DISEASE , metabolic disturbances DISEASE , gastroesophageal reflux, substances, or anesthesia, which must be recognized and treated to stabilize the apnea DISEASE .
If another medical condition appears to be the cause rather than an exacerbating factor for the CSA, then the condition should be classified as CSA CHEMICAL due to a medical or neurological condition, or CSA CHEMICAL due to a medication or substance.
Despite the heterogeneity of infant risk groups and underlying pathophysiology, most studies report a progressive decrease in frequency of apneas and risk of symptomatic apnea DISEASE secondary to other medical conditions after the early weeks of life.
95 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Associated Features Infants may present with an ALTE DISEASE (defined by a National Institutes of Health Development Conference as “an episode that is frightening to the observer, and that is characterized by some combination of apnea DISEASE
[
central or occasionally obstructive], color change, marked change in muscle tone, choking DISEASE or gagging.
In some cases, the observer fears that the infant has died”).
Many infants with primary CSA of infancy DISEASE will not have an ALTE DISEASE , and many ALTEs DISEASE are not associated with apnea DISEASE .
Primary CSA CHEMICAL of infancy is state dependent, and the frequency of respiratory events increases during active (REM) sleep.
Paradoxical chest wall movements are common during active sleep in infants and may cause a fall in arterial oxygen CHEMICAL saturation because of ventilation or perfusion defects associated with a decrease in functional residual capacity.
Underlying comorbidities (for example, chronic lung disease or abnormal neurological status) can predispose the infant to having a more severe or prolonged course for apnea DISEASE .
Note that a small upper airway will exaggerate the obstructive elements of this disorder.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Not applicable.
Demographics Less than 0.5% of full-term newborns experience symptomatic apnea DISEASE .
Studies have shown that during the first six months of life, 2% of healthy full-term infants will experience at least one apnea DISEASE event lasting 30 seconds or longer or an apnea DISEASE that lasts at least 20 seconds and is associated with a heart rate less than 60 beats per minute.
Apnea of infancy DISEASE occurs equally in males and females, and in infants of all races and ethnic groups.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Many factors may precipitate apneic DISEASE episodes, including gastroesophageal reflux, intra- cranial pathology, substances, anesthesia, metabolic disorders DISEASE , impaired oxygenation, and infection DISEASE (including sepsis DISEASE , meningitis DISEASE , respiratory syncytial virus infections DISEASE , and pertussis).
Infection DISEASE with respiratory syncytial virus, in particular, can increase the fre- quency and the duration of apneas.
Familial Patterns None known.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset is usually in the first weeks or months of life.
Some infants may be diagnosed by nursing observations or routine monitoring soon after birth.
Older infants may present with an ALTE DISEASE or may have failure to thrive. DISEASE
The prognosis is generally good, with res- olution of apnea DISEASE over the first few years of life and no residual sequelae.
The presence of persistent severe apnea DISEASE may be an indication of an underlying medical condition and should prompt further evaluation.
Patients with persistent severe apnea DISEASE may develop sequelae related to hypoxic events.
Developmental Issues This is a condition of infancy that normally improves over time.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Physiological factors contributing to apnea DISEASE are related to immaturity of respiratory control.
These include developmental alterations in central drive, chemoreceptor or mechanoreceptor responses, and upper airway reflexes.
Precipitating factors for wors- ening apnea DISEASE include gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , intracranial pathology, substances, anes- thesia, metabolic disturbances, impaired oxygenation, and infection DISEASE .
Objective Findings Apnea is predominantly central, but obstructive and mixed apneas may occur.
Apneas are seen most frequently during REM sleep.
Other diagnostic tests, such as a full EEG or evaluation for reflux, may be appropriate in individual cases.
Differential Diagnosis Primary CSA CHEMICAL of infancy should be distinguished from the normal respiratory pauses that occur during sleep.
Normative respiratory data from several large studies show that healthy asymptomatic infants commonly have central respiratory pauses, either as isolated events (particularly during REM sleep) or after sigh breaths or movements.
Primary CSA CHEMICAL of infancy should be distinguished from the popular clinical term, ALTE DISEASE , which is not a specific diagnosis but an ill-defined constellation of parent-reported apnea symptoms DISEASE that range in severity from benign to life threatening.
Recurrent, severe infant sleep apnea DISEASE is usually due to other comorbid conditions, such as gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , metabolic disease DISEASE , or unrecognized neurological conditions such as seizures DISEASE , brainstem malformation DISEASE , or neurodegenerative condi- tion; thus an evaluation for these conditions should be performed.
Another diagnos- tic consideration is a form of child abuse ( Munchausen syndrome DISEASE by proxy) mani- fest as imposed upper airway obstruction DISEASE or attempted suffocation.
Primary CSA CHEMICAL of infancy should be disassociated from the postmortem diagnosis of SIDS DISEASE .
Although a small percentage of SIDS DISEASE victims experience apnea DISEASE symptoms prior to death DISEASE , Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders primary apnea DISEASE in the newborn or infant has not been established as an independent risk factor for SIDS DISEASE .
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Infancy is a developmental period normally characterized by instability of control of breathing; thus, defining what is abnormal is a diagnostic challenge.
Further research is needed into the mechanisms of ventilatory control development in the infant and the pathophysiologic factors resulting in infant apnea DISEASE .
Bibliography American Academy of Pediatrics.
Apnea, sudden infant death syndrome, and home monitoring.
Pediatrics 2003;111:914–7.
Hunt CE, Hufford DR, Bourguignon C, Oess MA.
Home documented monitoring of cardiorespiratory pattern and oxygen CHEMICAL saturation in healthy infants.
Pediatr Res CHEMICAL 1996;39:216–22.

Pediatrics 1987;79:292–9. Ramanathan R, Corwin MJ, Hunt CE, et al.
Cardiorespiratory events recorded on home monitors: Comparison of healthy infants with those at increased risk for SIDS DISEASE .
JAMA 2001;285:2199–207.
Southall DP, Plunkett MC, Banks MW, Falkov AF, Samuels MP DISEASE .
Covert video recordings of life- threatening child abuse: lessons for child protection.
Pediatrics 1997;100:735–60.
Primary Central Sleep Apnea of Prematurity DISEASE ICD-9-CM code: 770.82 ICD-10-CM code:
P28.4 Alternate Names Apnea of prematurity DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-D must be met A. Apnea or cyanosis DISEASE is noted by an observer, or an episode of sleep related central apnea DISEASE , desaturation DISEASE , or bradycardia DISEASE is detected by hospital monitoring in the postnatal period.
B. The infant has a conceptional age less than 37 weeks at the time of onset of symptoms.
C. PSG or alternative monitoring such as hospital or home apnea DISEASE monitoring shows either: .
Recurrent prolonged (> 20 seconds duration) central apneas.1 2.
Periodic breathing2 for ≥ 5% of total sleep time.
98 D. The disorder is not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE , medical or neurological disorder DISEASE , or medication.
Notes .
Normative data concerning the number of prolonged central apneas per hour are not well established.
2. As defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
3. Short (< 20 seconds) central apneas associated with significant desaturation DISEASE are more likely to be a sign of decreased pulmonary reserve than of central nervous system pathology.
4. Obstructive DISEASE and mixed apneas may also be present, but central apneas are predominant.
Essential Features Apnea is very common in preterm infants, and the prevalence varies inversely with ges- tational age.
In the preterm infant, sleep apnea DISEASE can be anticipated, is primarily related to immaturity, and may require supportive ventilatory and pharmacologic treatment.
The condition will improve with maturation unless extenuating conditions, such as hypoxemia DISEASE due to chronic lung disease DISEASE or gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , are present.
Apneas are predominantly central, but mixed or obstructive apneas or hypopneas DISEASE may be seen.
The events are typically associated with physiological compromise ( hypoxemia DISEASE , bra- dycardia) or the need for intervention such as stimulation or resuscitation.
Associated Features Apnea in the preterm infant is commonly associated with bradycardia DISEASE .
Primary CSA of prematurity DISEASE is state dependent, and the frequency of respiratory events increases during active (REM) sleep.
Paradoxical chest wall movements are common during active sleep in neonates and may cause a fall in arterial oxygen CHEMICAL saturation because of ventilation or perfusion defects associated with a decrease in functional residual capac- ity.
Underlying comorbidities (for example, chronic lung disease or abnormal neuro- logical status) DISEASE can predispose the infant to having a more severe or prolonged course for apnea DISEASE .
Note that a small upper airway will exaggerate the obstructive elements of this disorder.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes None known.
99 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Demographics The prevalence of apnea DISEASE of prematurity DISEASE varies inversely with conceptional age.
In studies, approximately 25% percent of infants who weigh less than 2,500 g at birth and 84% of infants under 1,000 g may experience symptomatic apnea DISEASE during the neo- natal period.
Ninety-two percent of preterm infants will be symptom free by 37 weeks postconceptional age, and 98% by 40 weeks after conception, with resolution in most infants by 43 weeks postconception.
Apnea of prematurity DISEASE occurs equally in males and females, and in infants of all races and ethnic groups.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Developmental delay in respiratory control associated with premature birth is the major predisposing condition.
Diverse factors are known to precipitate development of apneic DISEASE episodes in predisposed preterm infants.
These include thermal instability, gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , intracranial pathology, substances, anesthesia, metabolic disorders DISEASE , impaired oxygenation, and infection DISEASE .
Infection DISEASE with respiratory syncytial virus can increase the frequency and the duration of apneas DISEASE in predisposed infants.
OSA DISEASE associated with upper airway abnormalities DISEASE can present as apnea DISEASE of prematurity DISEASE .
Persistence of apnea DISEASE after 43 weeks conceptional age should raise suspicion of addi- tional etiologic factors.
Familial Patterns None known.
Onset, Course, and Complications In preterm infants, apnea DISEASE is rare on day one of life, and its presence usually signals another illness.
More typical onset occurs between the second and seventh days.
Apnea of prematurity DISEASE usually ceases by 37 weeks conceptional age but may persist for several weeks beyond term, especially in infants born before 28 weeks postconception; apnea DISEASE beyond 43 weeks postconception is rare.
Adverse outcomes for former preterm infants are more closely related to the prenatal or neonatal course, associated comorbidities, and environmental factors than to the apnea DISEASE of prematurity DISEASE per se.
For most children, long-term outcomes for uncomplicated apnea DISEASE of prematurity DISEASE are excellent.
However, the prognosis for infants with persistent recurrent apnea spells DISEASE requiring frequent resuscitation is more guarded and depends on the cause of the apnea DISEASE and associated comorbidities.
Developmental Issues This is a condition related to prematurity DISEASE that normally improves over time.
100 Pathology and Pathophysiology Physiological factors contributing to apnea DISEASE are related to immaturity of respiratory control.
These include developmental alterations in central drive, chemoreceptor or mechanoreceptor responses, and upper airway reflexes.
Precipitating factors for wors- ening apnea DISEASE in preterm infants include thermal instability, gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , intracranial pathology, substances, anesthesia, metabolic disturbances, impaired oxy- genation, and infection DISEASE .
Objective Findings Most premature neonates are diagnosed with apnea DISEASE of prematurity DISEASE based on cardio- respiratory monitoring in the neonatal intensive care unit, rather than by PSG.
When PSG is performed, central apneas are often shown to have a mixed component, with mixed apneas accounting for 50% to 75% of apneas DISEASE in small premature infants; studies suggest that obstructive-type events account for 10% to 20% of events; and pure central events, 10% to 25%.
Periodic breathing may be present.
Differential Diagnosis Apnea of prematurity DISEASE should be distinguished from normal, physiologic respiratory pauses that occur during sleep in infants.
Studies have shown that healthy asymptom- atic infants commonly have brief (< 20 second) central respiratory pauses, either as isolated events (particularly during REM sleep) or after sigh breaths or movements (in which case the apneas may be longer).
These infants are typically asymptomatic, with no changes in color or muscle tone.
The differential diagnosis is long and includes apnea DISEASE secondary to severe gastroesoph- ageal reflux DISEASE , central nervous system malformations or hemorrhage DISEASE , seizures DISEASE , sepsis DISEASE , and rarely primary cardiac arrhythmias DISEASE .
Comorbid conditions should be suspected whenever apneas DISEASE are severe or continue beyond 43 weeks gestation.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions The mechanisms underlying physiologic maturation of ventilatory control are not well understood.
Further research is required to determine which infants are at greatest risk for severe apnea DISEASE .
