In: Loughlin G, Carroll J, Marcus C, eds.
Sleep and breathing in children.
New York: Marcel Dekker, 2000:495–515.
Schmidt B, Roberts RS DISEASE , Davis P, et al.
Long-term effects of caffeine CHEMICAL therapy for apnea DISEASE of prematurity DISEASE .
N Engl J Med 2007;357:1893–902.
Southall DP, Plunkett MC, Banks MW, Falkov AF, Samuels MP DISEASE .
Covert video recordings of life- threatening child abuse: lessons for child protection [see comments].
Pediatrics 1997;100:735–60. Treatment-Emergent Central Sleep Apnea ICD-9-CM code: 327.29 ICD-10-CM code: G47.39 Alternate names Complex sleep apnea DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A. Diagnostic PSG shows five or more predominantly obstructive respiratory events1 ( obstructive DISEASE or mixed apneas, hypopneas DISEASE or RERAs) per hour of sleep B. PSG during use of positive airway pressure without a backup rate shows significant resolution of obstructive events and emergence or persistence of central apnea DISEASE or central hypopnea DISEASE with all of the following:
1. Central apnea DISEASE —central hypopnea DISEASE index [CAHI] ≥ 5/hour.
2. Number of central apneas and central hypopneas DISEASE is ≥ 50% of total number of apneas DISEASE and hypopneas DISEASE .
C. The central sleep apnea DISEASE is not better explained by another CSA disorder DISEASE (e.g., CSA with CSB or CSA CHEMICAL due to a medication or substance).
Notes .
Respiratory events defined according the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
2. A diagnosis of treatment-emergent central sleep apnea DISEASE does not exclude a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE .
That is, a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE can be made based on the diagnostic sleep study.
102 Essential Features A diagnosis of treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL is characterized by predominantly obstructive events ( DISEASE obstructive DISEASE or mixed apnea DISEASE or hypopnea DISEASE ) during a diagnostic sleep study with persistence or emergence of CSA CHEMICAL during administration of positive airway pressure without a backup rate, despite significant resolution of obstructive respiratory events.
If the central apnea DISEASE is better explained by another CSA disorder DISEASE , patients are given a diagnosis of OSA DISEASE and that CSA disorder DISEASE rather than treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL (e.g., a patient with heart failure DISEASE exhibits mainly obstructive events during diagnostic PSG but then exhibits predominantly central apnea DISEASE with CSB on positive airway pressure).
Associated Features Patients with treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL have several characteristics when placed on positive airway pressure without a backup rate.
A high number of arousals DISEASE persist on PAP treatment, and the AHI is often higher during NREM than REM sleep.
This is due to the fact that treatment-emergent central apneas almost invariably occur during NREM sleep.
Pressures DISEASE that are effective in controlling obstructive events during REM sleep prove ineffective during NREM sleep due to emergence of central apneas.
If patients can attain stage N3, central apneas often decrease until interrupted by an arousal or transition to a lighter stage of sleep that precipitates another run of central apneas or hypopneas DISEASE .
Patients with treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL can have persistent sleep fragmentation on CPAP treatment and may report little benefit from therapy.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes None known.
Demographics The percentage of patients with persistent or emergent central apnea DISEASE on the initial poly- somnographic positive airway pressure titration varies from 2% to 20% depending on the characteristics of the group studied (community or referral sleep center) and the methodology.
If patients who are taking opioids or have underling central apnea DISEASE with CSB are included, the percentage is at the higher end of the range.
The percentage of patients with central sleep apnea DISEASE that persists on chronic CPAP treatment (approxi- mately 2%) is considerably lower than the percentage identified on the first or second night of CPAP treatment.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors A number of factors have been hypothesized to cause treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL , but definitive data are not available.
The patients presumably have characteristics that would predispose them to instability in ventilatory control or sleep maintenance.
103 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders These include a low arousal threshold and high ventilatory controller gain.
Studies have found that often a small increase in end-tidal PCO2 can stabilize breathing in patients with treatment-emergent central apneas.
Therefore, any events that predis- pose a patient to hypocapnia DISEASE can trigger treatment-emergent central apnea DISEASE .
In some, but not all studies, the overall AHI on the diagnostic PSG (or diagnostic portion of a split-night PSG) was higher in the treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL group compared to the patients without this diagnosis.
In other studies, patients with treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL had more central apneas during the diagnostic PSG and were more likely to be male.
However, identified risk factors for treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL vary considerably from study to study.
Of note, the emergence of central apnea DISEASE after treatment of obstructive apnea DISEASE with tra- cheostomy, maxillomandibular advancement, and oral appliance treatment for OSA DISEASE has been reported.
A case report of the development of central apnea DISEASE following nasal surgery in a patient with known obstructive apnea DISEASE has also recently been published.
Familial Patterns None known.
Onset, Course, and Complications The recognition of treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL follows PAP titration.
An accurate esti- mate of the percentage of patients with treatment-emergent central apneas whose central events persist on long-term PAP treatment does not exist, as most published reports are retrospective and had a significant number of patients lost to follow-up.
Of interest, one study comparing the results of an initial CPAP titration study with one per- formed after six months of therapy found patients who did not meet criteria for treat- ment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL on the initial study but met the criteria on the second study.
Those patients with treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL that do not experience resolution of central apneas on chronic PAP treatment are found to have a high number of residual events on PAP machine interrogation in clinic follow-up.
Nocturnal oximetry at home on PAP treatment may show persistent arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
Sleep fragmentation and daytime sleepiness DISEASE may persist if a significant number of central apneas remain.
There is the potential for poor adherence and acceptance of PAP treatment as a result of this.
Developmental Issues Treatment-emergent sleep apnea DISEASE has not been described in children but this may be due to the relatively small number of children with OSA DISEASE who are treated with PAP.
104 Pathology and Pathophysiology Due to variation in definitions of treatment-emergent CSA, the pathophysiology is not clearly defined.
A low arousal threshold and difficulty reaching stage N3 sleep may pre- dispose to sleep instability DISEASE .
Arousals DISEASE destabilize breathing.
A high ventilatory response to PaCO2 and a small difference between the sleeping PaCO2 and the apnea DISEASE threshold may also predispose patients to treatment-emergent central apneas.
Treatment with excessive positive airway pressure may trigger treatment-emergent central apneas in susceptible individuals.
Objective Findings PSG during a full night diagnostic study (or diagnostic portion of a split-night PSG) shows predominantly obstructive DISEASE or mixed apneas and hypopneas DISEASE of five or more per hour of sleep.
PSG with PAP (either a full night titration study or PAP treatment portion of a split night study) without a backup rate shows significant resolution of obstructive events and emergence or persistence of central apneas DISEASE or central hypopneas.
The CAHI is five or greater per hour, and more than 50% of the respiratory events are central in nature.
A diagnosis of treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL excludes patients who manifest central sleep apnea DISEASE on PAP treatment when the CSA CHEMICAL is better explained by another CSA dis- order or by over-titration.
PSG with administration of PAP often reveals adequate treatment during REM sleep and stage N3 sleep but repetitive episodes of central events during stages N1 and N2.
In some patients, progressive increases in pressure with a goal of preventing airflow limitation reach a “break point” at which central apneas appear.
Differential Diagnosis Many patients with OSA DISEASE have a few central events while on PAP.
However, in the majority of cases, the central AHI is not ≥ 5/hour and central events are not ≥ 50% of the total number of apneas DISEASE and hypopneas DISEASE .
Other patients with OSA DISEASE , while on PAP, exhibit predominantly central events that are believed to be secondary to a CSA disor- der classified elsewhere.
In this case, a diagnosis of both OSA DISEASE and the CSA disorder DISEASE is appropriate, rather than a diagnosis of treatment-emergent CSA.
For example, a patient taking methadone CHEMICAL has predominantly obstructive events during the diagnostic portion of a split-night PSG.
Once obstructive events are eliminated on PAP, CSA with ataxic breathing is noted.
A diagnosis of both OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL due to a medication or substance should be made if criteria for that disorder are met.
105 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Unresolved Issues and Further Directions The true incidence of treatment-emergent sleep apnea DISEASE as well as the percentage of patients who have persistent central apnea DISEASE on chronic PAP treatment remains to be defined.
Further prospective studies with clearly defined inclusion and exclusion crite- ria are needed to better define the exact percentage of patients with treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL who have persistent CSA CHEMICAL after chronic PAP treatment.
There may be night-to- night variability in the amount of CSA CHEMICAL displayed by a given patient.
It is unknown, for example, whether treatment-emergent central apneas that resolve on chronic PAP treatment will re-emerge if the patient discontinues PAP treatment for a period of time and then restarts treatment.
A number of factors have been hypothesized to increase the likelihood of treatment-emergent central apneas including overtitration (excessive pressure), undertitration (respiratory effort arousals DISEASE followed by central apnea DISEASE ), the use of bilevel PAP rather than CPAP, arousals DISEASE from mask leak, and use of a split night study.
Further study is needed to verify that these factors do indeed predispose a patient to develop treatment-emergent central apneas.
The evolution of treatment-emergent central apneas on chronic PAP treatment also remains to be determined; that is, to what extent do central events resolve over time and what is the time course of this resolu- tion?
In light of the increasing utilization of auto-titrating PAP, further investigation of the incidence of treatment-emergent CSA CHEMICAL with this modality is indicated.

Differentiating obstructive from central and complex sleep apnea DISEASE using an automated electrocardiogram-based method.

Obstructive sleep-disordered breathing DISEASE with a dominant cyclic alternating pattern--a recognizable polysomnographic variant with practical clinical implications.
Sleep 2004;27:229–34.
Westhoff M, Arzt M, Litterst P. Prevalence and treatment of central sleep apnoea DISEASE emerging after initiation of continuous positive airway pressure in patients with obstructive sleep apnoea DISEASE without evidence of heart failure DISEASE .
Sleep Breath 2012;16:71–8.
107 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Hypoventilation DISEASE Disorders The primary feature of these disorders is insufficient sleep related ventilation, result- ing in abnormally elevated arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide CHEMICAL (PaCO2) during sleep.
In addition, demonstration of daytime hypoventilation DISEASE is required for a diagno- sis of obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE (OHS).
Awake hypoventilation DISEASE is defined as an arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide CHEMICAL (PaCO2) greater than 45 mm Hg.
In the sleep related hypoventilation disorders DISEASE other than OHS, daytime hypoventilation DISEASE may or may not be present.
If hypoventilation DISEASE is present during wakefulness, it worsens during sleep in all of these disorders.
General Criteria Sleep Related Hypoventilation DISEASE Criterion A must be met A. Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE , as defined by the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events, is present.1,2 Notes .
Monitoring of arterial PCO2 during sleep is not practical.
Acceptable surrogates include end-tidal PCO2 or transcutaneous PCO2.
2. Arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation is often present but is not required for the diagnosis.
Obesity Hypoventilation Syndrome ICD-9-CM code: 278.03 ICD-10-CM code: E66.2 Alternate Names Hypercapnic sleep apnea DISEASE , sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE associated with obesity DISEASE .
Use of the term Pickwickian syndrome DISEASE is discouraged because not only has it been applied to those with OSA DISEASE , but also indiscriminately used to describe persons who are only obese and those with OHS.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A. Presence of hypoventilation DISEASE during wakefulness (PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg) as measured by arterial PCO2, end-tidal PCO2, or transcutaneous PCO2.
B. Presence of obesity DISEASE (BMI > 30 kg/m2; > 95th percentile for age and sex for children).

108 C. Hypoventilation DISEASE is not primarily due to lung parenchymal or airway disease DISEASE , pulmonary vascular pathology, chest wall disorder DISEASE (other than mass loading from obesity DISEASE ), medication use, neurologic disorder DISEASE , muscle weakness DISEASE , or a known congenital or idiopathic central alveolar hypoventilation syndrome.
Notes .
PSG shows worsening of hypoventilation DISEASE during sleep if PaCO2 or noninvasive estimate of the PaCO2 is measured.
2. OSA DISEASE is often present and, in such cases, a diagnosis of both OSA DISEASE and OHS should be made.
3.
Arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation is usually present but is not required for the diagnosis.
Essential Features OHS is characterized by obesity DISEASE and daytime hypercapnia CHEMICAL (arterial PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg) that cannot be fully attributed to an underlying cardiopulmonary or neurologic disease.
Hypercapnia DISEASE worsens during sleep and is often associated with severe arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
Hypoventilation DISEASE is often worse during REM than during NREM sleep.
The majority of OHS patients have comorbid OSA DISEASE (80% to 90%).
In these patients, daytime hypercapnia CHEMICAL may improve or even normalize with adequate PAP treatment and sustained adherence to treatment.
Those OHS patients without OSA DISEASE exhibit sustained or intermittent episodes of shallow breathing during sleep associated with worsening hypoventilation DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE .
Patients with OHS may have few, if any, sleep com- plaints, or may present with considerable sleep disturbance DISEASE including reduced sleep efficiency and frequent awakenings.
Hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE may remain unno- CHEMICAL ticed for quite some time until sudden deterioration with cardiopulmonary arrest DISEASE or severe decompensation DISEASE (acute or chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure) develops.
Associated Features Patients with OHS commonly complain of hypersomnolence DISEASE .
The severity of hyper- somnolence DISEASE may not correlate closely with degree of hypercapnia DISEASE .
Other symptoms include morning headaches DISEASE , fatigue DISEASE , mood disturbance DISEASE and impairments of memory DISEASE or concentration.
Physical examination may reveal features suggestive of cor pul- monale or circulatory congestion DISEASE , such as plethora, scleral injection, and peripheral edema DISEASE .
Laboratory testing commonly shows polycythemia DISEASE and elevated serum CO2 CHEMICAL on electrolyte testing (≈ serum bicarbonate CHEMICAL ), reduced forced vital capacity during pulmo- DISEASE nary function testing, right heart strain, right ventricular hypertrophy DISEASE and right atrial enlargement on electrocardiography and ventricular dysfunction DISEASE on echocardiography.
109 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Consequences of chronic hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE include pulmonary artery hyper- tension, cor pulmonale DISEASE , and neurocognitive dysfunction DISEASE .
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Not applicable or known.
Demographics OHS may be underdiagnosed if CO2 CHEMICAL analysis (≈ serum bicarbonate CHEMICAL ) is not performed in obese patients presenting with complaints suggestive of OHS.
The prevalence of OHS in populations of patients with OSA DISEASE varies across studies but is often in the range of 10% to 15% of obese patients with OSA DISEASE .
Although the prevalence of OHS is higher in men than women the difference is not as prominent as in OSA DISEASE .
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Obesity DISEASE is believed to be the primary pathophysiologic factor responsible for hypoven- tilation and hypoxemia DISEASE .
Greater degrees of obesity DISEASE are often associated with worse sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE , but individual variations in the severity of hypercap- nia at similar weights may be seen.
The use of central nervous system depressants, such as alcohol CHEMICAL , anxiolytics, and hypnotics, may further worsen respiratory impair- ment.
Patients who are hypercapnic and hypoxemic during wakefulness will invari- ably become even more so during sleep, in particular REM sleep, but the relationship between wake SaO2/PaCO2 and sleep related desaturation DISEASE is not sufficiently strong to have substantial predictive value in individual patients.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications Persons who are eventually diagnosed with OHS either present initially for evalu- ation of suspected OSA DISEASE or are identified following one or more episodes of severe hypercapnic respiratory failure DISEASE .
The course can be variable but is generally slowly pro- gressive.
Many affected individuals with severe hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE develop pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , heart failure DISEASE , cardiac arrhythmias DISEASE , and neurocognitive dys- DISEASE function.
Polycythemia DISEASE is common in those with chronic hypoxia DISEASE .
Although the risk of increased morbidity and mortality appears to increase with worsening sleep related hypoventilation/hypoxemia, the specific relationship between sleep related hypoventi- lation/hypoxemia DISEASE and morbidity and mortality is not well defined.
Obesity, itself, can lead to other respiratory complaints DISEASE , including shortness of breath DISEASE , dyspnea DISEASE on exer- tion and orthopnea DISEASE , even in the absence of demonstrable elevation of daytime PaCO2.
110 However, in one study of inpatients with obesity DISEASE , those with hypoventilation DISEASE had an 18-month mortality of 23% compared with 9% in the group with equivalent obesity DISEASE but no hypoventilation DISEASE .
Many patients with OHS respond to CPAP or bilevel CHEMICAL PAP with improvement in daytime PaCO2.
However, normalization of daytime PaCO2 occurs in only a minority of patients.
In one study, 34% of OHS patients using PAP more than 4.5 hours per night had normalization of the PaCO2.
In contrast hypercapnia DISEASE may worsen with oxygen CHEMICAL therapy alone for the associated hypoxia DISEASE .
Developmental Issues Not known.
Pathology and Pathophysiology The etiology of hypoventilation DISEASE is not completely understood.
Although comorbid OSA DISEASE is common, hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE are not entirely a function of upper airway obstruction DISEASE .
The importance of various factors leading to hypoventilation DISEASE likely varies among patients.
It has been postulated that sustained nocturnal hypercapnia DISEASE results from the development of short (due to apnea-hypopnea) or longer (secondary to hypoven- tilation) periods of hypercapnia DISEASE accompanied by inadequate compensation (i.e., CO2 CHEMICAL unloading) during periods of ventilation between obstructive events.
Abnormal venti- latory control (blunted hypercapnic ventilatory response) allows hypercapnia DISEASE to persist into wakefulness after the cause of acute hypercapnia DISEASE is no longer present.
A chronic hypercapnic state would produce an elevation of bicarbonate CHEMICAL .
Although this blunts the degree of acidosis DISEASE due to an elevated PaCO2, it reduces the compensatory CO2 ventilatory response.
Impaired renal bicarbonate excretion DISEASE rate, as seen in hypoxia DISEASE , heart failure DISEASE , or diuretic-related chloride deficiency DISEASE , may contribute to the persistence of hypercapnia DISEASE .
Obesity DISEASE itself is also associated with several factors that predispose to CO2 CHEMICAL retention.
Obesity DISEASE itself increases CO2 CHEMICAL production.
There is an increased work of breathing due to mass loading from the additional weight on the respiratory pump as well as resistive loading due to intermittent upper airway obstruction DISEASE during sleep.
Numerous factors impair CO2 CHEMICAL elimination including altered lung volumes and mechan- ics, ventilation-perfusion abnormalities DISEASE secondary to atelectasis DISEASE or pulmonary conges- tion, reduced chemosensitivity and load responsiveness, and suppression of respiratory drive due to obesity-related humoral factors, such as resistance to the elevated leptin levels that occur in patients with the OHS (leptin is a respiratory stimulant).
The impor- tance of these factors likely varies from patient to patient.
Objective Findings Arterial blood gas testing during wakefulness shows hypercapnia DISEASE and often hypoxemia DISEASE in untreated patients.
Even with effective treatment most OHS patients continue to Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders exhibit some degree of daytime hypoventilation DISEASE .
The characteristic polysomnographic finding is sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE and arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation during sleep with or without obstructive apneas and hypopneas DISEASE .
Worsening hypoventilation DISEASE during sleep can be documented by an arterial blood gas measurement of PaCO2 during sleep (rarely performed) or transcutaneous or end-tidal PCO2 measurements.
Periods of decreased tidal volume lasting up to several minutes with sustained arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation are usually present.
Intermittent arousals DISEASE may be observed.
OSA DISEASE is present in the majority of OHS patients, during at least a portion of the night.
The transient ven- tilation between obstructive events (even if associated with arousal from the preceding obstructive event) is not sufficient to prevent worsening hypoventilation DISEASE during sleep.
Severe arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation is usually associated with the obstructive events.
Chronic hypoxia DISEASE can be associated with polycythemia DISEASE .
Electrocardiography, chest radi- ography, and echocardiography may demonstrate evidence of pulmonary hypertension DISEASE .
The serum bicarbonate CHEMICAL level is usually elevated due to renal compensation for chronic respiratory acidosis DISEASE ( hypercapnia DISEASE ).
In one study, a serum bicarbonate CHEMICAL level threshold > 27 mEq/L had a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 50% of identifying OHS in obese patients suspected of having OSA DISEASE .
This suggests that the serum bicarbonate CHEMICAL level may be useful to screen patients for possible OHS.
However, an arterial blood gas is required for diagnosis of OHS, as the serum bicarbonate CHEMICAL level may be elevated due to metabolic alkalosis DISEASE .
Differential Diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes any disorder that can give rise to hypoventilation DISEASE during wakefulness and sleep.
This includes pulmonary airway and parenchymal dis- orders, pulmonary vascular pathology, neuromuscular and chest wall disorders DISEASE , severe untreated hypothyroidism DISEASE , use of respiratory suppressants DISEASE , and congenital or idio- pathic central alveolar hypoventilation syndromes.
OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL syndromes can be distinguished from sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE by the periodic alterations in airflow and accompanying periodic fluctuations in SaO2.
In contrast, oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation due to sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is generally more sustained, usually several minutes or longer in duration.
When more than one disorder is believed to be responsible for the ventilatory insufficiency DISEASE during sleep, all pertinent diagnoses should be coded.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Future research into the pathogenesis of this disorder, including renal bicarbonate CHEMICAL homeostasis, is needed.
Because it is clinically impractical to routinely obtain arterial blood samples during sleep in most persons suspected of this disorder, other techniques of measuring CO2 CHEMICAL levels must be investigated.
The degree and duration of hypercapnia/ hypoxemia DISEASE necessary to produce adverse consequences, such as pulmonary hyperten- sion, in individual patients is not well defined.
Little information is available regarding the effect of oxygen CHEMICAL therapy or noninvasive ventilation on the course of the underlying disease.
Studies are needed to determine the optimal time to initiate these interventions and the specific subpopulations of patients who will benefit most from these therapies.

Clin Chest Med 2009;30:467–78, vii-viii.

J Clin Sleep Med 2006;2:57–62.

Congenital Central Alveolar Hypoventilation Syndrome ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 327.25 ICD-10-CM code: G47.35 Alternate Names Congenital central hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE .
The term Ondine DISEASE ’s curse is no longer recommended due to its negative connotations.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A and B must be met A. Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is present.
B. Mutation of the PHOX2B DISEASE gene is present.
Notes .
Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE may be associated with either daytime hypoventilation DISEASE (PaCO2 > 45 mm Hg) or normal daytime PaCO2 levels.
Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders In either case, the PaCO2 is higher during sleep and meets criteria for sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
2. PSG monitoring demonstrates severe hypercapnia DISEASE and arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
Some central apneas may occur but the predominant pattern is reduced flow/tidal volume.
3.
Although the condition is termed congenital, some patients with a PHOX2B DISEASE genotype may present phenotypically later in life (and even in adulthood), especially in the presence of a stressor such as general anesthesia or a severe respiratory illness DISEASE .
Essential Features Congenital central alveolar hypoventilation syndrome (CCHS) is a syndrome of auto- nomic dysfunction, primarily the failure of automatic central control of breathing, due to a mutation of the PHOX2B DISEASE gene.
CCHS is characterized by the onset of hypoven- tilation, usually at birth.
The hypoventilation DISEASE is worse during sleep than wakefulness and is unexplained by primary pulmonary, neurological, or metabolic disease DISEASE .
CCHS typically presents in an otherwise normal-appearing infant who is noted to have cyano- sis, feeding difficulties, hypotonia DISEASE or, less commonly, central apnea DISEASE .
Some children are diagnosed following cardiovascular collapse.
The infant requires intubation and then cannot be weaned from mechanically assisted ventilation, despite appearing vigorous and having a normal chest radiograph.
Some infants may appear to breathe adequately on clinical examination but experience episodes of hypoventilation DISEASE (not necessarily apnea DISEASE ) characterized by hypoxemia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE .
Patients with CCHS may occa- sionally present later in life with cyanosis DISEASE , an apparent life-threatening event, cor pul- monale, or hypoxic neurological damage DISEASE .
CCHS has been diagnosed in adults who present with respiratory failure DISEASE following anesthesia or in association with a minor respiratory illness DISEASE ; these patients usually have a mild mutation, and may have evidence of longstanding hypoxemia DISEASE including cognitive deficits DISEASE .
Most patients with CCHS have sufficiently severe hypoventilation DISEASE during sleep that they require mechanically assisted ventilation, although this state-dependent difference may not be apparent during early infancy.
Some patients (~15%) hypoventilate during wakefulness as well as during sleep and require continuous ventilatory support.
However, most patients with CCHS do not require ventilatory support during wakefulness but may have subtle abnormali- ties in gas exchange when physically inactive or during vigorous exercise.
Associated Features Associated autonomic abnormalities DISEASE include Hirschsprung disease DISEASE in approximately 16% of patients with CCHS, autonomic dysfunction DISEASE (e.g., decreased heart rate variabil- ity or hypotension DISEASE ), neural tumors DISEASE (e.g., ganglioneuromas DISEASE or ganglioneuroblastomas), swallowing dysfunction DISEASE during the early years, and ocular abnormalities DISEASE (e.g., stra- bismus CHEMICAL ).
Most patients are cognitively normal, although developmental delay may be present, especially in patients in whom the hypoventilation DISEASE has not been well controlled.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Research suggests that severity of illness DISEASE is related to the type of mutation present.
Most patients have a polyalanine expansion mutation; those with more polyalanine repeats are more likely to have severe disease including waking hypoventilation DISEASE .
Patients with a point mutation or frame shift mutations are at greater risk for neural tumors DISEASE .
Demographics The prevalence of CCHS is not known, but the disease is rare.
The condition occurs equally among both sexes and all ethnic/racial groups.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors This is a congenital genetic syndrome DISEASE .
Familial Patterns CCHS usually occurs as a de novo mutation, but siblings with the condition have been reported.
As the gene is dominant, patients are at risk of having children with CCHS.
Onset, Course, and Complications
The condition is genetic and is therefore present from birth, but some patients may present later in life.
The physiological abnormalities of CCHS persist for life and are not ameliorated over time.
However, the clinical consequences of hypoventilation DISEASE can be prevented by providing adequate ventilatory support.
If untreated, death DISEASE usually results from cor pulmonale DISEASE or complications of apnea DISEASE or severe hypoventilation DISEASE .
Patients with poorly controlled CCHS may develop mental retardation DISEASE , growth failure, seizures DISEASE , or cor pulmonale DISEASE .
When treated, infants with CCHS may improve over the first six to 12 months.
Some patients who initially require ventilatory support 24 hours a day may progress to adequate ventilation during wakefulness.
However, patients continue to require ventilatory support during sleep.
Conversely, some patients may develop the need for continuous ventilatory support.
It is unclear whether these patients had condi- tions that worsened, were not adequately evaluated and treated initially, or were asso- ciated with changing ventilatory demands.
Even with treatment, patients with CCHS require close monitoring, particularly during infancy.
Minor medical illnesses, such as upper respiratory tract illnesses DISEASE or diarrhea DISEASE , may precipitate bouts of respiratory failure DISEASE .
Edema DISEASE and lethargy DISEASE are often early signs of impending respiratory failure DISEASE .
The clinical signs of hypoxemia DISEASE and hypoventilation DISEASE in these patients may be subtle, as the Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders children do not show signs of distress or increased work of breathing, such as retrac- tions and nasal flaring.
As a result, gas exchange abnormalities may progress for some time without notice until the child appears to deteriorate suddenly with cardiopulmo- nary arrest DISEASE or severe decompensation.
Developmental Issues Not applicable.
Pathology and Pathophysiology The exact pathophysiology of CCHS is unknown.
Radiologic and postmortem studies have not shown gross central nervous system abnormalities.
The PHOX2B DISEASE gene plays a role in the development of the autonomic system.
Functional MRI and physiologic studies have shown widespread cerebral abnormalities DISEASE in response to stimuli such as exogenous hypercapnia DISEASE .
Objective Findings Hypoxemia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE are present on PSG during sleep.
Central apneas may be present, but hypoventilation DISEASE associated with decreased tidal volume and respiratory rate is more common.
In contrast to most types of sleep disordered breathing DISEASE in children, abnormalities may be more severe during NREM than during REM sleep.
Patients may not arouse from sleep despite severe gas exchange abnormalities.
Paradoxical breath- ing and snoring DISEASE do not typically occur.
Patients with CCHS have flat rebreathing hypoxic and hypercapnic responses, although they may respond to transient ventilatory challenges of the peripheral chemorecep- tors.
Arterial blood gases may be normal during wakefulness but will be abnormal if obtained from an arterial line during sleep.
In patients with chronically untreated or poorly controlled CCHS, a compensated respiratory acidosis DISEASE may be present.
In these patients, polycythemia DISEASE may be present and the serum bicarbonate CHEMICAL level may be elevated.
Computed tomography and MRI scans of the head are normal.
Electrocardiography, echocardiography, or cardiac catheterization may reveal evidence of pulmonary hyper- tension.
Pulmonary function tests may be normal or show evidence of mild obstructive or restrictive lung disease DISEASE resulting from associated conditions such as tracheitis DISEASE .
Differential Diagnosis CCHS must be distinguished from other forms of central hypoventilation DISEASE , such as central hypoventilation DISEASE due to Chiari malformation DISEASE , other causes of central nervous system disturbance such as trauma DISEASE or tumors DISEASE , metabolic conditions such as Leigh disease DISEASE , or obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE .
CCHS must also be distinguished from hypoventilation DISEASE secondary to muscle weakness DISEASE due to conditions such as diaphrag- matic paralysis DISEASE or muscular dystrophy DISEASE .
Infants presenting with apnea DISEASE or an apparent life-threatening event due to causes such as gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE may be thought to have CCHS.
However, these infants typically have intermittent episodes of apnea DISEASE rather than sustained hypoventilation DISEASE , and the episodes typically resolve once the primary cause has been treated.
CCHS patients presenting with cor pulmonale DISEASE may be misdiagnosed as having congenital heart disease DISEASE .
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions
There are many unresolved issues regarding CCHS, including prevalence data, precise genotype-phenotype correlations, effect of aging on patients with CCHS, long-term outcome of children with CCHS born to parents with CCHS, and the exact nature of the gene-encoded deficit.

117 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Late-Onset DISEASE Central Hypoventilation DISEASE with Hypothalamic Dysfunction ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 327.26 ICD-10-CM code: G47.36 Alternate Names Late-onset DISEASE central hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE ; rapid-onset obesity DISEASE with hypothalamic dysfunction DISEASE , hypoventilation DISEASE , and autonomic dysregulation ( ROHHAD DISEASE ).
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-E must be met A. Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is present.
B. Symptoms are absent during the first few years of life.
C. The patient has at least two of the following: . Obesity.
2. Endocrine abnormalities DISEASE of hypothalamic origin.
3.
Severe emotional or behavioral disturbances.
4. Tumor DISEASE of neural origin.
D. Mutation of the PHOX2B DISEASE gene is not present.
E.
The disorder is not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE , medical or neurological disorder DISEASE , medication use, or substance use disorder.
Notes .
Central apneas may occur but the predominant pattern is reduced flow/tidal volume associated with hypoventilation DISEASE and arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
Essential Features Late-onset DISEASE central hypoventilation DISEASE with hypothalamic dysfunction DISEASE is a disorder of central control of ventilation.
Patients are usually healthy until early childhood (often 2-3 years of age) when they develop hyperphagia DISEASE and severe obesity DISEASE , followed by central hypoventilation DISEASE , which often presents as respiratory failure DISEASE .
The respiratory failure DISEASE may be precipitated by a mild respiratory illness DISEASE or anesthesia.
Patients require ventilatory support during sleep; most patients breathe adequately during wakefulness but some need ventilatory support during both wakefulness and sleep.
The hypoventila- tion persists even if the patients lose weight, differentiating the condition from obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE .
Patients often develop hypothalamic endocrine dysfunc- tion characterized by increased or decreased hormone levels, which may include one or more of the following: diabetes insipidus DISEASE , inappropriate antidiuretic hormone hyperse- cretion DISEASE , precocious puberty, hypogonadism DISEASE , hyperprolactinemia DISEASE , hypothyroidism DISEASE , and decreased growth hormone secretion.
Mood and behavior abnormalities DISEASE , sometimes severe, have frequently been reported.
Developmental delay or autism DISEASE may be present, but many patients are cognitively normal.
Other symptoms of hypothalamic dysfunc- tion, such as temperature dysregulation, have been reported.
Associated Features Tumors DISEASE of neural origin such as ganglioneuroma DISEASE may occur.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes None known.
Demographics There are no prevalence data.
The disorder seems to occur equally among males and females.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Unknown.
Patients do not have the PHOX2B DISEASE genetic mutation of congenital central hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE .
Familial Patterns Familial cases have not been reported.
Onset, Course, and Complications Patients are typically normal at birth.
Obesity often begins in early childhood, perhaps because the child is old enough to walk around and obtain his/her own food.
Respiratory failure DISEASE typically presents several years after the onset of obesity DISEASE , and requires ventila- tory support via face mask or tracheostomy.
The respiratory failure DISEASE does not improve over time.
Death DISEASE has been reported from respiratory failure DISEASE , cor pulmonale DISEASE , or hyper- natremia CHEMICAL secondary to diabetes insipidus DISEASE ; case series have reported a high mortality.
Developmental Issues Not applicable.
Pathology and Pathophysiology The cause of the disorder is not known.
The brain typically appears normal on imaging or at autopsy, or may show secondary signs of hypoxemia DISEASE .
Objective Findings Hypoxemia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE are present on PSG during sleep.
Central apneas may be present, but hypoventilation DISEASE associated with decreased tidal volume and respiratory rate is more common.
Obstructive apneas may occur but are not the primary abnormality.
119 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Patients have flat hypoxic and hypercapnic responses.
Oxygen CHEMICAL and carbon dioxide CHEMICAL determinations may be normal during wakefulness but will demonstrate hypoxemia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE during sleep.
In patients with chronically untreated or poorly con- trolled hypoventilation DISEASE , a compensated respiratory acidosis DISEASE may be present, with ele- vated serum bicarbonate CHEMICAL levels.
In these patients, polycythemia DISEASE may be present.
Serum tests may show evidence of endocrine abnormalities DISEASE ; hypernatremia DISEASE is common.
Computed tomography and MRI scans of the head are normal.
Electrocardiography, echocardiography, or cardiac catheterization may reveal evidence of pulmonary hyper- tension.
Pulmonary function tests may be normal or show evidence of mild obstructive or restrictive lung disease DISEASE resulting from associated conditions such as tracheitis DISEASE .
Differential Diagnosis The disorder can be distinguished from late presentation of congenital central hypoven- tilation syndrome by testing for the PHOX2B DISEASE gene.
Genetic testing may also be useful in distinguishing the disorder from Prader-Willi syndrome DISEASE , which is characterized by a known genetic abnormality.
Most children with Prader-Willi syndrome DISEASE have hypotonia DISEASE at birth and more severe developmental delay.
The disorder can be distinguished from obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE by the presence of endocrine abnormalities DISEASE and other associated hypothalamic abnormalities DISEASE , and by the persistence of hypoventilation DISEASE despite weight loss DISEASE .
In addition, the patients typically have a totally flat hypercapnic ventilatory response rather than the blunted response seen in children with obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE .
The disorder should be distinguished from isolated hypopituitarism DISEASE or other hypothalamic disease DISEASE without hypoventilation DISEASE , and from obesity-related OSA DISEASE .
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions The etiology of the disorder is not known.
Although the disorder shares some fea- tures of congenital central hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE , including the presence of neural tumors DISEASE , it does not share the same gene.
Little information is available on prevalence or long-term prognosis.

Pediatrics 2007;120:e179–88.

120 Idiopathic Central Alveolar Hypoventilation ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 327.24 ICD-10-CM code: G47.34 Alternate Names Alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , central alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , idiopathic central alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , nonapneic DISEASE alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , primary alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A and B must be met A. Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is present.
B. Hypoventilation DISEASE is not primarily due to lung parenchymal or airway disease DISEASE , pulmonary vascular pathology, chest wall disorder DISEASE , medication use, neurologic disorder DISEASE , muscle weakness DISEASE , or obesity DISEASE or congenital hypoventilation syndromes DISEASE .
Notes .
The predominant respiratory pattern is one of reduced tidal volume or ataxic breathing with associated arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
Although OSA DISEASE may be present, it is not believed to be the major cause of hypoventilation DISEASE .
When criteria are met, a diagnosis of both OSA DISEASE and idiopathic central alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE may be made.
2. Arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation is often present but is not required for the diagnosis.
Essential Features Idiopathic central alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE is defined as the presence of decreased alve- olar ventilation resulting in sleep related hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE in individuals with presumed normal mechanical properties of the lung and respiratory pump.
Thus, chronic hypoventilation DISEASE during sleep exists without any readily identifiable impairments of res- piration, such as pulmonary airway or parenchymal conditions, neurologic, neuromus- cular or chest wall abnormalities DISEASE , severe obesity DISEASE , other sleep related breathing disorder DISEASE , or use of respiratory depressant medications or substances.
Diurnal as well as nocturnal hypoventilation DISEASE is believed to be due primarily to blunted chemoresponsiveness to CO2 CHEMICAL and O2.
However, reported cases are few and not studied in enough detail to conclu- sively establish a well-defined etiology.
Alternatively, these cases may represent a mixed group of patients with varied underlying conditions erroneously deemed idiopathic DISEASE as a result of incomplete diagnostic work-up.
Patient may complain of morning headaches DISEASE , fatigue DISEASE , neurocognitive decline and sleep disturbance DISEASE , or may be entirely asymptomatic.
Frequent episodes of shallow breathing may be noted to occur during sleep.
Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Associated Features Consequences of chronic hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE include pulmonary artery hyper- tension, cor pulmonale DISEASE , and neurocognitive dysfunction DISEASE .
Patients with other comorbid sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE are likely to experience greater severity and dura- tion of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE than are patients with isolated idiopathic central hypoventilation DISEASE .
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Not applicable or known.
Demographics Not known.
It is likely that some patients with this diagnosis may have an underlying anatomic or functional defect affecting respiratory mechanics and ventilatory drive which remains undiagnosed.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors The use of central nervous system depressants, such as alcohol CHEMICAL , anxiolytics, and hyp- notics, may further worsen hypercapnia/hypoxemia.
Patients who are hypercapnic and hypoxemic during wakefulness will generally become even more so during sleep, in particular REM sleep, but the relationship between wake SaO2/PaCO2 and sleep related desaturation DISEASE is not sufficiently strong to have substantial predictive value in individual patients.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications The onset of the condition is variable, often presenting in adolescence or early adulthood.
The disorder is generally slowly progressive.
Many affected individuals with severe hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE develop respiratory impairment DISEASE , pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , heart failure DISEASE , cardiac arrhythmias DISEASE , and neurocognitive dysfunction DISEASE .
Polycythemia DISEASE is common in those with chronic hypoxia DISEASE .
Although the risk of increased morbidity and mortality appears to increase with worsening sleep related hypoventilation/hypoxemia, the specific relationship between sleep related hypoventilation/hypoxemia CHEMICAL and mor- bidity and mortality is not well defined.
Developmental Issues Not known.
122 Pathology and Pathophysiology The etiology of hypoventilation DISEASE in these patients is not understood.
Chronic hyper- capnia and hypoxemia DISEASE in idiopathic central alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE is believed to be due to defective CO2 CHEMICAL and O2 homeostasis CHEMICAL , with impaired CO2 CHEMICAL unloading, reduced chemoresponsiveness to CO2 CHEMICAL and O2, CHEMICAL and suppression of respiratory drive.
Imaging of the central nervous system does not document a structural defect.
Hypoventilation DISEASE worsens during sleep compared to waking levels due to a further reduction in che- mosensitivity and decreased activity of the ventilatory muscles.
Additionally, daytime hypoxemia DISEASE , if sufficiently severe, may place the patient near or on the steep portion of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve where even relatively small decrements in arterial oxygen CHEMICAL tension result in large decrements in oxyhemoglobin saturation.
Thus, sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE in these patients may have a relatively great impact on oxyhemoglobin saturation.
Objective Findings The characteristic polysomnographic finding is demonstration of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE (determination of PaCO2 by arterial blood gas or by a surrogate measure [end-tidal CO2 CHEMICAL or transcutaneous CO2 CHEMICAL ]).
Periods of decreased tidal volume lasting up to several minutes, with sustained arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation, are usually present.
Intermittent arousals DISEASE may be observed.
Daytime arterial blood gases may be normal or show hypoxia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE .
Chronic hypoxia DISEASE can be associated with polycythemia DISEASE .
Electrocardiography, chest radiography, and echocardiography may demonstrate evidence of pulmonary hypertension DISEASE .
Central nervous system imaging is generally unremarkable.
Differential Diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes any disorder that can cause hypoventilation DISEASE during sleep.
This includes obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE , pulmonary airway and paren- chymal disorders, pulmonary vascular pathology, neuromuscular and chest wall dis- orders, severe untreated hypothyroidism DISEASE , and use of respiratory suppressants DISEASE .
CCHS is associated with an abnormal PHOX2B DISEASE gene.
Unlike patients with late-onset DISEASE central hypoventilation DISEASE with hypothalamic dysfunction DISEASE , patients with idiopathic central hypoventilation DISEASE do not have evidence of hypothalamic dysfunction DISEASE .
It is essential to excluded medical and neurological disorders DISEASE that are associated with hypoventilation DISEASE before a diagnosis of idiopathic central hypoventilation DISEASE can be made.
OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL syndromes can be distinguished from sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE by the periodic alterations in airflow and accompanying periodic fluctuations in SaO2.
In contrast, oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation due to sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is generally more sustained, usually several minutes or longer in duration.
When more than one disorder is believed Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders to be responsible for the ventilatory insufficiency DISEASE during sleep, all pertinent diagnoses should be coded.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions A better understanding of the etiology of idiopathic central alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE is essential to guide preventive and treatment measures.
Because it is clinically imprac- tical to routinely obtain arterial blood samples during sleep in most persons suspected of this disorder, other techniques of measuring CO2 CHEMICAL levels must be investigated.
The degree and duration of hypercapnia/hypoxemia necessary to produce adverse conse- quences, such as pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , in individual patients is not well defined.
Little information is available regarding the effect of oxygen CHEMICAL therapy or noninvasive ventilation on the course of the underlying disease.
Studies are needed to determine the optimal time to initiate these interventions and the specific subpopulations of patients who will benefit most from these therapies.

Chest 2007;131:1936–48.
Chebbo A, Tfaili A, Jones SF.
Hypoventilation DISEASE syndromes.
Med Clin North Am 2011;95:1189–202.
Sleep Related Hypoventilation DISEASE Due to a Medication or Substance ICD-9-CM code: 327.26 ICD-10-CM code: G47.36 Alternate Names Alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , nocturnal hypoventilation DISEASE , nonapneic DISEASE alveolar hypoventila- tion, secondary alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A. Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is present.
B. A medication or substance known to inhibit respiration and/or ventilatory drive is believed to be the primary cause of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
C. Hypoventilation DISEASE is not primarily due to lung parenchymal or airway disease DISEASE , pulmonary vascular pathology, chest wall disorder DISEASE , neurologic disorder DISEASE , muscle weakness DISEASE , obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE , or a known congenital central alveolar hypoventilation syndrome. Notes .
2. 3.
Although OSA DISEASE or CSA CHEMICAL may be present, they are not believed to be the major cause of hypoventilation DISEASE .
The predominant respiratory pattern is one of reduced tidal volume or ataxic breathing and associated arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
When criteria are met, a diagnosis of both OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL due to medication or substance as well as sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE due to a medication or substance may be made.
Arterial desaturation DISEASE is often present but is not required for the diagnosis.
Hypoventilation DISEASE may be present during wakefulness but is not required for the diagnosis.
Essential Features This disorder is characterized primarily by chronic hypoventilation DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE due to prolonged use of medications or substances known to depress ventilatory drive and/or impair respiratory muscle mechanics.
These agents include long-acting nar- cotics, anesthetics, sedative compounds, and muscle relaxants.
The risk of respiratory insufficiency DISEASE is increased with the concomitant use of alcohol CHEMICAL or with polypharmacy.
Respiratory depressants DISEASE can precipitate respiratory failure DISEASE in patients with limited pul- monary reserves or exacerbate hypoventilation DISEASE in those with baseline hypercapnia DISEASE .
Hypoxemia DISEASE is commonly present and can show either a sustained reduction or episodic fluctuations.
Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is present.
Hypercapnia DISEASE may also be present during wakefulness in some patients.
Patients can either be asymptomatic or present with complaints of dyspnea DISEASE , chest tightness DISEASE , or fatigue DISEASE .
Neurocognitive dysfunction DISEASE may arise following use of narcotics.
Associated Features Medications and substances that reduce respiratory drive may also alter the mechanics of the upper airway.
By decreasing upper airway muscle tone, these agents may pre- cipitate or exacerbate OSA DISEASE and CSA.
It is not currently known whether chronic use of respiratory depressants DISEASE will eventually give rise to pulmonary artery hypertension DISEASE or cor pulmonale DISEASE , but this seems unlikely.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Not applicable or known.
Demographics The demographics of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE due to use of respiratory suppressants DISEASE are not known.
It is clear that baseline hypoventilation DISEASE prior to initiation of respiratory Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders depressant medication will worsen following DISEASE initiation of the medication.
Thus, preva- lence may be higher in patients with greater perturbations of pulmonary function or neuro- muscular weakness DISEASE .
Individuals with chronic hypercapnia DISEASE during wakefulness will expe- rience even greater decrements of alveolar ventilation during sleep.
Studies of patients on methadone CHEMICAL maintenance have generally found no or mild daytime hypoventilation DISEASE .
There is scant literature about daytime or nocturnal PaCO2 in patients on potent opioids for pain DISEASE .
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors The use of medications or substances that impair respiration mechanics or drive is the primary pathophysiologic factor responsible for hypoventilation DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE .
There are significant inter-individual differences in sensitivity and tolerance to respira- tory depressants.
Obesity or the presence of medical and neurologic diseases that may produce hypoventilation DISEASE may further worsen hypercapnia/hypoxemia.
Patients who are hypercapnic and hypoxemic during wakefulness will generally become even more so during sleep, in particular REM sleep, but the relationship between wake SaO2/ PaCO2 and sleep related desaturation DISEASE is not sufficiently strong to have substantial pre- dictive value in individual patients.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset and course of the hypoventilation DISEASE parallel the use and dosing of medications or substances that can impair respiration, as well as the development of tolerance to these substances.
There may be variability in susceptibility to hypoventilation DISEASE in dif- ferent individuals.
Comorbid pulmonary or neurologic disorders DISEASE may accentuate the severity of hypoventilation DISEASE .
Patients may present for evaluation of suspected OSA DISEASE or may be identified following one or more episodes of respiratory failure DISEASE .
It is not known if chronic use of respiratory depressants DISEASE can lead to the development of pulmo- DISEASE nary hypertension DISEASE , polycythemia DISEASE , and cardiac arrhythmias DISEASE .
Neurocognitive dysfunc- tion may develop either as a direct result of medication usage or as a consequence of chronic hypoxia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE .
Pathology and Pathophysiology Hypoventilation DISEASE is a direct result of impaired respiratory drive and CO2 CHEMICAL and O2 chemo- CHEMICAL sensitivity.
Hypoventilation DISEASE worsens during sleep, especially in REM sleep, compared to waking levels, due to a further reduction in chemosensitivity and decreased activity of the ventilatory muscles.
In addition, use of respiratory suppressants DISEASE may give rise to OSA DISEASE and CSA that may contribute to hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE .
126 Objective Findings The characteristic PSG finding is demonstration of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE by monitoring of PaCO2 or acceptable surrogate during sleep.
Sustained oxygen CHEMICAL desat- uration during sleep that is unexplained by discrete apnea DISEASE and hypopnea DISEASE events is common.
However, this finding alone is not sufficient to make a diagnosis of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
Medication use can also produce obstructive DISEASE or central apneas.
Intermittent arousals DISEASE associated with hypoxemia DISEASE may be observed.
An ataxic breathing pattern may be present.
Differential Diagnosis The differential diagnosis encompasses essentially all disorders that can lead to hypoventilation DISEASE during sleep.
This includes OHS, pulmonary airway and parenchy- mal disorders, pulmonary vascular pathology, neuromuscular and chest wall disor- ders, severe untreated hypothyroidism DISEASE , and congenital or idiopathic central alveo- lar hypoventilation DISEASE syndromes.
OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL syndromes can be distinguished from sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE by the periodic alterations in airflow and accompanying periodic fluctuations in SaO2.
In contrast, oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation due to sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is generally more sustained, usually several minutes or longer in dura- tion.
When more than one disorder is believed to be responsible for the ventilatory insufficiency DISEASE during sleep, all pertinent diagnoses should be coded.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Studies of the factors influencing individual susceptibility and tolerance to hypoven- tilation/hypercapnia DISEASE due to medications or substances are needed.
The long-term con- sequences of chronic use of respiratory depressants DISEASE are poorly understood.
The value of routinely measuring PaCO2 during sleep in patients taking respiratory depressants is not clear.
Additionally, because it is clinically impractical to routinely obtain arterial blood samples during sleep in most persons suspected of this disorder, other techniques of measuring CO2 CHEMICAL levels must be investigated.
Little information is available regarding the effect of oxygen CHEMICAL therapy or noninvasive ventilation on the course of the underlying disease.
Studies are needed to determine the optimal time to initiate these interventions and the specific subpopulations of patients who will benefit most from these therapies.

127 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Tassinari D, Sartori S, Tamburini E, et al.
Adverse effects of transdermal opiates treating moderate-severe cancer pain DISEASE in comparison to long-acting morphine CHEMICAL : a meta-analysis and systematic review of the literature.
J Palliat Med 2008;11:492–501.
Sleep Related Hypoventilation DISEASE Due to a Medical Disorder ICD-9-CM code: 327.26 ICD-10-CM code: G47.36 Alternate Names Alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , nonapneic DISEASE alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , secondary alveolar hypoventilation DISEASE , sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A. Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is present.
B. A lung parenchymal or airway disease DISEASE , pulmonary vascular pathology, chest wall disorder DISEASE , neurologic disorder DISEASE , or muscle weakness DISEASE is believed to be the primary cause of hypoventilation DISEASE .
C. Hypoventilation DISEASE is not primarily due to obesity hypoventilation syndrome DISEASE , medication use, or a known congenital central alveolar hypoventilation syndrome.
Notes .
Arterial desaturation DISEASE is often present but is not required for the diagnosis.
2.
Although OSA DISEASE or CSA CHEMICAL may be present, they are not believed to be the major cause of hypoventilation DISEASE .
The predominant respiratory pattern is one of reduced tidal volume or ataxic breathing and associated arterial oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
When criteria are met, a diagnosis of both OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL due to medical or neurological condition as well as sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE due to a medical disorder may be made.
3. Hypoventilation DISEASE may be present during wakefulness but is not required for the diagnosis.
Essential Features Lung airway or parenchymal disease, chest wall disorders DISEASE , pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , neurologic and neuromuscular disorders DISEASE , if sufficiently severe, can result in ventilatory impairment DISEASE and chronic hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE .
Acute exacerbations of respiratory disorders DISEASE can accentuate the severity of hypoventilation DISEASE .
Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is present and is usually most severe during REM sleep.
In some patients, hypercap- nia may also be present during wakefulness.
Patients can either be asymptomatic or present with complaints of dyspnea DISEASE , chest tightness DISEASE , or fatigue DISEASE .
Polycythemia DISEASE is often noted with severe chronic hypoxemia DISEASE .
Specific respiratory disorders DISEASE are associated with abnormal findings on pulmonary function testing, radiographic imaging, echo- cardiography, and pulmonary artery catheter measurements.
Suspected neurologic or neuromuscular DISEASE causes of hypoventilation DISEASE may be investigated using central nervous system imaging or measures of peripheral nerve or muscular function.
Associated Features Consequences of chronic hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE arising as a result of medical and neurologic disorders include pulmonary artery hypertension DISEASE , cor pulmonale DISEASE , and neu- rocognitive dysfunction.
Some of these disorders are prevalent diseases and commonly overlap.
Patients with multiple disorders DISEASE are likely to experience greater severity and duration of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE than are patients with either disorder DISEASE alone.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes The clinical presentation varies with the underlying disorder responsible for the sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease DISEASE is characterized by generally fixed and not fully reversible lower airways obstruction DISEASE , and includes chronic bronchitis DISEASE , emphysema DISEASE , cystic fibrosis DISEASE , and bronchiectasis DISEASE .
Chronic bron- chitis DISEASE is a clinical entity defined by the presence of chronic productive cough DISEASE for at least three months of the year, for at least two consecutive years, in the absence of other identifiable etiologies.
Emphysema is characterized by destruction of lung tissue and the dilation of peripheral airspaces without evident fibrosis DISEASE .
Emphysema and chronic bronchitis DISEASE often coexist.
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency DISEASE is a genetic cause of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease DISEASE .
Both bronchiectasis DISEASE and cystic fibrosis DISEASE are characterized by lower airway inflammation DISEASE and destruction of airways and lung parenchyma.
Patients with chronic lower airways obstruction DISEASE are increasingly predis- posed to developing hypoventilation DISEASE as the severity of the underlying lower airways obstruction DISEASE increases.
Parenchymal lung disease associated with restrictive ventilatory dysfunction DISEASE (e.g., interstitial lung disease DISEASE ) can also be associated with sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
Neurologic, neuromuscular, and chest wall disorders DISEASE can produce hypoventilation DISEASE due to an abnormal ventilatory pump (secondary to reduced muscle strength or anatomic distortion of the chest wall structures) that is unable to meet the ventilatory require- ments for maintaining PaCO2 at or below 45 mm Hg.
In addition, some of these patients have reduced central neural chemoresponsiveness.
Last, hypoxemia DISEASE may be worsened Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders by the development of atelectasis DISEASE or aspiration due to defective swallowing associated with some neurologic and neuromuscular conditions.
Demographics The demographics of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE due to a medical disorder are a function of the prevalence, clinical characteristics, and degree of severity of the under- lying conditions.
Thus, prevalence may be higher in patients with greater perturbations of pulmonary function or neuromuscular weakness DISEASE .
Individuals with chronic hyper- capnia during wakefulness will experience even greater decrements of alveolar venti- lation during sleep.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors
Greater impairments of respiratory function are associated with greater risk for sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE .
However, there is no recognized threshold of pulmonary parenchymal or vascular disease severity that adequately predicts the risk of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE in individual patients.
Reduced chemosensitivity DISEASE may be present in some neuromuscular disorders DISEASE .
The use of central nervous system depressants, such as alcohol CHEMICAL , anxiolytics, and hypnotics, may further worsen respira- tory impairment.
Patients who are hypercapnic and hypoxemic during wakefulness will generally become even more so during sleep, in particular REM sleep, but the rela- tionship between wake SaO2/PaCO2 and sleep related desaturation DISEASE is not sufficiently strong to have substantial predictive value in individual patients.
Familial Patterns Genetic patterns for many of the disorders are not known.
Alpha-1 antitrypsin CHEMICAL defi- ciency is a genetic disorder characterized by defective production of the enzyme inhib- itor; severe forms of deficiency can lead to emphysema.
Genetic causes of bronchi- ectasis include primary ciliary dyskinesia DISEASE and cystic fibrosis DISEASE .
Muscular dystrophies DISEASE are genetically inherited.
The familial patterns of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE due to these disorders reflect those of the underlying inherited conditions.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset and course of the hypoventilation DISEASE parallels the presence and severity of the underlying medical or neurological disorders DISEASE that impair respiration although substan- tial variability in course is observed even within the same underlying condition.
Many affected individuals with severe hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE develop respiratory impairment DISEASE , pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , heart failure DISEASE , cardiac arrhythmias DISEASE , and neurocog- nitive dysfunction.
Polycythemia DISEASE is common in those with chronic hypoxia DISEASE .
Although the risk of increased morbidity and mortality appears to increase with worsening sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE , the specific relationship between sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE and morbidity and mortality is not well defined.
Many patients respond to assisted ven- tilation, whereas hypercapnia DISEASE may worsen with oxygen CHEMICAL therapy alone.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Pulmonary parenchymal diseases are characterized by altered lung volumes (e.g., reduced functional residual capacity) and abnormal ventilation/perfusion relationships, which can result in hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE during wakefulness.
Decreased lung volume is associated with reduced oxygen CHEMICAL reserves that increase the risk of hypoxemia DISEASE .
In addition, sleep may be associated with an altered pattern of ventilatory-muscle acti- vation, particularly during REM sleep when, due to reduced activation of the intercos- tal and accessory muscles, there is a disproportionate ventilatory burden placed on the diaphragm.
This may lead to hypoventilation DISEASE in patients with chest wall abnormalities DISEASE or in those with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease DISEASE .
In the latter, lung hyperinfla- tion creates a mechanical disadvantage to the diaphragm.
Many neurologic and neu- romuscular disorders are associated with impaired respiratory mechanics and reduced CO2 CHEMICAL chemosensitivity.
Finally, daytime hypoxemia DISEASE , if sufficiently severe, may place the patient near or on the steep portion of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve, where even relatively small decrements in arterial oxygen CHEMICAL tension result in large decrements in oxyhemoglobin saturation.
Thus, sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE in these patients may have a relatively great impact on oxyhemoglobin saturation.
Objective Findings The characteristic polysomnographic finding is demonstration of sleep related hypoven- tilation (by arterial PaCO2, transcutaneous PCO2, or end-tidal PCO2).
Sustained oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation during sleep that is unexplained by discrete apnea DISEASE and hypopnea DISEASE events is common but is not sufficient to establish a diagnosis of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
Intermittent arousals DISEASE associated with hypoxemia DISEASE may be observed.
Many medical and neurologic disorders are associated with significant sleep disturbances DISEASE and changes in sleep architecture, including prolonged sleep onset latency, reduced sleep efficiency, and decreased sleep stages N3 and REM, may be present.
Obstructive DISEASE and central apneas, when present, will further disturb sleep and accentuate sleep related oxyhe- moglobin desaturation.
Daytime arterial blood gases may be normal or show hypoxia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE .
Chronic hypoxia DISEASE (especially when present during the day as well as at night) can be associated with polycythemia DISEASE .
Electrocardiography, chest radiography, and echocardiography may demonstrate evidence of pulmonary hypertension DISEASE .
In patients with neuromuscular weakness DISEASE or restrictive chest wall disorders DISEASE spirometry shows a restrictive ventilatory dysfunction DISEASE with the forced vital capacity (FVC) often Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders less than 50% of predicted.
However, significant nocturnal desaturation DISEASE can occur with FVC values greater than 50% of predicted.
Differential Diagnosis The differential diagnosis includes all disorders which can give rise to hypoventila- tion during sleep.
This includes OHS, use of medications or substances that can sup- press respiratory drive, and congenital or idiopathic central alveolar hypoventilation syndromes.
OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL can be distinguished from sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE by the periodic alterations in airflow and accompanying periodic fluctuations in SaO2.
In contrast, oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation due to sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is generally more sustained, usually several minutes or longer in duration.
When more than one disorder is believed to be responsible for the ventilatory insufficiency DISEASE during sleep, all pertinent diagnoses should be coded.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Thresholds of impairments of ventilation and respiratory drive producing hypercapnia/ hypoxemia DISEASE need to be identified.
The degree and duration of hypercapnia/hypoxemia necessary to produce adverse consequences, such as pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , in indi- vidual patients is not well defined.
The value of routinely measuring PaCO2 during sleep in these patients is not clear.
Additionally, because it is clinically impractical to routinely obtain arterial blood samples during sleep in most persons suspected of this disorder, other techniques of measuring CO2 CHEMICAL levels must be investigated.
Little infor- mation is available regarding the effect of oxygen CHEMICAL therapy or noninvasive ventilation on the course of the underlying disease.
Studies are needed to determine the optimal time to initiate these interventions and the specific subpopulations of patients who will benefit most from these therapies.
