133 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Hypoxemia DISEASE Disorder Sleep Related Hypoxemia DISEASE ICD-9-CM code: 327.26 ICD-10-CM code: G47.36 Alternate Names Nocturnal oxygen CHEMICAL (or oxyhemoglobin) desaturation DISEASE , low nocturnal oxygen CHEMICAL saturation, nocturnal hypoxemia DISEASE , sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE , sleep related oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A and B must be met A. PSG, OCST or nocturnal oximetry shows the arterial oxygen CHEMICAL saturation (SpO2) during sleep of ≤ CHEMICAL 88% in adults or ≤ CHEMICAL 90% in children for ≥ 5 minutes.
B. Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is not documented.1 Notes .
If sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is documented (as measured by arterial blood gas, transcutaneous PCO2, or end-tidal CO2 CHEMICAL sensors), the disorder is classified as sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE .
2. OSA DISEASE or CSA CHEMICAL may be present, but these are not believed to be the major cause of hypoxemia DISEASE .
3. Physiological causes, if known, should be indicated (e.g., shunt, ventilation-perfusion [V/Q] mismatch, low mixed venous oxygen CHEMICAL , and/ or high altitude).
Essential Features Significant hypoxemia DISEASE during sleep is present and is believed to be secondary to a medical or neurological disorder DISEASE .
The presence of hypoxemia DISEASE is not better explained by another sleep related breathing disorder DISEASE (e.g., OSA DISEASE ).
Although some amount of obstructive DISEASE or central apnea DISEASE may be present, these disorders are not thought to be pri- marily responsible for the hypoxemia DISEASE during sleep.
Some patients with sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE also exhibit hypoxemia DISEASE during wakefulness.
Sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE has not been documented (if so, a diagnosis of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE is made).
The presentation of patients with sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE varies with the underly- ing medical or neurological disorders DISEASE .
Chronic hypoxemia DISEASE can arise from airway or parenchymal pulmonary disease DISEASE , chest wall disorders DISEASE , pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , or neurologic and neuromuscular disorders DISEASE .
Acute exacerbations of respiratory disorders DISEASE can accentuate the severity of hypoxemia DISEASE .
Hypoxemia DISEASE due to underlying lower airway obstructive disease DISEASE , pulmonary parenchymal disease DISEASE , vascular pathology, and other causes of hypoventilation DISEASE is generally sustained (several minutes or longer), whereas sawtooth fluctuations of oxygen CHEMICAL saturation (typically less than one minute) characterize hypoxemia DISEASE due to OSA DISEASE or CSA.
Patients can either be asymptomatic or present with complaints of nocturnal dyspnea DISEASE , impaired sleep quality, chest tightness DISEASE , or fatigue DISEASE .
Polycythemia DISEASE is often noted with severe chronic hypoxemia DISEASE .
Associated Features Consequences of chronic hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE include pulmonary artery hyper- tension, cor pulmonale DISEASE , and neurocognitive dysfunction DISEASE .
Some of the disorders causing hypoxemia DISEASE are prevalent diseases and not uncommonly overlap.
Patients with multi- ple breathing disorders DISEASE are likely to experience greater severity and duration of sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE than are patients with a single disorder.
Clinical and Pathologic Subtypes Specific variations in the sleep related findings have not been described for the various etiologies.
Demographics The demographics of sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE are a function of the prevalence, clinical characteristics and degree of severity of the underlying conditions.
Thus, prevalence may be higher in patients with greater perturbations of pulmonary function or neu- romuscular weakness.
Individuals with chronic hypoxemia DISEASE during wakefulness will experience even greater decrements of oxygenation during sleep.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors
Greater impairments of respiratory function are associated with greater risk for sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE .
However, there is no recognized threshold of pulmonary paren- chymal or vascular disease severity or extent of neuromuscular weakness DISEASE that ade-
quately predicts the risk of sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE in individual patients.
Patients who are hypoxemic during wakefulness will generally become even more so during sleep, especially REM sleep.
Among the best predictors of sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE are reduced baseline wake SaO2 and hypercapnia DISEASE .
Patients with wake hypercapnia DISEASE should be suspected of sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE .
However, the relationship between wake SaO2/PaCO2 and sleep related desaturation DISEASE is not sufficiently strong to have substantial predictive value in individual patients.
135 Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Familial Patterns Genetic patterns for many of the disorders are not known.
Alpha-1 antitrypsin CHEMICAL defi- ciency is a genetic disorder characterized by defective production of the enzyme inhib- itor; severe forms of deficiency can lead to emphysema.
Genetic causes of bronchiec- tasis include primary ciliary dyskinesia DISEASE and cystic fibrosis DISEASE .
Muscular dystrophies DISEASE are genetically inherited.
The familial patterns of sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE due to these disorders reflect those of the underlying inherited conditions.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset and course of sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE parallel the presence and severity of the underlying medical or neurological disorders DISEASE that impair respiration, although sub- stantial variability in course is observed even within the same underlying condition.
Many affected individuals with severe hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE develop respiratory impairment DISEASE , pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , heart failure DISEASE , cardiac arrhythmias DISEASE , and neuro- cognitive dysfunction DISEASE .
Polycythemia DISEASE is common in those with chronic hypoxia DISEASE .
Higher rates of painful crises accompany hypoxemia DISEASE in children with sickle cell disease DISEASE .
Although the risk of increased morbidity and mortality appears to increase with wors- ening sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE , the specific relationship between sleep related hypox- emia CHEMICAL and morbidity and mortality is not well defined.
Many patients respond to oxygen CHEMICAL therapy; in some, hypercapnia DISEASE may worsen with oxygen CHEMICAL therapy alone for hypoxia DISEASE .
Pathology and Pathophysiology Hypoxemia DISEASE may arise from a shunt physiology, ventilation-perfusion [ V/Q CHEMICAL ] mismatch- CHEMICAL ing, low mixed venous oxygen CHEMICAL , and/or high altitude.
Hypoventilation DISEASE also gives rise to hypoxemia DISEASE ; however, when hypoventilation DISEASE has been documented, a diagnosis of sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE should be assigned, rather than sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE .
Pulmonary parenchymal diseases are characterized by altered lung volumes (e.g., reduced functional residual capacity) and abnormal ventilation/perfusion relationships, which can result in hypercapnia DISEASE and hypoxemia DISEASE during wakefulness.
Decreased lung volume is associated with reduced oxygen CHEMICAL reserves that increase the risk of hypoxemia DISEASE .
In addition, sleep may be associated with an altered pattern of ventilatory muscle acti- vation, particularly during REM sleep when, due to reduced activation of the intercos- tal and accessory muscles, there is a disproportionate ventilatory burden placed on the diaphragm.
This may lead to hypoventilation DISEASE in patients with chest wall abnormalities DISEASE or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease DISEASE .
In the latter, lung hyperinflation creates a mechanical disadvantage to the diaphragm.
In sickle cell anemia DISEASE , decreased oxyhemo- globin affinity may partly contribute to hypoxemia DISEASE .
Many neurologic and neuromuscu- lar disorders DISEASE are associated with impaired respiratory mechanics and reduced CO2 CHEMICAL che- mosensitivity.
Finally, daytime hypoxemia DISEASE , if sufficiently severe, may place the patient near or on the steep portion of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve where even rela- tively small decrements in arterial oxygen CHEMICAL tension result in large decrements in oxyhe- moglobin saturation.
Thus, sleep related hypoventilation DISEASE in these patients might have a relatively great impact on oxyhemoglobin saturation.
Objective Findings Various patterns of oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation (sustained, intermittent, or episodic) may be observed during sleep.
The diagnosis is generally made on the basis of overnight oxim- etry (alone or as a component of PSG or OCST); less commonly, arterial blood gas mea- surements are indicated, especially if concomitant hypoventilation DISEASE is suspected.
PSG may demonstrate normal sleep architecture or frequent arousals DISEASE , increased wakeful- ness after sleep onset and reduced sleep efficiency; however, the contribution of sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE to the altered sleep architecture, if present, is uncertain.
Daytime arterial blood gases may be normal or show hypoxia DISEASE and hypercapnia DISEASE .
Nocturnal oxim- etry usually shows sustained periods of reduced arterial oxygen CHEMICAL but clusters of more severe drops in the arterial oxygen CHEMICAL saturation can occur every one to two hours due to worsening of breathing during REM sleep.
A sawtooth pattern of briefer desaturations DISEASE (typically less than one minute) suggests the presence of discrete events (apneas or hypopneas DISEASE ).
Some sawtooth changes may be superimposed on low baseline oxygen CHEMICAL saturation but are not the predominant pattern.
Chronic hypoxia DISEASE can be associated with polycythemia DISEASE .
Electrocardiography, chest radiography, and echocardiography may demonstrate evidence of pulmonary hypertension DISEASE .
Differential Diagnosis The differential diagnosis encompasses all disorders which can give to hypoxemia DISEASE during sleep.
This includes pulmonary airway and parenchymal disorders, pulmonary vascular pathology, neuromuscular and chest wall disorders DISEASE , OHS, use of medications or substances that can suppress respiratory drive, and congenital or idiopathic central alveolar hypoventilation syndromes.
OSA DISEASE and CSA CHEMICAL syndromes can be distinguished from sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE by the periodic alterations in airflow and accompanying periodic fluctuations in SaO2.
In contrast, oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation associated with sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE is generally more sustained, usually several minutes or longer in duration.
In cases when more than one disorder is believed to be responsible for the ventilatory insufficiency DISEASE during sleep, all pertinent diagnoses should be coded.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions The degree and duration of hypercapnia/hypoxemia necessary to produce adverse consequences, such as pulmonary hypertension DISEASE , in individual patients is not well defined.
The value of routinely measuring arterial blood gases or SaO2 during sleep Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders is not clear.
With the exception of COPD DISEASE , little information is available regarding the effect of oxygen CHEMICAL therapy on the course of the underlying disease.
Even less is under- stood regarding the consequences of isolated sleep related hypoxemia DISEASE and the need for oxygen CHEMICAL supplementation in patients with normal daytime wake oxygen CHEMICAL levels.
Studies are needed to determine the optimal time to initiate oxygen CHEMICAL therapy and the specific subpopulations of patients who will benefit most from this intervention.
Bibliography Berry RB, Sriram P. Evaluation of hypoventilation DISEASE .
Semin Respir Crit Care Med 2009;30:303–14.
Brown LK.
Hypoventilation DISEASE syndromes.
Clin Chest Med 2010;31:249–70.
Casey KR, Cantillo KO, Brown LK.
Sleep-related hypoventilation/hypoxemic syndromes.
Chest 2007;131:1936–48.
Chebbo A, Tfaili A, Jones SF.
Hypoventilation DISEASE syndromes.
Med Clin North Am 2011;95:1189–202.
Mogri M, Desai H, Webster L, Grant BJ, Mador MJ.
Hypoxemia DISEASE in patients on chronic opiate therapy with and without sleep apnea DISEASE .
Sleep Breath 2009;13:49–57.
138 Isolated Symptoms and Normal Variants Snoring DISEASE ICD-9-CM code: 786.09 DISEASE ICD-10-CM code: R06.83 Snoring DISEASE is a respiratory sound generated in the upper airway during sleep that typically occurs during inspiration but may also occur in expiration; the snoring DISEASE described here occurs without episodes of apnea DISEASE , hypopnea DISEASE , RERAs or hypoventilation DISEASE .
The intensity of snoring DISEASE may vary and often will disturb the bed partner’s sleep and even awaken the patient.
Snoring DISEASE in this context does not cause symptoms of daytime sleepiness DISEASE or insomnia DISEASE in the patient.
This type of snoring DISEASE has variously been referred to as habitual, primary or simple snoring.
Snoring DISEASE is a cardinal symptom of obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE .
A designation of habitual snoring DISEASE cannot be made in those who exhibit symptoms ( daytime sleepiness/fatigue DISEASE or other related symptoms) or report possible breathing pauses, without objective mea- surement of breathing during sleep.
In addition, those individuals with snoring DISEASE and comorbid cardiovascular disease DISEASE (especially pulmonary or systemic hypertension DISEASE , cor- onary artery disease, or atrial fibrillation DISEASE ) are at increased risk for the presence of OSA DISEASE even in the absence of complaints of daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
Therefore, PSG or OCST is required in order to effectively rule out OSA DISEASE in such populations.
It should also be noted that patients who initially have isolated snoring DISEASE may be at risk for developing OSA DISEASE with aging or weight gain.
Occasional snoring DISEASE is almost universal.
Estimates on snoring DISEASE vary widely depending on its definition.
The incidence of snoring DISEASE in children is reported to be 10% to 12%.
The Wisconsin cohort study reports habitual snoring DISEASE in about 24% of adult women and 40% of adult men.
Prevalence of snoring DISEASE increases with age in both sexes, except that the prevalence of reported snoring DISEASE starts to decrease again in men after 70 years of age.
Some have hypothesized that his may be due to decreased hearing acuity DISEASE in older individuals.
Snoring DISEASE is most common in adult men and is also linked to obesity.
Nasal obstruc- tion increases the risk of snoring DISEASE .
Ingestion of alcohol CHEMICAL , muscle relaxants, narcotics, or other substances that decrease upper airway muscle tone predisposes an individual to snoring.
Smoking, particularly in males, has also been shown to be a risk factor.
Snoring DISEASE has also been shown to increase during pregnancy.
In children, an association has been reported between snoring DISEASE and adenotonsillar hypertrophy.
During snoring DISEASE Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Sleep Related Breathing Disorders there is vibration of the uvula and soft palate DISEASE , although it may also involve the faucial pillars, pharyngeal walls, and lower structures.
Snorers have been shown to have mor- phologic derangements of the palate DISEASE consistent with neurogenic lesions DISEASE .
These are thought to be due to trauma DISEASE from vibration.
If PSG is performed, snoring DISEASE tends to be loudest during stage N3 sleep or REM sleep.
Epidemiologic studies are difficult to interpret if sleep apnea DISEASE was not excluded by PSG.
Based on the current literature, habitual snoring DISEASE in children may be associated with worse school performance, but conclusive evidence for this is lacking.
Some studies have suggested that adult snorers DISEASE may have a higher prevalence of cardiovas- cular disease, including hypertension DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , and ischemic heart disease.
However, a large observational study in which all subjects underwent PSG found no increased risk of cardiovascular morbidity or mortality with habitual snoring DISEASE .
Of interest, one study found that snoring DISEASE was associated with atherosclerosis DISEASE of the carotid artery, but this has not been confirmed by other studies.
As snoring DISEASE tends to increase during pregnancy, the impact of snoring DISEASE on maternal health is of great interest.
A study found that preg- nancy-onset habitual snoring (but not chronic [pre-conceptual] snoring) was associated with increased risk of gestational hypertension DISEASE and preeclampsia DISEASE .
Further studies are needed in this area.
Bibliography Cho JG, Witting PK, Verma M, et al.
Tissue vibration induces carotid artery endothelial dysfunction DISEASE : a mechanism linking snoring DISEASE and carotid atherosclerosis DISEASE ?
Sleep 2011;34:751–7.
Kezirian EJ, Chang JL.
Snoring DISEASE without OSA DISEASE and health consequences: the jury is still out.
Sleep 2013;36:613.

Sleep 2008;31:1207–13.
Marin JM, Carrizo SJ, Vicente E, Agusti AG.
Long-term cardiovascular outcomes in men with obstructive sleep apnoea-hypopnoea DISEASE with or without treatment with continuous positive airway pressure: an observational study.
Lancet 2005;365:1046–53.
Mason RH, Mehta Z, Fonseca AC, Stradling JR, Rothwell PM.
Snoring DISEASE and severity of symptomatic and asymptomatic carotid stenosis DISEASE : a population-based study.
Sleep 2012;35:1147–51.
O’Brien LM, Bullough AS, Owusu JT, et al.
Pregnancy-onset habitual snoring DISEASE , gestational hypertension DISEASE , and preeclampsia DISEASE : prospective cohort study.
Am J Obstet Gynecol 2012;207:487.e1–9.
Rich J, Raviv A, Raviv N, Brietzke SE DISEASE .
An epidemiologic study of snoring DISEASE and all-cause mortality.
Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg 2011;145:341–46.
140 Catathrenia Catathrenia DISEASE , also known as sleep related groaning, is included in the SRBD section because it appears to be associated with prolonged expiration, usually during REM sleep.
However, some studies have documented catathrenia DISEASE during NREM sleep.
Typically, a deep inspiration is followed by prolonged expiration and a monotonous vocalization resembling groaning.
The pattern is sometimes called bradypnea DISEASE (low respiratory rate).
The affected individual is usually unaware of the problem, but clini- cal evaluation is sought due to complaints of the bed partner or family members.
The recurrent bradypneic DISEASE episodes may resemble central apnea DISEASE except that central apneas are not typically associated with vocalization.
Catathrenia DISEASE is thought to be rare and more common in men.
Several episodes may occur nightly and often in clusters.
The long-term consequences of catathrenia DISEASE are unknown, but the disorder is primarily a social problem for the affected individual.
The episodes of catathrenia DISEASE are not associ- ated with sleep talking or body movement.
No association with psychiatric disorders DISEASE has been demonstrated.
The onset of catathrenia DISEASE has recently been reported in patients taking sodium oxybate CHEMICAL for narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE .
The clinical significance of this finding is unclear.
Bibliography Abbasi AA CHEMICAL , Morgenthaler TI, Slocumb NL, et al.
Nocturnal moaning and groaning-catathrenia or nocturnal vocalizations.
Sleep Breath 2012;16:367–73.
Pevernagie DA, Boon PA, Mariman ANN, Verhaeghen DB, Pauwels RA.
Vocalization during episodes of prolonged expiration: a parasomnia DISEASE related to REM sleep.
Sleep Med 2001;2:19–30.
Poli F, Ricotta L, Vandi S, et al.
Catathrenia DISEASE under sodium oxybate CHEMICAL in narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE .
Sleep Breath 2012;16:427–34.
Vetrugno R, Lugaresi E, Plazzi G, Provini F, D’Angelo R, Montagna P. Catathrenia DISEASE ( nocturnal groaning DISEASE ): an abnormal respiratory pattern during sleep.
Eur J Neurol 2007;14:1236–43.
Vetrugno R, Provini F, Plazzi G, Vignatelli L, Lugaresi E, Montagna P. Catathrenia DISEASE ( nocturnal groaning DISEASE ): a new type of parasomnia DISEASE .
Neurology 2001;56:681–3. Sleep Related Breathing Disorders Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence Narcolepsy Type 1......................................................................................146 Narcolepsy Type 2......................................................................................155 Idiopathic Hypersomnia DISEASE ..............................................................................161 Kleine-Levin Syndrome DISEASE ..............................................................................166 Hypersomnia DISEASE Due to a Medical Disorder....................................................171 Hypersomnia DISEASE Due to a Medication or Substance .......................................175 Hypersomnia DISEASE Associated with a Psychiatric Disorder DISEASE .................................179 Insufficient Sleep Syndrome DISEASE .......................................................................182 Isolated Symptoms and Normal Variants Long Sleeper ..............................................................................................187 Adequate alertness DISEASE is necessary for well-being and performance in modern society.
Sleepiness predisposes an individual to developing serious performance decrements in multiple areas of function, as well as to potentially life-threatening domestic, occu- pational, and vehicular accidents.
This section includes a group of disorders in which the primary complaint is daytime sleepiness DISEASE not caused by disturbed nocturnal sleep or misaligned circadian rhythms.
Other sleep disorders DISEASE may be present, but they must be adequately treated before a diagnosis in this category can be established.
In this nosology, the term hypersomnolence DISEASE is used to describe the symptom of exces- sive sleepiness, whereas hypersomnia DISEASE refers to specific disorders, such as idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE .
Daytime sleepiness DISEASE is defined as the inability to stay awake and alert during the major waking episodes of the day, resulting in periods of irrepressible need for sleep or unin- tended lapses into drowsiness DISEASE or sleep.
Sleepiness may vary in severity and is more likely to occur in sedentary, boring, and monotonous situations that require little active participation.
Some patients are aware of increasing sleepiness DISEASE before falling asleep, whereas others can fall asleep with little or no prodromal symptoms (“sleep attacks”).
This group of patients sometimes can present following motor vehicle accidents attrib- utable to sleepiness.
In some forms of hypersomnolence DISEASE , sleepiness DISEASE is associated with large increases in total daily amount of sleep without any genuine feeling of resto- ration.
In others, sleepiness DISEASE can be alleviated temporarily by naps but reoccurs shortly thereafter.
In young children, sleepiness DISEASE may express itself as excessively long night sleep or with the recurrence of previously discontinued daytime napping.
Children may Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE paradoxically present with inattentiveness DISEASE , emotional lability, hyperactive behavior DISEASE , or decreased performance in school.
In most cases, excessive sleepiness DISEASE is a chronic symptom.
It must occur for at least three months prior to diagnosis.
The severity of daytime sleepiness DISEASE can be quantified subjectively using severity scales such as the Epworth Sleepiness Scale and objectively using the Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT).
These measures do not always correlate with each other and must be used with appropriate clinical judgment.
When applied in clinical settings, the MSLT is sensitive to sleep deprivation and circadian effects.
It has not been validated as a diagnostic test in people who are habitually awake throughout the night and sleep during the day.
Normal and abnormal ranges of sleep latencies have not been estab- lished when this test is administered at times other than the hours between 8:00 a.m. and
6:00 p.m. Normative data are not available for children younger than six years.
The MSLT measures the physiological tendency to fall asleep in quiet situations.
In the context of diagnosing central disorders of hypersomnolence DISEASE , the MSLT should be con- ducted according to standardized procedures, as defined in the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) practice parameters.
In particular, patients should be encour- aged to sleep as much as possible during the week and, especially, during the night prior to the MSLT.
Delaying wake-up time and subsequent MSLT start time may be appropriate in some patients with delayed sleep phase syndrome DISEASE .
It is strongly rec- ommended that adequate sleep be documented by sleep log and, whenever possible, actigraphy for a period of one to two weeks prior to the MSLT.
MSLT mean sleep latencies should be considered a continuum with values below five minutes generally considered as indicative of sleepiness DISEASE and those over 10 minutes generally consid- ered indicative of normal alertness.
In this section, a mean MSLT sleep latency of less than eight minutes is used to define sleepiness for diagnostic purposes.
This value has been shown to be the best cutoff in the context of diagnosing narcolepsy DISEASE , with approximately 90% of patients with narcolepsy DISEASE having a latency below this level.
The presence of multiple sleep onset rapid eye movement periods ( SOREMPs DISEASE ) during the MSLT is a more specific finding in narcolepsy DISEASE than is a mean sleep latency less than or equal to eight minutes, although SOREMPs DISEASE can also be seen in the presence of insuffi- cient sleep, circadian rhythm disorders DISEASE (including delayed sleep phase disorder DISEASE or shift work), sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE or, occasionally, normal subjects.
The results of an MSLT should be carefully interpreted in the context of the patient’s history and the complaint of daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
144 The maintenance of wakefulness test is a measure of the ability to remain awake during the daytime in a darkened, quiet environment and is usually administered to assess response to treatment.
It should not be used for diagnostic purposes.
A 24-hour continuous sleep recording or an actigraphic recording of at least one week is useful in the diagnosis of some patients with idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE .
In all cases in which a diagnosis of hypersomnolence DISEASE is to be made, a review of other sleep, medical, and psychiatric disorders DISEASE , as well as substance and medication use, should be performed.
In this edition of International Classification of Sleep Disorders the preferred names of certain central disorders of hypersomnolence DISEASE have been changed.
In particular, nar- colepsy has been divided into narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 and narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 rather than narcolepsy DISEASE with and without cataplexy DISEASE .
This change is predicated on the concept that absence of hypocretin (orexin) is a fundamental marker of the most precisely defined category of the disorder.
Because some patients without cataplexy DISEASE will also have low cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) hypocretin-1 levels, the use of the term “ narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE ” or “narcolepsy-cataplexy” is inappropriate.
The change is not intended to imply that the presence or absence of cataplexy DISEASE is unimportant clinically nor that mea- suring CSF hypocretin-1 levels is obligatory.
The motivation behind the decision to eliminate the subcategories of idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE is discussed in the appropriate section.
The decision to use Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE as the preferred name in place of recurrent hypersomnia DISEASE is based on data suggesting that the condition is fairly homo- geneous, as well as the lack of definite evidence for other major subcategories of the disorder.
Bibliography Arand D, Bonnet M, Hurwitz T, Mitler M, Rosa R, Sangal RB.
A Review by the MSLT and MWT Task Force of the Standards of Practice Committee of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine.
The clinical use of the MSLT and MWT.
Sleep 2005;28:123–44.
Aurora RN, Lamm CHEMICAL CI, Zak RS DISEASE , et al.
Practice parameters for the non-respiratory indications for polysomnography and multiple sleep latency testing for children.
Sleep 2012;35:1467–73.
Littner MR, Kushida C, Wise M, et al.; Standards of Practice Committee of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine.
Practice parameters for clinical use of the multiple sleep latency test and the maintenance of wakefulness test.
Sleep 2005;28:113–21.
Mignot E, Lin L, Finn L, et al.
Correlates of sleep-onset REM periods during the Multiple Sleep Latency Test in community adults.
Brain 2006;129:1609–23.
145 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence Narcolepsy Type 1 ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 347.01 ICD-10-CM code: G47.411 Alternate Names Hypocretin deficiency syndrome DISEASE , narcolepsy-cataplexy DISEASE , narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A and B must be met A.
The patient has daily periods of irrepressible need to sleep or daytime lapses into sleep occurring for at least three months.1 B.
The presence of one or both of the following: . Cataplexy DISEASE (as defined under Essential Features) and a mean sleep latency of ≤ CHEMICAL 8 minutes and two or more sleep onset REM periods ( SOREMPs DISEASE ) on an MSLT performed according to standard techniques.
A SOREMP DISEASE (within 15 minutes of sleep onset) on the preceding nocturnal polysomnogram may replace one of the SOREMPs DISEASE on the MSLT.2 . CSF hypocretin-1 concentration, measured by immunoreactivity, is either ≤ CHEMICAL 110 pg/mL or <1/3 of mean values obtained in normal subjects with the same standardized assay.
Notes .
In young children, narcolepsy DISEASE may sometimes present as excessively long night sleep or as resumption of previously discontinued daytime napping.
2.
If narcolepsy DISEASE type I is strongly suspected clinically but the MSLT criteria of B1 are not met, a possible strategy is to repeat the MSLT.
Essential Features Narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 is a disorder primarily characterized by excessive daytime sleepi- ness and signs of REM-sleep dissociation, the most specific of which is cataplexy DISEASE .
It has now been firmly established that narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 is caused by a deficiency of hypothalamic hypocretin (orexin) signaling.
Patients with low or undetectable concen- trations of hypocretin-1 in the CSF compose a specific disease population with a single etiology and relatively homogenous clinical and polysomnographic features.
Patients with sleepiness DISEASE and low or absent CSF hypocretin-1
levels are classified as having nar- colepsy type 1, even if they do not manifest cataplexy DISEASE .
146 Excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE is the cardinal symptom, and often the most disabling.
Patients with narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 experience repeated daily episodes of an irrepressible need to sleep or lapses into sleep.
Most patients awaken refreshed after a sleep episode but begin to feel sleepy again after variable times.
Sleepiness is most likely to occur in monotonous situations that require no active participation; for example, watching television or riding in a car.
Physical activity may temporarily suppress the urge to sleep.
In some cases sleepiness DISEASE manifests as sudden irresistible sleep DISEASE “attacks” that may occur in unusual situations such as eating or walking.
Often, such sleep attacks occur on a background of overall sleepiness.
Even when seemingly awake, many nar- colepsy patients have lapses in vigilance, sometimes in combination with automatic behavior, such as writing gibberish or interrupting a conversation with a completely different topic.
Sleepiness generally has a serious impact on the ability of the patient to function in educational, social, and occupational situations.
Because patients are rarely examined during an attack of cataplexy DISEASE , its presence needs to be established based on the clinical interview alone.
Cataplexy DISEASE is defined as more than one episode of generally brief (< 2 minutes), usually bilaterally symmetrical sudden loss of muscle tone with retained consciousness.
The episodes are precipitated by strong emotions, usually positive, with almost all patients reporting some episodes precipitated by emotions associated with laughter.
The finding of transient reversible loss of deep tendon reflexes during an attack, if observed, is a strong diagnostic finding.
In children (and rarely adults), cataplexy DISEASE may present close to disease onset as facial (or generalized) hypotonia DISEASE with droopy eyelids, mouth opening, and protruded tongue, or gait unsteadiness DISEASE , which clearly are not related to emotion.
Facial and masticatory movements DISEASE may occur.
In children, anticipation of a reward is a common precipitant.
It is important to use child-appropriate contexts and language when trying to elicit a history of cataplexy DISEASE in children.
The cataplexy DISEASE phenotype differs widely between patients, ranging from sporadic partial attacks DISEASE triggered by laughter, to frequent complete attacks of collapse brought about by a variety of emotions.
In the vast majority of attacks, cataplexy DISEASE is bilateral, although patients sometimes report one side of the body to be more affected than the other.
Partial attacks DISEASE can be very subtle and sometimes only recognized by experi- enced observers such as the patient’s partner.
Neck weakness DISEASE , producing head drop, is a common complaint, whereas facial weakness DISEASE may lead to sagging of the jaw and dysarthria DISEASE .
Respiratory muscles are not involved although patients sometimes describe shortness of breath DISEASE when symptomatic.
Attacks start abruptly and usually build up over several seconds, especially in attacks producing complete peripheral weakness DISEASE and collapse.
Positive motor phenomena are not uncommon, with muscle twitching Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence or small jerks DISEASE , particularly of the face.
Although many emotions can potentially lead to cataplexy DISEASE , those associated with mirth are usually the most potent.
Laughing out loud, telling a joke, and making a witty remark are typical examples.
The frequency of cataplexy DISEASE is variable, ranging from less than one attack per month to more than 20 attacks per day.
Cataplexy DISEASE is generally short-lived, lasting a matter of seconds, with the vast majority of attacks DISEASE lasting less than two minutes.
However, if a particular trigger continues, consecutive attacks DISEASE may merge together to form what seems to be one long episode.
Sudden withdrawal of anticataplectic medication, especially anti- depressants, can result in “ status cataplecticus DISEASE ” in which long-lasting attacks happen virtually continuously.
Associated Features In addition to sleepiness DISEASE and cataplexy DISEASE , patients with narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 often report several other symptoms, none of which are specific for the disorder.
Many patients report disruption of nocturnal sleep, which can sometimes be of major concern.
Although sleep onset is rarely a problem, an inability to maintain continuous sleep is very common.
33% to 80% of narcolepsy DISEASE patients have hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE and/or sleep paralysis DISEASE .
Hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE are defined as vivid dreamlike expe- riences occurring at the transition from wake to sleep.
Typically, hypnagogic halluci- nations have a multimodal or “holistic” character, often combining visual, auditory, and tactile phenomena.
Hypnopompic hallucinations DISEASE are similar but occur at sleep to wake transitions.
Sleep paralysis DISEASE describes the disturbing temporary inability to move voluntary muscles at sleep-wake transitions.
Despite being awake and conscious of the sleeping environment, it is impossible for subjects to move their limbs or even open their eyes.
The experience may last for several minutes and can be very distressing.
Other symptoms may include ptosis DISEASE , blurred vision DISEASE , and diplopia DISEASE , presumably as a result of sleepiness.
Epidemiological studies have shown that obesity DISEASE is a common symptom of narco- lepsy.
Around disease onset, an unexplained increase in body weight is often observed.
Obesity (defined as a body mass index ≥ 30 kg/m2) occurs more than twice as often in narcoleptic DISEASE populations as in control groups.
An increased frequency of several other sleep abnormalities DISEASE has been described in narcolepsy DISEASE , including sleep talking, periodic limb movements of sleep, sleep disordered breathing, and REM sleep behavior disor- der.
There is an increased prevalence of depressive symptoms DISEASE , although there are con- flicting reports on how often these symptoms qualify as a clinical depression DISEASE .
Recent studies point to a high level of anxiety disorders DISEASE in patients with narcolepsy DISEASE , with panic attacks or social phobias DISEASE in about 20%.
More than half of patients report severe fatigue DISEASE , which can be distinct from sleepiness.
148 Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Narcolepsy type 1 due to a medical condition:
This condition is primarily associated with central nervous system (CNS) disorders, including autoimmune or paraneoplastic disorders DISEASE associated with anti-Ma2 DISEASE or antiaquaporin4 antibodies, and tumors DISEASE or other lesions of the hypothalamus.
In addition, undetectable hypocretin-1 levels have been reported in association with sleepiness DISEASE after severe head trauma DISEASE .
The condition must fulfill criteria for narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 and be attributable to another medical disorder.
Narcolepsy DISEASE without cataplexy DISEASE with low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels: Narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 should be diagnosed, even in the absence of cataplexy DISEASE , if diagnostic criteria A and B2 are fulfilled.
Demographics Narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE occurs in 0.02% to 0.18% of the United States and western European populations.
A lower prevalence has been reported in Israel, whereas narco- lepsy with cataplexy DISEASE may be slightly more common in Japan (0.16% to 0.18%).
Both sexes are affected, with a slight preponderance of males.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Several unproven precipitating factors have been suggested in case reports, including head trauma DISEASE , sustained sleep deprivation, unspecified viral illness DISEASE , and sudden changes in sleep-wake patterns.
Several studies have pointed to seasonal patterns in the onset of narcolepsy DISEASE , which may point to a specific environmental trigger.
Recent studies have shown an increase in antibodies against beta-hemolytic streptococcus DISEASE , which were strongest around onset of narcolepsy DISEASE and decreased with disease duration, suggesting that streptococcal infections DISEASE may constitute an environmental trigger.
There have been reports of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 occurring after vaccination against H1N1 DISEASE associated influ- enza, but a definite causal association has not yet been established.
Tribbles homolog 2 antibodies, found in some patients with autoimmune uveitis DISEASE , have been described in 14% to 26% of narcolepsy DISEASE patients, but the significance is uncertain.
Familial Patterns At the genetic level, narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE is closely associated with the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) subtypes DR2/DRB1*1501 and DQB1*0602.
These two subtypes are always found together in whites and Asians, but in blacks, DQB1*0602 is more specifically associated with narcolepsy DISEASE .
Almost all patients with cataplexy DISEASE are positive for DQB1*0602, compared with 12% to 38% of the general population who have this HLA subtype.
Other subtypes also have less striking associations.
For example, DQB1*0301 is associated with increased susceptibility to narcolepsy DISEASE , Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE whereas subtypes such as DQB1*0501 and DQB1*0601, are protective in the presence of DQB1*0602.
Genomewide studies have found associations between narcolepsy DISEASE and polymorphisms in T cell receptor alpha, tumor DISEASE necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha 2, and TNF receptor 2 as well as the purinergic receptor P2Y11 genes.
There is a low prevalence of familial cases; the risk of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 in first-de- gree relatives of affected individuals is approximately 1% to 2%.
When compared to the population prevalence, this indicates a tenfold to fortyfold increase in risk.
This increased risk cannot be explained solely by HLA gene effects, suggesting the exis- tence of other genetic factors.
Multiplex families with more than two affected members are uncommon.
In most cases, normal CSF hypocretin levels have been found in these families, and the association with HLA DQB1*0602 is much weaker compared to spo- radic narcolepsy DISEASE .
So far, only a single case of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 has been described in association with a preprohypocretin mutation.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset usually occurs after five years of age and most typically between ages 10 and 25 years.
However, a bimodal distribution in the age at onset has been described in some populations with a first peak occurring at adolescence (age 15 years) and a second at the age of 35 years.
Recent studies highlight the fact that narcolepsy DISEASE , and especially cataplexy DISEASE , in young children may present somewhat differently, resulting in delayed diagnosis and erroneously high estimates of age of onset.
Sleepiness is usually the first symptom to manifest.
Cataplexy DISEASE most often occurs within one year of onset but in rare cases, may precede the onset of sleepiness DISEASE or commence up to 40 years later.
Hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE , sleep paralysis DISEASE , and disturbed noctur- nal sleep often manifest later in the course of the disease.
When left untreated, narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 is often socially disabling and isolating.
Patients have a tendency to fail in school and are often dismissed from their jobs.
Driving may be avoided for fear of a motor vehicle accident.
The inability to sleep at night may further contribute to a loss of control these patients have over their schedule.
Depression DISEASE and weight gain DISEASE also are common.
In most cases, symptoms gradually develop over several years.
When the clinical picture has fully developed, there are usually only minor fluctuations in severity.
Cataplexy DISEASE may lessen with age, or occasionally increase in frequency and severity.
150 Developmental Issues In recent years, increasing attention has been given to the clinical presentation of nar- colepsy in childhood.
Narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE is infrequent prior to the age of four years.
In addition, the clinical presentation in children may be different from that of adults.
In young children, sleepiness DISEASE may be difficult to assess, and may express itself as excessively long night sleep, or the recurrence of previously discontinued daytime napping.
Moreover, children may paradoxically present with hyperactive behavior DISEASE , behavioral problems or decreased performance in school.
Inattentiveness, lack of energy, insomnia DISEASE , bizarre hallucinations DISEASE , or a combination thereof can lead to a psy- chiatric misdiagnosis of schizophrenia DISEASE or depression DISEASE .
In this population, the presence of ancillary symptoms such as sleep paralysis DISEASE or hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE may also be difficult to confirm, depending on the child’s verbal ability.
Precocious puberty and obesity DISEASE may also develop around the time of symptom onset.
REM sleep behavior dis- order or REM sleep without atonia DISEASE may also be manifest at the time of symptom onset.
Cataplexy DISEASE may be very severe around disease onset and appear phenotypically differ- ent from typical episodes seen in adulthood.
In addition to typical attacks DISEASE triggered by positive emotions, children can also present with weakness DISEASE involving the face, eyelids, and mouth not clearly associated with emotion.
Together with tongue protrusion, this characteristic pattern has been termed a cataplectic facies DISEASE .
Children with cataplexy DISEASE may also display positive motor phenomena, ranging from perioral dyskinetic or dys- DISEASE tonic movements DISEASE to frank stereotypies.
In children, anticipation of reward may also be a precipitant.
The diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 in children may be complicated because of diffi- culties performing the MSLT, and lack of normative values in children younger than six years.
If the MSLT shows equivocal results, repeating it after a time interval may be helpful.
Given these difficulties, CSF hypocretin-1 measurements are of particular value, as hypocretin-1 levels are low or undetectable very shortly after disease onset in children as well.
Pathology and Pathophysiology It is now firmly established that narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 is caused by deficiencies in hypo- cretin DISEASE signaling, most likely due to a selective loss of hypothalamic hypocretin pro- ducing neurons.
Several animal models lacking hypocretin neurotransmission demon- CHEMICAL strate narcolepsy DISEASE , indicating a causal relationship.
The vast majority of patients (90% to 95%) with narcolepsy DISEASE and cataplexy DISEASE have undetectable or low (< 110 pg/mL) levels of hypocretin-1 in the CSF.
Patients without cataplexy DISEASE can be hypocretin deficient as well, although at a much lower frequency, and are thus also classified as narcolepsy DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE type 1.
The strong HLA association in narcolepsy DISEASE has led to the hypothesis that auto- immunity is a likely etiological mechanism, potentially explaining the selectivity of neuronal destruction DISEASE in the hypothalamus.
However, definitive proof for autoimmunity DISEASE has not been obtained.
Objective Findings Narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 is essentially defined as a hypocretin deficiency syndrome DISEASE , which is reflected in the need for objective measurements in the clinical criteria.
This require- ment is further driven by the fact that many patients require lifelong treatment with potentially addictive medications, underscoring the importance of objective confirma- tion of the diagnosis.
It is strongly recommended that the MSLT be preceded by at least one week of acti- graphic recording with a sleep log to establish whether the results could be biased by insufficient sleep, shift work, or another circadian sleep disorder DISEASE .
In patients with narcolepsy DISEASE type 1, the MSLT demonstrates a mean sleep latency of less than eight minutes and typically less than five minutes.
Meta-analysis shows mean sleep latencies in narcoleptic DISEASE patients with cataplexy DISEASE of 3.1 ± 2.9 minutes.
In addition, two or more SOREMPs CHEMICAL must be present.
Recent data suggest that a SOREMP DISEASE within 15 minutes of onset of nocturnal sleep is a highly specific finding in the absence of another sleep disorder DISEASE , but with low sensitivity.
Therefore, the criteria for narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 allow the “replacement” of one SOREMP DISEASE in the MSLT with a SOREMP DISEASE on the preceding poly- somnogram.
For the correct interpretation of MSLT findings, the recordings should be performed with the following conditions: (1) the patient must be free of drugs that influence sleep for at least 14 days (or at least five times the half-life of the drug and longer-acting metabolite), confirmed by a urine drug screen; (2) the sleep-wake sched- ule must have been standardized and, if necessary, extended to a minimum of seven hours in bed each night (longer for children) for at least seven days before polysom-
nography (preferably documented by sleep log and, whenever possible, actigraphy); and (3) nocturnal polysomnography should be performed on the night immediately preceding the MSLT to rule out other sleep disorders DISEASE that could mimic the diagnostic features of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1.
Sleep time during polysomnography should be curtailed as little as possible with the goal of at least seven hours asleep.
The overnight poly- somnogram may demonstrate an increase in the amount of stage N1 sleep, and there may be a disruption of the normal sleep pattern, with frequent awakenings.
REM sleep without atonia DISEASE may be present.
Measuring CSF levels of hypocretin-1 is a highly specific and sensitive test for the diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1. Hypocretin-1 can be measured in crude CSF, using a commercially available radioimmunoassay.
When using the Stanford reference sample, values less than 110 pg/mL are highly specific.
Alternatively, a laboratory may elect to obtain control data themselves, in which case a level of less than 33% of mean control values is considered abnormal.
Issues concerning the standardization of CSF hypocre- tin measurements remain, but extensive protocols are available.
Low CSF hypocre- tin values are occasionally observed in seriously ill DISEASE patients with other disorders and should be interpreted within the clinical context.
HLA typing of narcoleptic DISEASE patients with cataplexy DISEASE almost always shows the presence of HLA DQB1*0602 (and DR2 or DRB1*1501 in whites and Asians), but this is not diagnostic for narcolepsy DISEASE .
Approximately 25% of the normal Caucasian population, 12% of the Japanese population, and 38% of the black population are positive for DQB1*0602.
HLA typing could be considered when a spinal tap is contemplated to assess hypocretin-1 values: if the patient is HLA-negative, hypocretin-1 levels are most likely normal.
Differential Diagnosis In the absence of cataplexy DISEASE , narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 can be diagnosed based on the pres- ence of hypersomnolence DISEASE and low CSF hypocretin-1 levels.
When cataplexy DISEASE is absent and CSF hypocretin-1 levels are normal or unknown, narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 should be diagnosed.
Cataplexy DISEASE must be differentiated from cataplexy-like DISEASE episodes that are occasionally observed in normal individuals.
For example, feelings of muscle weakness DISEASE are some- times reported when healthy subjects laugh out loud.
In genuine cataplexy DISEASE , episodes most often occur with a significant frequency, and are associated with loss of muscle tone.
Cataplexy DISEASE should be differentiated from hypotension DISEASE , transient ischemic attacks DISEASE , drop attacks, akinetic seizures DISEASE , neuromuscular disorders DISEASE , vestibular disorders DISEASE , psycho- CHEMICAL logical or psychiatric disorders DISEASE , and sleep paralysis DISEASE .
Clear improvement with antide- pressant medications may favor a diagnosis of cataplexy DISEASE in difficult cases.
Sleepiness may be secondary to obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE , insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE , shift work, the effects of substances or medications, or other sleep disorders DISEASE .
Many of these conditions can result in early onset REM sleep as well.
When cataplexy DISEASE is present, these disorders do not preclude a diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1.
When there is a questionable history of cataplexy DISEASE in such cases, either comorbid conditions should be adequately treated before performing an MSLT or CSF hypocretin-1 should be measured.
153 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence Idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE is differentiated from narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 by the absence of cat- aplexy and the lack of two or more SOREMPs DISEASE on the MSLT.
In contrast with patients who have narcolepsy DISEASE , patients with idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE generally have high sleep efficiency, sleep drunkenness, and long, unrefreshing naps.
In insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE , there is no cataplexy DISEASE , and normalizing sleep time elim-
inates the daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
Chronic fatigue syndrome DISEASE and depression DISEASE may mimic narcolepsy DISEASE but do not show the typical MSLT findings.
Malingering and substance abuse disorder DISEASE should be considered in patients who try to mislead the clinician in order to obtain stimulant medications.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Ten percent of patients with narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE have normal hypocretin-1 levels in the CSF, which suggests that CSF levels either do not perfectly reflect brain hypocretin neurotransmission or that narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE can be caused by factors other than hypocretin deficiency DISEASE .
The cause of the hypocretin cell destruction remains unknown, although an autoimmune-mediated mechanism is suspected.
Levels of hypocretin-1 have been reported in the blood of some subjects.
The development of serum tests to determine hypocretin deficiency DISEASE would provide a less invasive diagnos- tic approach.

Narcolepsy DISEASE Type 2 ICD-9-CM code: 347.00 Alternate Names Narcolepsy DISEASE without cataplexy DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-E must be met ICD-10-CM code: G47.419 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE A.
The patient has daily periods of irrepressible need to sleep or daytime lapses into sleep occurring for at least three months.
B. A mean sleep latency of ≤ CHEMICAL 8 minutes and two or more sleep onset REM periods ( SOREMPs DISEASE ) are found on a MSLT performed according to standard techniques.
A SOREMP DISEASE (within 15 minutes of sleep onset) on the preceding nocturnal polysomnogram may replace one of the SOREMPs DISEASE on the MSLT.
C. Cataplexy DISEASE is absent.1 D. Either CSF hypocretin-1 concentration has not been measured or CSF hypocretin-1 concentration measured by immunoreactivity is either > 110 pg/mL or > 1/3 of mean values obtained in normal subjects with the same standardized assay.2 E.
The hypersomnolence DISEASE and/or MSLT findings are not better explained by other causes such as insufficient sleep, obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE , delayed sleep phase disorder DISEASE , or the effect of medication or substances or their withdrawal.
Notes .
If cataplexy DISEASE develops later, then the disorder should be reclassified as narcolepsy DISEASE type 1. Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE .
If the CSF Hcrt-1 concentration is tested at a later stage and found to be either ≤ CHEMICAL 110 pg/mL or < 1/3 of mean values obtained in normal subjects with the same assay, then the disorder should be reclassified as narcolepsy DISEASE type 1.
Essential Features Narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE and abnormal man- ifestations of REM sleep on polysomnography/MSLT.
Cataplexy DISEASE is absent, although some atypical sensations of weakness DISEASE triggered by unusual emotions such as stress and anger DISEASE may be reported.
Refreshing daytime naps are characteristic.
An essential feature of the diagnosis is the presence of a mean sleep latency less than or equal to eight minutes and two or more SOREMPs DISEASE on an MSLT (or one SOREMP DISEASE on an MSLT and one on the preceding nocturnal polysomnogram).
The presence of CSF hypocretin-1 concentrations ≤ CHEMICAL 110 pg/mL or less than one third of mean values obtained in normal subjects with the same assay excludes the diagnosis, but most patients with narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 will not have undergone CSF examination.
Associated Features Sleep paralysis DISEASE , hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE , or automatic behavior may be present.
Memory lapses, automatic behavior, ptosis DISEASE , blurred vision DISEASE , and diplopia DISEASE may occur in association with sleepiness DISEASE .
REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE and nonrapid eye movement (NREM) parasomnias DISEASE may occur.
Nocturnal sleep disruption with frequent awaken- ings CHEMICAL may be present.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Narcolepsy type 2 due to a medical condition: This condition fulfills criteria for nar- colepsy type 2 and is attributable to another medical disorder.
Neurologic disorders DISEASE associated with narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 include tumors DISEASE or sarcoidosis DISEASE of the hypothalamus, autoimmune DISEASE or paraneoplastic disorders DISEASE associated with anti-Ma-2 or anti-aquaporin-4 DISEASE antibodies, multiple sclerosis DISEASE , myotonic dystrophy DISEASE , Prader-Willi syndrome DISEASE , Parkinson disease DISEASE , and head trauma DISEASE .
In disorders associated with both sleep apnea DISEASE and narco- lepsy type 2, such as myotonic dystrophy DISEASE or Prader-Willi syndrome DISEASE , a diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 should only be made if abnormal MSLT findings persist after the sleep apnea DISEASE is adequately treated.
In all cases, especially with complex problems such as head trauma DISEASE , clinical judgment should be used to determine if the development of narcolepsy DISEASE was a mere coincidence or was triggered by the event or disorder.
156 Demographics The exact prevalence of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 is uncertain.
Cases of narcolepsy DISEASE without cat- aplexy represent 15% to 25% of the clinic narcoleptic DISEASE population.
A population-based study suggested a higher percentage (36%), corresponding to a point prevalence of 20.5/100,000.
Population-based studies have shown that approximately 4% to 9.5% of adults may have multiple SOREMPs CHEMICAL during random MSLTs DISEASE , but shift workers and subjects with sleep deprivation or sleep apnea DISEASE were included in the studies.
Although both sexes can be affected, the prevalence may be slightly higher in men.
The age of onset mirrors that of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1. Predisposing and Precipitating Factors As discussed below, about 24% of patients with narcolepsy DISEASE but no cataplexy DISEASE will have low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels and almost all of these will be positive for the HLA DQB1*0602 antigen.
These patients probably share a common pathogenesis with narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE and should be classified as narcolepsy DISEASE type 1.
Underlying genetic and envi- ronmental factors associated with other patients with narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 are unknown.
Environmental precipitating factors are suspected from case reports but have never been proven to trigger narcolepsy DISEASE without cataplexy DISEASE .
Among the most commonly reported triggers are head trauma DISEASE and unspecified viral illnesses.
Familial Patterns The detailed genetic pattern of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 is unknown.
Relatives of patients with narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 may be more likely to experience partial narcolepsy DISEASE symptoms compatible with the diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2. Onset, Course, and Complications Onset typically occurs during adolescence.
In about 10% of patients, cataplexy DISEASE will develop later in the course of the disease, necessitating a change in diagnosis to narco- lepsy type 1.
Most of these patients will, if tested, have absent or intermediate levels of CSF Hcrt-1.
In a cohort of patients with narcolepsy DISEASE without cataplexy DISEASE in whom CSF Hcrt-1 status was known, 33% of those with low levels later developed cataplexy DISEASE , compared with 18% with intermediate levels and only 1% with normal levels.
When left untreated, narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 is socially disabling and isolating.
Patients have a ten- dency to fail in school and are often dismissed from their jobs.
Driving may be avoided for fear of a motor vehicle accident.
The inability to sleep at night may further contrib- ute to a loss of control these patients have over their schedule.
Depression DISEASE and weight gain DISEASE also are common.
157 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Developmental Issues Children with narcolepsy type 2 will typically DISEASE present with a reappearance of regular daytime napping after naps had been discontinued.
In all pediatric cases, one should consider the possibility of an evolving disorder with the development of cataplexy DISEASE over time.
Once the patient develops clear cataplexy DISEASE , the diagnosis should be changed to narcolepsy DISEASE type 1.
Limited information is available on narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 prior to adolescence.
Descriptions of the experience of sleep paralysis DISEASE or hypnagogic halluci- nations are very difficult to evoke in young patients, and normative data are not avail- able for the MSLT in children younger than six years of age.
In peripubertal children and adolescents, the diagnosis is often challenging.
The most common causes of short sleep latencies, often with multiple SOREMPs CHEMICAL on the MSLT, are chronic sleep depri- vation and delayed sleep phase disorder DISEASE .
Behavioral problems may be associated with the onset of the disorder, and symptoms may be hidden by the patient.
Inattentiveness, lack of energy, insomnia DISEASE , bizarre hallucinations DISEASE , or a combination thereof can lead to a psychiatric DISEASE misdiagnosis of schizophrenia DISEASE or depression DISEASE .
If the MSLT shows equivocal results, repeating it after a time interval may be helpful, as SOREMPs DISEASE often emerge later in children.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Narcolepsy type 2 is most likely a heterogeneous disorder.
Approximately 24% of nar-
coleptic patients without cataplexy DISEASE have a low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL concentration, and another 8% have intermediate levels (> 110 pg/mL but ≤ CHEMICAL 200 pg/mL).
The CSF Hcrt-1 status of most patients with narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 is unknown (those patients who are known to have absent CSF Hcrt-1 levels are classified as narcolepsy DISEASE type 1).
Therefore, there will be a subgroup of about one fourth to one third of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 patients who will have hypocretin deficiency DISEASE , presumably from loss of the hypocretin-producing neurons.
This group of patients cannot be accurately separated clinically or by labora- tory tests (other than CSF Hcrt-1 level) from the majority of patients without cataplexy DISEASE who have normal CSF Hcrt-1 levels.
Although those with low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels have a younger age of onset and their MSLT shows shorter mean sleep latency with more SOREMPs DISEASE in comparison with those with normal levels, there is too much overlap between the groups for these differences to be helpful diagnostically in individual patients.
One hundred percent of patients with low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels are positive for HLA DQB1*0602.
About 26% of patients with normal levels are also HLA posi- tive DISEASE , a percentage not higher than that seen in the normal population.
The underlying pathophysiology of the remainder of patients who have normal CSF Hcrt-1 levels is unknown.
It is possible some may have partial hypocretin deficiency DISEASE severe enough to cause sleepiness DISEASE but not severe enough to result in cataplexy DISEASE or low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels.
However, support for this hypothesis is lacking in that there are no major differences in clinical or polysomnographic findings in those positive or negative for HLA DQB1*0602.
In the only postmortem study of a case of narcolepsy DISEASE without cata- plexy (CSF Hcrt-1 status unknown), the number of hypocretin cells was decreased but not as much as in cases of narcolepsy DISEASE with cataplexy DISEASE .
Objective Findings It is strongly rcommended that the MSLT be preceded by at least one week of acti- graphic recording with a sleep log to establish whether the results could be biased by insufficient sleep, shift work, or another circadian sleep disorder DISEASE .
The MSLT demon- CHEMICAL strates a mean latency of less than eight minutes, typically less than five minutes, with two or more SOREMPs DISEASE or one SOREMP DISEASE together with a SOREMP DISEASE on the preceding polysomnogram.
Meta-analysis shows mean sleep latencies in narcoleptic DISEASE patients with cataplexy DISEASE of 3.1 ± 2.9 minutes.
Recent data suggest that a SOREMP DISEASE within 15 minutes of onset of nocturnal sleep is a highly specific finding in the absence of another sleep disorder DISEASE , but with low sensitivity.
Therefore, the criteria for narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 allow the “replacement” of one SOREMP DISEASE in the MSLT with a SOREMP DISEASE on the preceding poly- somnogram.
For the correct interpretation of MSLT findings, the recordings should be performed with the following conditions: (1) the patient must be free of drugs that influence sleep for at least 14 days (or at least five times the half-life of the drug and longer-acting metabolite), confirmed by a urine drug screen; (2) the sleep-wake sched- ule must have been standardized and, if necessary, extended to a minimum of seven hours in bed each night (longer for children) for at least seven days before polysom-
nography (preferably documented by sleep log and, whenever possible, actigraphy); and (3) nocturnal polysomnography should be performed on the night immediately preceding the MSLT to rule out other sleep disorders DISEASE that could mimic the diagnostic features of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2.
Sleep time during polysomnography should be curtailed as little as possible, with the goal of at least seven hours asleep.
The overnight poly- somnogram may demonstrate an increase in the amount of stage N1 sleep, and there may be a disruption of the normal sleep pattern, with frequent awakenings.
REM sleep without atonia DISEASE may be present.
About 45% of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 cases have been reported to be HLA DQB1*0602 positive, compared with 12% to 38% of controls.
Whereas essentially all patients who have low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels will be positive, about 25% of those with normal levels will also be positive.
Assuming that 24% of patients with narcolepsy DISEASE but no cataplexy DISEASE will have low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels, the probability that an HLA- positive patient will have low Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels is only 0.56.
Therefore the HLA status of a patient cannot be used to diagnose narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 nor to predict with high probability the patient’s CSF Hcrt-1 levels.
However, if lumbar puncture is contemplated to measure CSF Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Hcrt-1 levels, HLA typing should be performed first; if the patient is HLA negative, CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels will almost certainly be normal and the lumbar puncture will be unnecessary.
Approximately 24% of narcoleptic DISEASE patients without cataplexy DISEASE have a low CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL concentration and another 8% have intermediate levels (> 110 pg/mL but ≤ CHEMICAL 200 pg/ mL).
If the CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels of such patients are known to be low, they are classified as narcolepsy DISEASE type 1, but the CSF Hcrt-1 status will not be known for most of these patients.
Possible indications for considering measuring CSF Hcrt-1 CHEMICAL levels as a diag- nostic procedure would be the presence of disorders such as obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE or the use of psychotropic medications that may complicate interpretation of an MSLT.
Differential Diagnosis Narcolepsy type 1 is diagnosed if cataplexy DISEASE is present or the CSF hypocretin levels are known to be low even in the absence of cataplexy DISEASE .
Patients with idiopathic hyper- somnia DISEASE may have mean sleep latencies on MSLT similar to those of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2, but have fewer than two SOREMPs DISEASE on MSLT and the preceding polysomnogram combined.
In contrast to narcolepsy DISEASE , patients with idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE generally have high sleep efficiency, sleep drunkenness, and long, unrefreshing naps.
Sleepiness may be secondary to obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE ( OSA DISEASE ), insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE , shift work, the effects of substances or medications, or other sleep disorders DISEASE .
Many of these conditions can result in early-onset REM sleep DISEASE , so their clinical and polysomnographic exclusion is essential before a diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 is made.
However, the presence of other sleep disorders DISEASE does not preclude a diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 if daytime sleepiness DISEASE and REM abnormalities DISEASE persist after adequate treatment of the initial disorder.
Chronic fatigue syndrome DISEASE and depression DISEASE may mimic narcolepsy DISEASE but do not show the typical MSLT findings.
Malingering and substance abuse disorder DISEASE should be considered in patients who try to mislead the clinician in order to obtain stimulant medications.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Excluding the minority of patients with definite hypocretin deficiency DISEASE , the underlying biology of narcolepsy DISEASE without the presence of cataplexy DISEASE is unknown.
It is not estab- lished whether narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 is a homogeneous or heterogeneous condition.
It is uncertain whether or not some patients have partial hypocretin deficiency DISEASE not iden- tifiable from CSF measurements.
Further advances in classification will depend on answers to these unknowns.
Further studies on the natural history of narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 are needed to determine the cause of the hypersomnolence DISEASE and the risk of development of cataplexy DISEASE over time.
