Idiopathic Hypersomnia ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 327.11 Alternate Names Idiopathic CNS hypersomnolence DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-F must be met ICD-10-CM code: G47.11 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE A.
The patient has daily periods of irrepressible need to sleep or daytime lapses into sleep occurring for at least three months.1 B. Cataplexy DISEASE is absent.
C. An MSLT performed according to standard techniques shows fewer than two sleep onset REM periods or no sleep onset REM periods if the REM latency on the preceding polysomnogram was less than or equal to 15 minutes.2 D.
The presence of at least one of the following: .
The MSLT shows a mean sleep latency of ≤ CHEMICAL 8 minutes.
2. Total 24-hour sleep time is ≥ 660 minutes (typically 12–14 hours)3 DISEASE on 24-hour polysomnographic monitoring (performed after correction of chronic sleep deprivation), or by wrist actigraphy in Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE association with a sleep log (averaged over at least seven days with unrestricted sleep).4 E. Insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE is ruled out (if deemed necessary, by lack of improvement of sleepiness DISEASE after an adequate trial of increased nocturnal time in bed, preferably confirmed by at least a week of wrist actigraphy).
F. The hypersomnolence DISEASE and/or MSLT findings are not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE , other medical or psychiatric disorder DISEASE , or use of drugs or medications.
Notes .
Severe and prolonged sleep inertia, known as sleep drunkenness (defined as prolonged difficulty waking up with repeated returns to sleep, irritability DISEASE , automatic behavior, and confusion DISEASE ) and/or long (> 1 hour), unrefreshing naps are additional supportive clinical features.
2. A high sleep efficiency (≥ 90%) on the preceding polysomnogram is a supportive finding (as long as sleep insufficiency DISEASE is ruled out).
3. The total 24-hour sleep time required for diagnosis may need to be adapted to account for normal changes in sleep time associated with stages of development in children and adolescents as well as for variability across cultures in all age groups.
4. Occasionally, patients fulfilling other criteria may have an MSLT mean sleep latency longer than 8 minutes and total 24-hour sleep time shorter than 660 minutes.
Clinical judgment should be used in deciding if these patients should be considered to have idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE (IH).
Great caution should be exercised to exclude other conditions that might mimic the disorder.
A repeat MSLT at a later date is advisable if the clinical suspicion for IH remains high.
Essential Features IH is characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE that occurs in the absence of cat- aplexy, is accompanied by no more than one SOREMP DISEASE on MSLT and preceding poly- somnogram combined, and is not adequately explained by another disorder.
Other dis- orders causing sleepiness must be carefully considered and excluded, especially insuf- ficient sleep syndrome DISEASE .
Objective evidence of hypersomnolence must be demonstrated by an MSLT showing a mean sleep latency of ≤ CHEMICAL 8 minutes or by polysomnography or wrist actigraphy showing a total 24-hour sleep time of ≥ 660 minutes.
A prolonged and severe form of sleep inertia, historically known as sleep drunkenness, consists of prolonged difficulty waking up with repeated returns to sleep, irritability DISEASE , automatic behavior, and confusion DISEASE .
It is reported in 36% to 66% of patients with IH in differ- ent series.
Subjects typically do not easily awaken to alarm clocks and frequently use special devices or procedures to wake up.
Naps are generally long, often more than 60 minutes, and described as unrefreshing DISEASE by 46% to 78% of patients.
Sleep efficiency on polysomnogram is usually high (mean 90% to 94%).
Self-reported total sleep time is longer than in controls and is ≥ 10 hours in at least 30% of patients.
Associated Features Associated symptoms which suggest a dysfunction of the autonomic nervous system DISEASE may be present.
These symptoms include headache DISEASE , orthostatic disturbance DISEASE , perception of temperature dysregulation, and peripheral vascular complaints (Raynaud-type phe- nomena with cold hands and feet).
Sleep paralysis DISEASE and hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE may also be reported, but the frequency is uncertain (4% to 40% in different series).
Clinical and Pathologic Subtypes The 2005 2nd edition of the International Classification of Sleep Disorders divided IH into two disorders: IH with long sleep time, and IH without long sleep time.
IH is likely a heterogeneous condition, the pathophysiology of which is currently unknown.
However, recent studies suggest that a division of the disorder based on the length of nocturnal sleep lacks validity.
Comparison of patients with ≥ 10 hours of sleep to those with < 10 hours show no differences in Epworth Sleepiness Scale scores, MSLT mean sleep latencies, or percentage with sleep drunkenness DISEASE , unrefreshing DISEASE naps, hypnago- gic hallucinations DISEASE , or sleep paralysis DISEASE .
The only reported differences are that the group with long sleep is somewhat younger and thinner, with lower Horne-Ostberg scores and marginally higher sleep efficiency.
If MSLT mean sleep latencies are not used as a diagnostic criterion, the distribution of latencies is unimodal, suggesting no sepa- rate subtypes.
In addition, an actigraphy study has shown that patients with IH tend to overestimate their sleep time by a mean of 0.99 hours, thus making the fundamental criterion for distinguishing between patients with long and shorter sleep inaccurate.
Clinicians may wish to continue to note sleep duration as an important clinical feature, but the caveats discussed above should be clearly considered.
Any future separation of IH into distinct conditions must await advances in understanding the underlying biology.
Demographics Prevalence and incidence of IH are not known.
Some studies have suggested a higher prevalence in women.
163 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Predisposing and Precipitating Factors In contrast to narcolepsy DISEASE , the disorder is not known to be HLA associated, and no con- sistent precipitating factor has been identified.
Familial Patterns A familial predisposition to hypersomnia DISEASE has been reported but rigorous studies have not been performed.
Onset, Course, and Complications The mean age of onset of IH in different series is 16.6–21.2 years.
Once established, the disorder is generally stable in severity and long lasting, although a spontaneous remission rate of 14% has been reported in one series.
Complications are mostly social and professional, and include poor work or school performance, reduced earnings, and loss of employment.
Developmental Issues IH frequently develops in adolescence.
Exclusion of other causes of hypersomno- lence in that age group, including delayed sleep-wake phase disorder, obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE , insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE , and use of recreational drugs, is essential.
Early in the development of narcolepsy DISEASE , SOREMPs DISEASE may not be present on MSLT; therefore, some patients may need to be reclassified later as narcolepsy DISEASE type 2.
If the 24-hour total sleep time is used to confirm the diagnosis of IH in a child or adolescent, normal values may need to be adapted to account for changes in sleep time associated with stages of development.
Pathology and Pathophysiology The pathophysiology of IH is unknown.
Neurochemical studies measuring monoamine metabolites in the CSF DISEASE have been inconclusive.
CSF hypocretin-1 concentrations in patients with IH are normal.
CSF histamine CHEMICAL levels have been reported to be low in patients with narcolepsy DISEASE and IH, but a recent study did not confirm these findings.
Objective Findings Polysomnographic monitoring generally demonstrates NREM and REM sleep in expected proportions with normal REM latency.
Total sleep time is often prolonged.
Sleep apnea DISEASE should be either absent or adequately treated before diagnosing this disor- der, with special attention paid to excluding significant respiratory effort related arous- als.
The MSLT should not show more than one SOREMP DISEASE (or none if a SOREMP DISEASE was observed on the preceding night’s polysomnogram (PSG)).
The mean sleep latency on the MSLT is usually shorter than in controls but longer than in most patients with nar- colepsy, averaging 8.3 and 7.8 minutes in two large studies.
In patients with MSLT mean latencies > 8 minutes, prolonged sleep monitoring should be performed by polysomnography (24 hours) or wrist actigraphy (7 days with unre- stricted sleep) after correction of sleep deprivation, exclusion of other sleep disorders DISEASE , and discontinuation of sedating medication as required for an MSLT (see Narcolepsy– Objective Findings).
Total 24-hour sleep time in adults (major sleep episode plus naps) must be ≥ 660 minutes (note that the use of 24-hour PSG monitoring for the diagnosis of IH CHEMICAL has been validated against controls, but the use of seven days of actigraphic mon- DISEASE itoring still awaits validation).
Differential Diagnosis IH may be confused with OSA DISEASE , especially when respiratory-related arousals DISEASE (rather than apneas or hypopneas DISEASE ) are present.
Narcolepsy DISEASE type 2 is distinguished from IH by the presence of two or more sleep onset REM periods on the MSLT or preceding PSG.
Insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE must be carefully excluded by extending the patient’s sleep before testing.
Historical information, physical examination, and, if indicated, laboratory testing including brain imaging should help rule out hypersomnolence DISEASE due to a medical disorder.
In particular, posttraumatic hypersomnolence DISEASE , residual hyper- somnolence DISEASE following adequate treatment of sleep apnea DISEASE , and sleep fragmentation due to pain DISEASE may mimic IH.
Hypersomnolence DISEASE due to a medication or substance must be considered and ruled out by discontinuation of possible causative agents, if clinically appropriate.
Hypersomnia DISEASE associated with a psychiatric disorder DISEASE should be consid- ered in patients with a psychiatric DISEASE condition, most typically depression DISEASE .
The complaint of excessive sleepiness DISEASE and prolonged sleep may be rather similar to that of patients with IH, except that it may vary from day to day and is often associated with poor sleep at night.
The MSLT in hypersomnia DISEASE associated with a psychiatric disorder DISEASE does not demonstrate a short mean sleep latency.
Chronic fatigue syndrome DISEASE is character- ized by persistent or relapsing fatigue DISEASE that does not resolve with sleep or rest.
Patients clearly complain of fatigue DISEASE rather than excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE , and the mean MSLT sleep latency is normal.
Long sleepers feel fully refreshed and do not experience daytime sleepiness DISEASE if they are allowed to sleep as long as they need, in contrast with patients with IH who continue to feel sleepy regardless of prior sleep duration.
Unresolved Issues and Future Directions There is a paucity of knowledge regarding the neurobiology of IH.
Further research in this area, as well as more precise characterization of clinical characteristics and treat- ment response, is required.
165 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Bibliography Ali M, Auger RR, Slocumb NL, Morgenthaler TI.
Idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE : clinical features and response to treatment.
J Clin Sleep Med 2009;5:562–8.
Anderson KN, Pilsworth S, Sharples RD, Smith IE, Shneerson JM.
Idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE : a study of 77 cases.
Sleep 2007;30:1274–81.
Bassetti C, Aldrich MS.
Idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE : a series of 42 patients.
Brain 1997;120:1423–35.
Dauvilliers Y, Delallee N, Jaussent I, et al.
Normal cerebrospinal fluid histamine CHEMICAL and tele-methylhistamine CHEMICAL levels in hypersomnia DISEASE conditions.
Sleep 2012;35:1359–66.
Kanbayashi T, Kodama T DISEASE , Kondo H, et al.
CSH histamine CHEMICAL contents in narcolepsy DISEASE , idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE and obstructive sleep apnea syndrome DISEASE .
Sleep 2009;32:181–7.
Vernet C, Arnulf I. Idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE with and without long sleep time: a controlled series of 75 patients.
Sleep 2009;32:753–9.
Vernet C, Leu-Semenescu S, Buzare MA, Arnulf I. Subjective sleepiness DISEASE in idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE : beyond excessive sleepiness DISEASE .
J Sleep Res 2010;19:525–34.
Kleine-Levin Syndrome ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 327.13 Alternate Names Recurrent hypersomnia DISEASE , periodic hypersomnolence.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-E must be met ICD-10-CM code:
G47.13 A.
The patient experiences at least two recurrent episodes of excessive sleepiness DISEASE and sleep duration, each persisting for two days to five weeks.
B. Episodes recur usually more than once a year and at least once every 18 months.
C. The patient has normal alertness, cognitive function, behavior, and mood between episodes.
D.
The patient must demonstrate at least one of the following during episodes:
1. Cognitive dysfunction DISEASE .
2. Altered perception.
3.
Eating disorder DISEASE ( anorexia DISEASE or hyperphagia DISEASE ).
4. Disinhibited behavior (such as hypersexuality DISEASE ).
E.
The hypersomnolence DISEASE and related symptoms are not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE , other medical, neurologic, or psychiatric disorder DISEASE (especially bipolar disorder DISEASE ), or use of drugs or medications.
166 Essential Features Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE is characterized by relapsing-remitting episodes of severe hypersomnolence DISEASE in association with cognitive, psychiatric, and behavioral distur- bances. DISEASE
A typical episode lasts a median 10 days (range, 2.5–80 days), with rare epi- sodes lasting several weeks to months.
The first episode is often triggered by an infec- tion or alcohol CHEMICAL intake, with further episodes recurring every 1–12 months (median three months) for years.
During episodes, patients may sleep as long as 16 to 20 hours per day, waking or getting up only to eat and void ( incontinence DISEASE is not observed).
They remain rousable, but are irritable DISEASE if prevented from sleeping.
When they are awake during episodes, most patients are exhausted, apathetic, confused, and slow in speaking and answering.
Anterograde amnesia DISEASE is typical.
Almost all report a dreamlike, altered perception of the environment (derealization).
Less commonly, patients eat ravenously (66%, although one third eat less), are hypersexual DISEASE (53%, principally men), childish, depressed DISEASE (53%, predominantly women), and anxious at being left alone and seeing strangers, and experience hallucinations DISEASE and delusions DISEASE (30%).
Patients are remark- ably normal between episodes with regard to sleep, cognition, mood, and eating.
The disease typically resolves after a median of 14 years, except in adult-onset DISEASE cases, when the course may be more prolonged.
The simultaneous occurrence of all these symp- toms is the exception rather than the rule, with hypersomnolence DISEASE being more char- acteristic at the disease onset and during the first part of the episodes, and disinhib- ited behaviors being evident during only a few episodes.
In occasional cases, isolated recurrent hypersomnolence DISEASE may be the only symptom.
Amnesia DISEASE , transient dysphoria DISEASE , or elation DISEASE with insomnia DISEASE may signal the termination of an episode.
Associated Features Physical examination is unremarkable, except for general psychomotor slowing.
Social and occupational impairment during attacks DISEASE is often severe, with teenagers bedridden for days, but can be variable depending on the frequency, severity, and duration of episodes.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Menstrual-related Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE (alternate name: menstrual-related hyper- somnia DISEASE ):
This descriptor is used when episodes are exclusively associated with men- struation (occurring just before or during menses), a condition reported in only 18 women worldwide.
Hypersomnolence DISEASE episodes in these cases have been associated with compulsive eating in 65%, sexual disinhibition in 29%, and depressive mood DISEASE in 35%.
Episodes last 3 to 15 days and recur less than three times a year.
One boy with Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE is reported to have a sister affected by menstrual-related hypersomnolence.
Menstrual-related hypersomnia DISEASE may be a variant of Kleine-Levin DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence syndrome DISEASE , although response to contraceptive doses of estrogen CHEMICAL and progesterone CHEMICAL , reported in some cases, suggests a reproductive endocrine disturbance DISEASE .
Demographics Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE is rare, with a prevalence estimated around 1 to 2 cases per million.
Roughly 500 cases have been reported to date in the literature, from all countries in which the disease has been investigated.
The disease starts during the second decade in 81% of patients, with a male/female ratio of 2:1.
Adults and younger children may also be affected.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Birth and developmental problems, as well as Jewish heritage, are risk factors for devel- oping the syndrome.
The frequency of the HLA DQB1*02 was increased compared with controls in a retrospective, multicenter series of 30 patients with Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE , but not in another larger prospective series (n = 108).
A flu-like illness DISEASE or an infection DISEASE of the upper airway (and more rarely gastroenteritis DISEASE ) is often reported imme- diately prior to the onset of the first episode, and more rarely before relapses.
Other less frequently reported triggering events include alcohol CHEMICAL consumption, head trauma DISEASE , travel, or exposure to anesthesia.
Familial Patterns Familial cases of Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE are found in 5% of patients, including twins, parent-child, siblings, and uncle-nephew associations.
There is no increased history of mood disorders DISEASE in family members of patients.
Onset, Course, and Complications Early adolescence (second decade) is the usual age of onset.
The course of Kleine-
Levin syndrome DISEASE is characterized by recurrent episodes of severe sleepiness DISEASE , lasting up to several weeks, with normal functioning between episodes.
Several long-term studies suggest an often-benign course, with episodes lessening in duration, severity, and fre- quency over a median course of 14 years.
Male sex, age at onset younger than 12 years or older than 20 years, as well as the presence of hypersexuality DISEASE during episodes, predict longer disease duration.
Complications are mainly social and occupational.
In rare cases, subjects have been reported to choke while eating voraciously, to have suicidal thoughts, or to be involved in a car accident.
A reduced long-term working memory capacity following episodes was reported in eight patients with Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE .
Developmental Issues Adolescents are affected in most cases.
However, the onset of the condition has been reported in children as young as four years.
168 Pathology and Pathophysiology Postmortem examination of the central nervous system has been performed in only four cases, with inconsistent findings.
One subject showed significant perivascular lymphocytic infiltrations in the hypothalamus, amygdala, and the grey matter of the temporal lobes; a second demonstrated similar infiltrations in the thalamus; and a third in the diencephalon and the midbrain with a suggestion of mild localized encephali- tis.
In the fourth case, a smaller locus coeruleus and decreased pigmentation in the substantia nigra were reported.
Magnetic resonance imaging was unremarkable.
In contrast, functional brain imaging studies during episodes are frequently abnormal, showing hypometabolism in the thalamus, hypothalamus, mesial temporal lobe, and frontal lobe.
Some of these abnormalities persist during asymptomatic periods in half of the patients.
An autoimmune basis for the disorder is suggested clinically (onset occurs during adolescence, often in conjunction with an infection DISEASE ) and by the occa- sional association with HLA DQB1*02.
Objective Findings Routine electroencephalograms obtained during episodes have shown general slowing of background electroencephalographic activity and often paroxysmal—0.5-2.0-sec- ond—bursts of bisynchronous, generalized, moderate- to high-voltage 5- to 7-Hz waves.
Polysomnography studies are often difficult to interpret, and results are depen- dent on the duration of recording (overnight vs. 24-hour monitoring) as well as the timing (at the beginning versus the end of episodes or at onset of the disease or later in its course).
Twenty-four-hour polysomnography demonstrates prolonged total sleep time (a mean 11–12 hours), and 18 hours or more in some reports.
During nocturnal polysomnography in 17 children, nighttime slow wave sleep percentage was decreased during the first half of the episodes, and REM sleep decreased during the second half.
Results of the MSLT are highly dependent on the subjects ’ DISEASE willingness to comply with the procedure, and may either be normal or abnormal, showing short latencies or mul- tiple SOREMPs DISEASE .
CSF cytology and protein are normal.
CSF levels of hypocretin-1 were within normal range in 16 patients, although intraepisodic levels are lower than interepisodic levels.
Computed tomography scans and magnetic resonance imaging are normal.
Brain functional imaging is abnormal in most cases, with hypoperfusion DISEASE of the left or right temporal and frontal lobes as well as the diencephalon.
These abnor- malities are present during the episode of hypersomnolence DISEASE and sometimes between episodes.
Hormone levels are normal, as are 24-hour secretory patterns.
Differential Diagnosis Recurrent waxing and waning episodes of sleepiness DISEASE may be secondary to struc- tural insults of the central nervous system.
Tumors DISEASE within the third ventricle (such as Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence colloid cysts DISEASE , pedunculated astrocytomas DISEASE , or, in some cases, craniopharyngiomas DISEASE ) may produce intermittent obstructions of ventricular flow DISEASE , leading to headaches DISEASE , vomiting DISEASE , vague sensorial disturbances, and a paroxysmal impairment of alertness.
Encephalitis DISEASE , hyperammonemic encephalopathy DISEASE , multiple sclerosis DISEASE , head trauma DISEASE , porphyria DISEASE , Lyme disease DISEASE , basilar migraine DISEASE , and complex partial status epilepticus DISEASE less frequently mimic symptoms of Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE .
Recurrent episodes of sleepiness DISEASE also are reported in the context of psychiatric disorders DISEASE , such as depression DISEASE , bipolar disorder DISEASE , seasonal affective disorder DISEASE , and somatoform disorder DISEASE .
However, the onset and offset of symptoms are less abrupt than in Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE and persist to some extent between episodes.
Other differential diagnoses include excessive sleepiness DISEASE due to a medication or substance, OSA DISEASE , narcolepsy DISEASE , IH, and insufficient sleep.
In these disor- ders, however, the complaint of excessive sleepiness DISEASE occurs daily and is usually not recurrent or periodic.
There is no evidence that Kleine-Levin syndrome DISEASE occurs as a result of a seizure DISEASE disorder.
Unresolved Issues and Future Directions The pathophysiology of this disorder is not known.
Evidence to date suggests that a localized but multifocal encephalopathy DISEASE occurs during episodes of Kleine-Levin syn- drome DISEASE , as functional imaging and electroencephalography (EEG) slowing indicate tha- lamic, temporal, and frontal lobe involvement.
The cause of these episodic abnormali- ties may be genetic, autoimmune, inflammatory, or metabolic.

Neurology 2002;59:1739–45.

170 Hypersomnia DISEASE Due to a Medical Disorder ICD-9-CM code: 327.14 CHEMICAL ICD-10-CM code: G47.14 Alternate Names Not applicable.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-D must be met A.
The patient has daily periods of irrepressible need to sleep or daytime lapses into sleep occurring for at least three months.
B. The daytime sleepiness DISEASE occurs as a consequence of a significant underlying medical or neurological condition.
C.
If an MSLT is performed, the mean sleep latency is ≤ CHEMICAL 8 minutes, and fewer than two sleep onset REM periods ( SOREMPs DISEASE ) are observed.1 D.
The symptoms are not better explained by another untreated sleep disorder,2 a mental disorder DISEASE , or the effects of medications or drugs.
Notes .
In the subtype of residual hypersomnolence after treatment of obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE , the MSLT mean latency may be > 8 minutes.
2. Should criteria for narcolepsy DISEASE be fulfilled, a diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1 or type 2 due to a medical condition should be used rather than hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medical condition.
3.
In patients with severe neurological or medical disorders in whom it is not possible or desirable to perform sleep studies, the diagnosis can be made by clinical criteria.
Essential Features Patients with this disorder have excessive nocturnal sleep, daytime sleepiness DISEASE , or excessive napping DISEASE that is attributable to a coexisting medical or neurological disor- der.
Daytime sleepiness DISEASE may be of variable severity and may resemble that of narco- lepsy (i.e., refreshing naps) or idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE (i.e., long periods of unrefresh- ing sleep).
Sleep paralysis DISEASE , hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE , or automatic behavior may be present, but if the patient has cataplexy DISEASE , the MSLT shows two or more SOREMPs DISEASE , or CSF Hcrt-1 levels are low, then narcolepsy DISEASE (type 1 or type 2) due to a medical condi- tion should be diagnosed.
In patients with both sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE and hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medical disorder, the latter diagnosis should be made only if the hypersomnolence DISEASE persists after adequate treatment of the sleep disordered breathing.
Hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medical disorder is only diagnosed if the medical condition is Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE judged to be directly causing the excessive sleepiness DISEASE .
Hypersomnolence DISEASE has been described in association with a large range of conditions, including metabolic enceph- alopathy, head trauma DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , brain tumors DISEASE , encephalitis DISEASE , systemic inflammation DISEASE (e.g., chronic infections DISEASE , rheumatologic disorders DISEASE , cancer DISEASE ), genetic disorders, and neurode- generative diseases.
Associated Features Not applicable or known.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Many medical conditions can cause hypersomnolence.
Hypersomnia DISEASE secondary to Parkinson disease DISEASE : Significant hypersomnolence docu- mented by MSLT has been reported in some cases of Parkinson disease DISEASE .
Hypersomnia DISEASE in Parkinson disease DISEASE may be due to insufficient control of nocturnal symptoms, result- ing in insufficient sleep and daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
If so, the diagnosis should be insomnia disorder DISEASE .
Cases of hypersomnolence DISEASE that are due to the side effects of dopaminergic agents should be coded as hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medication or substance.
In other cases, however, hypersomnolence DISEASE is likely of central origin and should be classified in this section.
Parkinson disease DISEASE patients with an MSLT profile consistent with narco- lepsy should be coded as narcolepsy DISEASE due to a medical condition.
Posttraumatic hypersomnia DISEASE : Hypersomnolence DISEASE appears to be common after trau- CHEMICAL matic brain injury DISEASE ( TBI DISEASE ), with one meta-analysis suggesting a frequency of 28% of TBI DISEASE patients.
In some cases this may be caused by injury to the hypocretin/orexin neurons or other wake-promoting neural systems.
However, the prevalence of sleep related breathing disorder DISEASE (SRBD) in patients with head trauma DISEASE is high (frequency 23% to 25%).
The nature of the relationship between TBI DISEASE and OSA DISEASE remains undefined.
Therefore, control of other potential sleep disorders DISEASE is necessary prior to making a diagnosis of hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medical disorder ( posttraumatic hypersomnia DISEASE ).
Genetic disorders associated with primary central nervous system somnolence DISEASE : Genetic disorders such as Niemann Pick type C disease DISEASE and Norrie disease DISEASE have been associated with daytime somnolence DISEASE .
Prader-Willi syndrome DISEASE , myotonic dystrophy DISEASE , Moebius syndrome DISEASE , and fragile X syndrome DISEASE are other examples of centrally mediated sleepiness.
A number of genetic disorders have been reported to be associated with both sleep disordered breathing DISEASE and hypersomnolence DISEASE (e.g., myotonic dystrophy DISEASE and Prader-Willi syndrome DISEASE ).
In these cases, hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medical disorder should be diagnosed only if the excessive sleepiness DISEASE is still present after adequate treatment of the SRBD.
Smith-Magenis syndrome DISEASE is a neurodevelopmental disorder DISEASE characterized by dysmorphic facial features, behavioral disturbance DISEASE with onset in early childhood, daytime somnolence DISEASE , and night awakenings in association with reversal in the timing of the melatonin CHEMICAL secretion pattern (i.e., the serum levels of melatonin CHEMICAL are high during the daytime and low at night).
Hypersomnia DISEASE secondary to brain tumors DISEASE , infections DISEASE , or other central nervous system lesions: Strokes DISEASE , infections DISEASE , tumors DISEASE , sarcoidosis DISEASE , or neurodegenerative lesions of the brain, especially in the hypothalamus or rostral midbrain, may produce daytime sleepi- ness.
In patients with brain tumors DISEASE , the sleepiness DISEASE may be due to the tumor DISEASE itself or the effects of treatment.
Hypersomnia DISEASE secondary to endocrine disorder DISEASE : Hypothyroidism DISEASE is the most recog- nized example of this condition.
Hypersomnia DISEASE secondary to metabolic encephalopathy DISEASE : Hepatic encephalopathy DISEASE , chronic renal insufficiency DISEASE , adrenal or pancreatic insufficiency, exposure to toxins, and certain inherited metabolic disorders DISEASE in childhood may result in hypersomnolence.
Residual hypersomnia DISEASE in patients with adequately treated OSA DISEASE : Some patients with SRBDs DISEASE report persistent sleepiness DISEASE despite apparently adequate amounts of sleep and optimal treatment of their sleep apnea DISEASE and other known sleep disorders DISEASE .
They may have moderately elevated Epworth Sleepiness Scale scores, but most have mean sleep laten- cies > 8 minutes on MSLT.
They also report more fatigue DISEASE , apathy DISEASE , and depression DISEASE .
It is essential that sleep disordered breathing be fully treated for at least three months, and that control of the SRBD be confirmed by: (1) a download of positive airway pressure (PAP) machine compliance data demonstrating optimal usage (preferably at least 7 hours a night); and (2) a polysomnogram demonstrating elimination of essentially all sleep disordered breathing.
Other causes of sleepiness DISEASE , such as insufficient sleep syn- drome DISEASE , psychiatric disorders DISEASE , or hypersomnolence DISEASE related to medications or drugs must be eliminated.
Animal studies have suggested this residual sleepiness DISEASE could be caused by hypoxic injury DISEASE to monoamine systems.
Obesity DISEASE itself may also contribute, and more research is needed to understand the underlying mechanism.
Demographics Demographics reflect those of the underlying condition.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Predisposing and precipitating factors reflect those of the underlying condition.
173 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Familial Patterns Familial patterns reflect those of the underlying condition.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset, course, and complications reflect those of the underlying condition.
Developmental Issues Daytime naps are normal in children younger than 3-4 years; thus, it is difficult to dif- ferentiate physiologic napping DISEASE from hypersomnolence DISEASE in children younger than this age.
Inattentiveness, mood swings DISEASE , and learning difficulties DISEASE often accompany child- hood daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
Reference values for the MSLT in children differ from those of adults, and this issue should be considered during the evaluation process.
Special attention should be paid to genetic disorders in children.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Pathology and pathophysiology reflect those of the underlying condition.
Objective Findings Nocturnal polysomnography may show normal or moderately disturbed sleep.
In patients with a metabolic encephalopathy DISEASE , EEG abnormalities may be present, such as an increase in the amount of slow wave sleep.
MSLT must show fewer than 2 SOREMPs DISEASE and usually will show a mean sleep latency less than eight minutes.
If clin- ically significant sleep disordered breathing or periodic limb movements are present, they should be treated prior to diagnosing hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medical disorder.
Differential Diagnosis See the differential diagnosis in previous hypersomnolence sections.
The major chal- lenge in establishing a diagnosis of hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medical disorder is deter- mining whether the associated medical or neurological disorder DISEASE is truly causing the hypersomnolence.
Unresolved Issues and Future Directions
This area is understudied.
Multiple complex neurological, metabolic, endocrine, and medication-related interactions may be present.
Further studies are needed to define the reciprocal relationships between sleep disorders DISEASE and other diseases.
Bibliography Bruin VM, Bittencourt LR, Tufik S. Sleep-wake disturbances DISEASE in Parkinson’s disease DISEASE : current evidence regarding diagnostic and therapeutic decisions.
Eur Neurol 2012;67:257–67.

Selective loss of catecholaminergic wake active neurons in a murine sleep apnea DISEASE model.

Hypersomnia DISEASE Due to a Medication or Substance ICD-9-CM code: 292.85 (drug-induced); 291.82 (alcohol-induced) ICD-10-CM code: F11-F19 (see table in Appendix B for detailed coding instructions)
Alternate Names Hypersomnia DISEASE due to substance abuse DISEASE , hypersomnia DISEASE due to stimulant withdrawal, hyper- somnia CHEMICAL due to sedative abuse, toxic hypersomnia DISEASE , toxic encephalopathy DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A.
The patient has daily periods of irrepressible need to sleep or daytime lapses into sleep.
B. The daytime sleepiness DISEASE occurs as a consequence of current medication or substance use or withdrawal from a wake-promoting medication or substance.
C. The symptoms are not better explained by another untreated sleep disorder DISEASE , medical or neurological disorder DISEASE , or mental disorder DISEASE .
Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Essential Features Patients with this disorder have excessive nocturnal sleep, daytime sleepiness DISEASE , or excessive napping DISEASE that is attributable to sedating medications, alcohol CHEMICAL , or drugs of abuse.
This diagnosis also includes hypersomnolence DISEASE associated with withdrawal from amphetamines CHEMICAL and other drugs.
If narcolepsy DISEASE or hypersomnolence DISEASE existed prior to stimulant abuse, the diagnosis of hypersomnia DISEASE due to a medication or substance should not be used.
Associated Features Associated features reflect those of the medications or substances responsible.
Clinical and Pathological Subtypes Hypersomnia DISEASE due to sedating medications: Sedation is a common side effect of many prescription medications including benzodiazepines CHEMICAL , nonbenzodiazepine CHEMICAL hypnot- ics, opioids, barbiturates, anticonvulsants, antipsychotics, anticholinergics, and some antidepressants CHEMICAL and antihistamines CHEMICAL .
Sleepiness also can occur with some dopamine CHEMICAL agonists such as pramipexole CHEMICAL or ropinirole CHEMICAL , and with many antiseizure DISEASE medications.
Though less common, sleepiness DISEASE can also occur with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, some antibiotics, antispasmodics, antiarryhthmics, and beta-blockers.
Over-the- counter medications, such as valerian and melatonin CHEMICAL , can produce sedation.
Excessive sleepiness DISEASE is especially common when these drugs are used in elderly patients or those with multiple medical conditions, or in combination.
Some tolerance to the sedative effects can occur with time.
Hypersomnia DISEASE due to substance abuse DISEASE : Daytime sleepiness DISEASE can occur with abuse of alcohol CHEMICAL , benzodiazepines CHEMICAL , barbiturates, gamma hydroxybutyrate CHEMICAL , opiates, and marijuana.
Hypersomnia DISEASE due to stimulant withdrawal: Daytime sleepiness DISEASE is common with abrupt discontinuation of stimulants.
In chronically heavy amphetamine CHEMICAL users, sleepiness DISEASE is most severe in the first week of withdrawal and can persist for up to three weeks; indi- viduals may have an increase in total sleep and daytime napping, but sleep may seem fragmented and nonrestorative DISEASE .
Significant depression DISEASE often accompanies the hyper- somnolence DISEASE .
Infrequently, sleepiness DISEASE may be a residual complaint in those who have used stimulants CHEMICAL in the past but have been abstinent for many years.
In people who regularly consume coffee or other sources of caffeine CHEMICAL , discontinuation can produce sleepiness DISEASE , fatigue DISEASE , and inattentiveness DISEASE for two to nine days.
176 Demographics Patients of any age can experience sleepiness DISEASE from sedating medications.
Stimulant abuse and the consequent sleepiness DISEASE during withdrawal are most common in adoles- cents and young adults.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Sleepiness from sedating medications may be more common in older patients and in those with multiple medical problems.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset, course, and complications reflect those of the medications or substances responsible.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Not applicable or known.
Objective Findings Polysomnography is generally unnecessary unless a concomitant sleep disorder DISEASE is sus- pected.
Polysomnography and MSLT results vary depending on the specific substance in question and the timing of the most recent intake.
With stimulant withdrawal, noc- turnal polysomnography may show normal sleep, whereas the MSLT typically demon- CHEMICAL strates a short mean sleep latency with or without multiple SOREMPs CHEMICAL .
A urine tox- icology screen may be positive for the suspected substance.
The diagnosis is often confirmed if symptoms resolve after the causal agent is removed.
Differential Diagnosis Major sleep disorders DISEASE that are associated with excessive sleepiness DISEASE , especially SRBDs DISEASE , periodic limb movement disorder DISEASE , narcolepsy DISEASE , IH, and insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE should be ruled out.
A urine drug screen should routinely accompany an MSLT as the use of or withdrawal from some medications or substances may affect MSLT test results.
Although many psychotropic medications may result in daytime sleepiness DISEASE , it is import- ant for clinicians to recognize that many psychiatric disorders DISEASE also are associated with increased prevalence of other sleep disorders DISEASE (e.g., insomnia DISEASE , SRBD, circadian disor- ders, and movement disorders DISEASE ).
Although sedative effects of the psychotropic agents Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE may contribute to sleepiness DISEASE , clinicians must maintain a high index of suspicion for other sleep related etiologies.
When other sleep disorders DISEASE are identified, multiple diag- noses may be appropriate.
Unresolved Issues and Future Directions Sedatives can worsen sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE , and more research is needed to understand and manage this interaction.

178 Hypersomnia DISEASE Associated with a Psychiatric Disorder ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 327.15 ICD-10-CM code: F51.13 Alternate Names Hypersomnia DISEASE not due to substance or known physiological condition, nonorganic hypersomnia DISEASE , pseudohypersomnia, or pseudonarcolepsy.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A.
The patient has daily periods of irrepressible need to sleep or daytime lapses into sleep occurring for at least three months.
B. The daytime sleepiness DISEASE occurs in association with a concurrent psychiatric disorder DISEASE .
C. The symptoms are not better explained by another untreated sleep disorder DISEASE , a medical or neurological disorder DISEASE , or the effects of medications or drugs.
Essential Features Patients with hypersomnia DISEASE associated with a psychiatric disorder DISEASE may report excessive nocturnal sleep, daytime sleepiness DISEASE , or excessive napping.
In addition, they often feel their sleep is of poor quality and nonrestorative.
Patients are often intensely focused on their hypersomnolence, and psychiatric DISEASE symptoms may become apparent only after prolonged interviews or psychometric testing.
Associated psychiatric DISEASE conditions include mood disorders DISEASE , conversion or undifferentiated somatoform disorder DISEASE , and less frequently other mental disorders DISEASE such as schizoaffective disorder DISEASE , adjustment disor- der, or personality disorders.
Associated Features Poor work attendance, spending full days in bed several times a week, or abruptly leaving work because of a perceived need to sleep are common symptoms.
Patients may also have social withdrawal, apathy DISEASE , and feelings of low energy.
Clinical and Pathological Subtypes Hypersomnia DISEASE associated with mood disorder DISEASE :
Hypersomnolence DISEASE in the context of depression DISEASE is a frequent feature of atypical depression DISEASE and bipolar II disorder DISEASE (recur- rent major depressive episodes DISEASE with hypomanic DISEASE episodes).
In seasonal affective disor- der, daytime fatigue DISEASE , loss of concentration, increased appetite for carbohydrates, and weight gain DISEASE are reported.
MSLT results are usually normal, but long hours spent in bed are reported.
Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence Hypersomnia DISEASE associated with a conversion disorder or somatic symptom disorder DISEASE : Pseudohypersomnia or pseudonarcolepsy, sometimes with pseudocataplexy, has been described.
Demographics Hypersomnia DISEASE associated with a psychiatric disorder DISEASE accounts for 5% to 7% of hyper- somnolence DISEASE cases.
Women are more susceptible than men, and the typical age range is between 20 and 50 years.
In patients with major depression DISEASE , the prevalence of hypersom- nolence ranges from 5% to over 50% depending on how hypersomnolence DISEASE is defined.
Hypersomnolence DISEASE affects over 50% of patients with seasonal affective disorder DISEASE .
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Not applicable or known.
Familial Patterns Not known, except for the familial patterns of certain psychiatric disorders (e.g., bipolar II disorder DISEASE ).
Onset, Course, and Complications The mean age of onset is usually in the third decade in both sexes.
With major depres- sion, hypersomnolence DISEASE may persist even after the depressive DISEASE episode improves, and persistent hypersomnolence DISEASE is associated with increased risk of recurrent depression DISEASE .
Complications are mostly social and occupational.
Developmental Issues Hypersomnolence DISEASE occurs in 10% to 20% of children with major depression DISEASE , some- times in combination with insomnia DISEASE , but sleep quality appears normal.
Although sleep problems may develop at any stage of depression DISEASE , they are most pronounced during the acute phase.
Children and adolescents with depression DISEASE who manifest either insomnia DISEASE or hypersomnolence DISEASE generally manifest more pronounced symptoms, such as anhedo- nia and weight loss DISEASE .
Pathology and Pathophysiology The underlying cause is unknown.
Although patients with this disorder report sleep- iness, sleep studies reveal little or no evidence of increased propensity to sleep.
In some patients, fragmented nighttime sleep may contribute to their daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
Because of uncertainty about the nature of the relationship, the term “ hypersomnia DISEASE associated with a psychiatric disorder DISEASE ” is preferred to “ hypersomnia DISEASE due to a psychi- atric disorder.”
180 Objective Findings Nocturnal polysomnography typically shows a prolonged total time in bed with frag- mented sleep.
Sleep latency is prolonged, wake time after sleep onset is increased, awakenings may be frequent and prolonged, and sleep efficiency is low.
REM sleep latency may be shortened in the case of untreated depression DISEASE .
Sleep latencies on the MSLT are often within normal limits, a result contrasting with the subjective complaint of daytime sleepiness DISEASE and an elevated score on the Epworth Sleepiness Scale.
24-hour continuous sleep-recording studies typically show considerable time spent in bed during day and night, a behavior sometime referred to as clinophilia.
Psychiatric inter- views and evaluations are essential to diagnose the underlying psychiatric DISEASE condition.
Differential Diagnosis As there are no definitive tests for diagnosing hypersomnolence DISEASE associated with a psy- chiatric disorder, it is essential to rule out other common causes of sleepiness DISEASE such as insufficient sleep, sedation from medications or substances, SRBD, periodic limb movement disorder DISEASE , and IH.
Chronic fatigue syndrome DISEASE is characterized by persistent or relapsing fatigue DISEASE that does not resolve with sleep or rest, but the main complaint is usually fatigue DISEASE rather than sleepiness.
Insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE is associated with excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE , impaired concentration, and lowered energy level, but a detailed history of the subject’s current sleep schedule reveals chronic sleep deprivation.
Unresolved Issues and Future Directions The lack of concordance between subjective and objective findings raises multiple issues.
It is unclear to what extent these patients are objectively sleepy or, instead, suffer from decreased energy and lack of interest that confines them to bed.
More research is needed to create an effective definition of hypersomnolence DISEASE in this population and to develop tools for measuring it.
Finally, future efforts should define the mechanism through which some patients express their psychiatric DISEASE symptoms as excessive sleepiness DISEASE .

Lancet 1998;352:1369–74.
van den Berg JF, Luijendijk HJ, Tulen JH, Hofman A, Neven AK, Tiemeier H. Sleep in depression DISEASE and anxiety disorders DISEASE : a population-based study of elderly persons.
J Clin Psychiatry 2009;70:1105–13.
Vgontzas AN, Bixler EO, Kales A, Criley C, Vela-Bueno A. Differences in nocturnal and daytime sleep between primary and psychiatric hypersomnia DISEASE : diagnosis and treatment implications.
Psychosom Med 2000;62:220–6.
Insufficient Sleep Syndrome ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 307.44 ICD-10-CM code: F51.12 Alternate Names Behaviorally induced insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE , insufficient nocturnal sleep, chronic sleep deprivation, sleep restriction.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-F must be met A.
The patient has daily periods of irrepressible need to sleep or daytime lapses into sleep or, in the case of prepubertal children, there is a complaint of behavioral abnormalities DISEASE attributable to sleepiness.
B. The patient’s sleep time, established by personal or collateral history, sleep logs, or actigraphy1 DISEASE is usually shorter than expected for age.2 C. The curtailed sleep pattern is present most days for at least three months.
D.
The patient curtails sleep time by such measures as an alarm clock or being awakened by another person and generally sleeps longer when such measures are not used, such as on weekends or vacations.
E. Extension of total sleep time results in resolution of the symptoms of sleepiness DISEASE .
F. The symptoms are not better explained by another untreated sleep disorder DISEASE , the effects of medications or drugs, or other medical, neurologic, or mental disorder DISEASE .
Notes .
If there is doubt about the accuracy of personal history or sleep logs, then actigraphy should be performed, preferably for at least two weeks.
2. In the case of long sleepers, reported habitual sleep periods may be normal based on age.
However, these sleep periods may be insufficient for these patients.
182 Essential Features Insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE occurs when an individual persistently fails to obtain the amount of sleep required to maintain normal levels of alertness and wakefulness.
The individual is chronically sleep deprived as a result of failure to achieve necessary sleep time due to reduced time in bed.
There is a U-shaped relationship between age and average sleep time, with the minimum in middle-aged individuals.
Examination reveals unimpaired or above-average ability to initiate and maintain sleep, with little or no psychopathology.
Physical examination reveals no medical explanation for the patient ’s sleepiness DISEASE .
A detailed history of the sleep pattern reveals a substantial dis- parity between the need for sleep and the amount actually obtained.
The significance of this disparity often goes unappreciated by the patient.
Sleep time that is markedly extended on weekend nights or during holidays compared to weekday nights is also suggestive of this disorder.
A therapeutic trial of a longer major sleep episode can reverse the symptoms.
In individuals with physiologic sleep requirements significantly in excess of seven to eight hours, reported “average” amounts of sleep (e.g., seven hours/night) may, in fact, be insufficient.
Additional symptoms such as sleep paralysis DISEASE and hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE may occur.
Associated Features Depending upon chronicity and extent of sleep loss DISEASE , individuals with this condition may show irritability DISEASE , concentration and attention deficits, reduced vigilance, distract- ibility, reduced motivation, anergia DISEASE , dysphoria DISEASE , fatigue DISEASE , restlessness, uncoordination DISEASE , and malaise.
Secondary symptoms may become the main focus of the patient, serving to obscure the primary cause of the difficulties.
Psychologically and somatically normal individuals who chronically obtain less sleep than they physiologically require typi- cally experience daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
Situational factors such as demands of the family and work schedule may, on occasion, make it very difficult to obtain adequate sleep.
Clinical and Pathophysiologic Subtypes Not applicable or known.
Demographics Insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE affects all ages and both sexes.
It may be more frequent in adolescence, when sleep need is high, but social pressure and tendency to delay sleep often lead to chronic restricted sleep.
Cultural factors may also influence sleep dura- tion, with students from different countries reporting sleep time varying between six and eight hours per night.
183 Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Social and psychological factors may impact nocturnal sleep length and daytime sleep- iness.
Cultural habits such as the siesta may enhance evening alertness at the expense of reducing nocturnal sleep efficiency.
Also, the evening preference chronotype predis- poses to complaints of insomnia DISEASE and insufficient sleep.
The association of eveningness DISEASE with insufficient sleep persists after controlling for variables such as sex, age, and sleep duration.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications This condition results in increased daytime sleepiness DISEASE , concentration problems, lowered energy level, and malaise.
If unchecked, insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE may predispose to depression DISEASE and other psychological difficulties, as well as poor work performance and withdrawal from family and social activities.
Abuse of stimulants CHEMICAL may also occur.
Traffic accidents DISEASE or injury at work may result.
Developmental Issues Insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE is a common problem in adolescents.
It should be differ- entiated from delayed sleep phase disorder DISEASE , the effects of recreational drug use, and school avoidance behavior.
Increased predisposition to substance use and accidents DISEASE in teens may be consequent to insufficient sleep.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Symptoms are due to normal physiological and psychological responses to sleep depri- vation.
Sleep restriction studies in normal volunteers have shown that even mild sleep restriction (for example, six hours of nocturnal sleep per night) results in a correspond- ing decrease in performance and increased sleepiness.
Sleep restriction to four hours per night (i.e., extension of wakefulness to 20 hours per day) will likely lead to greater buildup of homeostatic sleep drive during the waking hours and greater likelihood of impaired performance on a psychomotor vigilance task.
The effects of sleep depriva- tion on neurobehavioral performance measures may vary with the nature of the task being considered.
In some long sleepers, it is important to be aware that extending sleep to nine or more hours often results in improved performance.
The diagnosis of insufficient sleep syn- drome may be especially difficult to make in subjects who have a physiologic need for unusually large amounts of sleep.
184 Objective Findings Actigraphy combined with sleep diaries maintained for a 2- to 3-week period may be helpful by documenting total time in bed, sleep latency, total sleep time, and sleep efficiency.
Polysomnography and MSLT are not required to establish a diagnosis of insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE .
Rather, sleep time is extended first, and the patient is reevaluated.
If a therapeutic trial with a longer sleep episode eliminates the symptoms, insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE is diagnosed.
Polysomnography, when performed, reveals reduced sleep onset latency, and high (greater than 90%) sleep efficiency.
When extended sleep is permitted, prolonged sleep time with slow wave rebound may be seen.
Noting a disparity between reported sleep at home and observed total sleep time in the sleep laboratory can be helpful.
The MSLT reveals excessive sleepiness DISEASE , with stage N1 sleep occurring in most naps, with short sleep latency.
Stage N2 sleep occurs in more than 80% of MSLT naps.
SOREMPs DISEASE can occur.
Differential Diagnosis Insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE may be confused with narcolepsy DISEASE or other hypersom- nolence disorders because an abnormal MSLT (even with two SOREMPs DISEASE ) can be observed as the result of acute or chronic sleep deprivation.
The confusion DISEASE may be most frequently encountered in adolescents or young adults.
The differential diagno- sis of insufficient sleep syndrome DISEASE includes numerous other conditions that may result in daytime sleepiness DISEASE or shortening of nocturnal sleep duration.
These include other central disorders of hypersomnolence DISEASE , long sleeper or short sleeper, SRBD, circadian rhythm sleep disorders DISEASE , insomnia disorder DISEASE , affective disorder DISEASE , and periodic limb move- ment disorder.
Unresolved Issues and Future Directions
The correlation between subjectively reported sleepiness DISEASE , performance-test decre- CHEMICAL ments, and MSLT-measured sleepiness DISEASE after sleep deprivation is poor.
Short sleepers often have a higher NREM sleep pressure, as measured by EEG delta power, than long sleepers, even if they do not complain of daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
There is interindividual susceptibility to sleep deprivation, with some people being consistently more tired and experiencing greater performance decrement after even a mild degree of sleep deprivation.
Bibliography Carskadon MA, Dement WC.
Effects of total sleep loss DISEASE on sleep tendency.
Percept Mot Skills 1979;48:495–506. Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Central Disorders of Hypersomnolence DISEASE Habeck C, Rakitin BC, Moeller J, et al.
An event related fMRI study of the neurobehavioral impact of sleep deprivation on performance of a delayed match to sample task.
Cogn Brain Res CHEMICAL 2004;18:306–21.
Merikanto I,Kronholm E, Peltonen M, Laatikainen T, Lahti T, Partonen T. Relation of chronotype to sleep complaints in the general Finnish population.
Chronobiol Int 2012;29:311–7.
Mont TH, Buysse DJ, Carrier J, Bart BD, Rose LR.
