Winkelman JW.
Clinical and polysomnographic features of sleep-related eating disorder DISEASE .
J Clin Psychiatry 1998;59:14–9.
Winkelman JW, Herzog DB, Fava M.
The prevalence of sleep-related eating disorder DISEASE in psychiatric DISEASE and non-psychiatric populations.
Psychol Med 1999;29:1461–6.
Winkelman JW.
Sleep-related eating disorder DISEASE and night eating syndrome DISEASE : sleep disorders DISEASE , eating disorders DISEASE , or both?
Sleep 2006;29:876–7.
245 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE REM-Related Parasomnias REM Sleep Behavior Disorder ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 327.42 Alternate Names None.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-D must be met ICD-10-CM code: G47.52 A. Repeated episodes of sleep related vocalization and/or
complex motor behaviors.1,2 B. These behaviors are documented by polysomnography to occur during REM sleep or, based on clinical history of dream enactment, are presumed to occur during REM sleep.
C. Polysomnographic recording demonstrates REM sleep without atonia DISEASE (RWA)3 D.
The disturbance is not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE , mental disorder DISEASE , medication, or substance use.
Notes .
This criterion can be fulfilled by observation of repetitive episodes during a single night of video polysomnography.
2. The observed vocalizations or behaviors often correlate with simultaneously occurring dream mentation, leading to the frequent report of “acting out one’s dreams.”
3.
As defined by the guidelines for scoring PSG features of RBD DISEASE in the most recent version of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
4. Upon awakening, the individual is typically awake, alert, coherent, and oriented.
5.
On occasion, there may be patients with a typical clinical history of RBD DISEASE with dream-enacting behaviors DISEASE , who also exhibit typical RBD behaviors DISEASE during vPSG, but do not demonstrate sufficient RWA, based on the current evidence-based data, to satisfy the PSG criteria for diagnosing RBD DISEASE .
In such patients, RBD DISEASE may be provisionally diagnosed, based on clinical judgment.
The same rule applies when vPSG is not readily available.
246 .
Medications may unmask latent RBD DISEASE with preexisting RWA, according to current expert opinion.
Therefore, medication-induced RBD DISEASE can be diagnosed as RBD DISEASE , using clinical judgment, pending future longitudinal studies.
Essential Features RBD DISEASE is characterized by abnormal behaviors DISEASE emerging during REM sleep that may cause injury or sleep disruption DISEASE .
RBD DISEASE is also associated with EMG abnormalities during REM sleep.
The EMG demonstrates an excess of muscle tone during REM sleep, and/or an excess of phasic EMG twitch DISEASE activity during REM sleep.
A complaint of sleep related injury is common with RBD DISEASE , which usually manifests as an attempted enactment of unpleasant, action-filled, and violent dreams in which the individual is being confronted, attacked, or chased by unfamiliar people or animals.
Typically, at the end of an episode, the individual awakens quickly, becomes rapidly alert, and reports a dream with a coherent story.
The dream action corresponds closely to the observed sleep behaviors DISEASE .
Sleep and dream-related behaviors reported by history and documented during vPSG include both violent DISEASE and (less commonly) nonviolent behaviors: talking (including giving speeches), smiling, laughing, singing, whistling, shouting, swearing profan- ities, crying, chewing, gesturing, reaching, grabbing, arm flailing, clapping, slap- ping, punching, kicking, sitting up, leaping from bed, crawling, running, or dancing.
Walking, however, is quite uncommon with RBD DISEASE , and leaving the room is especially rare, because the eyes are usually closed, precluding attention to the environment.
There can be rare occurrences of smoking a fictive cigarette, masturbation-like behav- ior, pelvic thrusting, and mimics of eating, drinking, urinating, and defecating.
The eyes usually remain closed during an RBD DISEASE episode, with the person attending to the dream action and not to the actual environment.
Medical attention is usually sought after sleep related injury has occurred to either the person or the bed partner, and rarely because of sleep disruption.
Because RBD DISEASE occurs during REM sleep, it usually appears at least 90 minutes after sleep onset, unless there is coexisting narcolepsy DISEASE , in which case RBD DISEASE can emerge shortly after sleep onset during a sleep onset rapid eye movement period ( SOREMP DISEASE ).
There is an acute form of RBD DISEASE that emerges during intense REM sleep rebound states, such as during withdrawal from alcohol CHEMICAL and sedative-hypnotic agents, or in association with certain medication use, drug intoxication, or relapsing multiple sclerosis.
247 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Associated Features PLMs during NREM sleep are very common with RBD DISEASE and may disturb the sleep of the bed partner.
Daytime tiredness DISEASE or sleepiness DISEASE is uncommon, unless narcolepsy DISEASE is also present.
There is typically no history of irritable DISEASE , aggressive, or violent behav- ior during the day.
There may be a longstanding prodromal history of sleep talking, yelling, limb twitching, and jerking DISEASE during sleep that may or may not be dream related.
Clinical or Pathophysiological Subtypes Parasomnia DISEASE overlap disorder is a condition in which patients have both RBD DISEASE and either a disorder of arousal, sleep related eating disorder DISEASE , sexsomnia, or rhythmic movement disorder DISEASE .
This condition is male predominant, but less so than isolated RBD DISEASE .
Most cases begin during childhood or adolescence.
Virtually all age groups can be affected.
It can be idiopathic DISEASE or symptomatic of a broad set of disorders, including narcolepsy DISEASE , mul- tiple sclerosis DISEASE , brain tumor DISEASE (and therapy), rhombencephalitis DISEASE (right pontine CHEMICAL tegmen- tum/medulla lesion), brain trauma DISEASE , congenital Moebius syndrome DISEASE , agrypnia excitata DISEASE , Machado-Joseph disease DISEASE , various psychiatric disorders DISEASE and their pharmacotherapies, and substance abuse disorders DISEASE and withdrawal states.
Status dissociatus DISEASE can be classified as a subtype of RBD DISEASE that manifests as an extreme form of state dissociation without identifiable sleep stages, but with sleep and dream-related behaviors DISEASE that closely resemble RBD DISEASE .
Status dissociatus DISEASE represents a major breakdown of the polysomnographic markers for REM sleep, NREM sleep, and wakefulness, with admixtures of these states being present, but with conventional sleep stages not being identifiable during polysomnographic monitoring.
There is abnormal behavioral release that can be associated with disturbed dreaming, strongly suggestive of dream-enacting behaviors DISEASE that closely resemble RBD DISEASE .
Not uncommonly, the indi- vidual thinks he is awake when observers presume he is asleep and attempting to act out a dream, or vice versa.
An underlying neurologic or medical condition, spanning a broad range of pathology, is virtually always present.
Dream enactment (“oneirism”) that is REM sleep related or related to a dissociated REM sleep-wakefulness state can be a core feature of a pathologic condition called agrypnia excitata DISEASE that is characterized by generalized motor overactivity DISEASE , impaired ability to initiate and maintain sleep (with “wakeful dreaming”), loss of slow wave sleep, and marked motor and autonomic sympathetic activation.
Agrypnia excitata DISEASE is found with such diverse conditions as delirium tremens DISEASE , Morvan syndrome DISEASE , and fatal familial insomnia DISEASE .
Thus, agrypnia excitata DISEASE manifests as both a severe parasomnia DISEASE and a severe insomnia DISEASE .
248 Demographics RBD DISEASE is a male predominant disorder that usually emerges after age 50 years.
Cases of RBD DISEASE from early childhood up to age 88 years have been reported.
RBD DISEASE emerging in adults before age 50 years tends to have different demographics and associated features, including greater sex parity and increased rates of idiopathic RBD DISEASE and para- somnia DISEASE overlap disorder (POD), comorbid narcolepsy DISEASE , antidepressant CHEMICAL medication use, and possibly autoimmune diseases DISEASE .
In addition, the clinical presentation of RBD DISEASE in younger adults differs from that in older adults in being less aggressive and violent, presumably due to greater female representation and higher rates of comorbid narco- lepsy (which manifests with milder RBD behaviors DISEASE ).
RBD DISEASE associated with neurologic disorders DISEASE and other symptomatic forms of RBD DISEASE are as male predominant as idiopathic RBD DISEASE , with the exception of narcolepsy DISEASE (as described below) and multiple system atrophy DISEASE .
Of note, RBD DISEASE may not be the presenting com- plaint to a sleep disorders DISEASE center.
Therefore, systematic questioning for RBD DISEASE should be included for all newly evaluated patients at a sleep center.
RBD DISEASE in children is virtually never idiopathic DISEASE and is usually associated with narcolepsy DISEASE (at times emerging months before the emergence of narcoleptic DISEASE symptoms), brainstem tumors DISEASE , antidepressant CHEMICAL medications, neurodevelopmental disorders DISEASE , and various rare conditions.
The prevalence is not known with much certainty, although a prevalence of 0.38% to 0.5% is reported in the elderly and the general population.
A 2.1% prevalence of current sleep related violence has been reported; 38% of these events have associated dream enactment, suggesting a prevalence of RBD DISEASE as high as 0.8%.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors The major predisposing factors are male sex, age 50 years or older, and an under- lying neurological disorder DISEASE , particularly Parkinson disease DISEASE , multiple system atrophy DISEASE , dementia DISEASE with Lewy DISEASE bodies, narcolepsy DISEASE , or stroke DISEASE .
A recent multicenter case-control study of environmental risk factors of RBD DISEASE found that smoking, head injury DISEASE , pesticide exposure, and farming were significant risk factors.
Medications, particularly the anti- depressants venlafaxine CHEMICAL , serotonin-specific CHEMICAL reuptake inhibitors ( SSRIs CHEMICAL ), mirtazapine CHEMICAL , and other antidepressant CHEMICAL agents (but not bupropion CHEMICAL ) are an increasingly recognized precipitating factor.
Beta-blockers ( bisoprolol CHEMICAL , atenolol CHEMICAL ), anticholinesterase inhibitors, and selegiline CHEMICAL can also trigger RBD DISEASE .
Psychiatric disorders DISEASE involving depression DISEASE (that require antidepressant CHEMICAL pharmacotherapy) may comprise a predisposing factor, particu- larly in adults younger than 50 years.
RBD DISEASE may also be associated with posttraumatic stress disorder DISEASE .
249 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Familial Pattern A recent multicenter controlled study revealed a significantly increased positive family history of dream enactment, raising the possibility of a genetic contribution to RBD.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset of chronic RBD DISEASE can be gradual or rapid, and the course is often progressive.
Complications include sleep related injuries DISEASE to self and/or bed partner that at times are life threatening, and disruption of the bed partner’s sleep that can be severe.
Marital discord due to the RBD DISEASE is uncommon but can be severe when present, due to repeated injury and/or disruption of the bed partner’s sleep.
Delayed emergence of a neurodegenerative disorder DISEASE , often more than a decade after the onset of idiopathic RBD DISEASE , is very common in men 50 years of age and older.
These dis- orders include Parkinson disease DISEASE ( PD DISEASE ), multiple system atrophy DISEASE ( MSA CHEMICAL ), and dementia DISEASE with Lewy DISEASE bodies ( DLB DISEASE ).
Two recently reported series found 81% and 82% eventual conversion rates from idiopathic RBD DISEASE to parkinsonism/dementia DISEASE (and also mild cog- nitive impairment in the latter study).
Conversely, RBD DISEASE is present in >90% of reported cases of MSA CHEMICAL , in approximately 50% of reported cases of DLB DISEASE , and in up to 46% of reported patients with PD DISEASE .
Developmental Issues As stated previously, RBD DISEASE can emerge in children, usually in association with narco- lepsy-cataplexy DISEASE , brainstem tumors DISEASE , or antidepressant CHEMICAL medications.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Current evidence suggests a selective association between RBD DISEASE and neurodegenera- tive disorders DISEASE .
The synucleinopathies DISEASE comprise a set of neurodegenerative disorders DISEASE that share a common pathologic lesion composed of aggregates of insoluble α-synu- clein protein in selectively vulnerable populations of neurons and glial cells.
These pathologic aggregates appear to be closely linked to the onset and progression of clin- ical symptoms and the degeneration of affected brain regions in neurodegenerative disorders DISEASE .
The major synucleinopathies DISEASE include PD DISEASE , DLB DISEASE , and MSA.
RBD DISEASE can be strongly linked with narcolepsy DISEASE (almost always narcolepsy DISEASE type 1), rep- resenting another form of REM sleep motor-behavioral dyscontrol.
The RBD DISEASE may be precipitated or worsened by the pharmacologic treatment of cataplexy DISEASE .
RBD DISEASE associ- ated with narcolepsy DISEASE is now considered to be a distinct phenotype of RBD DISEASE , character- ized by lack of sex predominance, less complex and more elementary movements in REM sleep, less violent behavior DISEASE in REM sleep, earlier age of onset, and hypocretin deficiency DISEASE (that is characteristic of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1).
The presence of RBD DISEASE in pediat- ric patients may be an initial manifestation of narcolepsy DISEASE type 1.
Other reported etiologic associations of RBD DISEASE with neurologic disorders DISEASE include isch- emic or hemorrhagic cerebrovascular disease DISEASE , multiple sclerosis DISEASE , progressive supranu- clear palsy DISEASE , Guillain-Barré syndrome DISEASE , brainstem neoplasms (including cerebellopon- tine angle tumors DISEASE ), Machado-Joseph disease DISEASE ( spinocerebellar ataxia DISEASE type 3), mitochon- drial encephalomyopathy DISEASE , normal pressure hydrocephalus DISEASE , Tourette syndrome DISEASE , group A xeroderma DISEASE , and autism DISEASE .
The pathophysiology of human RBD DISEASE is presumed to correspond to the findings from an animal model of RBD DISEASE with respect to interruption of the REM atonia DISEASE pathway and/ or disinhibition of brainstem motor pattern generators.
Objective Findings Polysomnography demonstrates an excessive amount of sustained or intermittent loss of REM atonia DISEASE and/or excessive phasic muscle twitch activity of the submental and/or limb EMGs during REM sleep.
Some patients have almost exclusively arm and hand behaviors during REM sleep, indicating the need for both upper and lower extremity EMG monitoring in fully evaluating for RBD DISEASE .
Some patients preserve most of their REM atonia DISEASE but have excessive EMG twitching during REM sleep.
The most current evidence-based data for detecting RWA in the evaluation of RBD DISEASE indicate that any (tonic/phasic) chin EMG activity combined with bilateral phasic activity of the flexor digitorum superficialis muscles in >27% of REM sleep (scored in 30-second epochs) reliably distinguishes RBD DISEASE patients from controls.
Autonomic nervous system activa- tion (such as tachycardia DISEASE ) is uncommon during REM sleep motor activation in RBD DISEASE , in contrast to the disorders of arousal.
Approximately 75% of patients have PLMs during NREM sleep; a low percentage of these movements is associated with EEG signs of arousal.
Increased percentages of slow wave sleep and increased delta power in RBD DISEASE have been found in controlled and uncontrolled studies, but this can be a highly vari- able finding in RBD DISEASE , depending on the clinical population.
Sleep architecture and the customary cycling among REM and NREM sleep stages are usually preserved in RBD DISEASE , although some patients show a shift toward N1 sleep.
Validated RBD DISEASE screening questionnaires that can assist in the process of diagnosing RBD DISEASE are currently available.
251 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Differential Diagnosis RBD DISEASE is one of several disorders that can manifest as complex, injurious, and violent sleep related and dream-related behaviors DISEASE in adults.
Other disorders that can mimic RBD DISEASE in adults and/or children include sleepwalking, sleep terrors DISEASE , OSA DISEASE , nocturnal seizures DISEASE ( nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy DISEASE ; nocturnal complex partial seizures DISEASE ); rhyth- mic movement disorders DISEASE ; sleep related dissociative disorders, frightening hypnopom- pic hallucinations DISEASE , and posttraumatic stress disorder DISEASE ; a diagnosis of malingering also should be considered.
In general, RBD DISEASE involves attempted enactment of unpleasant, aggressive dreams that usually occurs two or more hours after sleep onset, with rapid awakening from an episode.
In contrast, sleepwalking and sleep terror episodes often emerge within two hours after sleep onset, are not usually associated with rapid alertness, and are rarely associated with dreaming in children.
Adults can have dreams associated with disor- ders of arousal, but they are usually more fragmentary and limited than RBD DISEASE dreams.
Sleep related seizures DISEASE usually present with repetitive, stereotypical behaviors.
Parasomnia DISEASE overlap disorder can be distinguished from status dissociatus DISEASE in several ways: if there is an awakening after an episode of RBD DISEASE , sleepwalking, or sleep terror, there is the realization of having just been asleep; status dissociatus DISEASE , however, is more likely to manifest with confusion DISEASE over whether one is asleep, awake, or dreaming.
vPSG in overlap conditions shows the typical findings for both RBD and disorders of arousal, whereas with status dissociatus DISEASE , there is an inability to discern sleep stages.
Also, patients with status dissociatus DISEASE do not walk far during an episode, and their behavioral repertoire more closely resembles that of RBD DISEASE than that of the disorders of arousal.
Unresolved Issues and Future Directions Numerous questions related to the vPSG evaluation of RBD DISEASE remain unresolved.
These include issues of defining and quantifying RWA and RBD DISEASE activity such as: (1) What is the minimum REM sleep percentage of total sleep time (and minimum absolute REM sleep time) needed to diagnose RWA or rule out RWA?
(2) What is the minimum number of REM sleep epochs and minimum duration of REM sleep epochs necessary to diagnose RWA or rule out RWA?
(3) What guidelines can be developed for diag- nosing or ruling out RWA in the setting of disrupted REM sleep continuity associated with conditions such as obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE and with medications?
(4) What are the minimal amounts of true RBD behaviors DISEASE documented by vPSG needed to identify RBD DISEASE in patients without sufficient RWA?
252 It is unclear why there is a male predominance of this disorder in middle-aged and older adults.
It is unknown if RBD DISEASE subgroups other than men age 50 years or older demon- CHEMICAL strate increased risk for development of parkinsonism DISEASE or dementia DISEASE .
One such subgroup comprises patients with antidepressant-triggered RBD DISEASE for whom the potential risk for future parkinsonism DISEASE and dementia DISEASE is unclear.
New antidepressant CHEMICAL or other psychotro- pic agents being developed for clinical use should be assessed for their immediate and long-term effects on REM atonia DISEASE , REM phasic activity, REM sleep behavioral release, and proclivity to precipitate dream-enacting DISEASE behaviors.

Oudiette D, De Cock VC, Lavault S, Leu S, Vidailhet M, Arnulf I. Non-violent DISEASE elaborate behaviors may also occur in REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE .
Neurology 2009;72:551–7.
Postuma RB, Gagnon JF, Vendette M, Fantini ML, Massicotte-Marquez J, Montplaisir J. Quantifying the risk of neurodegenerative disease DISEASE in idiopathic REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE .
Neurology 2009;72:1296–300.
Schenck CH, Mahowald MW.
REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE : clinical, developmental, and neuroscience perspectives 16 years after its formal identification in SLEEP.
Sleep 2002;25:120–38.
Schenck CH, Boeve BF, Mahowald MW.
Delayed emergence of a parkinsonian disorder DISEASE or dementia DISEASE in 81% of older males initially diagnosed with idiopathic REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE ( RBD DISEASE ): 16 year update on a previously reported series.
Sleep Med 2013;14:744–8.
Schenck CH, Howell MJ.
Spectrum of RBD DISEASE (overlap between RBD DISEASE and other parasomnias DISEASE ).
Sleep and Biological Rhythms 2013;11(Supplement 1):27–34. Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Recurrent Isolated Sleep Paralysis ICD-9-CM code: 327.43 ICD-10-CM code: G47.53 Alternate Names Hypnagogic and hypnopompic paralysis DISEASE , predormital and postdormital paralysis DISEASE , kanashibari (Japan).
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-D must be met A. A recurrent inability DISEASE to move the trunk and all of the limbs at sleep onset or upon awakening from sleep.
B. Each episode lasts seconds to a few minutes.
C.
The episodes cause clinically significant distress including bedtime anxiety DISEASE or fear of sleep.
D.
The disturbance is not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE (especially narcolepsy DISEASE ), mental disorder DISEASE , medical condition, medication, or substance use.
Essential Features Recurrent isolated sleep paralysis DISEASE is characterized by an inability to perform voluntary movements at sleep onset (hypnagogic or predormital form) or on waking from sleep ( hypnopompic DISEASE or postdormital form) in the absence of a diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE .
The event consists of an inability to speak or to move the limbs, trunk, and head.
Respiration is usually unaffected.
Consciousness is preserved, and full recall is present.
An episode of sleep paralysis DISEASE lasts seconds to minutes.
It usually resolves spontaneously but can be aborted by sensory stimulation, such as being touched or spoken to, or by the patient making intense efforts to move.
Associated Features At least during the initial episodes, intense anxiety DISEASE is usually present.
Hallucinatory experiences accompany the paralysis DISEASE in about 25% to 75% of patients.
These may include auditory, visual, or tactile hallucinations DISEASE , or the sense of a presence in the room.
Some patients experience predormital or postdormital hallucinations DISEASE at separate times from episodes of sleep paralysis DISEASE .
Clinical or Pathophysiological Subtypes A familial form of sleep paralysis DISEASE has been described (see below).
254 Demographics Estimates of the prevalence of sleep paralysis DISEASE vary widely due to differences in the definition used, the age of the population sampled, and possibly cultural and ethnic factors.
Most prevalence studies of sleep paralysis DISEASE (usually of students younger than 30 years) have investigated the occurrence of one or more episodes without require- ment of recurrence or distress.
These suggest a 15% to 40% prevalence of at least one episode of sleep paralysis DISEASE .
Two notable exceptions are a 1962 study of mostly college students that reported a prevalence of 5%, and a 1999 study of all adult ages that found a prevalence of 6%.
No consistent sex differences have emerged from multiple studies.
The mean age of onset is 14 to 17 years, although onset earlier and later in life has been reported.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Sleep deprivation and irregular sleep-wake schedules have been identified as predis- posing factors to episodes of sleep paralysis DISEASE .
Mental stress has been reported as a precipitating factor in some but not other studies.
Sleep paralysis DISEASE appears to be more common with sleep in the supine position.
Personality factors have not been shown to play a major role, although one study found a higher score on the paranoia scale of the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory in patients with sleep paralysis DISEASE com- pared to controls.
Other factors that have been noted on regression analysis include an association with bipolar disorder DISEASE , the use of anxiolytic medication, and sleep related leg cramps.
Familial Pattern Two families with apparent familial sleep paralysis DISEASE occurring over three and four gen- erations have been reported.
A maternal form of transmission has been postulated.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset is usually in adolescence.
Most events appear to occur in the second and third decades, but may continue later in life.
There are no known complications, apart from anxiety DISEASE over the episodes.
Developmental Issues Though sleep paralysis DISEASE may be present as part of the narcolepsy DISEASE tetrad in children, there is no information currently available about childhood presentation of recurrent isolated sleep paralysis DISEASE .
255 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Pathology and Pathophysiology Episodes of sleep paralysis DISEASE elicited by awakening patients from nocturnal sleep appear to arise from REM sleep.
Sleep paralysis DISEASE is an example of state dissociation with ele- ments of REM sleep persisting into wakefulness.
Early-onset REM sleep after forced awakenings DISEASE has been shown to predispose an individual to having sleep paralysis DISEASE .
It may be that subjects with less tolerance to sleep disruption are more likely to experi- ence the phenomenon.
Objective Findings Analysis of sleep paralysis DISEASE after forced awakenings during PSG studies reveals the event to be a dissociated state with the persistence of REM-related DISEASE electromyographic atonia DISEASE into conscious wakefulness.
Hallucinatory experiences may be present but are not essential for the diagnosis.
Differential Diagnosis Cataplexy DISEASE produces similar generalized paralysis DISEASE of skeletal muscles but occurs during wakefulness and is precipitated by emotion.
Atonic seizures DISEASE occur during wakefulness.
Nocturnal panic attacks DISEASE are not usually associated with paralysis DISEASE .
Familial periodic paralysis DISEASE syndromes, especially hypokalemic DISEASE periodic paralysis DISEASE , may occur at rest and on awakening.
However, the episodes usually last hours, may be associated with car- bohydrate intake, and are usually accompanied by hypokalemia DISEASE .
There are also hyper- kalemic and normokalemic periodic paralysis DISEASE syndromes.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Not applicable or known.
Bibliography Fukuda K. Sleep paralysis DISEASE and sleep-onset REM period in normal individuals.
In: Olgilvie R, Harsh J, eds.
Sleep onset: normal and abnormal processes.
Washington: American Psychological Association, 1994:161–81.
Goode G. Sleep paralysis DISEASE .
Arch Neurol 1962;6:228–34.
Hishikawa Y. Sleep paralysis DISEASE .
In: Guilleminault C, Dement W, Passouant P, eds.
Narcolepsy DISEASE .
New York: Spectrum, 1976:97–124.
Ohayon M, Zulley J, Guilleminault C, Smirne S. Prevalence and pathologic associations of sleep paralysis DISEASE in the general population.
Neurology 1999;52:1194–200.
Takeuchi T, Fukuda K CHEMICAL , Sasaki Y, Inugami M, Murphy T. Factors related to the occurrence of isolated sleep paralysis DISEASE elicited during a multi-phasic sleep-wake schedule.
Sleep 2002;25:89–96.
Takeuchi T, Miyasita A, Sasaki Y, Inugami M, Fukuda K. Isolated sleep paralysis DISEASE elicited by sleep interruption.
Sleep 1992;15:217–25.
256 Nightmare Disorder ICD-9-CM code: 307.47 ICD-10-CM code: F51.5 Alternate Names Nightmares, REM nightmares, recurrent nightmares, dream anxiety disorder DISEASE , anxiety DISEASE dreams.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A. Repeated occurrences of extended, extremely dysphoric DISEASE , and well- remembered dreams that usually involve threats to survival, security, or physical integrity.
B. On awakening from the dysphoric DISEASE dreams, the person rapidly becomes oriented and alert.
C. The dream experience, or the sleep disturbance DISEASE produced by awakening from it, causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning as indicated by the report of at least one of the following:
1.
Mood disturbance (e.g., persistence of nightmare affect, anxiety DISEASE , dysphoria DISEASE ).
2. Sleep resistance (e.g., bedtime anxiety DISEASE , fear of sleep/subsequent nightmares).
3. Cognitive impairments DISEASE (e.g., intrusive nightmare imagery, impaired concentration, or memory).
4. Negative impact on caregiver or family functioning (e.g., nighttime disruption).
5.
Behavioral problems (e.g., bedtime avoidance, fear of the dark).
6. Daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
7. Fatigue DISEASE or low energy.
8.
Impaired occupational or educational function.
9. Impaired interpersonal/social function Notes .
Nightmare disorder DISEASE in children is most likely to occur in those exposed to severe psychosocial stressors.
Because childhood nightmares often resolve spontaneously, the diagnosis should be given only if there is persistent distress or impairment.
Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Essential Features Nightmare disorder DISEASE is characterized by recurrent, highly dysphoric dreams DISEASE , which are disturbing mental experiences that generally occur during REM sleep and that often result in awakening.
Given that these experiences are most often associated with REM sleep, the episodes have a greater tendency to occur during the second half of the major sleep episode when the REM pressure is most pronounced.
Nightmares involve an internally generated conscious experience or dream sequence that seems vivid and real.
They have a tendency to become increasingly more disturbing as they unfold.
Emotions are characteristically negative and most frequently involve anxiety DISEASE , fear, or terror but may also involve anger DISEASE , rage, embarrassment, and disgust.
Nightmare content most often focuses on imminent physical danger to the individual but may also involve other distressing themes.
Ability to detail the nightmare’s contents upon awakening is common in nightmare disorder.
Multiple nightmares within a single sleep episode may occur and may bear similar themes.
Because nightmares typically arise during REM sleep, they may occur at any moment that REM pressure is high.
Nightmares are very common in children.
They typically occur in the last third of the night and result in a complete awakening, after which the child can often provide a detailed description of the frightening scenario.
However, clear distinction from con- fusional arousals DISEASE and sleep terrors DISEASE in young children is often not possible.
Associated Features Postawakening anxiety DISEASE and difficulty returning to sleep may be present.
Nightmares are more common in those with higher levels of anxiety DISEASE .
Additionally, nightmares are commonly seen in those who have been physically or sexually abused and in those suf- fering from posttraumatic stress disorder DISEASE .
Nightmares arising either immediately following a trauma DISEASE ( acute stress disorder DISEASE [ASD]) or one month or more after a trauma DISEASE ( posttraumatic stress disorder DISEASE [ PTSD DISEASE ]) have been described during NREM sleep, especially N2, as well as during REM sleep and at sleep onset.
Posttraumatic nightmares may take the form of a realistic reliving of a traumatic DISEASE event or may depict only some of its elements or emotional content.
Clinical or Pathophysiological Subtypes None known.
Demographics Occasional nightmares are very common in children, occurring in 60% to 75% of chil- dren, beginning as young as 2.5 years of age.
The occurrence of occasional nightmares in children does not constitute a nightmare disorder.
However, frequent nightmares are uncommon, occurring in 1% to 5% of preadolescent children.
It is estimated that 10% to 50% of children aged three to five years have at least occasional nightmares severe enough to disturb their parents.
Nightmares appear to be a trait-like characteristic that persists over time during childhood.
The best predictor of recurrent nightmares at an older age is recurrent nightmares in childhood.
Approximately 2% to 8% of the general population has a current problem with nightmares, and this frequency is higher in clini- cal populations.
Trauma-related nightmares are the most consistent problem reported by patients with PTSD.
Nightmares beginning within three months of a trauma DISEASE are present in up to 80% of patients with PTSD.
Although approximately 50% of PTSD DISEASE cases resolve within three months, posttraumatic nightmares may persist throughout life.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Frequent nightmares are associated with enduring personality characteristics and psy- chopathologies; they are inversely correlated with measures of well-being.
Associations with psychopathology have been identified for adults and adolescents, but research on children is largely absent other than for assessments of PTSD.
Measures of nightmare distress are much more robustly associated with psychopathology than are measures of nightmare frequency.
The clinical use of pharmacologic agents affecting the neurotransmitters norepinephrine CHEMICAL , serotonin CHEMICAL , and dopamine CHEMICAL is associated with the complaint of night- mares.
A majority of these agents are antidepressants CHEMICAL , antihypertensives, and dopa- mine-receptor agonists.
Agents affecting the neurotransmitters gamma-aminobutyric acid CHEMICAL ( GABA CHEMICAL ), acetylcholine CHEMICAL , and histamine CHEMICAL , and the withdrawal of REM sleep sup- pressive agents also can be associated with the complaint of nightmares.
Of note, nightmares are a common reaction in varenicline CHEMICAL , which is an agent that blocks α-4-β-2 nicotinic acetylcholine CHEMICAL receptors.
Familial Pattern Twin-based studies have identified persistent genetic predisposition to nightmares in childhood (reported retrospectively by adults) and adulthood as well as genetic influ- ences on the co-occurrence of nightmares and some other parasomnias DISEASE , such as sleep talking ( somniloquy DISEASE ).
Onset, Course, and Complications Nightmares usually start between ages three years and six years.
The proportion of children reporting nightmares reaches a peak between six and ten years of age and decreases thereafter.
A subgroup of children continue to have nightmares into Parasomnias Parasomnias adolescence DISEASE or adulthood and may become lifelong nightmare sufferers.
Nightmares generally diminish in frequency and intensity over the course of decades, but some patients still describe frequent episodes at the age of 60 or 70 years.
Nightmare dis- order can lead to sleep avoidance and deprivation, and thereby to more intense night- mares, which can produce insomnia DISEASE .
ASD and PTSD DISEASE associated nightmares can develop at any age after physical or emo- tional trauma DISEASE .
Individuals with PTSD DISEASE are at risk for developing mood disorders DISEASE and depression DISEASE , social and employment consequences, self-destructive and impulsive behavior, and substance abuse DISEASE ; it is not known to what extent the nightmares symp- tomatic of PTSD DISEASE contribute to these complications.
Developmental Issues As stated above, nightmares are very common in children but the occurrence of occa- sional nightmares does not constitute nightmare disorder.
Population studies have revealed that the prevalence and frequency of nightmares increases through childhood into adolescence.
For example, preschoolers seldom report “bad dreams.”
Furthermore, in regard to the prevalence of nightmares, children appear to exhibit a sex divergence over time, with girls demonstrating higher prevalence by late adolescence.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Not applicable or known.
Objective Findings PSG recordings during actual nightmares are few in number and, in some instances, have shown abrupt awakenings from REM sleep preceded by accelerated heart and respiratory rates.
Highly disturbing dream content frequently contrasts strikingly with relatively minor autonomic changes.
Distinctive anomalies DISEASE in nightly sleep architec- ture have not been demonstrated; brainstem and auditory-evoked potentials appear normal.
Recordings during posttraumatic nightmares DISEASE are few but have been recorded from both REM and NREM sleep.
PSG recordings of sleep in patients with PTSD DISEASE have provided widely variable results.
PSG evaluation is not routinely performed but may be indicated in some circumstances to exclude other parasomnias DISEASE such as disorders of arousal and sleep-associated sei- zures. DISEASE
A PSG is particularly appropriate if patients report nightmares in conjunction with sleep behaviors DISEASE that are repetitive or stereotyped or are injurious to self or others.
260 Differential Diagnosis Nightmare disorder must be distinguished from dream disturbances associated with certain other neurological and sleep disorders DISEASE .
Rare cases of seizures DISEASE presenting only as “nightmares” have been reported and should be considered in the differential diagno- sis, particularly in those patients who present with a history of central nervous system disease.
PSG or continuous video EEG may be necessary to identify nightmares asso- ciated with nocturnal seizures DISEASE .
Nightmares differ from sleep terrors DISEASE in having detailed recollection of dreaming in contrast to fragments of dreams or no dream recall, pre- senting no or minimal overt movement or autonomic activity, occurring late in the night, being followed by rapid awakening and difficulty returning to sleep, and most often arising from REM sleep.
RBD DISEASE occurs more often in late middle-aged men and is more often associated with violent explosive movements DISEASE and a history of nocturnal injuries DISEASE .
The dream disturbance of RBD DISEASE usually involves being threatened or attacked by unfamiliar people or animals and is controlled in tandem with the sleep behavioral disturbance by appropriate medication.
Nightmares occur at any age and are not typ- ically associated with movements, overt behaviors DISEASE , or injuries DISEASE .
Anxiety DISEASE may accom- pany episodes of sleep paralysis DISEASE occurring either at sleep onset (hypnagogic) or offset ( hypnopompic DISEASE ), when the individual feels conscious but unable to move, speak, and, at times, breathe properly.
Anxiety DISEASE may be further worsened if disturbing hypnago- gic hallucinations DISEASE or dream sequences accompany the paralysis DISEASE .
Nightmares, although they may involve some degree of movement inhibition or some degree of apparent wakefulness, are usually not accompanied by feelings of either total paralysis DISEASE or com- plete waking consciousness.
Patients with narcolepsy DISEASE often report nightmares; these may occur at sleep onset.
However, narcolepsy DISEASE and nightmare disorder are clearly distinguishable by other clinical symptoms.
Nocturnal panic attacks DISEASE occur either during or immediately after nocturnal awakenings from NREM sleep, usually in the first four hours of the sleep episode.
Although frequency of panic DISEASE attacks is correlated with frequency of night- mares and many patients report that dysphoric dreams DISEASE precede their attacks, there may be no dream recall reported on awakening with a panic DISEASE attack.
Sleep related dissociative disorders DISEASE comprise a sleep related variant of the dissociative disorders DISEASE as defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-V).
These include dissociative identity disorder DISEASE (formerly called multi- ple personality disorder) and dissociative fugue, in which individuals meeting waking criteria for these diagnoses may at times experience the recall of actual physical or emotional trauma DISEASE as a “dream” during periods of EEG-documented DISEASE nocturnal waking. Parasomnias Parasomnias Nightmares DISEASE that occur intermittently during the course of ASD or PTSD DISEASE are an expected symptom of those mental disorders and do not always require independent coding as nightmare disorder.
However, as is often the case, when the frequency and/or severity of posttraumatic nightmares DISEASE is such that they require independent clinical attention, then a diagnosis of nightmare disorder should be applied.
In some cases, other symp- toms of PTSD DISEASE may have largely resolved while the nightmares persist.
Nightmare disorder DISEASE should be coded in these cases as well.
It is clinically important to establish whether nightmares are associated with PTSD DISEASE or ASD because the evaluation, course, complications, and treatment differ significantly for these groups.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Basic pathophysiologic studies are still needed, especially studies contrasting “idio- pathic” nightmare disorder and nightmares associated with PTSD.
In particular, deter- mining whether posttraumatic nightmares DISEASE arise from sleep or primarily from wakeful- ness would be an important distinguishing feature particularly when determining effec- tive DISEASE clinical interventions.
The PSG correlates of nightmare disorder and posttraumatic nightmares as well as the variables affecting dream mentation and recall require further definition and delineation.
The distinction between nightmares and sleep terrors DISEASE is difficult when assessed only by questionnaires.
It still remains unclear to what degree and level of complexity sleep mentation is associated with sleep terrors DISEASE .
The topic of NREM sleep dream distur- bances (other than disturbed mentation that may occur with sleep terrors DISEASE ) also needs formal investigation, including whether or not the term NREM sleep nightmare should be utilized.
The optimal methods for assessing nightmare frequency and nightmare distress are still unclear.
Standardized scales assessing nightmare distress should be developed and utilized.
Retrospective questionnaire-based evaluations of nightmares are problematic inasmuch as they underestimate nightmare frequencies relative to home logs, whereas home logs may selectively increase recall of nightmares.
Bibliography Germain A, Nielsen T. Sleep pathophysiology in posttraumatic stress disorder DISEASE and idiopathic DISEASE nightmare sufferers.
Biol Psychiatry 2003;54:1092–8.
Hobson J. REM sleep and dreaming: towards a theory of protoconsciousness.
Nat Rev Neurosci 2009;10:803–13.
Hublin C, Kaprio J, Partinen M, Koskenvuo M. Nightmares: familial aggregation DISEASE and association with psychiatric disorders DISEASE in a nationwide twin cohort.
Am J Med Genet 1999;88:329–36.
262 Lavie P. Sleep disturbances DISEASE in the wake of traumatic DISEASE events.
N Engl J Med 2001;345:1825–32.
Levin R, Fireman G. Nightmare prevalence, nightmare distress, and self-reported psychological disturbance.
Sleep 2002;25:205–12.
Muzur A, Pace-Schott EF, Hobson J.
The prefrontal cortex in sleep.
Trends Cogn Sci 2002;6:475–81.
Nielsen T, Zadra A. Idiopathic nightmares and dream disturbances DISEASE associated with sleep-wake transitions.
In: Kryger MH, Roth T, Dement WC, eds.
Principles and practice of sleep medicine, 5th ed.
Philadelphia: Elsevier Saunders, 2010:1106–15.
Pagel J, Helfter P. DISEASE Drug induced nightmares—an etiology based review.
Hum Psychopharmacol 2003;18:59–67.
Zadra A, Donderi D. Nightmares and bad dreams: their prevalence and relationship to well-being.
J Abnorm Psychol 2000;109:273–81.
263 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Other Parasomnias DISEASE Exploding Head Syndrome ICD-9-CM code: 327.49 Alternate Names Sensory sleep starts, sensory sleep DISEASE shocks.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met ICD-10-CM code: G47.59 A. There is a complaint of a sudden loud noise or sense of explosion in the head either at the wake-sleep transition or upon waking during the night.
B. The individual experiences abrupt arousal following the event, often with a sense of fright.
C. The experience is not associated with significant complaints of pain DISEASE .
Essential Features Exploding head syndrome DISEASE is characterized by a sudden, loud imagined noise or sense of a violent explosion DISEASE in the head occurring as the patient is falling asleep or waking during the night.
The event is variously described as a painless loud bang, an explosion, a clash of cymbals, or a bomb DISEASE exploding, but occasionally may be a less alarming sound.
It is usually associated with a sense of fright, and many patients believe they are having a stroke DISEASE .
In a minority of cases a flash of light or myoclonic jerk DISEASE may accompany the event.
The abnormal sensation lasts a few seconds and may recur during further attempts at sleeping.
The number of attacks DISEASE varies—from many on a single night to infrequent—with some patients reporting clustering of attacks over several nights fol- lowed by a gap of weeks to months.
A high level of clinical distress can be associated with recurrent attacks, with concern about their underlying cause.
Associated Features A flash of light may accompany the sound, and a myoclonic jerk DISEASE may sometimes occur.
Although the event is typically painless, a simultaneous stab of pain DISEASE in the head has occasionally been reported.
An insomnia complaint DISEASE may develop as a result of the recurring arousals DISEASE and anxiety DISEASE regarding the events.
264 Clinical or Pathophysiological Subtypes None known.
Demographics The prevalence is unknown.
Exploding head syndrome DISEASE is reported to be more common in women than in men.
The median age of onset is 58 years, but onset at all ages has been reported, including the first and eighth decades.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Most patients do not detect precipitating factors, but some report increased numbers of attacks DISEASE when under personal stress or overtired.
Familial Pattern Occasional cases of exploding head syndrome DISEASE occurring in the same family have been reported, although it is not clear whether this represents a true familial pattern.
Onset, Course, and Complication The course is benign with no reported neurologic sequelae DISEASE .
Frequent events on a single night can result in insomnia DISEASE .
Clinical levels of anxiety DISEASE may result from patient concern about a serious medical basis for the exploding head syndrome DISEASE .
The condition may also exacerbate a comorbid migraine disorder DISEASE .
In many patients, the symptoms appear to remit spontaneously over some years.
Developmental Issues Not known or applicable.
Pathology and Pathophysiology The events occur most frequently during a period of drowsiness DISEASE preceding sleep.
Some events are reported to occur upon waking during the night, but may actually be occur- ring during reinitiating sleep.
The condition appears to be a sensory variant of the better-known transient motor phenomenon of sleep starts or hypnic jerks DISEASE occurring at wake-sleep transition.
The neurophysiologic mechanisms underlying these hypnago- gic phenomena are unknown.
Objective Findings VPSG in a small sample of patients found that events arose from early drowsiness DISEASE with predominant alpha rhythm interspersed with some theta activity.
In one patient, events arose during transition from N1 sleep, in another patient from N1 sleep to wakeful- ness, and in a third patient from N2 sleep to wakefulness.
Events occurring in the N1/ Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE N2 to wake transition have been recorded during both nocturnal vPSG and MSLTs DISEASE .
Slow eye movements were present in the only tracing reproduced in the report of a patient with exploding head syndrome DISEASE emerging during wake to N1 sleep transition.
Arousals DISEASE occurred immediately following the episodes.
No epileptiform discharges accompany the event.
Differential Diagnosis Exploding head syndrome DISEASE should be distinguished from sudden onset-headache syn- CHEMICAL dromes.
“ Idiopathic stabbing headache” (ice-pick headache DISEASE ) is a benign syndrome of brief stabs of pain DISEASE on the side of the head.
Although they can occur at sleep onset, they are more common during wakefulness.
“ Thunderclap headache DISEASE ” is a very severe sudden onset headache DISEASE characteristic of subarachnoid hemorrhage DISEASE but also resulting from other causes and occasionally occurring as a benign symptom.
It does not usually occur at sleep onset.
“ Hypnic headache syndrome DISEASE ” affects older people who regularly awaken 4-6 hours after sleep onset, with a diffuse headache DISEASE that lasts 30-60 minutes and is often associated with nausea DISEASE but no autonomic symptoms.
Other conditions to be con- sidered include sleep related migraines DISEASE , cluster headaches DISEASE , and nocturnal paroxysmal hemicrania DISEASE .
In contrast to headache DISEASE syndromes, exploding head syndrome DISEASE is usually painless.
Simple partial seizures DISEASE can present with sensory phenomena but do not usually occur predominantly at sleep onset.
Nocturnal panic attacks DISEASE can waken a person from sleep, but are not usually associated with a sense of noise or explosion.
Recurrent night- mares are characterized by recall of more complex and longer-lasting visual imagery.
Sleep starts occur at wake-sleep transition but are predominantly a motor phenomenon with sudden myoclonic jerks DISEASE rather than an emphasis on sensory symptoms.
Unresolved Issues and Future Directions The neurophysiologic basis of these events requires further study.
Bibliography Chakravarty A. Exploding head syndrome DISEASE : report of two new cases.
Cephalalgia 2008;28:399–400.
Evans RW.
Exploding head syndrome DISEASE followed by sleep paralysis DISEASE : a rare migraine DISEASE aura.
Headache DISEASE 2006;46:682–3.
Kallweit U, Khatami R, Bassetti CL.
Exploding head syndrome DISEASE - more than “snapping of the brain”?
Sleep Med 2008;9:589.
Palikh GM CHEMICAL , Vaughn BV.
Topiramate CHEMICAL responsive exploding head syndrome DISEASE .
J Clin Sleep Med 2010;6:382–3.
Pearce JM.
Clinical features of the exploding head syndrome DISEASE .
J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1989;52:907–10.
Sachs C, Svanborg E.
The exploding head syndrome DISEASE : polysomnographic recordings and therapeutic suggestions.
Sleep 1991;14:263–6.
266 Sleep Related Hallucinations DISEASE ICD-9-CM code: 368.16 ICD-10-CM code: H53.16 Alternate Names Hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE , hypnopompic hallucinations DISEASE , complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met A.
There is a complaint of recurrent hallucinations DISEASE that are experienced just prior to sleep onset or upon awakening during the night or in the morning.
B. The hallucinations DISEASE are predominantly visual.
C. The disturbance is not better explained by another sleep disorder DISEASE (especially narcolepsy DISEASE ), mental disorder DISEASE , medical disorder DISEASE , medication, or substance use.
Essential Features Sleep related hallucinations DISEASE are hallucinatory DISEASE experiences that occur at sleep onset or on awakening from sleep.
Sleep related hallucinations DISEASE are predominantly visual but may include auditory, tactile, or kinetic phenomena.
Hallucinations DISEASE at sleep onset ( hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE ) may be difficult to differentiate from sleep onset dream- ing.
Hallucinations DISEASE on waking in the morning ( hypnopompic hallucinations DISEASE ) may arise out of a period of REM sleep, and patients also may be uncertain whether they rep- resent waking or dream-related experiences.
Complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE may represent a distinct form of sleep related hallucinations DISEASE .
They typically occur fol- DISEASE lowing a sudden awakening, without recall of a preceding dream.
They usually take the form of complex, vivid, relatively immobile images of people or animals, sometimes distorted in shape or size.
These hallucinations DISEASE may remain present for many minutes but usually disappear if ambient illumination is increased.
Patients are clearly awake but often initially perceive the hallucinations DISEASE as real and frightening.
Associated Features Sleep related hallucinations DISEASE may be associated with episodes of sleep paralysis DISEASE , either at the same time or on different nights.
Patients with complex nocturnal visual hal- lucinations may jump out of the bed in terror, sometimes injuring themselves.
Some patients may experience other parasomnias DISEASE , such as sleep talking or sleepwalking, sep- CHEMICAL arate from the hallucinations DISEASE ; some patients may also experience similar complex hal- lucinations during the day, unassociated with sleep.
Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Dream-like hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations DISEASE appear to differ in clini- cal features and pathogenesis from complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE arising in wakefulness after sudden arousals DISEASE during the night.
Sleep related hallucinations DISEASE are common in narcolepsy DISEASE and also occur as occasional phenomena in a high per- centage of the general population.
In contrast, complex nocturnal visual hallucina- tions appear to be rare and occur in the setting of a range of neurologic and visual disorders DISEASE (see Differential Diagnosis) as well as in an idiopathic DISEASE form.
However, further work is needed to establish whether or not these forms of hallucinations DISEASE represent different entities.
Demographics In large European population studies, sleep related hallucinations DISEASE have been reported to occur with a prevalence of 25% to 37% for hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE , whereas the equivalent reported prevalence for hypnopompic hallucinations DISEASE is 7% to 13%.
Both hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations DISEASE are more common in younger persons and occur slightly more frequently in women than in men.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Multivariate analyses in large population studies have suggested that sleep related hal- lucinations are associated with younger age, current drug use, past alcohol CHEMICAL use, anxiety DISEASE , mood disorder DISEASE , sleep onset insomnia DISEASE , and perceived insufficient sleep.
Familial Pattern Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications Sleep related hallucinations DISEASE appear to be more common in adolescence and early adult- DISEASE hood.
In many patients, the frequency appears to decrease with age.
The natural history of complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE depends on the underlying cause.
Developmental Issues Not known or applicable.
Pathology and Pathophysiology It is presumed that most sleep related hallucinations DISEASE are due to dream ideation DISEASE of REM sleep intruding into wakefulness, but this has not been firmly established.
Infrequent hallucinations DISEASE of this type may be within the limits of normal sleep-wake transition.
Complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE may in some cases be release phenomena in which loss of visual input or decreased reticular activating system activity results in the visual cortex generating aberrant images DISEASE .
Objective Findings Hypnagogic hallucinations DISEASE appear to arise predominantly from sleep onset REM periods.
However, the very few reports of polysomnography in complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE suggest an onset from NREM sleep.
MRI scans of the brain, PSG, EEG, and neuropsychological testing may help in the differential diagnosis and in identifying underlying disorders.
Differential Diagnosis Nightmares are frightening dreams awakening the patient from sleep.
They are clearly recognized as dreams and do not persist into wakefulness.
Exploding head syndrome DISEASE consists of a sudden sensation of an explosion in the head, usually at sleep onset and sometimes accompanied by a noise or flash of light.
It does not involve complex visual imagery and lasts only seconds.
In RBD DISEASE , the patient acts out dreams during REM sleep.
If not awakened by an observer, the person usually has little recollection of dream content.
Sleepwalking may occasionally be associated with dream ideation DISEASE , but the patient recognizes that the dream occurred during sleep.
Visual hallucinations DISEASE can be due to epileptic seizures DISEASE but are usually brief, stereotyped, and fragmentary in such cases.
Occasionally, complex visual hallucinations DISEASE may be associated with migraine DISEASE but are usually followed by a headache DISEASE .
Complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE may be seen in patients with narcolepsy DISEASE , PD DISEASE , DLB DISEASE , visual loss DISEASE (Charles Bonnet hallucinations DISEASE ), and midbrain and diencephalic pathology (peduncular hallucinosis DISEASE ), as well as with the use of β-adrenergic receptor- blocking medications.
Anxiety disorders DISEASE have been noted in some patients.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions
In contrast to the extensive study of sleep paralysis DISEASE , little work has been reported on sleep related hallucinations DISEASE .
It is uncertain whether they represent normal variants or pathologic entities.
It is unclear whether they are always associated with REM sleep intruding into wakefulness.
It is uncertain how frequently complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE are an independent entity, as opposed to representing a final common pathway of a range of other disorders.
Further work is needed to determine from which stages of sleep they arise.
269 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Bibliography Barnes J, David AS.
Visual hallucinations DISEASE in Parkinson’s disease DISEASE : a review and phenomenological survey.
J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2001;70:727–33.
Kavey N, Whyte J. Somnambulism associated with hallucinations DISEASE .
Psychosomatics 1993;34:86–90.
Mahowald M, Woods S, Schenck C. Sleeping dreams, waking hallucinations DISEASE , and the central nervous system.
Dreaming 1998;8:89–102.
Manford M, Andermann F. Complex visual hallucinations DISEASE .
Clinical and neurobiological insights.
Brain 1998;121:1819–40.
Ohayon M. Prevalence of hallucinations DISEASE and their pathological associations in the general population.
Psychiatry Res CHEMICAL 2000;97:153–64.
Ohayon M, Priest R, Caulet M, Guilleminault C. Hypnagogic DISEASE and hypnopompic hallucinations DISEASE : pathological phenomena?
Br J Psychiatry 1996;169:459–67.
Silber MH DISEASE , Hansen M, Girish M. Complex nocturnal visual hallucinations DISEASE .
Sleep Med 2005;6:363–6.
Sleep Enuresis ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 788.36 ICD-10-CM code: N39.44 CHEMICAL Alternate Names Enuresis nocturna DISEASE ; nocturnal bedwetting DISEASE ; primary, familial, functional, idiopathic DISEASE , monosymptomatic DISEASE , or essential enuresis DISEASE ; night wetting; sleep related enuresis DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Primary Sleep Enuresis – Criteria A-D must be met A.
The patient is older than five years.
B. The patient exhibits recurrent involuntary voiding during sleep, occurring at least twice a week.
C. The condition has been present for at least three months.
D.
The patient has never been consistently dry during sleep.
Secondary Sleep Enuresis – Criteria A-D must be met A.
The patient is older than five years.
B. The patient exhibits recurrent involuntary voiding during sleep, occurring at least twice a week.
C. The condition has been present for at least three months.
D.
The patient has previously been consistently dry during sleep for at least six months.
Essential Features Sleep enuresis DISEASE ( SE DISEASE ) is characterized by recurrent involuntary voiding that occurs during sleep.
In primary SE DISEASE , recurrent involuntary voiding occurs at least twice a week during sleep after five years of age in a patient who has never been consistently dry during sleep for six consecutive months.
SE DISEASE is considered secondary in a child or adult who had previously been dry for six consecutive months and then began wetting at least twice a week.
Both primary and secondary enuresis must be present for a period of at least three months.
Though primary and secondary enuresis DISEASE share the common symptom of voiding during sleep, they are understood as distinct phenomena with different etiologies.
SE DISEASE is associated with difficulty arousing from sleep in response to an urge to urinate and may occur during any sleep stage.
Sleep disorders DISEASE that fragment sleep such as sleep apnea DISEASE are associated with SE DISEASE , and treatment of these disorders may cure or reduce their incidence.
Associated Features Involuntary voiding during wakefulness may be associated with SE DISEASE and, if present, generally points toward a physiological etiology.
Psychosocial problems are consid- ered a relatively rare cause in primary SE DISEASE , though it does occur more commonly in children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder DISEASE and in children living in disorga- nized families.
Secondary SE DISEASE is seen more commonly in children who have recently experienced a significant psychosocial stress, such as parental divorce, physical or sexual abuse, or neglect.
Chronic constipation DISEASE and encopresis DISEASE (fecal soiling) often occur in children with secondary SE.
SE DISEASE can occur in association with diabetes DISEASE and urinary tract infection.
It may occur in individuals with nocturnal epilepsy DISEASE .
Among older adults, SE DISEASE may be associated with symptoms of congestive heart failure DISEASE , OSA DISEASE , depression DISEASE , and dementia DISEASE .
SRBD is reported in 8% to 47% of children with enuresis DISEASE , compared to an overall prev- alence of 1% to 2%.
PLMS DISEASE have been reported in patients with refractory SE DISEASE .
A large epidemiology study of children aged 6-10 years found that a current complaint of SE DISEASE was significantly associated with increased ORs (2.7-3.4) for subjectively high arousal threshold, night terrors DISEASE , nocturia DISEASE , and confusion DISEASE when awakened from sleep.
Other studies have found mouth breathing, nasal congestion DISEASE , snoring DISEASE , and restless sleep to be highly related to enuresis DISEASE in children.
271 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes The most important distinction is between primary and secondary SE.
Demographics SE DISEASE occurs in 15% to 20% of 5-year-olds.
It is three times more common in boys than in girls.
SE DISEASE is reported by 2.1% of community-dwelling older adults and is more common among women than men.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors The etiology of SE DISEASE is complex.
The factors that precipitate SE DISEASE on a particular night and at a particular time remain unknown.
One popular model hypothesizes that SE DISEASE consists of three interrelated factors: large nocturnal urine volume production, noc- turnal bladder overactivity DISEASE , and difficulty arousing from sleep.
Several studies suggest difficulty arousing from sleep is most important in primary enuresis DISEASE , whereas bladder instability/overactivity DISEASE is more important in secondary enuresis DISEASE .
Children with enuresis DISEASE are often described by their families as “deep sleepers” and very difficult to arouse.
A high arousal threshold has been objectively confirmed in these children.
It has been reported that fragmentation of sleep by disorders such as sleep apnea DISEASE is highly correlated with SE DISEASE .
Sleep fragmenting disorders such as sleep apnea DISEASE and PLMS DISEASE have been previously reported to be proximal triggers for the occurrence of disorders of arousal—sleepwalking DISEASE , confusional arousals DISEASE , and night terrors DISEASE .
Successful treatment of sleep apnea DISEASE in these disorders has been reported to result in reduction or elimination of disorders of arousal.
Similarly, surgical treatment of sleep apneas by adenotonsillec- tomy has been reported to cure nocturnal enuresis DISEASE in 60% or more of patients, although this is not a consistent result.
Several studies have noted the presence of sleep related breathing disorder DISEASE in > 40% of enuresis DISEASE patients studied.
However, not all sleep studies have noted SRBD in patients with enuresis DISEASE .
Those without SRBD were still found to have high arousal threshold from sleep.
Primary SE DISEASE is a disorder that occurs when an individual fails to arouse from sleep in response to bladder sensations DISEASE or fails to inhibit a bladder contraction.
These are devel- opmentally acquired skills, and, as such, there is a range in the ages of their acquisition.
A small proportion of children with primary SE DISEASE lack the normal increase in vasopressin CHEMICAL release during sleep, leading to a high urinary volume that exceeds the bladder capac- ity.
If these children do not arouse to the sensation of a full bladder, primary SE DISEASE is the result.
Secondary SE DISEASE can be caused by, or be associated with, any one of the following identifiable problems: (1) an inability to concentrate urine due to diabetes mellitus DISEASE , diabetes insipidus DISEASE , nephrogenic diabetes insipidus DISEASE ( idiopathic DISEASE or pharmacologic
[e.g., secondary to the use of lithium carbonate CHEMICAL ]), or sickle cell disease DISEASE ; (2) increased urine production secondary to the ingestion of caffeine CHEMICAL , diuretics, or other agents; (3) urinary tract pathology, such as urinary tract infections DISEASE , irritable bladder DISEASE , malformations of the genitourinary tract (e.g., ectopic ureter); (4) chronic constipation DISEASE and encopresis DISEASE ; (5) neurologic pathology, such as seizures DISEASE or neurogenic bladder; or (6) psychosocial stressors, such as parental divorce, neglect, physical or sexual abuse, and institution- alization.
The mechanisms by which secondary SE DISEASE is associated with these problems are often not understood.
Familial Patterns Hereditary factors are suspected in children with primary enuresis DISEASE .
There is often a high prevalence of enuresis DISEASE among the parents, siblings, and other relatives of the child with primary enuresis DISEASE .
The reported prevalence is 77% when both parents were enuretic as children and 44% when one parent has a history of enuresis DISEASE .
Recent linkage studies support the hypothesis of genetic and phenotypic heterogeneity of SE DISEASE .
A putative linkage of SE DISEASE to a region on chromosomes 22q, 13q, and 12q across different families has been reported.
Onset, Course, and Complications Voiding is a spinal reflex during wakefulness and sleep during infancy, until about 18 months of age.
Between 18 months and three years of age, the child is able to delay voiding with a full bladder, first during wakefulness and at a later age during sleep.
The primary determinant of the age at which this skill is acquired is developmental matura- tion.
Somewhat arbitrarily, primary SE DISEASE is defined as a problem if it persists beyond five years of age.
The spontaneous cure rate is 15% per year.
The primary complication of SE DISEASE is to the child’s self-esteem.
How well the child’s family deals with the symptom is an important determinant of whether complications develop.
Secondary SE DISEASE can occur at any age.
Complications of secondary SE DISEASE are determined by the problem leading to the enuresis DISEASE .
Developmental Issues The developmental pattern of enuresis DISEASE is similar to NREM parasomnias DISEASE , although its first occurrence in adulthood is uncommon.
Pathology and Pathophysiology SE DISEASE is a heterogeneous disorder DISEASE with various underlying pathophysiological mecha- nisms, resulting in a mismatch between nocturnal bladder capacity and the amount of Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE urine produced during sleep, in association with a simultaneous failure of arousal from sleep in response to the sensation of bladder fullness DISEASE .
SE DISEASE can be seen in association with sleep fragmentation disorders DISEASE including SRBD, which in children is most often secondary to adenotonsillar hypertrophy.
Objective Findings In primary and secondary SE DISEASE , enuretic episodes can occur in all sleep stages, during nocturnal wakefulness, and in association with transient arousals DISEASE .
Sleep stages have not been found to be different on nights when enuresis DISEASE occurs versus nights on which it does not occur.
The results of polysomnographic studies of children with enuresis DISEASE com- pared to normal controls have been inconsistent.
A computerized power analysis of sleep data suggested an increase in delta power, whereas the majority of other studies have reported no differences.
However, a recent study found those age 6-14 years had elevated light stage N1 sleep and reduced N3 sleep and REM sleep compared to normal controls.
The population with enuresis DISEASE had a significantly elevated arousal index.
SRBD has been reported in 8% to 47% of children with SE DISEASE .
SE DISEASE and sleep apnea DISEASE are highly correlated with an increasing prevalence of enuresis DISEASE as the respiratory distur- bance index (RDI) increases.
In addition to SRBD, PLMS DISEASE (range of 3.9 to 38.6 per hour of sleep) have been reported in a group of children with treatment-resistant DISEASE SE.
Recent studies have demonstrated that patients with enuresis DISEASE are subjectively sleepier than normal controls.
This has been hypothesized to result from fragmented nocturnal sleep and is consistent with a large body of sleep research in other areas.
Differential Diagnosis Enuresis DISEASE may be caused by a variety of medical or neurological disorders DISEASE such as diabetes mellitus DISEASE , diabetes insipidus DISEASE , epilepsy DISEASE , sickle cell disease DISEASE , bowel or bladder dysfunction DISEASE , anatomical abnormalities or infection DISEASE of the urinary tract, neurological/ DISEASE developmental disorders or other sleep disorders DISEASE , especially OSA DISEASE .
Organic pathology of the urinary tract is more prevalent in children who, in addition to sleep enuresis DISEASE , also exhibit daytime enuresis DISEASE , abnormalities in the initiation of micturition DISEASE , or abnormal urinary flow.
Evaluation of sleep enuresis DISEASE should include complete enuresis DISEASE history, sleep history, physical examination and laboratory studies (as indicated) to exclude these etiol- ogies.
When signs and symptoms of sleep apnea DISEASE are present—mouth breathing, snoring DISEASE , adenotonsillar hypertrophy DISEASE , daytime sleepiness DISEASE , hyperactivity DISEASE —a sleep study should be conducted.
274 Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Recent advances suggest that the terms primary and secondary enuresis DISEASE may be overly simplistic.
Further work is necessary to understand the genetic and clinical aspects of SE DISEASE .
Other sleep disorders DISEASE are common in children with SE DISEASE .
Though it may be possible that the apneas, hypopneas DISEASE , and snoring-related arousals DISEASE in children with SRBD could be the trigger of SE DISEASE , many children with SE DISEASE do not have a sleep disorder DISEASE .
In such cases, the underlying bladder overactivity DISEASE may be the stimulus for arousal.
Studies of the relationship of sleep, sleep disorders DISEASE , and sleep fragmentation to SE DISEASE performed to date have been inconsistent.
This is likely due to differing definitions of enuresis DISEASE and varying research methodologies.
Further sophisticated sleep laboratory studies are necessary to elucidate the relationship.
In particular, the proximal trigger for episodes of SE DISEASE has not been determined.
Some studies suggest enuresis DISEASE is sponta- neous, whereas others suggest a relationship to sleep disorders DISEASE that result in arousals— similar to findings in disorders of arousal.

Elevated sleep arousal thresholds in enuretic boys: clinical implications.
Acta Paediatr 1997;86:381–4.

Sleep disturbance DISEASE and bladder dysfunction DISEASE in enuretic children with treatment failure: fact or fiction?
Scand J Urol Nephrol Suppl 1999;202:20–3.
