N Engl J Med 2008;359;22–4.
Parasomnia DISEASE Due to a Medical Disorder ICD-9-CM code: 327.44 ICD-10-CM code: G47.54 The essential feature of this diagnosis is the presence of a parasomnia DISEASE that is attrib- utable to an underlying neurological or medical condition.
RBD DISEASE is the parasomnia DISEASE most commonly associated with an underlying neurological condition (“symptomatic RBD DISEASE ”).
However, when diagnostic criteria for RBD DISEASE are met, the more specific diagno- sis of REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE should be made.
Complex nocturnal sleep related (hypnagogic and hypnopompic DISEASE ) visual hallucina- tions can occur with neurological disorders DISEASE such as narcolepsy DISEASE , PD DISEASE , DLB DISEASE , visual loss DISEASE (Charles Bonnet hallucinations DISEASE ), and midbrain and diencephalic pathology (pedun- cular hallucinosis DISEASE ).
Dreaming and sleep paralysis DISEASE may or may not be associated with these hallucinations DISEASE .
Parasomnia DISEASE Due to a Medication or Substance ICD-9-CM code: 292.85 (drug-induced); 291.82 (alcohol-induced) ICD-10-CM code: F11-F19 (see table in Appendix B for detailed coding instructions)
The essential feature of this diagnosis is the close temporal relationship between expo- sure to a drug, medication, or biological substance and the onset of the signs and symp- toms of that disorder.
A likely causal relationship can be inferred if signs and symp- toms of the parasomnia DISEASE disappear when the drug or substance is withdrawn.
The emergent parasomnia DISEASE can be a de novo parasomnia DISEASE , the aggravation of a chronic intermittent parasomnia DISEASE , or the reactivation of a previous parasomnia DISEASE .
As discussed previously, a variety of medications and biological substances, including selective serotonin CHEMICAL reuptake inhibitors, venlafaxine CHEMICAL , tricyclic antidepressants CHEMICAL , mono- amine CHEMICAL oxidase inhibitors, mirtazapine CHEMICAL , bisoprolol CHEMICAL , selegiline CHEMICAL , or cholinergic treatment for Alzheimer disease DISEASE , have been reported to be associated with acute or chronic RBD DISEASE .
Acute RBD DISEASE can also be seen during states of withdrawal from cocaine CHEMICAL , amphetamine CHEMICAL , alcohol CHEMICAL , barbiturate CHEMICAL , and meprobamate CHEMICAL abuse.
Caffeine CHEMICAL and chocolate abuse DISEASE have been implicated in causing or unmasking RBD DISEASE .
However, when diagnostic criteria for RBD DISEASE are met, the more specific diagnosis of REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE should be made.
The use of medications such as β-adrenergic receptor-blocking agents can be associ- ated with sleep related hallucinations DISEASE .
When the clinical presentation suggests a direct relationship between a drug or substance and sleep related hallucinations DISEASE , a diagnosis of parasomnia DISEASE due to a medication or substance should be employed.
Sedative-hypnotics such as zolpidem CHEMICAL and zopiclone CHEMICAL have been associated with apparent NREM parasomnias DISEASE including SRED and sleep driving.
It has been suggested that sleep driving is an overlap behavior in which the sedative-hypnotic increases the arousal threshold during sleep at the beginning of the behavior, while later behavior is due to the CNS depressing effects of the drug while awake.
It has not been determined if drug-re- lated NREM parasomnias DISEASE are associated with the same genetic predisposition, priming factors, and triggers observed in disorders of arousal.
When clinical presentation sug- gests a direct relationship between disorders of arousal and use of a drug or substance DISEASE , a diagnosis of parasomnia DISEASE due to a medication or substance should be employed.
Alcohol CHEMICAL has often appeared on lists of potential sleepwalking triggers without a basis in reliable empirical scientific research.
Recent evidence-based reviews have found no relationship between alcohol CHEMICAL and sleepwalking.
The behavior of the alcohol-in- toxicated individual may superficially resemble that of the sleepwalker.
However, the sleepwalker is typically severely cognitively impaired, but with only limited motor impairment.
The alcohol-intoxicated individual’s level of cognitive functioning may be reduced, but not absent, whereas motor behavior is severely impaired.
Proponents of the theory of alcohol CHEMICAL related sleepwalking suggest that the effects of alcohol CHEMICAL are similar to that of sleep deprivation—that is, alcohol CHEMICAL increases deep sleep.
However, this claim in not substantiated by sleep laboratory-based studies in normal controls, and no empirical sleep studies of alcohol CHEMICAL and sleepwalking DISEASE have ever been conducted.
There is no scientific evidence that complex behaviors occurring during the sleep period following alcohol CHEMICAL ingestion are anything other than the nocturnal wandering of Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE an alcohol-intoxicated individual.
Unconsciousness, intoxication, and sleep are very different states of consciousness.
Parasomnias DISEASE should be easily distinguished from alcohol CHEMICAL intoxication by the presence of significant alcohol CHEMICAL ingestion prior to bedtime.
The association of therapeutic doses of sedative hypnotic drugs and apparent para- somnias should be carefully distinguished from the expected effects of drug abuse DISEASE or misuse that result in CNS depression DISEASE .
Investigations of drivers who had accidents DISEASE attributed to drug-related sleep driving are reported to show that (1) blood levels of prescribed sedative hypnotics exceeded therapeutic ranges; (2) the individuals failed to take the medication at the correct time or remain in bed for sufficient time follow- ing ingestion; and/or (3) the individuals combined sedative-hypnotics with other CNS depressants and/or alcohol CHEMICAL .
Driving with a high blood level of a sedative-hypnotic can result in significant cognitive and motor impairment DISEASE .
Serious accidents DISEASE can result.
Sleep driving and other complex behaviors in this population are more likely to have resulted from drug misuse and abuse rather than true parasomnias DISEASE .
Parasomnia DISEASE , Unspecified ICD-9-CM code: 327.40 ICD-10-CM code: G47.50 This diagnosis is intended for parasomnias DISEASE that cannot be classified elsewhere or for cases in which the physician has a clinical suspicion of a parasomnia DISEASE but is unable to establish a specific diagnosis.
In many cases, “ parasomnia DISEASE , unspecified” will be a tem- porary diagnosis.
However, in other patients, an underlying condition may not ever be established, and in those patients, “ parasomnia DISEASE , unspecified” should remain an ongoing diagnosis.
278 Isolated Symptoms and Normal Variants
Sleep Talking Alternate Names Somniloquy.
The essential feature is talking, with varying degrees of comprehensibility, during sleep.
Sleep talking may occur during REM or NREM sleep.
Sleep talking can be idiopathic DISEASE or associated with parasomnias DISEASE such as RBD DISEASE or disorders of arousal such as confusional arousal.
Sleep talking may follow arousals DISEASE from sleep or more rarely cause them.
Sleep talking is highly prevalent.
A recent cross-sectional epidemiologic study found the life- time prevalence of sleep talking to be 66% and current prevalence—in the past three months—to be 17%.
There is no apparent sex difference.
Onset and course are unknown.
Complications usually arise when sleep talking is very frequent or loud or if the content is objectionable to others.
Sleep talking is usually reported by the bed partner or someone sleeping in the same room or sleeping area as the affected individual.
Sleep talking can disrupt the sleep of a bed partner, roommate, or others in a group-sleeping situation (such as college dormitories, military barracks, fire stations, or a tent while camping).
The content of sleep talking has not been shown to reflect actual prior waking behavior or memories.
The sleep talker is rarely aware of his or her sleep talking.
Nocturnal vocalization, including frank sleep talking, is often seen in patients with RBD DISEASE and subclinical RBD DISEASE .
A recent report notes that sleep talking may be a useful diagnostic marker for differentiating DLB DISEASE from Alzheimer disease DISEASE and other types of dementia DISEASE .
The vocalizations of RBD DISEASE may be loud, emotional, profane, and associated with behav- iors that correlate with remembered dream mentation.
Nocturnal seizures DISEASE may be asso- ciated with vocalization that tends to be stereotypic.
The vocalizations associated with sleep terrors DISEASE are emotionally laden and associated with behaviors of intense arousal and agitation DISEASE .
In PTSD, increased vocalizations during sleep have been described.
Bibliography Arkin AM, Toth MF, Baker J, Hastey JM.
The frequency of sleep talking in the laboratory among chronic sleep talkers and good dream recallers.
J Nerv Ment Dis 1970;151:369–74.
Bjorvatn B, Grønli J, Pallesen S. Prevalence of different parasomnias DISEASE in the general population.
Sleep Med 2010;11:1031–4.
279 Parasomnias Parasomnias DISEASE Honda K CHEMICAL , Hashimoto DISEASE M, Yatabe Y, et al.
The usefulness of monitoring sleep talking for the diagnosis of Dementia DISEASE with Lewy DISEASE bodies.
Int Psychogeriatr 2013;25:851–8.
Hublin C, Kaprio J, Partinen M, Koskenvuo M. Sleeptalking in twins: epidemiology and psychiatric DISEASE comorbidity.
Behav Genet 1998;28:289–98.
Reimao RN, Lefevre AB.
Prevalence of sleep-talking DISEASE in childhood.
Brain Dev 1980;2:353–7.
280 Sleep Related Movement Disorders Restless Legs Syndrome DISEASE ............................................................................282 Periodic Limb Movement Disorder DISEASE .............................................................292 Sleep Related Leg Cramps ........................................................................299 Sleep Related Bruxism...............................................................................303 Sleep Related Rhythmic Movement Disorder.............................................312 Benign Sleep Myoclonus of Infancy ...........................................................317 Propriospinal Myoclonus DISEASE at Sleep Onset....................................................321 Sleep Related Movement Disorder DISEASE Due to a Medical Disorder..................325 Sleep Related Movement Disorder DISEASE Due to a Medication or Substance .....326 Sleep Related Movement Disorder, Unspecified........................................327 Isolated Symptoms and Normal Variants Excessive Fragmentary Myoclonus DISEASE ...........................................................328 Hypnagogic Foot Tremor DISEASE and Alternating Leg Muscle Activation ...............330 Sleep Starts ( Hypnic DISEASE Jerks)........................................................................335 Sleep related movement disorders are primarily characterized by relatively simple, usually stereotyped, movements that disturb sleep or its onset.
Restless legs syndrome DISEASE ( RLS DISEASE ) is an exception in that patients typically engage in walking or nonstereotypic limb movement to reduce leg discomfort.
However, RLS DISEASE is closely associated with periodic limb movements (PLMs), which are usually simple and stereotyped within a series.
Nocturnal sleep disturbance DISEASE or complaints of daytime sleepiness DISEASE or fatigue DISEASE are a prerequisite for a diagnosis of a sleep related movement disorder DISEASE .
For example, many normal sleepers exhibit episodes of periodic limb movements of sleep (PLMS) but have no complaint of a sleep disturbance DISEASE , nor do they show a significant objective dis- turbance of their sleep as a result of the movements.
Such persons should not be classi- fied as having periodic limb movement disorder DISEASE ( PLMD DISEASE ), but instead, the presence of PLMS DISEASE should simply be noted.
Similar considerations relate to the distinction between rhythmic movement disorder DISEASE and the presence of rhythmic movements.
Body movements that disturb sleep also are seen in many other sleep disorder DISEASE categories (e.g., in parasomnias DISEASE such as sleepwalking, sleep terrors DISEASE , and rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder DISEASE ( RBD DISEASE )).
However, these parasomnias DISEASE differ from the simple ste- reotyped movements categorized as sleep related movement disorders in that they involve complex behaviors during the sleep period.
Parasomnia-related movements may appear Sleep Related Movement Disorders purposeful and goal directed, but are outside the conscious awareness of the individual.
Parasomnias DISEASE are listed in a separate section from the sleep related movement disorders.
Although the history may be diagnostic, polysomnography is sometimes necessary to make a firm diagnosis of sleep related movement disorders and distinguish them from parasomnias DISEASE .
In these cases, it is necessary to add all-night video recording to the poly- somnographic recording and to correlate the documented movements with the techni- cian’s description of the patient’s behavior and level of consciousness in order to estab- lish a diagnosis.
There are some movement disorders DISEASE that may occur during both sleep and wakefulness.
If the presentation during sleep is significantly different from that during wakefulness, or if the movement is entirely confined to sleep, then the move- ment disorder is classified here (e.g., the occurrence of bruxism DISEASE exclusively in sleep).
Restless Legs Syndrome ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 333.94 Alternate Names Willis-Ekbom disease DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met ICD-10-CM code: G25.81 A. An urge to move the legs, usually accompanied by or thought to be caused by uncomfortable and unpleasant sensations in the legs.1,2
These symptoms must: . Begin or worsen during periods of rest or inactivity such as lying down or sitting; . Be partially or totally relieved by movement, such as walking or stretching, at least as long as the activity continues;3 and .
Occur exclusively or predominantly in the evening or night rather than during the day.4 B. The above features are not solely accounted for as symptoms of another medical or a behavioral condition (e.g., leg cramps DISEASE , positional discomfort, myalgia DISEASE , venous stasis DISEASE , leg edema DISEASE , arthritis DISEASE , habitual foot tapping).
C. The symptoms of RLS DISEASE cause concern, distress, sleep disturbance DISEASE , or impairment in mental, physical, social, occupational, educational, behavioral, or other important areas of functioning.5 Notes .
Sometimes the urge to move the legs is present without the uncomfortable sensations, and sometimes the arms or other parts of the body are involved in addition to the legs.
2. For children, the description of these symptoms should be in the child’s own words.
3.
When symptoms are very severe, relief by activity may not be noticeable but must have been previously present.
4.
As a result of severity, treatment intervention, or treatment-induced augmentation, the worsening in the evening or night may not be noticeable but must have been previously present.
5.
For certain research applications, such as genetic or epidemiological studies, it may be appropriate to omit criterion C.
If so, this should be clearly stated in the research report.
Essential Features RLS DISEASE is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by a complaint of a strong, nearly irresist- ible urge to move the limbs.
This urge to move is often but not always accompanied by other uncomfortable sensations felt deep inside the limbs or by a feeling that is simply difficult or impossible to describe.
Although the legs are most prominently affected, “restless legs” is a misnomer, in that 21% to 57% of individuals with RLS DISEASE describe some arm sensations.
The most common adult RLS DISEASE descriptors in English are “rest- less,” “uncomfortable,” “twitchy,” “need to stretch,” “urge to move,” and “legs want to move on their own.”
About half express their RLS sensations DISEASE as painful.
“Numb” and “cold” are very uncommon descriptors for RLS. Criteria A1-3 specify the necessary characteristics of the RLS sensations DISEASE : worse at rest, better with movement, and predominant occurrence in the evening or night.
The separation of worsening at rest (criterion A1) from worsening in the evening/ night (criterion A3) is based on circadian rhythm studies that show an increase at night, independent of activity level.
RLS DISEASE must be differentiated from other condi- tions that can mimic RLS DISEASE (criterion B).
Clinically significant RLS DISEASE is defined by RLS DISEASE symptoms causing substantial distress, sleep disturbance DISEASE , or impairment of function (criterion C).
Associated Features Disturbed sleep is a common, prominent, and distressing aspect of RLS.
Sleep onset and maintenance complaints in individuals with RLS DISEASE are notably higher than in con- trols, with odds ratios (OR) between 1.7 and 3.5.
In clinical populations, disturbed Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders sleep is reported in 60% to 90% of individuals with RLS DISEASE , is typically the most trou- bling symptom, and is often the primary reason for seeking medical care.
The Medical Outcomes Study Sleep Questionnaire scores for sleep quantity, sleep disturbance DISEASE , sleep adequacy, and sleep problems are significantly worse for RLS DISEASE patients than con- trols.
Daytime fatigue DISEASE and daytime sleepiness DISEASE are also common complaints; however, the sleepiness DISEASE is not as severe as expected for the degree of sleep disruption, implying hyperarousal in RLS.
In contrast to obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE , Epworth Sleepiness Scale scores in RLS DISEASE are typically in the normal range, and either no different or marginally elevated when compared to normal controls.
Clinical sleep disturbance correlates with both severity of RLS DISEASE and health impact of RLS.
Some individuals with RLS DISEASE may choose to work at night, thereby shifting quiet activities and their sleep schedule away from the circadian peak of their RLS DISEASE symptoms. PLMs, a family history of RLS DISEASE , and response to dopaminergic therapy are supportive of the diagnosis.
Periodic limb movements can occur in sleep (PLMS) or wakeful- ness (PLMW).
PLMW occur during quiet rest and frequently at the transition between waking and sleep, disrupting sleep onset or the return to sleep.
PLMS DISEASE are frequently associated with arousal from sleep.
RLS DISEASE sensory and motor features respond initially to treatment with dopaminergic therapy in almost all cases.
Multiple clinic-based and population-based studies have shown an increased preva- lence of mood and anxiety disorders DISEASE in individuals with RLS DISEASE .
Most controlled studies using validated assessments have shown significantly increased ORs for moderately or highly elevated depressive symptoms DISEASE (OR 1.95 and 3.67), major depression DISEASE (OR 2.6), major depressive disorder DISEASE (OR 2.57 and 4.7), generalized anxiety disorder DISEASE (OR 3.5), panic disorder DISEASE (OR 4.7, 12.9, and 18.9), and posttraumatic stress disorder DISEASE (OR 3.76).
In addition, a positive correlation has been found between the severity of RLS DISEASE and depression/anxiety DISEASE symptoms.
Relevant to the RLS-depression relationship is the emerging evidence that treatment of RLS DISEASE improves depressive DISEASE symptoms.
Similarly, increased rates of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder DISEASE ( ADHD DISEASE ) have been found in RLS DISEASE , both in pediatric and adult studies.
Emerging data indicate that about one fourth of individuals with RLS DISEASE have ADHD DISEASE symptoms, and conversely, that 12% to 35% of those with ADHD DISEASE meet criteria for RLS.
Other medical condi- tions for which there is some evidence for greater-than-chance association include narcolepsy DISEASE , migraine DISEASE , chronic obstructive pulmonary disease DISEASE , Parkinson disease DISEASE , multiple sclerosis DISEASE , peripheral neuropathy DISEASE , obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE , diabetes melli- DISEASE tus, fibromyalgia DISEASE , rheumatoid arthritis DISEASE , nocturnal eating, obesity DISEASE , thyroid disease DISEASE , and heart disease DISEASE .
284 Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Evidence in the literature is not sufficient to support well-defined subtypes of RLS.
Early-onset RLS DISEASE (prior to age 45 years) is more familial and associated with slower progression than late-onset RLS DISEASE .
In addition, the classification of “secondary” RLS DISEASE has been suggested when the condition occurs in association with iron deficiency DISEASE , preg- nancy, and chronic renal failure DISEASE , but this construct has been challenged based on patho- physiological, family history, genetic, and clinical course data.
Demographics The overall prevalence of RLS DISEASE has been estimated at 5% to 10% in European and North American population-based studies.
However, in Asian countries, studies thus far indicate a lower prevalence.
Prevalence is about twice as high in women than in men.
In most studies, prevalence increases with age up to 60-70 years, except in Asian populations where an age-related increase has not been found.
Various measures of clinical significance such as frequency (1-2 times/week), severity (moderate to severe distress), differential diagnosis, and impact have been applied to population-based studies.
These analyses indicate the prevalence of clinically significant RLS DISEASE to be 2% to 3% in Europe and North America, but lower in Asia.
Annual incidence rates have been reported as 0.8% to 2.2%.
Pediatric prevalence rates are 2% to 4% in UK/US and Turkish studies, with moderate to severe RLS DISEASE in about 0.5% to 1%.
Adolescents are more likely to have moderate to severe RLS DISEASE symptoms than younger children—one half of 12- to 17-year-olds com- pared to one fourth of 8- to 11-year-olds with RLS.
Boys are affected as often as girls, with the sex difference not emerging until the late teens or twenties.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors A positive family history of RLS DISEASE , the genetic variants noted below, and female sex confer increased risk for RLS.
The best characterized precipitating factors are iron CHEMICAL deficiency, certain medications, pregnancy, chronic renal failure DISEASE , and prolonged immo- bility.
Mild iron deficiency DISEASE , characterized by serum ferritin below 50 μg/L, has been associated with increased severity of RLS DISEASE , and repletion of iron CHEMICAL stores from below 50-75 μg/L has been found to diminish RLS DISEASE symptoms.
Medications that may precip- itate or aggravate RLS DISEASE and/or PLMS DISEASE include sedating antihistamines CHEMICAL , some centrally active dopamine CHEMICAL receptor antagonists, and most antidepressants CHEMICAL .
An exception is the antidepressant bupropion CHEMICAL , with its dopamine-promoting activity.
The prevalence of RLS DISEASE during pregnancy is two to three times greater than in the general population.
There is a peak in the number of women affected by RLS DISEASE in the Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders third trimester, with resolution of symptoms for most, but not all, by one month after delivery.
Independent predictors of RLS DISEASE during pregnancy are a family history of RLS DISEASE (OR 8.43), a history of RLS DISEASE in prior pregnancy (OR 53.74), a history of RLS DISEASE in the past (OR 12.91), and hemoglobin ≤11 g/dL (OR 2.05).
Parity, the number of previous pregnancies, appears to account for the 2:1 sex difference between women and men in the general population prevalence of RLS.
In chronic renal failure DISEASE patients, the prevalence of RLS DISEASE is two to five times greater than in the general population.
This represents prevalence rates of 11% to 58% in US and European chronic renal failure DISEASE clinics.
Compared to patients with chronic renal failure DISEASE without RLS DISEASE , those with RLS DISEASE have greater sleep disturbance DISEASE , report poorer quality of life, and more frequently discontinue dialysis prematurely.
Typically, RLS DISEASE symptoms improve dramatically within one month after kidney transplantation but become severe again with transplant failure.
There is limited or contradictory evidence for sleep deprivation, peripheral neuropathy DISEASE , radiculopathy DISEASE , pain DISEASE , caffeine CHEMICAL , tobacco, or alcohol CHEMICAL as exacerbating factors for RLS.
Familial Patterns Early-onset RLS DISEASE is highly familial, with 40% to 92% of cases reporting affected family members.
High concordance rates are observed in monozygotic twins.
The risk of RLS DISEASE is two to six times greater for first-degree relatives of patients with RLS DISEASE than for those from the general population.
Although an autosomal dominant model of RLS DISEASE is sug- gested by many family studies, recent genomewide linkage and association studies suggest a more complex gene-environment pattern.
Linkage analyses have reported several different gene loci associated with RLS DISEASE but, to date, no single causative gene.
However, genomewide association studies have identified single nucleotide poly- morphisms in RLS, four of which have been replicated: BTBD9, MEIS1, MAP2K5/ LBXCOR, and PTPRD.
Nonetheless, the relationship between familial RLS DISEASE and these findings remains to be determined.
Onset, Course, and Complications Onset of RLS DISEASE symptoms occurs at all ages, from childhood to late adult life.
Mean age of onset for familial RLS DISEASE is in the third or fourth decade, with onset prior to age 21 years in about one third of cases.
The clinical course of RLS DISEASE differs based on age of onset.
In early-onset RLS DISEASE (before age 45 years), slow progression of symptoms is found in about two thirds of cases.
Most of the remaining one third report stable symp- toms over time, although remission has been described.
In late-onset RLS DISEASE , rapid pro- gression is typical and aggravating factors are common.
286 Significant impairment of health-related quality of life (HRQoL) has been found in moderate to severe RLS DISEASE .
Both physical health and mental health scores have consis- tently been found to be lower for individuals with RLS DISEASE , using standard QoL assess- ment tools.
The HRQoL impairments are strongly associated with severity of RLS DISEASE and remain after controlling for age, sex, and disease comorbidity.
In addition, patients with cancer DISEASE , type 2 diabetes DISEASE , or renal failure DISEASE who also have RLS DISEASE have been shown to have poorer quality of life than those without RLS DISEASE .
Overall, RLS DISEASE accounts for a major disease burden on those who suffer from it, demonstrated to be similar to or worse than that associated with osteoarthritis DISEASE , congestive heart failure DISEASE , depression DISEASE , Parkinson disease DISEASE , or stroke DISEASE .
Large population-based studies have found positive associations between RLS DISEASE and cardiovascular disease DISEASE , including coronary heart disease DISEASE and stroke DISEASE .
Repetitive surges in heart rate and blood pressure associated with PLMS DISEASE are a potential mediator in the physiology of these relationships.
Only limited mortality data are available, suggesting increased risk of mortality in women and in chronic renal failure DISEASE patients with RLS DISEASE .
Developmental Issues The accurate diagnosis of RLS DISEASE in children and adolescents requires understanding of developmental language and cognitive skills.
Adequate verbal skills are needed for children to communicate the sensory component of RLS DISEASE and description must be in “the child’s own words,” rather than by a parent or caretaker.
For criterion A, children rarely use or understand the word “urge.”
Instead they describe that their legs “need to” “have to” or “got to” move.
Descriptors for the discomfort include: bugs, ants, weird/ funny feelings, tingle DISEASE , wiggly, and shaky.
Younger children often use the word “kick” rather than “move,” e.g., “my legs want to kick.”
Similar to adults, children report arm involvement in almost half of cases.
Sitting in class, lying in bed, reading a book, and riding in a car are situations where children report onset or worsening of their symp- toms.
Relief is typically achieved by moving around, walking, rubbing, kicking, or distraction.
Perhaps as a result of prolonged periods of sitting in class, two thirds of children and adolescents with RLS DISEASE report daytime leg sensations DISEASE .
Because of this, for diagnostic criterion A3 (worse in the evening/night), it is important to compare equal duration of sitting or lying down in the day to sitting or lying down in the evening/ night.
However, even with such comparisons, a significant subset of children do not report worsening at evening/night, yet meet all other diagnostic criteria and have sup- portive features for RLS DISEASE , including a positive family history.
Children who are age six years or older and developmentally normal have been shown to report detailed, ade- quate descriptors for RLS DISEASE symptoms.
For children who are too young to adequately describe RLS sensations DISEASE or are developmentally delayed, a PLMD DISEASE diagnosis may be Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders the initial diagnosis, with full RLS symptomatology evident over time.
Diagnosis by observational techniques has been suggested but not yet validated.
The differential diagnosis of pediatric RLS DISEASE includes positional discomfort, sore DISEASE leg muscles, joint/tendon injury DISEASE , and bruises, all of which are common mimics.
In child- hood, RLS DISEASE is frequently misdiagnosed as “growing pains DISEASE .”
Four specific domains that are affected in pediatric RLS DISEASE are sleep, daily activities, mood, and energy/vital- ity.
Difficulties with sleep onset, sleep maintenance, and sleep quality are common.
Negative influence of RLS DISEASE on waking activities includes academic impact due to dis- ruption of schoolwork, homework, and ability to concentrate.
Severity assessment of pediatric RLS DISEASE has thus far been limited to simple measures of self-reported frequency and intensity.
Because pediatric RLS DISEASE is highly familial, the presence of RLS DISEASE in a first-degree rela- tive DISEASE helps to increase diagnostic certainty in childhood RLS DISEASE .
Similarly, the presence of PLMS DISEASE or a history of PLMD DISEASE is quite helpful in supporting an RLS DISEASE diagnosis in chil- dren.
As in adults, approximately 70% of children with RLS DISEASE demonstrate PLMS DISEASE ≥ 5/ hour on a single night and nearly 90% when multiple nights are sampled.
PLMS DISEASE ≥ 5/ hour are uncommon in pediatric normative samples.
As noted above, pediatric RLS DISEASE is comorbid with ADHD DISEASE in about one fourth of cases, and, as in adults, higher rates of anxiety DISEASE and depressive DISEASE symptoms are found.
RLS DISEASE is common in pediatric chronic kidney disease DISEASE .
Prevalence rates of RLS DISEASE increase with age until late adulthood then stabilize or decrease slightly in the elderly.
However, strong associations with anxiety DISEASE , mood disorders DISEASE , and decreased QoL measures remain in the elderly.
Diagnostic criteria for RLS DISEASE in the cog- nitive-impaired elderly have been suggested but not validated.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Brain iron CHEMICAL deficiency, central nervous system dopamine CHEMICAL regulation, and genetics appear to be primary factors in the pathophysiology of RLS.
Iron CHEMICAL is important in brain dopa- mine production and synaptic density, as well as in myelin synthesis and energy pro- duction.
A connection between RLS DISEASE and low brain iron CHEMICAL is supported by autopsy data, MRI, brain sonography, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis.
Evidence for central nervous system dopaminergic system involvement comes mainly from multiple randomized clinical trials that have clearly demonstrated the effect of dopaminergic drugs for RLS DISEASE and PLMS DISEASE .
In addition, an altered dopaminergic profile in RLS DISEASE is supported by func- tional MRI, positron emission tomography, and autopsy data.
Association of gene vari- ants BTBD9, MEIS1, MAP2K5/LBXCOR, and PTPRD with RLS DISEASE has been replicated, indicating a genetic substrate upon which environmental factors might act.
BTBD9 is estimated to confer a population attributable risk (PAR) of 50% for RLS.
Together, BTBD9, MEIS1, and MAP2K5/LBXCOR account for 70% of the PAR for RLS DISEASE in indi- viduals with European ancestry.
Thus far, two of the variants, BTBD9 and MEIS1, appear to influence expression of PLMS DISEASE , as well as iron CHEMICAL homeostasis.
However, the full role of RLS DISEASE gene variants has not been adequately defined.
Objective Findings Although polysomnography is not routinely indicated in the evaluation of RLS DISEASE , poly- somnographic studies demonstrate significant objective sleep abnormalities DISEASE in RLS DISEASE , with increased latency to persistent sleep and higher arousal index as the most consis- tent differences in sleep architecture.
PLMS DISEASE ≥5/hour occur in 70% to 80% of adults with RLS DISEASE on single-night testing but in >90% when multiple nights are sampled.
In adult RLS DISEASE , PLMS DISEASE are more prominent during the first half of the night and vary in frequency from night to night.
About one third of PLMS DISEASE are associated with cortical arousals DISEASE , and most have associated autonomic arousals DISEASE .
PLMS DISEASE are not influenced by placebo effect.
PLMS arousals DISEASE contribute to the primary RLS morbidity of sleep dis- turbance.
Furthermore, RLS DISEASE sensory symptoms impair return to sleep, and thereby result in more prolonged awakening.
The Suggested Immobilization Test (SIT) evaluates PLMW and related sensory com- ponents of RLS DISEASE during resting wakefulness.
A standard polysomnogram recording without respiratory measures is used for one hour before the usual bedtime while the subject sits comfortably awake and upright in bed with the legs outstretched.
RLS DISEASE diagnosis is supported by a finding of more than 40 PLMW/hour.
Activity monitors with high-frequency sampling and body-position monitoring may be attached to the ankle or foot to provide an alternate measure of PLMs.
Recordings assess the frequency and variability of PLMs from night to night, typically over three to five nights.
Differential Diagnosis The differentiation of RLS DISEASE from other conditions that may have characteristics of RLS DISEASE is essential, because approximately 40% of individuals without RLS DISEASE will report some urge or need to move the legs while at rest.
Fulfilling diagnostic criteria A2 (better with movement) and A3 (worse in the evening/night) improves specificity for an RLS DISEASE diagnosis to only about 70%, based on studies that have used structured diagnostic interviews.
However, differentiating RLS DISEASE from leg cramps DISEASE and positional discomfort improves specificity to 94%, emphasizing the importance of differential diagnosis.
The Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders most important “mimics” of RLS DISEASE are leg cramps DISEASE , positional discomfort, arthralgias/ arthritis DISEASE , myalgias DISEASE , leg edema DISEASE , peripheral neuropathy DISEASE , radiculopathy DISEASE , and habitual foot tapping.
Not characteristic of RLS DISEASE are: “knotting” of the muscle ( cramps DISEASE ), relief with a single postural shift (positional discomfort), limitation to joints ( arthritis DISEASE ), sore- ness to palpation ( myalgias DISEASE ), and other abnormalities on physical examination.
Less common conditions to be differentiated from RLS DISEASE include neuroleptic-induced DISEASE akathi-
sia, myelopathy DISEASE , symptomatic venous insufficiency DISEASE , peripheral artery disease DISEASE , eczema DISEASE , orthopedic problems, painful legs and moving toes, and anxiety-induced restlessness.
Neuroleptic-induced akathisia DISEASE differs from RLS DISEASE in that akathisia DISEASE is associated with the need to move the entire body and occurs in association with use of dopamine-receptor antagonists.
Painful legs and moving toes have neither a clear circadian pattern nor the sense of an urge to move.
Pain DISEASE involving the legs occurs with numerous conditions, including arthritis DISEASE , vascular problems, sports/orthopedic injuries DISEASE , and neuropathy DISEASE .
These pains DISEASE can have a nocturnal presentation and may be worse at rest, but improvement with movement either does not occur or entails more exercise than simple movement of the leg.
The urge to move, if present at all, usually stems from awareness that movement produces relief rather than the strong primary urgency of movement felt with RLS DISEASE .
The presence of pain DISEASE , however, does not exclude a diagnosis of RLS DISEASE , because about 50% of patients with RLS DISEASE report their RLS DISEASE symptoms as painful.
Although it is important that RLS DISEASE symptoms not be attributable solely to another medical or behavioral condition, it should also be appreciated that any of these mimics can occur in an individual who also has RLS.
For example, some subjects may have both RLS DISEASE and leg cramps.
When the diagnosis of RLS DISEASE is not certain, evaluation for the supportive features such as the presence of PLMS DISEASE or a family history of RLS DISEASE may be helpful.
Diagnostic interviews that include differential diagnosis have been validated for RLS.
These demonstrate sensitivity and specificity of > 90%.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions The diagnosis of RLS DISEASE relies on the subjective report of sensory symptoms that lie outside the range of common sensory experience.
Many patients have difficulty describing the sensations.
Further studies of the biological bases for RLS DISEASE may lead to better classification of RLS DISEASE and possibly to objective tests for diagnosis.
Iron CHEMICAL , dopa- mine, and genetic research hold particular promise.
Additional epidemiological and genetic studies outside the US and Europe are needed to explore apparent population differences.
The diagnostic standards and severity assessment for children and cogni- tively impaired adults require further development.
Clarification of the natural course and potential exacerbating factors is needed.
Better understanding of RLS DISEASE with comor- bidities such as DISEASE mood disorders DISEASE and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder DISEASE might lead to improved outcomes in those disorders.
Further evaluation of long-term complica- tions is important, including clarification of associations with hypertension DISEASE , cardiovas- cular disease, and stroke DISEASE .

Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders Periodic Limb Movement Disorder ICD-9-CM DISEASE code: 327.51 ICD-10-CM code: G47.61 Alternate Names Periodic movement disorder DISEASE of sleep, sleep myoclonus syndrome DISEASE , nocturnal myoclo- nus syndrome.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-D must be met A. Polysomnography demonstrates PLMS DISEASE , as defined in the most recent version of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
B. The frequency is > 5/hour in children or > 15/hour in adults.1 C.
The PLMS DISEASE cause clinically significant sleep disturbance DISEASE or impairment in mental, physical, social, occupational, educational, behavioral, or other important areas of functioning.2,3 D. The PLMS DISEASE and the symptoms are not better explained by another current sleep disorder DISEASE , medical or neurological disorder DISEASE , or mental disorder DISEASE (e.g., PLMS DISEASE occurring with apneas DISEASE or hypopneas DISEASE should not be scored).4,5 Notes .
The PLMS DISEASE Index must be interpreted in the context of a patient’s sleep related complaint.
In adults, normative values greater than five per hour have been found in studies that did not exclude respiratory event-related arousals DISEASE (using sensitive respiratory monitoring) and other causes for PLMS.
Data suggest a partial overlap of PLMS DISEASE Index values between symptomatic and asymptomatic individuals, emphasizing the importance of clinical context over an absolute cutoff value.
2.
If PLMS DISEASE are present without clinical sleep disturbance or daytime impairment DISEASE , the PLMS DISEASE can be noted as a polysomnographic finding, but criteria are not met for a diagnosis of PLMD DISEASE .
3. The presence of insomnia DISEASE or hypersomnia DISEASE with PLMS DISEASE is not sufficient to establish the diagnosis of PLMD DISEASE .
Studies have shown that in most cases the cause of the accompanying insomnia DISEASE or hypersomnia DISEASE is something other than the PLMS.
To establish the diagnosis of PLMD DISEASE , it is essential to establish a reasonable cause-and-effect relationship between the insomnia DISEASE or hypersomnia DISEASE and the PLMS.
This requires that other causes of insomnia DISEASE such as anxiety DISEASE or other causes of hypersomnia DISEASE such as obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE or narcolepsy DISEASE are ruled out.
PLMS DISEASE are common, but PLMD DISEASE is thought to be rare in adults.
4. PLMD DISEASE cannot be diagnosed in the context of RLS DISEASE , narcolepsy DISEASE , untreated obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE , or REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE ; PLMS DISEASE occur commonly in these conditions but the sleep complaint is more readily ascribed to the accompanying disorder.
The diagnosis of RLS DISEASE takes precedence over that of PLMD DISEASE when potentially sleep- disrupting PLMS DISEASE occur in the context of RLS.
In such cases, the diagnosis of RLS DISEASE is made and the PLMS DISEASE are noted.
5.
When it is reasonably certain that the PLMS DISEASE have been induced by medication, and full criteria for PLMD DISEASE are met, it is preferred that the more specific diagnosis of PLMD DISEASE be used, rather than “Sleep related movement disorder DISEASE due to a medication or substance.”
Essential Features PLMD DISEASE is characterized by periodic episodes of repetitive, highly stereotyped limb movements that occur during sleep ( PLMS DISEASE ), in conjunction with clinical sleep dis- turbance or fatigue DISEASE that cannot be accounted for by another primary sleep disorder DISEASE or other etiology.
PLMS DISEASE occur most frequently in the lower extremities.
They typically involve exten- sion of the big toe, often in combination with partial flexion of the ankle, the knee, and sometimes, the hip.
Similar movements can occur in the upper limbs.
Individual movements may be associated with an autonomic arousal, a cortical arousal, or an awakening.
Typically, the patient is unaware of the limb movements or the frequent sleep disruption.
An arousal may precede, coincide with, or follow the limb movement, suggesting that a central generator may give rise to both the periodic movements and the related sleep disturbance DISEASE .
A clinical history of sleep onset problems, sleep maintenance problems, or unrefresh- ing sleep attributable to the PLMS DISEASE is needed for a diagnosis of PLMD DISEASE .
These symp- toms have most consistently been associated with PLMS DISEASE , and the presence of these clinical symptoms differentiates PLMD DISEASE from asymptomatic PLMS DISEASE .
Although exces- sive daytime sleepiness DISEASE has been reported with PLMD DISEASE in the past, newer data do not find significantly elevated Epworth Sleepiness Scale scores or Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT) values in subjects with PLMS DISEASE .
If the only complaint is sleep disruption for the bed partner, then PLMD DISEASE should not be diagnosed but the sleep disturbance of the bed partner can be noted.
293 Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders The PLMS DISEASE index should exceed five per hour in children and 15 per hour in adult cases for a diagnosis of PLMD DISEASE .
This is based on substantial normative data in children.
In adults, there is a significant increase in sleep disturbance DISEASE symptoms with PLMS DISEASE >15/hour.
The PLMS DISEASE and the symptoms of sleep disturbance DISEASE or nonrestorative sleep should not be better explained by another etiology.
Most important in the differential diagnosis are RLS DISEASE , REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE ( RBD DISEASE ), and narcolepsy DISEASE .
Research studies indicate that five or more PLMS DISEASE per hour occur in 80% to 90% of patients with RLS DISEASE , in about 70% with RBD DISEASE , and in 45% to 65% with narcolepsy DISEASE .
In RBD DISEASE , PLMS DISEASE are often present without arousals DISEASE during nonrapid eye movement sleep (NREM) sleep but can also con- tinue into REM sleep, which is unusual in all other settings.
If significant daytime sleep- iness and PLMS DISEASE are present, a diagnosis of narcolepsy DISEASE should be considered.
PLMD DISEASE should not be diagnosed when criteria for one of these three disorders is met.
However, the primary disorder DISEASE “with PLMS DISEASE ” can be specified (e.g., “ RLS DISEASE with PLMS DISEASE ”).
A sensitive technique, such as pressure transducer airflow monitoring or esophageal manometry, should be used to monitor breathing during polysomnography to rea- sonably exclude sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE ( SRBDs DISEASE ) as the direct cause of the PLMS DISEASE .
When independent PLMS DISEASE are present in patients with SRBDs DISEASE , a separate diag- nosis of PLMD DISEASE may be considered if the PLMS DISEASE persist despite adequate treatment of the SRBD and otherwise unexplained sleep disturbance DISEASE remains.
Ideally, polysom- nography for the diagnosis of PLMD DISEASE should be performed after the biologic effect of a medication or substance, such as an antidepressant CHEMICAL known to induce or aggravate PLMS DISEASE , has ended.
Associated Features Higher rates of mood disorders DISEASE , anxiety DISEASE , attention deficits DISEASE , oppositional behaviors DISEASE , and parasomnias DISEASE have been reported in some studies of patients with PLMD DISEASE .
In children with PLMD DISEASE , a family history of RLS DISEASE is common.
A sustained clinical response to dopa- minergic therapy is supportive of the diagnosis of PLMD DISEASE .
Although PLMD DISEASE symptoms may be responsive to benzodiazepines CHEMICAL , benzodiazepine CHEMICAL responsiveness is not support- ive of the diagnosis due to the nonspecific effect of benzodiazepines CHEMICAL on sleep.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Not applicable or known.
Demographics Although PLMD DISEASE is thought to be rare, the exact prevalence is not known.
PLMD DISEASE has been reported in both children and adults.
PLMS DISEASE >5/hour are very uncommon in children and adults younger than the age of 40 years, but then increase markedly with advancing age, occurring in over 45% of the elderly.
The population prevalence of PLMS DISEASE >15/hour has been estimated at 7.6% of 18- to 65-year-olds, with 4.5% of the total population also reporting sleep disturbance DISEASE or excessive sleepiness DISEASE .
However, RLS DISEASE and medication-induced PLMS DISEASE were not exclusionary criteria in this popula- tion, suggesting much lower rates for PLMD.
The increase in PLMS DISEASE with age may occur as a partial expression of familial or genetic factors associated with RLS DISEASE , based on data that show very little increase in PLMS DISEASE with age when individuals who have RLS DISEASE or first-degree relatives with RLS DISEASE are excluded.
PLMS DISEASE are less common in black adults and children than in whites.
No sex difference has been described for PLMS DISEASE or PLMD DISEASE .
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors A positive family history of RLS DISEASE confers increased risk for PLMS DISEASE and PLMD DISEASE .
The genetic variants noted below may be a mediator of this risk.
Precipitation or aggrava- tion of PLMS DISEASE has been reported with the use of several medications.
Selective sero- tonin reuptake inhibitor antidepressants CHEMICAL , tricyclic antidepressants CHEMICAL , lithium CHEMICAL , and dopa- mine receptor antagonists have most often been associated with this effect.
Low brain iron CHEMICAL , as reflected by serum ferritin level, may worsen PLMS DISEASE via the role of iron CHEMICAL in dopamine CHEMICAL function.
Less evidence is available for obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE ( OSA DISEASE ), alcohol CHEMICAL , pain DISEASE , and sleep deprivation as factors that worsen PLMS DISEASE .
Familial Patterns The familial pattern of PLMD DISEASE has not been studied in detail.
Families with RLS DISEASE have been found to include first-degree relatives DISEASE without RLS DISEASE but with increased rates of PLMS DISEASE or PLMD DISEASE , raising the possibility that PLMD DISEASE is an attenuated manifestation or a precursor to RLS.
The gene variants BTBD9 and MEIS1, which were found in genome- wide studies of RLS DISEASE , appear to influence the expression of PLMS.
Onset, Course, and Complications Although the typical age of onset is not known, PLMD DISEASE occurs in both children and adults, with onset as early as infancy.
The natural history has not been described in detail, but some pediatric cases of PLMD DISEASE progress to RLS.
Incidence and remission rates are unknown.
Impaired performance in a simulated driving task has been found in patients with PLMD DISEASE .
Increased PLMS DISEASE have been associated with a higher risk of cardiovascular disease DISEASE , stroke DISEASE , and mortality in some studies.
PLMS-related overac- tivity of the sympathetic nervous system is postulated to be a potential mechanism for these associations.
295 Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders Developmental Issues Given the low background rates of PLMS DISEASE in children, PLMD DISEASE has emerged as a useful diagnostic category in pediatric sleep medicine.
Pediatric PLMD DISEASE has important
clini-
cal
and polysomnographic correlates that are comparable in severity to pediatric OSA DISEASE .
However, PLMS DISEASE and PLMD DISEASE normative data remain sparse for children younger than two years.
In the elderly, frequent occurrence of other conditions that can account for sleep dis- turbance and fatigue DISEASE makes application of PLMD DISEASE criteria difficult, even though PLMS DISEASE are common.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Dopaminergic impairment DISEASE has been implicated in the pathophysiology of PLMS DISEASE and PLMD DISEASE .
The study of PLMS DISEASE in RLS DISEASE and in children also suggests genetic diathesis DISEASE and iron CHEMICAL status as factors.
Cyclic alternating pattern, a marker of nonrestorative DISEASE sleep, is increased in individuals with PLMS DISEASE and may influence the periodicity of PLMS DISEASE .
Cortical arousals DISEASE can precede, coincide with, or follow PLMS DISEASE , indicating that PLMS DISEASE do not cause the arousals DISEASE .
In addition, PLMS DISEASE can be dissociated from arousals DISEASE pharma- cologically, suggesting an indirect relation, possibly mediated by a central generator.
The autonomic arousals DISEASE associated with PLMS DISEASE are characterized by significant heart rate and blood pressure surges, a mechanism for possible increased cardiovascular and cerebrovascular disease DISEASE risk.
Objective Findings PLMS DISEASE can appear immediately with the onset of stage N1 sleep, are frequent during stage N2 sleep, decrease in frequency in stage N3, and are usually absent during stage R sleep.
PLMS DISEASE typically occur in discrete episodes that last from a few minutes to an hour.
Both lower limbs should be monitored for the presence of limb movements.
Movements of the upper limbs may be sampled if clinically indicated.
The anterior tibialis electro- myogram (EMG) shows repetitive contractions, each lasting 0.5 to 10 seconds.
The movements may affect one or, more typically, both of the lower limbs, but not neces- sarily in a symmetric or simultaneous pattern.
Specific scoring criteria for PLMS DISEASE are described in the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events.
Self-reports, bed partner observations, or parental reports for children have not been found to have sufficient specificity or sensitivity to replace objective testing for PLMS.
Care must be taken to discriminate PLMS DISEASE from other movements such as a simple change in body position, stretching of a limb, or a muscle cramp DISEASE .
PLMS DISEASE are longer in duration than myoclonic jerks DISEASE , which, by definition, are typically 50 to 150 millisec- onds long.
Movements associated with respiratory events, hypnagogic foot tremor DISEASE , or alternating leg muscle activation during sleep (ALMA) should not be included in the PLMS DISEASE index.
PLMS DISEASE may be associated with electroencephalographic (cortical) arousals DISEASE or with awakenings.
Autonomic arousals DISEASE —measured by a change in heart rate, blood pressure, or pulse transit time—have been shown to be more frequent than cortical arousals DISEASE .
In some cases, periodic arousals DISEASE may persist even though the PLMS DISEASE have subsided.
The arousals DISEASE are typically more difficult to measure than are the PLMS DISEASE , and their clinical significance is a topic of ongoing debate.
As with obstructive sleep apnea DISEASE , the associated cortical arousal index has not proven more useful than the PLMS DISEASE index in making clini- cal decisions.
Although a subjective report of excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE is present in some patients with PLMD DISEASE , mean sleep latency measured by MSLT has not been found to be consistently abnormal or to correlate with the PLMS cortical arousal index.
The movements should be reported as an index of total sleep time, called the PLMS DISEASE index.
The PLMS DISEASE index is the number of periodic limb movements per hour of total sleep time, as determined by polysomnography.
The PLMS arousal index is the number of PLMS DISEASE associated with a cortical arousal, expressed per hour of total sleep time.
Other parameters for the description of PLMS DISEASE include periodicity index, intermove- ment interval distribution, and time of night distribution.
These features have been shown to help differentiate PLMS DISEASE patterns in different conditions (e.g., a finding of the highest periodicity indices in adult RLS DISEASE and PLMD DISEASE ).
Leg actigraphy has been validated against PSG for the measurement of PLMS DISEASE and provides a methodology to assess PLMS DISEASE in large populations, as well as night-to-night variability.
Differential Diagnosis As described in the essential features section, PLMD DISEASE is a diagnosis of exclusion and it is important to differentiate it from other conditions in which PLMS DISEASE occur, particularly RLS DISEASE , RBD DISEASE , narcolepsy DISEASE , and SRBDs DISEASE .
Increased rates of PLMS DISEASE have also been reported in multiple system atrophy DISEASE , dopa-responsive dystonia DISEASE , sleep related eating disorder DISEASE , spinal cord injury DISEASE , end-stage renal disease DISEASE , congestive heart failure DISEASE , Parkinson disease DISEASE , sickle cell disease DISEASE , posttraumatic stress disorder DISEASE , Asperger syndrome DISEASE , Williams syn- drome DISEASE , and multiple sclerosis.
Dopaminergic impairment and/or diminished inhibition of the central pattern generator for PLMS DISEASE have been proposed as common factors linking various disorders and PLMS DISEASE .
297 Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep starts ( hypnic jerks DISEASE ) need to be differentiated from PLMS.
Sleep starts typically are limited to the transition from wakefulness to sleep, are not periodic, and are briefer (20 to 100 milliseconds) than PLMS DISEASE .
Normal phasic REM activity is limited to REM sleep, typically occurs in 5- to 15-second clusters, and is usually associated with bursts of REMs DISEASE .
Phasic REM EMG twitches are more variable in duration and do not have the periodicity of PLMS DISEASE .
Fragmentary myoclonus DISEASE is characterized by EMG activity that is briefer (75 to 150 milliseconds), more variable in duration, less periodic than PLMS DISEASE , and has little or no associated visible movement.
Also, PLMS DISEASE must be differentiated from movements associated with nocturnal epileptic seizures DISEASE and myoclonic epilepsy DISEASE and from a number of forms of myoclonus DISEASE seen while awake, such as in Alzheimer disease DISEASE , Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease DISEASE , and other neuropathologic conditions.
However, in these disorders, the involuntary movements DISEASE are prominent during the daytime, often do not disappear with activity, are prominent in the arms and other body parts in addition to the legs, and do not display the periodicity seen with PLMS DISEASE .
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions
There has been controversy over the clinical significance of PLMS DISEASE .
To date, the inter- pretation of most studies has been confounded by multiple factors that include: impre- cise diagnostic criteria; confusion DISEASE between PLMS DISEASE and PLMD DISEASE ; inadequate monitoring for subtle SRBDs DISEASE ; a lack of consideration of medications known to induce, worsen, or suppress PLMS DISEASE ; and inadequate measurement of the known night-to-night vari- ability of PLMS DISEASE .
Newer respiratory monitoring techniques for polysomnography and the use of actigraphy monitors over several nights should help address a number of these issues.
The role of associated arousals DISEASE in relation to clinical symptoms is yet to be determined, but the appreciation of autonomic arousals DISEASE as well as cortical arousals DISEASE might be critical.
It is possible that PLMS DISEASE are a measurable marker of unstable sleep, related to genetic diathesis DISEASE and dopaminergic impairment.

Sleep Related Leg Cramps ICD-9-CM code: 327.52 Alternate names Leg cramps DISEASE , “charley horse,” nocturnal leg cramps DISEASE .
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A-C must be met ICD-10-CM code: G47.62 Sleep Related Movement Disorders A. A painful sensation DISEASE in the leg or foot associated with sudden, involuntary muscle hardness DISEASE or tightness DISEASE , indicating a strong muscle contraction.
B. The painful muscle contractions DISEASE occur during the time in bed, although they may arise from either wakefulness or sleep.
C. The pain DISEASE is relieved by forceful stretching of the affected muscles, thus releasing the contraction.
Essential Features Sleep related leg cramps DISEASE are painful sensations DISEASE caused by sudden and intense involun- tary contractions of muscles or muscle groups during which there is muscle spasm DISEASE and hardness DISEASE for several seconds.
These painful sensations DISEASE are usually in the calf or small muscle of the foot.
Occurring during the time in bed, sleep related leg cramps DISEASE may arise from either wakefulness or sleep.
Sleep related leg cramps usually start abruptly but may in some cases be preceded by a less painful warning sensation DISEASE .
The muscle contractions last for a few seconds up to several minutes and then remit spontaneously.
The frequency of sleep related leg cramps varies considerably from less than yearly to multiple episodes every night.
299 Sleep Related Movement Disorders The cramps DISEASE can be relieved by strongly stretching the affected muscle and sometimes also by local massage, application of heat, or movement of the affected limb.
Leg cramps DISEASE can be present primarily during the daytime.
Associated Features The muscle cramp DISEASE affects sleep.
The pain DISEASE from the cramp DISEASE itself and from the activities used to relieve it commonly disturb sleep onset or cause an awakening from sleep.
Often the presenting complaint DISEASE is insomnia DISEASE , at times severe.
Tenderness DISEASE and discomfort in the muscle may persist for several hours after the cramp- ing.
Persisting discomfort after the cramping DISEASE episode often delays subsequent return to sleep.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Sleep related leg cramps DISEASE are known to be either idiopathic DISEASE or secondary to other medical conditions, but there have been no indications of significant differences in the clinical features of the disorder related to the cause.
Demographics Sleep related leg cramps DISEASE are common.
It has been suggested that nearly every adult older than 50 years has experienced sleep related leg cramps DISEASE at least once.
Both the prevalence and the frequency of the events increase with age.
Sleep related leg cramps DISEASE have been reported to occur at least occasionally in about 7% of children and adoles- cents, 33% in adults older than 60 years, and 50% in adults older than 80 years, with both older groups reporting a symptom frequency of at least once every two months.
Nightly leg cramps DISEASE have been reported in 6% of adults older than 60 years.
No defin- itive sex information has been reported, though a single study reported a higher prev- alence in women.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors
Predisposing factors include diabetes mellitus DISEASE , amyotrophic lateral sclerosis DISEASE , cramp fasciculation syndrome DISEASE , peripheral vascular disease DISEASE , hypokalemia DISEASE , hypocalcemia DISEASE , hypomagnesemia DISEASE , and metabolic disorders.
The disorder can be associated with prior vigorous exercise, prolonged standing at work, dehydration DISEASE , fluid and electrolyte distur- bances, endocrine disorders DISEASE , neuromuscular disorders DISEASE , disorders of reduced mobility DISEASE , vascular disease DISEASE , cirrhosis DISEASE , and hemodialysis.
Medications that have been associated with sleep related leg cramps DISEASE include oral contraceptives CHEMICAL , intravenous iron sucrose CHEMICAL , teriparatide CHEMICAL , raloxifene CHEMICAL , diuretics, long-acting β-agonists, and statins CHEMICAL .
Sleep related leg cramps DISEASE occur in about 40% of pregnant women and generally resolve after delivery.
300 Familial Pattern Not known.
Onset, Course and Complications Sleep related leg cramps DISEASE have not been reported in infancy, nor in children younger than eight years.
The peak onset is usually in adulthood, but the condition may be seen for the first time in old age.
The natural history of leg cramps DISEASE is not well under- stood.
Many patients describe a waxing and waning course of many years ’ DISEASE duration.
Complications include muscle tenderness DISEASE , insomnia DISEASE , and occasional daytime fatigue DISEASE due to interrupted sleep.
No marked mental or social dysfunction has been described due to sleep related leg cramps DISEASE alone.
Pathology and Pathophysiology Many sleep related leg cramps DISEASE appear to be idiopathic DISEASE .
Although leg cramps DISEASE involve abnormal muscle tone DISEASE , they are generally considered not to involve agonist-antagonist co-contractions and, thus, are not classified as dystonias DISEASE .
Some nocturnal leg cramps DISEASE , particularly those in the feet, may resemble dystonias DISEASE but, unlike classic dystonias DISEASE , sleep related leg and foot cramps DISEASE are relieved by stretching the affected muscle or muscles.
Electrophysiologic recordings show that the cramps DISEASE typically start with spontaneous firing of anterior horn cells followed by motor unit discharges for contractions at rates up to 300 Hz (considerably more than with voluntary muscle contractions DISEASE ).
The pain DISEASE may result from local metabolite accumulations or from local ischemia DISEASE .
Muscle and tendon shortening due to age or lack of stretching exercise is thought to contribute to the development of sleep related leg cramps.
Exercise involving stretch- ing the affected muscles is thought to help prevent or reduce the occurrence of sleep related leg cramps.
Objective Findings Polysomnographic studies of patients with chronic sleep related leg cramps DISEASE reveal non- periodic bursts of gastrocnemius EMG activity.
Episodes arise from sleep without any specific preceding physiologic changes during sleep.
Differential Diagnosis Sleep related leg cramps DISEASE are common in chronic myelopathy DISEASE , peripheral neuropathy DISEASE , muscular pain fasciculation syndrome DISEASE , and disorders of calcium CHEMICAL metabolism.
These causes should be differentiated by clinical history and physical examination.
RLS DISEASE is Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders sometimes confused with sleep related leg cramps DISEASE because both can present with leg discomfort during the sleep period and RLS DISEASE patients sometimes complain of a cramping DISEASE sensation.
However, if patients meet the diagnostic criteria for RLS DISEASE and do not describe an actual cramp DISEASE or hardening of the muscle, the diagnosis should be RLS.
Because leg cramps DISEASE can mimic RLS DISEASE and meet all the criteria for RLS, the description of an actual spasm DISEASE or hardening of the muscle is a critical differentiating factor.
A leg cramp DISEASE is also a much briefer event than the typical symptoms of RLS DISEASE , which can persist for hours.
However, RLS DISEASE and leg cramps DISEASE may sometimes be seen in the same individual.
Dystonia DISEASE is ongoing daily spasm DISEASE of muscles and is distinguished electrophysiologi- cally from leg cramps DISEASE by ongoing co-contraction of agonist and antagonist muscles.
Dystonia DISEASE can be focal, as in the case of muscles of the neck ( torticollis DISEASE ) or hand (writer’s cramp DISEASE ), or generalized as in the case of torsion dystonia DISEASE .
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Sleep related leg cramps DISEASE are common and can affect sleep.
Their association with other disorders and different medications hinder accurate epidemiological data and under- estimate their effect on sleep and on quality of life.
Instruments to quantify the sever- ity of the disorder and its impact are needed to adequately address clinical relevance, treatment, and the potential occupational hazards.
Effective treatments for sleep related leg cramps DISEASE have yet to be developed.
The prophylactic benefits of stretching exercises remain to be adequately validated.

Electroencephalogr Clin Neurophysiol 1957;9:139–47.
Parisi L, Serrao M, Rossi P, et al.
Afterdischarge activity in neuropathic DISEASE patients with frequent muscle cramps DISEASE .
Acta Neurol Scand 2000;102:359–62.
Pitkin RM.
Endocrine regulation of calcium CHEMICAL homeostasis during pregnancy.
Clin Perinatol 1983;10:575–92.
Saskin P, Whelton C, Moldofsky H, Akin F. Sleep and nocturnal leg cramps DISEASE .
