JAMA 1980;244:2332–3.
Sleep Related Bruxism ICD-9-CM code: 327.53 ICD-10-CM code: G47.63 Alternate Names Nocturnal bruxism DISEASE , nocturnal tooth grinding, tooth clenching.
Diagnostic Criteria Criteria A and B must be met A.
The presence of regular or frequent tooth grinding sounds occurring during sleep.
B. The presence of one or more of the following clinical signs: .
Abnormal tooth wear DISEASE consistent with above reports of tooth grinding during sleep.
2. Transient morning jaw muscle pain DISEASE or fatigue DISEASE ; and/or temporal headache DISEASE ; and/or jaw locking upon awakening consistent with above reports of tooth grinding during sleep. Notes .
Although polysomnography is not required for the diagnosis, sleep bruxism DISEASE , as described in the most recent version of the AASM Manual for the Scoring of Sleep and Associated Events, is ideally recorded with masseter muscle activity with audio-video signal to increase diagnostic reliability.
Essential Features Bruxism DISEASE is defined as a repetitive jaw-muscle activity characterized by clenching or grinding of the teeth and/or by bracing or thrusting of the mandible.
Bruxism Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders has been divided into its two distinct circadian manifestations: sleep bruxism and awake bruxism.
In sleep, jaw muscle contractions DISEASE are frequently repeated over time and are termed rhythmic masticatory muscle activity (RMMA).
These contractions can take two forms on electromyographic traces: a series of repetitive activity (phasic muscle contractions) or isolated sustained jaw clenching (tonic contractions).
These contractions during sleep produce tooth-grinding DISEASE sounds and are referred to as sleep related bruxism.
Sleep related bruxism DISEASE can lead to abnormal tooth wear DISEASE , tooth pain DISEASE , jaw muscle pain DISEASE , and temporal headache DISEASE .
Severe sleep related bruxism DISEASE may also result in sleep dis- ruption.
This may involve not only the individual affected, but also the bed partner, because the sounds made by the friction of the teeth are usually perceived as being unpleasant and can be quite loud and disturbing to those nearby.
The disorder is typically brought to dental or medical attention because of the tooth damage DISEASE , pain DISEASE , or disturbing sounds.
Less commonly, it may present as a cause of dis- turbed sleep.
Young and otherwise healthy individuals with sleep related bruxism DISEASE appear to have normal sleep structure and homeostasis.
The majority of RMMA epi- sodes during sleep occur in association with sleep arousal.
Jaw muscle pain DISEASE , tenderness DISEASE in the masseter and temporalis muscle regions, morning headache DISEASE , or fatigue DISEASE can arise due to sleep related bruxism.
Associated Features Additional symptoms include a variety of unpleasant muscle and tooth sensations DISEASE , lim- itation of jaw movements, orofacial pain DISEASE , and temporal/tension headaches DISEASE .
Tooth wear DISEASE , fractured teeth, and buccal lacerations also can occur.
These symptoms may be induced by sleep related bruxism DISEASE , but the connection may not be apparent to the affected indi- vidual and diagnostic discrimination is weak.
Headaches DISEASE are frequently reported by both adults and children with sleep related bruxism DISEASE .
The headache DISEASE usually involves the temporal regions and it has the charac- teristics of a tension headache DISEASE .
It is reported either in the morning (more frequently) or during the day (with wake bruxism).
The estimated OR for headache DISEASE in individuals with sleep related bruxism DISEASE is > 4 compared to controls.
There is high individual variability in the intensity and duration of sleep related bruxism DISEASE , but in the most severe cases, hundreds of events can occur during a night of sleep.
However, no direct relationship has been observed between the severity of sleep related bruxism DISEASE and the appearance of clinical signs and symptoms.
Indeed, indi- viduals with a mild to moderate index of sleep bruxism DISEASE (2 to 4 RMMA episodes/hour of sleep DISEASE ) have a higher risk of reporting painful jaw upon awakening (OR 3.9), and masticatory muscle fatigue DISEASE (OR 5.1) compared to individuals with severe sleep related bruxism DISEASE (> 4 RMMA episodes/hour of sleep DISEASE ).
Psychosocial components may also be linked to sleep related bruxism DISEASE .
The psycholog- ical assessment of otherwise healthy adults with sleep related bruxism DISEASE suggests a cor- relation (not yet proven as a causality) between bruxism DISEASE and stress/anxiety DISEASE .
Moreover, both children and adults with sleep related bruxism DISEASE seem to have higher scores in stress, anxiety DISEASE , and psychiatric DISEASE scales compared to control individuals.
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Sleep related bruxism DISEASE without clear cause is termed primary or idiopathic.
Forms of sleep related bruxism DISEASE associated with the use of psychoactive medications, recreational drugs, or a variety of medical disorders (e.g., Parkinson disease DISEASE , RBD DISEASE , Down syndrome DISEASE ) are defined as secondary sleep related bruxism DISEASE .
Treatment-induced sleep related bruxism DISEASE is also termed iatrogenic.
Although the primary form of sleep related bruxism DISEASE is most often reported in healthy children and adults, secondary sleep related bruxism DISEASE is observed in children with cere- bral palsy DISEASE and mental retardation DISEASE and in adult patients with abnormal movements DISEASE such as in oromandibular DISEASE myoclonus/facio-mandibular myoclonus DISEASE or with sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE and sleep related bruxism DISEASE commonly co-occur.
Tooth grinding and clenching also can occur during wakefulness, as an oral parafunc- tional activity known as awake bruxism.
Awake bruxism DISEASE is considered a different dis- order, probably with different diagnostic criteria and pathophysiology; its association with sleep bruxism DISEASE is still under debate.
However, the two oral activities may coexist in the same individual.
Demographics The prevalence of sleep related bruxism DISEASE , based on reports from parents or sleep partner, is highest in childhood (approximately 14% to 17%) and then decreases over the life span.
In teenagers to young adults, prevalence is in the 12% range.
In young to middle-aged adults, it is approximately 8% but as little as 3% in older persons.
The reported reduction in tooth grinding in the elderly probably overestimates the actual Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders reduction, because edentulism, use of dentures, and changes in sleeping behaviors DISEASE (i.e., in isolation) may influence reporting.
There is no reported sex difference for the prev- alence of sleep related bruxism.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors
Predisposing factors include personality types; for example, individuals who are highly motivated or characteristically maintain high vigilance may have an increased preva- lence of sleep related bruxism.
Genetic predisposition is plausible but still under investigation.
As described below, there is some familial predisposition DISEASE due to environmental or shared genetic factors.
Recently, a serotonin CHEMICAL gene was described in bruxism DISEASE patients but the absence of distinction between the wake and sleep forms in this report preclude firm conclusions.
Precipitating factors can include anxiety DISEASE related to current life events, tasks requir- ing high levels of performance, and repetitive tasks with short deadlines.
The use of cigarettes or caffeine CHEMICAL in the hours before sleep also can contribute to the occur- rence of sleep related bruxism DISEASE (probably due to the increased arousals DISEASE and sleep instability DISEASE ).
The role of dental morphologic “defects” (occlusal interferences) remains controver- sial in the etiology of sleep related bruxism DISEASE .
Tooth contacts do not usually set in motion a bruxism DISEASE episode; they are usually late in the series of events occurring during sleep related bruxism/
tooth grinding.
Hence, the causality link between tooth contact and sleep related bruxism DISEASE is not supported by the temporal sequence.
Familial Patterns Sleep related bruxism DISEASE tends to occur in families; approximately 20% to 50% of affected individuals have at least one direct family member with a history of tooth DISEASE grinding, and childhood sleep related bruxism DISEASE appears to persist into adulthood in two thirds of reported cases.
However, no genetic variants or genetic inheritance patterns so far have been associated with sleep related bruxism.
Onset, Course, and Complications The onset of sleep related bruxism DISEASE may occur during childhood, adolescence, or adulthood.
It is difficult to establish the time of onset with precision because it is mainly based on the awareness of the individual or
his/her family members who report the disorder.
306 Sleep related bruxism DISEASE in childhood has been reported by parents to begin as soon as both upper and lower teeth have erupted.
Secondary sleep related bruxism DISEASE may occur at any age, but is more common in younger and middle-aged adults.
Even without a tooth grinding history or complaints, RMMA may be observed in most normal sleepers (on average, one episode per hour of sleep) across the life span.
However, in individuals with sleep related bruxism, jaw-muscle contractions are more frequent and more intense.
This may explain the secondary tooth damage DISEASE and the occurrence of pain DISEASE and other symptoms.
The night-to-night variability in episodes of audible tooth grinding sounds is large (greater than 50% coefficient of variation).
In-laboratory polysomnographic record- ings CHEMICAL indicate that the corresponding variability in frequency of RMMA is smaller (approximately 25%), although ambulatory recording has suggested somewhat higher RMMA variability.
First-night effect on RMMA index is minimal.
Dental damage and abnormal tooth wear DISEASE are the most frequent signs of the disorder.
However, they are not a direct proof of current sleep related bruxism DISEASE and many contrib- uting factors have to be ruled out (e.g., type of diet in the occurrence of abnormal tooth wear DISEASE ).
Diagnostic discriminative strength of these dental findings is weak; severity of wear DISEASE cannot account for the index (i.e., frequency of RMMA).
Sleep related bruxism DISEASE could lead to temporomandibular joint disorders DISEASE (e.g., pain DISEASE , joint sound [click], or jaw movement limitations), although recent evidence does not support this association.
Transient morning orofacial pain DISEASE , including temporal headaches DISEASE , is not uncommon, as described above.
Hypertrophy of the masseter and temporalis muscles can occur, but the diagnostic specificity of this finding for sleep related bruxism DISEASE is also weak.
The natural course of this sleep disorder DISEASE is usually benign.
Many individuals with sleep related bruxism DISEASE remain asymptomatic for most of their lives.
Others can experi- ence associated symptoms (i.e., pain DISEASE ) that may interfere with their quality of life and/ or sleep and may require treatments.
Further diagnostic investigations and assessment are recommended if sleep related bruxism DISEASE is associated with other more severe sleep or medical disorders (e.g., SRBD, RBD DISEASE , epilepsy DISEASE ).
Developmental Issues Sleep related bruxism DISEASE is frequently reported in childhood but decreases with age.
However, some individuals may experience it every night for most of their lives.
307 Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders Conceptualizations of sleep related bruxism DISEASE in children vary.
Some consider this a physiological oral parafunction DISEASE while teeth are erupting or exfoliating, whereas others view this as a sleep disorder DISEASE with many associated signs and symptoms.
Sleep related bruxism DISEASE , especially in children, has been associated with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder DISEASE , parasomnias DISEASE , SRBD, snoring DISEASE , and many psychological and medical conditions.
In the elderly, sleep related bruxism DISEASE has been observed in association with movement disorders DISEASE (e.g., Parkinson disease DISEASE or oral tardive dyskinesia DISEASE persisting during sleep), RBD DISEASE , and dementia DISEASE .
Pathology and Pathophysiology The majority of RMMA episodes during sleep (up to 80%) occur in association with sleep arousals DISEASE .
Sleep related bruxism DISEASE episodes typically follow a clear arousal sequence, starting with increased sympathetic-cardiac activity and fast electroenceph- alographic (EEG) waves in the minutes to seconds preceding the onset of an RMMA episode.
The jaw muscle contractions are then followed by, or are concomitant with, an increase in blood pressure and ventilation.
RMMA episodes sometimes conclude with swallowing.
Other causes of sleep bruxism onset are unknown, although potential candidates include airway resistance and oropharyngeal dryness.
In the majority of individuals with sleep related bruxism DISEASE , the frequency of sleep arous- als is within the normal range.
However, they may have an exaggerated responsiveness to ongoing sleep arousals DISEASE or an increased magnitude of arousal.
Individuals with sleep related bruxism DISEASE show more CAP CHEMICAL phase A3 (as described by the scoring and analysis of cyclic alternating pattern (CAP) during sleep) than controls, an expression of increased arousal pressure and increased sleep instability.
This increased sleep instability DISEASE seems to be the “permissive window” for occurrence of RMMA during sleep.
Objective Findings Polysomnographic (PSG) monitoring of individuals with sleep related bruxism DISEASE demonstrates increased masseter and temporalis muscle activity during sleep, along with grinding sounds.
RMMA episodes can occur during all sleep stages, but are most common in sleep stages N1 and N2 (more than 80% of episodes), whereas fewer than 10% of RMMA episodes occur during REM sleep.
However, in some individuals, sleep related bruxism DISEASE occurs predominantly in REM sleep.
As described above, the majority of sleep related bruxism DISEASE episodes are temporally associated with sleep arousal and are preceded by signs of autonomic/cardiac activa- tion (e.g., increased heart rate and blood pressure).
308 Three subtypes of the EMG pattern of sleep related bruxism DISEASE have been described: phasic activity at 1 Hz frequency with EMG bursts lasting 0.25 to 2 seconds; sustained tonic activity lasting longer than 2 seconds; or a mixed pattern.
An episode begins after at least a three-second interval with no muscle activity.
Polysomnography is not usually performed in otherwise healthy individuals with sleep related bruxism DISEASE in routine clinical settings.
However, PSG may be indicated to demon- CHEMICAL strate the disorder and to rule out associated respiratory disturbances DISEASE , gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , RBD DISEASE , night terrors DISEASE , faciomandibular myoclonus DISEASE , or epilepsy DISEASE .
The sensitivity of polysomnographic study in detecting sleep related bruxism DISEASE in severe cases is moderate to high; in milder cases, however, it may be low due to the night-to-night variability in RMMA and tooth grinding.
Ambulatory home monitoring may be used for screening, diagnosis, and treatment outcome assessment by studying the individual in his/her usual environment, but it is characterized by lower diagnostic specificity due to the absence of audiovisual record- ings CHEMICAL (i.e., 20% overestimation in RMMA frequency is expected due to poor capacity to exclude concomitant nonspecific activities).
To record and score sleep related bruxism DISEASE activity (i.e., RMMA)
, there must be a minimum of one masseter muscle monitor, ideally with audiovisual recording, to associate muscular activity with grinding sound production.
Video monitoring helps distinguish bruxism DISEASE from other orofacial and masticatory movements DISEASE that normally occur during sleep (e.g., swallowing, coughing) and from specific movement disorders DISEASE ( RBD DISEASE , epilepsy DISEASE and tooth DISEASE tapping, oromandibular myoclonus DISEASE ).
For the best level of diagnostic specificity and sensitivity, bilateral masseter and tem- poralis muscle EMG recordings, referenced to ear, mastoid, or zygomatic bone, are advisable.
Differential Diagnosis The disorder seldom poses diagnostic problems.
Evaluation for temporomandibular disorders DISEASE and damage to dentition is indicated.
Sleep related bruxism DISEASE needs to be differentiated from other faciomandibular activities occurring during sleep, such as faciomandibular myoclonus DISEASE , SRBD, RBD DISEASE , abnormal swallowing, gastro-esophageal reflux, night terrors DISEASE , confusional arousals DISEASE , dyskinetic jaw movements persisting in sleep ( dystonia DISEASE , tremor DISEASE , chorea DISEASE , dyskinesia DISEASE ), and, rarely, sleep related epilepsy DISEASE .
309 Sleep Related Movement Disorders Sleep Related Movement Disorders Oromandibular DISEASE or faciomandibular myoclonus DISEASE has been observed in approximately 10% of individuals with severe sleep related bruxism DISEASE , but it can also occur in indi- viduals without abnormally increased RMMA events.
As opposed to sleep related bruxism DISEASE , faciomandibular myoclonus DISEASE consists of EMG bursts of brief duration (less than 250 milliseconds in length) in the facial muscles; these can occur either as isolated bursts or as a cluster of regularly or irregularly occurring brief bursts.
A high index of oromandibular myoclonus DISEASE in sleep has been observed in idiopathic RBD DISEASE patients.
Rhythmic jaw movements also have been observed in association with partial complex or generalized seizure disorders DISEASE .
Epilepsy DISEASE needs to be considered in the differential diagnosis, although the presentation of epilepsy DISEASE as relatively isolated sleep related bruxism DISEASE is very rare.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions An expert bruxism DISEASE international group has proposed a diagnostic grading system of “possible,” “probable,” and “definite” for both sleep and awake bruxism.
Such a clinical tool will help to discriminate sleep bruxism from awake bruxism, although further validation is required for clinical and research purposes in all relevant dental and medical domains.
In summary, this group suggests that a rating of: (1) “possible” is given if based on self-report, by means of questionnaires, and/or the anamnestic part of a clinical examination; (2) “probable” sleep or awake bruxism DISEASE is given if based on self-report and supportive physical findings; (3) “definite” sleep bruxism DISEASE if based on self-report, physical findings, and a polysomnographic recording, preferably with audiovisual recordings.
The clinical relevance of sleep related bruxism DISEASE in cases of comorbidity DISEASE with other medical problems such as snoring DISEASE , sleep related breathing disorder DISEASE , RBD DISEASE , attention deficit hyperactivity disorder DISEASE , headache DISEASE , and orofacial pain DISEASE needs to be assessed in order to distinguish primary benign forms of sleep related bruxism DISEASE from those that rep- resent an epiphenomenon of other more severe sleep and medical disorders.
Sleep related bruxism DISEASE may be concomitant to breathing disorders DISEASE , including any level of severity of OSA DISEASE ; further research is in progress to assess the specificity and validity of this association.
There is currently no evidence supporting the possibility that patients with sleep related bruxism DISEASE , in its primary form, are at increased risk of neurological disorders DISEASE ; such a risk factor assessment needs long- term study before any conclusion can be drawn.
310 Investigation of genetic associations to sleep related bruxism DISEASE require large sample sizes, using valid tools to assess the specificity of RMMA versus other oromandibular DISEASE activities and to discriminate gene candidates specific for bruxism DISEASE from those related to its comorbidities such as stress or other related triggers of RMMA.
Bibliography Abe S, Yamaguchi T, Rompré PH, De Grandmont P, Chen YJ, Lavigne GJ.
Tooth wear DISEASE in young subjects: a discriminator between sleep bruxers DISEASE and controls?
