N Engl J Med 1986;315:997–1003.
Monari L, Chen S, Brown P, et al.
Fatal familial insomnia DISEASE and familial Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease DISEASE : different prion proteins determined by a DNA polymorphism.
Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A 1994;91:2839–42.
Montagna P, Cortelli P, Gambetti P, Lugaresi E. Fatal familial insomnia DISEASE : sleep, neuroendocrine and vegetative alterations.
Adv Neuroimmunol 1995;5:13–21.
Montagna P, Gambetti P, Cortelli P, Lugaresi E. Familial and sporadic fatal insomnia DISEASE .
Lancet Neurol 2003;2:167–76.
Sforza E, Montagna P, Tinuper P, et al.
Sleep-wake cycle abnormalities in fatal familial insomnia DISEASE .
Evidence of the role of the thalamus in sleep regulation.
Electroencephalogr Clin Neurophysiol 1995;94:398–405.
Telling G, Parchi P, DeArmond S, et al.
Evidence for the conformation of the pathologic isoform of the prion protein enciphering and propagating prion diversity.
Science 1996;274:2079–82. Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Sleep Related Epilepsy DISEASE Alternate Names Sleep epilepsy DISEASE , nocturnal seizure DISEASE , sleep related seizures DISEASE .
Essential Features A seizure DISEASE is a paroxysmal event resulting from a sudden excessive discharge of the neurons of the cerebral cortex, whereas epilepsy DISEASE is a condition of recurrent unpro- voked seizures DISEASE .
Sleep facilitates epileptic DISEASE activity and seizures DISEASE .
The characteristics of specific subtypes of sleep related epilepsy DISEASE are discussed in the Clinical and Pathologic Subtypes section below.
Associated Features The different types of nocturnal frontal lobe epilepsy DISEASE ( NFLE DISEASE ) may cause severe sleep disruption, affecting both macrostructure and microstructure of sleep, resulting in poor sleep quality, daytime fatigue DISEASE , and sleepiness DISEASE in some patients.
The movements also may be so severe that injuries DISEASE can occur.
From one third to one half of patients with sleep related epilepsy DISEASE also have occasional attacks DISEASE during the day, although these are not necessarily of the same type as those occurring at night.
Neurocognitive impairment DISEASE is typically diagnosed in almost all cases of continuous spike waves during NREM sleep (CSWS).
Motor impairment in the form of a unilat- eral deficit is sometimes seen as an associated feature of CSWS.
Clinical and Pathologic Subtypes Clinical and EEG criteria are used to define a variety of sleep related epilepsy DISEASE subtypes.
Several types of epileptic syndromes DISEASE have a marked tendency to manifest only or pre- dominantly during sleep, or after arousal from sleep.
These include NFLE DISEASE , benign epilepsy DISEASE of childhood with centrotemporal spikes ( BECT DISEASE ), benign epilepsy DISEASE with occip- ital paroxysms DISEASE ( BEOP DISEASE ), early-onset DISEASE or late-onset DISEASE childhood occipital epilepsy DISEASE , juvenile myoclonic epilepsy DISEASE ( JME DISEASE ), generalized tonic-clonic seizures DISEASE on awakening, certain forms of temporal lobe epilepsy DISEASE , tonic seizure DISEASE (as a component of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome DISEASE ), Landau-Kleffner syndrome DISEASE , and continuous spike waves during NREM sleep (CSWS).
NFLE DISEASE may present in three distinct ways: (1) nocturnal paroxysmal arousal, (2) noc- turnal paroxysmal dystonia DISEASE , or (3) episodic nocturnal wanderings.
345 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders BECT DISEASE can present with focal clonic facial twitching that is often preceded by perioral numbness DISEASE .
These seizures DISEASE are more often seen in drowsiness DISEASE and sleep than wakeful- ness.
The clinical course is often benign with disappearance of the seizures DISEASE in adulthood.
BEOP DISEASE is characterized by focal seizures DISEASE marked by deviation of the eyes and vom- iting.
Sleep is the main precipitating factor, with most of the seizures DISEASE occurring soon after sleep onset or in the early hours of the morning.
There is frequent evolution to secondary generalized attacks.
The clinical evolution of the early-onset DISEASE type is benign, whereas in the late-onset DISEASE type with visual seizures DISEASE , the prognosis is uncertain.
JME DISEASE is characterized by massive bilaterally synchronous myoclonic jerks DISEASE , which are most frequently noted on awakening.
CSWS DISEASE (formerly known as electrical status epilepticus of sleep [ESES DISEASE ]) is charac- terized by continuous and diffuse slow spike-and-wave complexes persisting through NREM sleep (at least 85% of the duration), as well as neuropsychological and motor impairment.
Despite the continuous presence of epileptic DISEASE spike-wave activity on EEG in sleep, there may be no associated visible sleep related movement.
However, clinical epileptic seizures DISEASE are sometimes seen in the daytime.
Demographics There is no significant sex predominance.
Predisposing and Participating Factors Stress, sleep deprivation, irregularities of the sleep-wake rhythm, other sleep patholo- gies, and the use of stimulant drugs or other drugs that modify sleep architecture may predispose an individual to having seizures DISEASE .
Perinatal or prenatal problems, congenital hemiparesis DISEASE , and prior encephalopathy DISEASE may be considered antecedents of the syndrome of CSWS DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE may exacerbate sleep related seizures DISEASE and complicate their treatment.
Familial Patterns The idiopathic generalized epilepsies DISEASE form the largest category of epilepsies DISEASE that appear to be heritable but show no clear mendelian mode of transmission.
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy DISEASE and idiopathic generalized epilepsy DISEASE with adolescent onset appear to be genet- ically heterogeneous.
Among the partial epilepsies DISEASE , BECT DISEASE shows a familial pattern.
A form of autosomal dominant NFLE DISEASE with 70% to 80% penetrance has been reported in many countries, and a genetic heterogeneity also has been reported.
Genetic factors have not been established in CSWS DISEASE and seem to play a minor role.
Familial anteced- ents of epilepsy DISEASE (including febrile convulsions DISEASE ) have been found in 15% of cases.
346 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Onset, Course, and Complications Idiopathic generalized epilepsies DISEASE and partial epilepsy DISEASE may start at any age.
The onset of benign epilepsies DISEASE of childhood with centrotemporal or occipital spikes is between 4 and 12 years of age.
The onset of NFLE DISEASE is generally from age 10 to 16 years, mostly before the age of 20 years.
The average age of recognition of CSWS DISEASE is between 4 and 14 years, but the appearance of the first seizure DISEASE is early, typically between two months and 12 years of age.
Most patients with recurrent sleep related epilepsy DISEASE continue to have seizures DISEASE restricted to sleep.
In some cases, they may have seizures DISEASE during both sleep and wakefulness.
For focal epilepsies DISEASE (excluding BECT DISEASE and the early-onset type of BEOP DISEASE ), the prognosis is less favorable compared to generalized epilepsies DISEASE .
At least 35% of the focal seizures DISEASE confined to sleep are resistant to antiepileptic drugs.
Definitive data on the natural history of NFLE DISEASE are not available, although a high prev- alence of parasomnias DISEASE has been documented in NFLE DISEASE patients.
CSWS DISEASE resolves in many cases within three years after onset, and in almost all cases by the mid-teen years.
Despite normalization of the EEG and elimination of seizures DISEASE , neuropsychological impairment may persist.
Interictal paroxysmal activity may induce prolonged cognitive and motor impairment DISEASE .
Hyperkinesias DISEASE , aggressiveness DISEASE , and psy- chotic states may appear.
OSA DISEASE may exacerbate sleep related seizures DISEASE and complicate their treatment.
Pathology and Pathophysiology In idiopathic generalized epilepsy DISEASE , genetic factors are contributory.
Pathogenic markers, associated neurologic deficits DISEASE , or characteristic brain imaging findings have not been identified.
However, microdysgenesis DISEASE has been described in some forms of idiopathic generalized epilepsy DISEASE .
EEG recordings with sphenoidal or zygomatic leads may show epileptic DISEASE activity over the mesiotemporal regions in partial complex seizures DISEASE .
Video-polysomnographic (vPSG) analysis confirms that the motor pattern of NFLE DISEASE resembles that noted in orbital and mesial frontal seizures DISEASE .
Nocturnal frontal lobe sei-
zures involve a large neuronal network, and some of their clinical expressions are pos- sible consequences of disinhibition of innate motor patterns produced by the central pattern generator.
Recent reports derived from stereo-EEG studies seem to show that in some cases, the seizures DISEASE (in particular nocturnal wanderings) may arise from temporal or insular regions (rather than frontal regions) with a secondary spread to the cingulate regions.
They may sometimes mimic parasomnias DISEASE .
347 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Secondary bilateral synchrony is the mechanism generating CSWS.
This hypothesis is supported by EEG, intracranial recordings, EEG with coherence computer-assisted analysis, and metabolic (positron emission tomography
[PET] and single-photon emis- sion computed tomography [SPECT]) studies.
CSWS DISEASE associated with Landau-Kleffner syndrome DISEASE (an acquired epileptic aphasia DISEASE ) is probably secondary to an alteration of function over the temporal area.
Objective Findings Patients with suspected sleep related epilepsy DISEASE often need to be evaluated in the sleep laboratory with video and full-head EEG monitoring in order to obtain the correct diagnosis.
The characteristic interictal epileptiform activity in idiopathic general- ized epilepsies DISEASE usually increases during NREM sleep, whereas it decreases during REM sleep and wakefulness.
Interictal epileptiform activity may be associated with phasic arousals DISEASE .
In partial epilepsies DISEASE , the interictal epileptiform activity occurs in a localized distribu- tion with an increase in spike frequency in stages N2 and N3 compared to REM sleep.
Most of the seizures DISEASE are activated in stage N2 sleep.
Monitoring may also detect tran- sient autonomic alterations in cardiac rhythm, blood pressure, and respiration during seizures DISEASE .
If epilepsy DISEASE is suspected, a standard daytime 16-channel to 20-channel EEG (with partial or total sleep deprivation the night before, as indicated) should be per- formed.
Ambulatory 24-hour EEG recordings may be useful to detect distribution of interictal epileptiform activity during the sleep-wake cycle.
Nocturnal vPSG is the gold standard test for NFLE DISEASE .
Most of the seizures DISEASE appear during NREM sleep, with preponderance in NREM stages N1 and N2 (greater than 60%).
Rarely do they emerge from REM sleep.
In some cases, particularly in paroxysmal arousals DISEASE , the motor attacks may show a periodicity (every 20 seconds to two minutes).
Due to the fact that the discharges originate deep in the frontal lobe and are not visible using scalp EEG, the EEG during the attacks DISEASE is uninformative in almost half of the cases.
In a few cases, recording using intracranial or depth electrodes confirms the paroxysms DISEASE during or preceding the motor components.
The interictal sleep EEG is generally normal, but in 30% to 40% of subjects, focal epileptic abnormalities DISEASE are seen, predominantly in the anterior regions.
The video recording of the different types of attacks in NFLE DISEASE permits categorization of the seizures DISEASE and characterization of the main features.
During CSWS DISEASE , diffuse spike waves at two to 2.5 Hz occur in bursts, with or without clinical manifestations.
The discharges are continuous and occupy from 85% to 100%
348 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders of NREM sleep stages.
Abnormalities arise as soon as the patients fall asleep and dis- appear abruptly on awakening.
REM sleep is typically preserved, and the frequency of spike-wave discharges significantly decreases but the frontal predominance of the infrequent bursts may become more prominent.
In general, EEG patterns during REM sleep are similar to those in the awake records.
The sleep structure is normal, but the presence of almost continuous spike-wave discharges makes the recognition of normal NREM sleep EEG elements (such as K CHEMICAL complexes, spindles, or vertex sharp transients) difficult.
Differential Diagnosis NFLE DISEASE may be mistaken for a disorder of arousal from NREM such as sleepwalking, confusional DISEASE arousal, or sleep terror.
Ictal and interictal EEGs are often normal because the focus for the epileptic DISEASE discharge may be deep in the brain.
Disorders of arousal show a different pattern of episodes in that they occur out of stage N3 sleep, are not ste- reotyped, often have a sustained autonomic component, and are frequently seen during the first part of the night.
Partial arousal disorders tend to disappear or decrease in fre- quency after adolescence.
VPSG is often useful.
Sleep talking, bruxism DISEASE , and rhythmic movement disorders can be differentiated from nocturnal seizures DISEASE by history and vPSG recordings.
Benign neonatal sleep myoclonus DISEASE may be confused with clonic DISEASE or myoc- lonic seizures DISEASE during sleep.
In the elderly (older than 60 years), the main differentiation from RBD DISEASE is by vPSG recording.
PLMD DISEASE , sleep starts, and propriospinal myoclonus DISEASE at sleep onset do not show EEG epileptiform activity and belong in the category of move- ment disorders during sleep.
Jerks DISEASE , dyskinesias DISEASE , or arousal on resumption of breathing in patients with OSA DISEASE also enter into the differential diagnosis of sleep related epilepsy DISEASE .
Rare cases of anoxic syncope DISEASE with some clonic jerks DISEASE at the end of a prolonged (longer than two minutes) obstructive event have been described.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Not applicable or known.
Bilbliography Bazil C, Malow B, Sammaritano M. Sleep and epilepsy DISEASE : the clinical spectrum.

Brain 1999;122:1017–31.

Brain 1995;118:61–73.

Encephalography related to electrical status epilepticus DISEASE during slow sleep.
Electroencephalogr Clin Neurophysiol 1977;43:529–30.

Handb Clin Neurol 2011;99:1109–37.
Sleep Related Headaches DISEASE Alternate Names Various (see Clinical and Pathologic Subtypes).
Essential Features Sleep related headaches DISEASE are a group of unilateral or bilateral cephalalgias DISEASE of varying severity and duration that occur during sleep or upon awakening from sleep.
It is a heterogenous group of different headache DISEASE entities with the common feature of occur- rence during sleep or upon awakening.
The characteristics of specific subtypes of sleep related headache DISEASE are discussed in the Clinical and Pathologic Subtypes section below.
Associated Features Individual features associated with specific sleep related headache DISEASE types are discussed in the following section.
Clinical and Pathologic Subtypes Most sleep related headaches DISEASE are daytime headache DISEASE conditions that also may occur during sleep.
These include the primary headaches DISEASE such as migraine DISEASE , cluster head- ache DISEASE , and chronic paroxysmal hemicrania.
There are other primary headaches DISEASE that occur solely with sleep; for example, hypnic headaches DISEASE .
In addition, secondary head- aches DISEASE related to medical, neurological, psychiatric DISEASE , and sleep disorders DISEASE can cause sleep related headaches DISEASE .
Migraines DISEASE are common recurrent headaches DISEASE of moderate to severe intensity that last between four and 72 hours.
Pain DISEASE is typically unilateral and pulsating, aggra- vated by routine physical activity and associated with nausea DISEASE , and/or photophobia DISEASE Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders or phonophobia DISEASE .
They occur during the day or during sleep; approximately 50% of migraine DISEASE attacks occur between 4:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m.
Migraine headaches DISEASE do not have a fixed association with a particular sleep stage.
The patient may awaken with a migraine DISEASE out of REM sleep, or the headaches DISEASE may occur in relationship to stage N3 sleep.
A “classic migraine DISEASE ” headache DISEASE is preceded by an aura (if the patient is awake), which usually lasts four to 60 minutes and typically consists of homonymous visual field defects DISEASE and scintillating scotomas.
In some patients, the aura may continue or even begin during the headache DISEASE phase.
In contrast, “common migraine DISEASE ” does not start with an aura.
Other signs of neurological dysfunction DISEASE may include unilateral paresthesias DISEASE , weakness DISEASE , and aphasia DISEASE .
Features of brainstem involvement may include vertigo DISEASE , tinni- tus, dysarthria DISEASE , decreased hearing DISEASE , diplopia DISEASE , ataxia DISEASE , bilateral paresthesias DISEASE , and impaired level of consciousness.
A familial syndrome DISEASE with hemiplegia DISEASE is well described.
The hemiplegia DISEASE is ipsilateral or contralateral to the side of the headache DISEASE .
Cluster headaches DISEASE are severe, unilateral, periorbital or temporal headaches DISEASE that start quickly and peak within 10 to 15 minutes.
They have a relatively shorter duration, usually lasting 15 minutes to three hours (mean, 60 minutes).
The headaches DISEASE occur daily during cluster periods—usually one to three attacks per day over a period of one to two months.
Most patients have one cluster period per year, though this can vary from patient to patient.
The headaches DISEASE tend to occur at the same hour each day, with 75% of cluster episodes reported to occur between 9:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.
One or more cranial autonomic features (e.g., ipsilateral conjunctival injection DISEASE , lacrimation, nasal congestion DISEASE , rhinorrhea DISEASE , forehead and facial sweating, miosis DISEASE , ptosis DISEASE , or eyelid edema DISEASE ) invariably accompany attacks of cluster headaches DISEASE .
A strong predilection for attacks DISEASE to occur during sleep is well recognized, and these attacks are strongly related to REM sleep.
Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania DISEASE closely resembles cluster headaches DISEASE and consists of severe unilateral orbital, supraorbital, or temporal pain DISEASE associated with one or more cranial autonomic features.
However, the attacks DISEASE are usually of shorter duration (lasting two to 30 minutes) and occur more frequently, most often at a frequency of more than five per day.
In contrast to cluster headaches DISEASE , chronic paroxysmal hemicrania DISEASE is exqui- sitely sensitive to indomethacin CHEMICAL .
Attacks are also strongly associated with REM sleep.
Hypnic headaches DISEASE are an uncommon type of headache DISEASE that awakens the patient from sleep with a generalized or lateralized headache DISEASE that lasts at least 15 minutes (range, one to 180 minutes) with a frequency of at least 15 times per month.
Onset is typically after the age of 50, although similar headaches DISEASE are described rarely in younger indi- viduals, including children.
In comparison to cluster headaches DISEASE , hypnic headaches DISEASE are Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders less severe, often bilateral and not associated with cranial autonomic features.
Isolated nausea DISEASE , photophobia DISEASE , or phonophobia DISEASE may be present.
They may occur one to three times during the night, with many patients reporting that the headaches DISEASE occur at the same time of the night.
The headaches DISEASE tend to occur during REM sleep.
However, they also have been reported to occur during stage N3 sleep.
A positive therapeutic response to lithium CHEMICAL , indomethacin CHEMICAL , and caffeine CHEMICAL has been reported in many patients.
Other medical (e.g., hypertension DISEASE ), neurologic (e.g., brain tumors DISEASE , arteriovenous mal- DISEASE formations, cerebral venous thrombosis DISEASE and trauma DISEASE ), psychiatric DISEASE (e.g., depression DISEASE ), and sleep disorders DISEASE (e.g., snoring DISEASE and OSA DISEASE ) also can give rise to headaches DISEASE that may occur during sleep or upon awakening from sleep.
Patients with increased intracranial pressure (due, for example, to brain tumor DISEASE , hematoma DISEASE , arteriovenous malformations DISEASE , or cerebral venous thrombosis DISEASE ) may complain of headache DISEASE in the morning or head- ache DISEASE that starts after recumbence and improves after the patient is up for 30 to 60 minutes.
Nausea DISEASE , vomiting DISEASE , signs of focal neurological deficits DISEASE , and papilledema DISEASE may be present.
The headache DISEASE may worsen with bending down or sneezing DISEASE or with other activities that may cause further increase in intracranial pressure.
Sleep related headaches DISEASE can disrupt nocturnal sleep, although the exact prevalence of this complication is unknown.
Demographics The exact prevalence of sleep related headaches DISEASE is not known.
One study from a head- ache DISEASE clinic suggested that 17% of all headache DISEASE patients complain of nocturnal or early morning headaches DISEASE , and roughly half of these were related to an identifiable sleep disorder DISEASE .
However, many primary headache disorders DISEASE can occur during sleep as well.
Sleep related migraines DISEASE have been reported to increase in frequency with age.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Migraine headaches DISEASE have several predisposing factors that vary from patient to patient.
However, stress, relaxation, changes in weather and barometric pressure, changes in sleep pattern, hypoglycemia DISEASE , and specific foods (e.g., chocolate, Chinese food, alcohol CHEMICAL ) have been known to trigger migraine headaches DISEASE .
Alcohol CHEMICAL can also predispose an indi- vidual to having cluster headache DISEASE and chronic paroxysmal hemicrania DISEASE .
OSA DISEASE and atten- dant hypoxia DISEASE have been reported to be a trigger for cluster headache DISEASE .
However, sleep apnea DISEASE may also predispose a person to having other types of headache DISEASE and may inde- pendently lead to morning headaches DISEASE .
Change of sleep pattern and insomnia DISEASE can pre- dispose the patient to developing headaches DISEASE .
352 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Familial Patterns There is a positive family history for migraine DISEASE in up to 80% of patients with this disor- der.
Familial hemiplegic migraine DISEASE is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with a variety of genetic mutations identified on chromosomes 1 and 19.
Cluster headache DISEASE does not have as strong of a familial disposition as migraine headache DISEASE , but first-degree relatives of probands with cluster headache DISEASE are seven times more likely to develop cluster headaches DISEASE , and the concordance rates in monozygotic twins is 100%.
The inheritance patterns of hypnic headache DISEASE are not known.
Onset, Course, and Complications Migraine headache DISEASE usually starts in the second or third decade of life, with a slightly earlier onset in men than in women.
The mean age of onset of cluster headache DISEASE is 28 years.
Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania DISEASE has a wide range of onset, from childhood to old age.
Most patients with hypnic headache DISEASE are elderly, with the age of onset from 40 to 82 years.
Brain tumors DISEASE are more prevalent in the elderly, most occurring from the fifth decade to late life.
Most sleep related headaches DISEASE are benign and tend to decrease in frequency with age.
There may be spontaneous remissions that last from months to years.
Pregnancy has a variable effect on these headaches DISEASE .
Migraines DISEASE tend to decrease with age and, in women, may stop after menopause.
Cluster headaches DISEASE , as the name suggests, occur in clusters and are accompanied by pain-free intervals lasting months to a couple of years.
They also tend to decrease with age.
Hypnic headache DISEASE occurs infrequently.
Headaches DISEASE in patients with brain tumors DISEASE are related to an increase in intracranial pressure and tend to improve with treatment of the primary lesion and a decrease in intracranial pres- sure.
Some patients with OSA DISEASE report improvement of the headache DISEASE after treatment of the apnea DISEASE .
The sleep related headaches DISEASE can cause sleep disruption and insomnia DISEASE with decreased sleep efficiency.
Cluster headaches DISEASE occurring regularly in sleep can also lead to tran- sient situational insomnia DISEASE that may resolve after the remission or the treatment of the cluster headache DISEASE .
Depending on the etiology of the sleep related headache DISEASE (e.g., brain tumor DISEASE ), other complications may occur.
Developmental Issues Not applicable or known.
353 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Pathology and Pathophysiology Several anatomic areas are common to the physiology of both sleep and headaches DISEASE ; these include the brainstem and diencephalon, specifically the ventrolateral periaque- ductal gray and the posterior hypothalamus.
From a neurochemical perspective, ade- nosine CHEMICAL , melatonin CHEMICAL , and orexin also are involved in both the regulation of sleep and the evolution of headaches DISEASE .
Dysfunction of REM sleep and arousal mechanisms are common to many headache disorders DISEASE .
Data from transgenic models indicate that dis- ruption of sleep occurs in two forms of familial migraine DISEASE .
However, current mechanis- tic explanations of the relationship between sleep and headache DISEASE are speculative.
Objective Findings Polysomnographic aspects of sleep related headaches DISEASE need to be better defined.
Migraine headache DISEASE is reported to occur in association with REM sleep or stage N3 sleep.
An excess of stage N3 sleep also has been reported in patients with migraine DISEASE .
However, large controlled studies are not available.
Fifty percent of cluster headaches DISEASE and a majority of chronic paroxysmal hemicrania DISEASE are associated with REM sleep.
OSA DISEASE and hypoxia DISEASE during sleep may aggravate other sleep related headaches DISEASE or may be an independent cause of headache DISEASE .
Hypnic headache DISEASE occurs during sleep, with recent reports of headache DISEASE during REM sleep and uncommonly during stage N3 sleep.
Thus, the majority of sleep related headaches DISEASE seem to have some relationship with REM sleep, but there are no defining or pathognomonic polysomnographic aspects of indi- vidual headache DISEASE syndromes.
Neuroimaging studies (computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging head scans or angiography) may be performed to rule out structural, vascular, or infectious disease DISEASE processes that may cause headaches DISEASE .
Differential Diagnosis Sleep related headaches DISEASE are a heterogeneous group of different headache DISEASE entities with a common expression of occurrence during sleep.
They need to be differentiated from other headache DISEASE conditions that are not sleep related.
These include tension-type DISEASE head- aches DISEASE and headaches DISEASE associated with paranasal sinus inflammation DISEASE , tooth infection DISEASE , ear infection DISEASE , febrile illness DISEASE , benign intracranial hypertension DISEASE , intracranial hypoten- sion, vasculitis DISEASE , head trauma DISEASE , alcohol intoxication DISEASE , or bruxism DISEASE .
Although the initial presentation may be one of headache DISEASE , detailed history and examination will identify one of these contributing conditions.
Tension-type headaches DISEASE are bilateral headaches DISEASE with a feeling of a band-like tighten- ing sensation around the head.
In patients older than 50 years, giant cell arteritis DISEASE may Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders present with lateralized or bilateral headache DISEASE with tenderness DISEASE over the temporal area, accompanied by polymyalgia rheumatica and visual problems DISEASE , including loss of vision DISEASE .
Exploding head syndrome DISEASE is in the differential diagnosis of headache DISEASE because it may occur in association with the sleep period.
Patients report hearing an explosion in the head which is unaccompanied by pain DISEASE .
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Not applicable or known.
Bibliography Brennan KC, Charles A. Sleep and headache DISEASE .
Semin Neurol 2009;29:406–17.
Sleep Related Laryngospasm Alternate Names Stridor DISEASE , laryngeal dysfunction DISEASE .
Essential Features Sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE is a disorder in which tracheal muscle dysfunction DISEASE or para- tracheal soft-tissue swelling DISEASE causes stridor DISEASE or interruption of airflow, with associated awakening from sleep.
Patients may have total or near-total cessation of airflow while asleep, and suddenly arouse.
This brief respiratory blockage DISEASE (lasting an estimated five to 45 seconds) is often followed by a period of stridor DISEASE that lasts several minutes and gradually evolves to normal breathing.
Episodes are associated with panic DISEASE and fear of suffocation DISEASE ; cyanosis DISEASE may be observed.
In some cases of laryngospasm DISEASE during sleep, patients may have frequent laryngeal stridor DISEASE (which may be difficult for families to dif- ferentiate from snoring DISEASE ), associated tachypnea DISEASE , and intermittent upper airway blockage.
Associated Features Fear and panic DISEASE upon awakening often accompany events and may, at times, lead to insomnia DISEASE .
In some cases of sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE , gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE has been identified.
Less commonly, sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE has been related to underlying OSA DISEASE .
Clinical and Pathophysiological Subtypes Sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE may be associated with multisystem atrophy DISEASE , a neurode- generative disorder.
355 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Demographics Prevalence data do not exist.
Typical age of onset is unknown, although when the con- dition is due to multisystem atrophy DISEASE , affected individuals are typically older.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE may be associated with gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE .
Laryngeal dysfunction DISEASE seen in other disorders, including laryngeal tumors DISEASE and multisystem atrophy DISEASE , may cause sleep related stridor DISEASE and intermittent laryngospasm.
Precipitating factors include use of hypnotic or other central nervous system depressant medications.
Tonic-clonic seizures DISEASE may be a rare cause of sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE in children.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications Laryngospasm DISEASE is a common cause of death DISEASE in multiple system atrophy DISEASE .
Developmental Issues Not known.
Pathology and Pathophysiology When not associated with neurodegenerative disorders DISEASE of known pathology (e.g., mul- tisystem atrophy DISEASE ), the pathology and pathophysiology is uncertain.
Sleep related laryn- gospasm can be related to tracheal muscle dysfunction DISEASE , postnasal DISEASE drip, or reflux of gas- troesophageal contents causing irritation of soft tissue in the upper airway.
Laryngeal tumors DISEASE and multisystem atrophy DISEASE can cause laryngeal dysfunction DISEASE , resulting in sleep related laryngospasm.
Objective Findings Sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE may be observed on PSG with accompanying audio record- ing.
It is seen in all stages of sleep but is most severe in REM sleep.
Laryngospasm DISEASE can appear to be similar to snoring DISEASE on the polysomnographic snoring channel, but the audio recording will confirm the high-pitched inspiratory sound as laryngospasm.
OSA DISEASE has also been detected in some cases.
Patients or family members may mistake laryngospasm DISEASE for snoring DISEASE or sleep apnea DISEASE .
PSG evaluation may be necessary to distin- guish these disorders.
In children, PSG or sleep-deprived EEG may demonstrate sei- zures that manifest solely as nocturnal laryngospasm DISEASE .
Endoscopy of the upper airway is necessary to examine vocal cord function and to exclude upper airway pathology.
Gastroesophageal studies may reveal evidence of reflux.
356 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Differential Diagnosis OSA DISEASE may cause awakenings, with choking DISEASE or gasping for air, excessive daytime som- nolence, restlessness, or insomnia DISEASE .
If OSA DISEASE is a diagnostic consideration, sleep study is warranted.
Sleep related gastroesophageal reflux may result in coughing or choking DISEASE episodes during the night without true laryngospasm.
However, these episodes usually are described in the setting of chest pain DISEASE or “ heartburn DISEASE .”
One possible cause of sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE may be occult acid reflux DISEASE into the upper airway, causing irritation DISEASE or swelling DISEASE .
Sleep terrors DISEASE may be associated with sensations of impaired breathing or choking DISEASE , rapid heartbeat, and agitation DISEASE .
However, sleep terrors DISEASE are most common in children, and most patients do not focus on upper airway choking.
Panic disorder DISEASE can involve abrupt awakening with respiratory distress DISEASE , signs of sympathetic activity, and fear of dying.
However, most patients also have daytime episodes of panic DISEASE .
Nocturnal asthma DISEASE can result in sleep related coughing, wheezing DISEASE , or shortness of breath DISEASE .
REM sleep behavior disorder DISEASE ( RBD DISEASE ) may be in the differential diagnosis of laryngospasm DISEASE , but is generally recognizable by polysomnographic features of RBD DISEASE and a history of dream enactment.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Published reports generally have been limited to case series.
Clarification of the rela- tionship between laryngospasm DISEASE , sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE , and gastroesopha- geal reflux DISEASE is needed.

357 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Sleep Related Gastroesophageal Reflux Alternative Names Gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , nocturnal gastroesophageal reflux, supine gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , nocturnal heartburn DISEASE , reflux esophagitis DISEASE , esophagitis DISEASE , heartburn DISEASE .
Essential Features Sleep related gastroesophageal reflux ( GER DISEASE ) occurs when gastric contents cross the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) into the esophagus and, potentially, into more prox- imal sites during sleep time.
Symptoms are usually noticed during arousals DISEASE or awak- enings.
Symptoms may include heartburn DISEASE , substernal burning DISEASE , chest discomfort, a sour or bitter taste in the mouth, regurgitation, water brash, coughing, choking DISEASE , or unex- plained excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE , even in the absence of typical reflux symptoms.
Sleep related GER DISEASE is associated with sleep onset and sleep maintenance insomnia DISEASE , early morning awakenings DISEASE , sleep disturbances DISEASE , arousals DISEASE , unrefreshing sleep, daytime functioning difficulties DISEASE , and excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
GER DISEASE is a potential asthma DISEASE trigger, predisposes to aspiration, and is a cause of cough DISEASE .
GER DISEASE commonly coexists in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease DISEASE , cystic fibrosis DISEASE , idiopathic pulmo- DISEASE nary fibrosis DISEASE , and bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome DISEASE in lung transplant recipients.
Sleep related GER DISEASE is associated with sleep related laryngospasm DISEASE and is prevalent in patients with OSA DISEASE .
Associated Features Associated features of this disorder include dysphagia DISEASE , odynophagia DISEASE , laryngopharyn- DISEASE gitis, laryngospasm DISEASE , epigastric burning, chronic cough DISEASE , wheezing DISEASE , or chest pain DISEASE that may mimic angina DISEASE .
Other associated features of sleep related GER DISEASE include sleep onset and sleep maintenance insomnia DISEASE , excessive daytime sleepiness DISEASE , daytime fatigue DISEASE , poor daytime functioning, and reduced work productivity.
Patients with sleep related GER DISEASE also have a decrease in health-related quality of life and more health care visits.
Clinical and Pathological Subtypes Not applicable or known.
Demographics GER symptoms affect up to 44% of adults in the United States monthly, and 20% weekly.
Among patients with weekly heartburn DISEASE , 79% report GER DISEASE symptoms during sleep time, 57% report waking up during sleep, and 40% report that GER DISEASE during sleep time affected their ability to work the next day.
Among the 15,315 subjects of the Sleep Heart Health Study, 25% reported heartburn DISEASE during sleep.
In a review of 5 large Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders population studies, the mean prevalence of heartburn DISEASE during sleep time was 54% ± 22% (standard deviation).
In patients with OSA DISEASE , sleep related reflux symptoms are present in up to 62%.
Furthermore, in a trial examining consecutive asthmatics, 50% had awakenings from sleep because of heartburn DISEASE .
Thus, GER DISEASE symptoms during sleep time are common.
There is no known predilection for men or women.
However, men are more likely than women to develop Barrett esophagus DISEASE .
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors Predisposing factors for sleep related GER DISEASE include eating within two hours of bedtime, an elevated body mass index, erosive esophagitis DISEASE , and hiatal hernia.
Predictors of heart- burn during sleep include consumption of alcohol CHEMICAL or carbonated beverages, or the use of benzodiazepines CHEMICAL before sleep time.
Other predictors of heartburn DISEASE during sleep include the presence of insomnia DISEASE , hypertension DISEASE , asthma DISEASE , snoring DISEASE , or daytime sleepiness DISEASE .
The relationship between GER DISEASE and sleep disturbance DISEASE is bidirectional.
Sleep related GER DISEASE is associated with short sleep duration, difficulty falling asleep, arousals DISEASE , poor sleep quality, and early morning awakenings.
Conversely, sleep deprivation induces a state of esophageal hyperalgesia DISEASE to acid, thus worsening heartburn DISEASE symptoms.
Familial Patterns Not applicable or known.
Onset, Course, and Complications GER DISEASE occurs in all age groups, including infants and children.
Sleep disruption occurs more frequently in infants and children with GER DISEASE , compared to infants and children without GER DISEASE .
The incidence of GER DISEASE increases with age.
GER DISEASE may be more severe and is associated with more complications in older adults.
GER DISEASE is a chronic disease which is rarely cured, but it may be controlled with lifestyle, and medical and/or surgical therapies.
In patients with sleep related GER DISEASE , medical GER DISEASE therapy improved sleep disturbances DISEASE and daytime functioning in placebo-con- trolled trials.
Long-term outcome data are currently lacking.
If GER DISEASE is left untreated, the disease generally progresses and can be associated with many complications.
Esophageal complications DISEASE include esophagitis DISEASE , esophageal erosions DISEASE , esophageal stric- ture, ulcerations with stricture DISEASE , and Barrett esophagus DISEASE , which is thought to be a precur- sor to esophageal adenocarcinoma DISEASE .
Reflux can also result in dysphagia DISEASE , weight loss DISEASE , and upper gastrointestinal bleeding DISEASE .
Sleep related GER DISEASE is more commonly associated with erosive esophagitis DISEASE , stricture DISEASE , Barrett esophagitis DISEASE , and esophageal adenocarci- noma DISEASE , compared to diurnal reflux.
Extraesophageal complications DISEASE include pulmonary complications DISEASE previously discussed in the Essential Features section.
359 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Pathology and Pathophysiology Two major pathophysiologic mechanisms cause individual reflux DISEASE episodes.
Transient LES relaxations (LES relaxations occurring without esophageal contractions) account for 53% to 74% of GER DISEASE episodes.
Transient LES relaxations decrease the LES pres- sure to the gastric pressure gradient, facilitating the retrograde flow of gastric contents.
An LES pressure of 10 mm Hg or less is the second mechanism by which intra-abdom- inal pressure overcomes the LES pressure, resulting in the retrograde flow of gastric contents into the esophagus.
Pathophysiology of sleep related GER DISEASE is similar to diurnal GER DISEASE (i.e., transient LES relaxations and a low LES pressure).
However, sleep impacts esophageal physiology through the impairment of esophageal acid clearance mechanisms when GER DISEASE events occur.
With sleep onset, the upper esophageal sphincter (UES) pressure decreases and is lowest during N3 sleep, thus predisposing to aspiration.
The UES contractile reflex remains intact during sleep, including REM sleep.
Lower esophageal sphincter (LES) pressure remains unchanged during sleep.
Sleep increases the vagal threshold for trig- gering transient LES relaxations, so they usually do not occur during stable sleep and are usually confined to arousals DISEASE .
When GER DISEASE events occur during sleep, esophageal refluxate DISEASE clearance is prolonged and an arousal is required.
Sleep facilitates proxi- mal refluxate DISEASE migration toward the UES.
Saliva secretion, with its acid-neutralizing bicarbonate CHEMICAL , ceases during sleep.
Swallowing, required for esophageal peristalsis and refluxate DISEASE clearance, does not occur during sleep and is dependent on an arousal.
Sleep also delays gastric emptying DISEASE by disrupting gastromyoelectric function.
Events causing arousals DISEASE , including periodic limb movements and apneas DISEASE , could trigger transient LES relaxations and thus GER DISEASE events.
Because refluxate DISEASE clearance requires an arousal, medications decreasing the arousal response (including benzodiazepines CHEMICAL and zolp- idem) may prolong refluxate DISEASE clearance and increase the risk of aspiration during sleep.
The pathology of GER DISEASE includes abnormal esophageal manometry, endoscopy, and esophageal biopsy findings.
Esophageal manometry findings include an increased frequency of transient LES relaxations, altered or decreased esophageal peristaltic contraction amplitude, and a decrease in LES pressure.
Endoscopic findings include changes ranging from mild erythema DISEASE , erosions DISEASE , and ulcerations DISEASE to severe erosions DISEASE with stricture DISEASE .
Barrett esophagus DISEASE is identified when columnar tissue replaces the normal squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus.
Objective Findings Diagnostic testing is not required for sleep related GER DISEASE .
The diagnosis can be made if typical symptoms of heartburn DISEASE and/or regurgitation are present during sleep time.
360 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders PSG is not indicated.
Esophageal pH monitoring, which may be combined with esophageal impedance, objectively measures individual GER DISEASE events.
Esophageal monitoring is recommended in difficult, refractory cases, or when symptoms continue despite therapy.
Sleep related GER DISEASE is more likely to occur during the first two hours of sleep time.
Furthermore, in studies using combined esophageal pH monitoring with actigraphy, acid reflux events occurred primarily during the recumbent-awake period, versus the recumbent-asleep period.
Reflux events are more likely to occur in the right side down and supine positions than in the left side down position.
PSG without esophageal pH or impedance monitoring reveals arousals DISEASE that are often associated with swallows and a notable increase in chin EMG tone.
Esophageal pH monitoring detects acid reflux events and can be integrated with PSG.
Esophageal pH monitoring should be performed over a 24-hour period to improve the test’s sensitiv- ity and specificity, which approximate 90%.
The distal pH probe is placed 5 cm above the LES.
A proximal pH probe is often placed near the UES.
An acid reflux event is defined when the pH drops CHEMICAL to less than 4.0, and this variable is reported as time (%) where pH is less than 4.0.
The percent time where pH is less than 4 is reported over the total recording time, upright time and supine time.
Note that supine (in this testing) is defined as the period of time that the patient is in bed.
Symptom correlation is also helpful using the event marker on the device or diaries.
Normal esophageal pH times during the “supine” or sleep period are: 1) distal pH < 4 - less than 3.5% of the time; and 2) proximal pH < 4 - less than 0.6% of the time.
If esophageal pH monitoring is integrated with polysomnography, esophageal acid events can be cor- related with sleep events, including arousals DISEASE , apneas, laryngospasm DISEASE , and increased chin EMG tone.
Esophageal pH monitoring also can be performed simultaneously with actigraphy to correlate acid reflux events with sleep and wake periods.
Catheter- DISEASE free wireless pH systems are also available and are deployed into the esophagus, usually by endoscopy.
Esophageal impedance monitoring can be combined with pH probes detecting liquid, gas, or liquid gas in the esophagus, and can assess both acid and nonacid reflux DISEASE events.
Use of esophageal impedance monitoring is often performed in esophageal centers, and this technique would be difficult to integrate with polysomnography.
Other objective measures include esophageal endoscopy with or without biopsy in order to evaluate for esophagitis DISEASE and other esophageal complications DISEASE .
A histologic evaluation is required to establish a diagnosis of Barrett esophagus DISEASE .
361 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Differential Diagnosis The differential diagnosis is primarily with peptic ulcer disease DISEASE and angina DISEASE .
The chest pain DISEASE associated with GER DISEASE is sometimes indistinguishable from that of angina DISEASE .
Duodenal ulcer disease DISEASE is commonly associated with a burning epigastric pain DISEASE , and this can sometimes be similar to the pain DISEASE experienced by patients with GER DISEASE .
Other conditions that may be associated with GER DISEASE include OSA DISEASE , sleep related abnormal swallowing, and sleep related laryngospasm.
PSG evaluation with respiratory and pH monitoring can differentiate these disorders.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions Not applicable or known.

362 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Schey R, Dickman R, Parthasarathy S, et al.
Sleep deprivation is hyperalgesic DISEASE in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease DISEASE .
Gastroenterology 2007;133:1787–95. Shaheen NJ, Weinberg DS, Denberg TD DISEASE , et al.

Ann Intern Med 2012;157:808–16. Shaker R. Castell DO, Schoenfeld PS, et al.
Nighttime heartburn DISEASE is an under-appreciated clinical problem that impacts sleep and daytime function: the results of a Gallup survey conducted on behalf of the American Gastroenterological Association.
Am J Gastroenterol 2003;98:1487–93.
Sontag SJ, O’Connell S, Miller TQ CHEMICAL , et al.
Asthmatics have more nocturnal gasping and reflux symptoms than nonasthmatics, and they are related to bedtime eating.
Am J Gastroenterol 2004;99:789–96.
Sleep Related Myocardial Ischemia DISEASE Alternate Names Unstable angina DISEASE , coronary insufficiency-acute, nocturnal angina DISEASE , angina DISEASE decubitus, variant angina DISEASE , Prinzmetal angina DISEASE , vasospastic angina DISEASE , angina pectoris DISEASE , atherosclerotic heart disease DISEASE , asymptomatic cardiac ischemia DISEASE , silent ischemia DISEASE .
Essential Features Sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE is characterized by nocturnal reduction of blood flow to the myocardium, typically during sleep.
The symptoms of sleep related myo- CHEMICAL cardial ischemia DISEASE are very similar to those that characterize episodes of cardiac isch- emia CHEMICAL during the daytime.
Classically, there is a feeling of chest pressure or pain DISEASE that awakens the patient from sleep and may be described as a “viselike” discomfort.
The discomfort may radiate to the chin and jaw and to the arm, especially the left arm.
Associated Features Acute episodes of sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE sometimes elicit atrial or ventric- ular arrhythmias DISEASE .
Other associated presentations include acute onset of shortness of breath DISEASE that wakes the patient from sleep and that may be secondary to left ventricular diastolic dysfunction or ischemic mitral regurgitation DISEASE .
Other related features depend on the trigger for the cardiac ischemia DISEASE .
Ischemic events related to OSA DISEASE may present during those times of sleep when nocturnal desaturation DISEASE is most severe.
Cardiac isch- emia CHEMICAL related to hemodynamic changes or vasospasm DISEASE occurring during REM sleep may present in the early hours of the morning, around the time of waking, when REM sleep is most likely to occur.
Ischemia DISEASE associated with nocturnal hypotension DISEASE is most likely to occur during slow wave (N3) sleep, when blood pressure is lowest.
Clinical and Pathophysiologic Subtypes None known.
363 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Demographics The specifics of prevalence, sex ratios, and age ranges have not been comprehensively evaluated.
Some insights into demographics can be extrapolated, depending on the cause of nocturnal angina DISEASE .
For sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE triggered by OSA DISEASE , the preponderance of OSA DISEASE in men suggests that middle-aged men with severe OSA DISEASE are more likely to experience nocturnal angina DISEASE , particularly if they have more severe coronary artery disease DISEASE .
Variant angina DISEASE (also referred to as vasospastic DISEASE or Prinzmetal angina DISEASE ) more commonly affects younger populations, particularly women and those of Asian descent.
Cardiac ischemia DISEASE secondary to nocturnal hypotension DISEASE is more com- monly manifested in older individuals, particularly those with severe vasculopathy DISEASE who are taking multiple antihypertensive medications, and especially those in whom autonomic dysfunction DISEASE (related to either age or diabetes DISEASE ) may impair blood pressure homeostatic mechanisms.
Predisposing and Precipitating Factors
Predisposing factors include established coronary artery disease DISEASE or valvular disease DISEASE such as aortic stenosis DISEASE .
Because coronary filling occurs during diastole, conditions associated with reduced diastolic blood pressure, such as severe aortic regurgita- tion, may elicit nocturnal angina DISEASE , particularly in the presence of preexisting coro-
nary artery disease DISEASE .
Similarly, any predisposition to hypotension DISEASE , which is most likely to occur during slow wave (N3) sleep, may heighten risk.
Usual risk factors for coronary artery disease DISEASE that predispose an individual to the development of sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE include hypertension DISEASE , diabetes mellitus DISEASE , cigarette smoking, and hyperlipidemia DISEASE .
Retrospective and prospective studies suggest that OSA DISEASE may be a trigger for myo- CHEMICAL cardial infarction DISEASE and sudden death DISEASE that occurs at night.
Deeper oxyhemoglobin desaturations, which may be encountered in REM, particularly with coexisting pulmonary disease DISEASE or truncal-abdominal obesity DISEASE , are more likely to trigger cardiac ischemia DISEASE .
In patients with vasospastic angina DISEASE , use of nonselective β-adrenergic receptor-blocking agents may theoretically increase the likelihood of vasospasm DISEASE .
In patients with nocturnal angina DISEASE secondary to hypotension DISEASE , an excess of antihy- pertensive medications, as well as long-acting nitroglycerin CHEMICAL administered prior to sleep, may contribute.
Finally, in the proper clinical context, abuse of drugs such as amphetamine CHEMICAL , cocaine CHEMICAL , and other stimulants, needs to be considered in the evaluation of myocardial ischemia DISEASE .
Familial Patterns Familial patterns reflect those of the underlying disease process.
364 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Onset, Course, and Complications For angina DISEASE related to OSA DISEASE , the first presentation of nocturnal angina DISEASE may occur only when the severity of both the sleep apnea DISEASE and the coronary artery disease DISEASE are suffi- cient to elicit sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE .
This is likely to be most common in middle-aged to older men, particularly those who are overweight, although several studies have documented life-threatening OSA DISEASE related cardiac ischemia DISEASE in women.
It is notable that several studies have reported cardiac ischemia DISEASE in patients with OSA DISEASE even in the absence of severe coronary artery stenosis DISEASE .
ST segment changes occur- ring as a result of OSA DISEASE would be expected to resolve with treatment of the OSA DISEASE .
Regardless of the underlying etiology, potential complications of sleep related myo- CHEMICAL cardial ischemia DISEASE include acute left ventricular dysfunction DISEASE , ischemic mitral regur- gitation and pulmonary edema DISEASE , arrhythmias DISEASE , and even progression to myocardial infarction DISEASE and death DISEASE .
Pathology and Pathophysiology For sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE related to OSA DISEASE , the apnea-related hypoxemia DISEASE and surges in blood pressure and heart rate at termination of apnea DISEASE may all result in rel- ative myocardial oxygen deficiency DISEASE .
A substrate of preexisting severe coronary artery disease DISEASE is expected to exacerbate this problem.
Variant angina DISEASE may be more likely to occur during sleep because of the significant and abrupt fluctuations in cardiovascular neural control during REM sleep.
For nocturnal angina DISEASE related to hypotension DISEASE , perfu- sion of the coronary arteries during diastole makes maintenance of diastolic pressures during sleep important for adequate myocardial perfusion.
Autonomic insufficiency DISEASE due to old age, diabetes DISEASE , and medication effects blunts the ability of the cardiovascular system to maintain adequate blood pressure.
Objective Findings Electrocardiographic monitoring during sleep reveals horizontal or downsloping ST segment depression DISEASE of greater than or equal to 1 mm, or ST segment elevation of 1 mm or more.
The electrocardiographic evidence of sleep related coronary artery ischemia DISEASE is sometimes unaccompanied by chest discomfort or other symptoms (silent ischemia DISEASE ) and may be incidentally noted on either Holter monitoring or telemetry.
In general, ST segment abnormalities indicative of myocardial ischemia DISEASE are 1 mm or more horizontal or down-sloping depression DISEASE or ST segment elevation, which may be detected on the single lead electrocardiogram (ECG) employed in most sleep labo- ratories.
However, because the sensitivity of single-lead ECG in detecting ischemic changes is poor, the patient with symptoms compatible with angina DISEASE with a normal-ap- pearing single ECG channel should be further evaluated with multichannel ECG.
365 Appendix A: Sleep Related Medical and Neurological Disorders Sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE in patients without sleep related breathing disor- ders may be associated with REM sleep.
Slow wave sleep with a fall in blood pressure and heart rate can be associated with ischemia DISEASE .
Sleep related breathing disorders DISEASE , par- ticularly OSA DISEASE , may elicit oxygen CHEMICAL desaturation and consequent sleep related myocar- dial ischemia DISEASE .
The presence of cardiac arrhythmias DISEASE should prompt an evaluation for nocturnal ischemia DISEASE .
Differential Diagnosis Sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE must be differentiated from gastroesophageal reflux DISEASE , which may also be associated with chest discomfort.
The nature of the pain DISEASE , associated symptoms and prior history are helpful in making a distinction, although 12-lead ECG may be necessary in some cases.
Nocturnal panic attacks DISEASE may be asso- ciated with chest wall pain DISEASE and respiratory distress DISEASE .
Although the majority of patients with nocturnal panic DISEASE will have a history of daytime panic attacks DISEASE , a small percentage have only nocturnal events.
Nocturnal panic attacks DISEASE typically occur during transition from N2 to N3 sleep.
Other causes of nocturnal respiratory distress DISEASE , including heart failure DISEASE and pulmonary disease, may be confused with myocardial ischemic DISEASE episodes, although typical anginal chest pain DISEASE is not evident in these cases.
Chest pain DISEASE due to thoracic mass, pleuritic pain DISEASE , aortic aneurysm DISEASE , or other thoracic disease DISEASE should be considered in the differential diagnosis.
Chest wall pain DISEASE may be sec- CHEMICAL ondary to a variety of causes such as trauma DISEASE , muscle spasm DISEASE , or immobility.
Unresolved Issues and Further Directions More comprehensive data are needed to identify the prevalence and demographics of the various causes of sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE .
Further information is also needed to explore the relationship between sleep related myocardial ischemia DISEASE and the circadian variation in myocardial infarction DISEASE and sudden death DISEASE , particularly the role of treatment on outcomes.

367 Appendix B: ICD-10-CM Coding for Substance- Induced Sleep Disorders ICD-10-CM coding for substance-induced disorders DISEASE is more complex than ICD-9-CM coding.
The series F10.xxx-F19.xxx DISEASE (which is the general section for substance-in- duced mental and behavioral disorders DISEASE in ICD-10-CM) contains the pertinent codes for substance-induced sleep disorders DISEASE .
There are specific codes for sleep disorders DISEASE induced by alcohol CHEMICAL , opioids, sedatives, cocaine CHEMICAL , other stimulants CHEMICAL and other psychoactive sub- stances.
However, in the case of cannabis CHEMICAL , hallucinogens, nicotine CHEMICAL and inhalants, there are no sleep-specific codes.
In these instances, the coder must use an “unspecified” or “other” code.
A detailed list of the appropriate codes for substance-induced sleep dis- orders is included in the table below.

sleep disorder DISEASE Glossary Actigraphy: A measurement of physical activity, typically via a wrist-worn movement sensor, employed to estimate sleep and wakefulness based on relative levels of physical inactivity and activity.
Alveolar Hypoventilation DISEASE : A condition in which ventilation of the lung gas exchanging units is decreased relative to the carbon dioxide CHEMICAL production (excretion) such that the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide CHEMICAL is increased.
Alveolar ventilation is equal to the minute ventilation (tidal volume × respiratory rate) minus the dead space ventilation.
Apneic Threshold:
The value of PaCO2 below which central apnea DISEASE occurs during NREM sleep.
Ataxic Breathing: A breathing pattern consisting of irregular variation in tidal volume and respiratory rate, characteristic of the effects of opioids on breathing.
Autonomic Arousal: An abrupt shift in autonomic nervous system activity during sleep characterized by an increase in sympathetic activity, including heart rate and blood pressure.
Biological Day/Night: In humans, biological day refers to the internal circadian time when wakefulness and associated functions are promoted (e.g., when endogenous melatonin CHEMICAL levels are low).
Biological night refers to the internal circadian time when sleep and associated functions are promoted (e.g., when endogenous melatonin CHEMICAL levels are high).
Cataplexy DISEASE :
More than one episode of generally brief (< 2 minutes), usually bilaterally symmetrical sudden loss of muscle tone with retained consciousness.
The episodes are precipitated by strong emotions, usually positive, with almost all patients reporting some episodes precipitated by emotions associated with laughter.
Chemosensitivity: The sensitivity of the chemoreceptors to increases in PCO2 or decreases in PO2 CHEMICAL .
In humans this is measured by increases in ventilation associated with these stimuli.
Chronotype: Individual timing preference for various physical and mental activities, and sleep and wakefulness, over the course of a day.
“Morningness” refers to preference for earlier timing of activities and sleep initiation; “eveningness” refers to preference for later timing of activities and sleep initiation.
371 Glossary Circadian Misalignment: Incorrect or inappropriate timing of sleep and wakefulness with respect to internal circadian timing (e.g., the wake episode occurring entirely or partially during the biological night and/or the major sleep episode occurring entirely or partially during the biological day).
Circadian Period (tau): The time it takes to complete one circadian cycle (e.g., time from one circadian phase on day 1 to the same circadian phase on day 2).
Circadian Phase: The time at which a particular event occurs within the circadian cycle (e.g., onset, offset, trough, peak).
Circadian Rhythm: Biological oscillation, with a periodicity near 24 hours, which is clock- driven (i.e., not caused by external or non-circadian clock factors).
Comorbid Insomnia DISEASE : An insomnia syndrome DISEASE thought to have partial or total independence from a co-occurring sleep disorder DISEASE or sleep-disruptive medical, psychiatric DISEASE , substance dependence/abuse disorder DISEASE .
Conditioned Arousal: An arousal response developed by the repeated association of a specific setting such as the bedroom with unsuccessful sleep attempts.
Cortical Arousal: An abrupt shift of EEG frequency to a faster frequency lasting at least 3 seconds, indicating cortical activation.
Cyclic Alternating Pattern (CAP): The occurrence in NREM sleep of transient EEG events (phase A, subtypes A1, A2 and A3) interrupting the background activity (phase B).
CAP CHEMICAL is a sensitive marker of sleep instability DISEASE , usually increased in sleep disorders DISEASE that adversely affect sleep continuity.
Dim Light Melatonin CHEMICAL Onset (DLMO): A marker of internal circadian phase designated by the rise in melatonin CHEMICAL above low daytime levels, typically assessed via blood or salivary melatonin CHEMICAL levels.
Melatonin CHEMICAL levels are reduced by exposure to light and thus need to be assessed in dim light to be accurate.
Dopaminergic:
Related to the neurotransmitter dopamine CHEMICAL .
Dystonia DISEASE : Involuntary muscle contractions that result in slow repetitive movements DISEASE or abnormal postures.
372 Early Morning Awakening: The termination of sleep at least 30 minutes before the desired rising time with a concomitant reduced total sleep time compared to the usual premorbid sleep pattern.
Electromyogram (EMG): Physiological recording of muscle activity, based on electrical activity that accompanies muscle contraction.
For sleep monitoring purposes, EMG is typically recorded from skin surface rather than intramuscular electrodes.
Entrained/Entrainment: The successful end result (entrained) or process of (entrainment) synchronization of an internal circadian clock to the environment (e.g., light dark cycle), producing a stable phase relationship between the circadian clock and environmental time.
Fatigue: A lack of energy, accompanied by a desire to reduce or limit activity levels.
This symptom should be differentiated from reports of subjective sleepiness DISEASE as well as from unintended sleep episodes.
Homeostasis:
The tendency of a living organism to maintain internal equilibrium by adjusting and regulating its physiological processes.
Hypercapnia DISEASE : Elevation of the arterial partial pressure of carbon dioxide CHEMICAL (PaCO2) to a level > 45
mm
Hg during wakefulness.
Hypersomnolence DISEASE : Excessive sleepiness DISEASE during the normal wake period.
Hypersomnia DISEASE : A disorder characterized by excessive sleepiness DISEASE (e.g. idiopathic hypersomnia DISEASE ).
Hypnagogic Hallucinations DISEASE :
Vivid dreamlike experiences occurring at the transition from wake to sleep.
Hypnopompic Hallucinations DISEASE :
Vivid dreamlike experiences occurring at the transition from sleep to wake.
Myalgia DISEASE : Muscle pain DISEASE .
Nonrestorative Sleep: Sleep that is perceived to be poor in quality and unrefreshing, resulting in a sense of feeling unrested upon awakening.
373 Glossary Glossary Odds Ratio: A statistical term that provides a measure of the strength of relationship between two variables; the odds of an event occurring in one group compared to the odds of it occurring in another group.
Oneirism: Acting-out of dreams, usually from REM sleep.
Out of Center Sleep Testing: A sleep study performed outside of the sleep center, usually at a patient’s home and with limited (typically respiratory related) channels (parameters) recorded.
Parasomnia DISEASE Pseudo-Suicide: A death DISEASE , erroneously attributed by authorities to suicide, which results from complex parasomnia DISEASE , usually from NREM sleep.
Parkinson Disease DISEASE : A neurodegenerative movement disorder DISEASE which may result in bradykinesia DISEASE , rigidity DISEASE , tremor DISEASE , and/or postural instability, and eventually cognitive decline.
Phase Advance/Delay: A shift in the timing of the internal circadian clock in which circadian phase is moved earlier (advance, such as required for eastward jet travel or to assume an earlier sleep schedule) or later (delay, such as required for westward jet travel or to assume a later sleep schedule).
Phase Response Curve: Graphic representation that describes the circadian phase shifting response to a time cue (e.g., light) as a function of the internal circadian time at which the cue is presented.
Phase Tolerance:
The ability to be awake or asleep at an inappropriate internal circadian time.
Physiological Hyperarousal: A state of chronic physiologic arousal as reflected by measures such as increased mean latency on MSLT, increased metabolic rate and glucose CHEMICAL metabolism in the CNS ( PET CHEMICAL scan), decreased heart rate variability and increased heart rate.
PHOX2B DISEASE :
A paired-like homobox gene, mutation of which is the defining abnormality of Congenital Central Hypoventilation Syndrome DISEASE .
Prevalence: The proportion of the population affected by a disease or condition at a given time; prevalence indicates how widespread a disease or condition is, thereby serving as a measure of its burden on society.
374 REM Sleep without Atonia, REM-without DISEASE Atonia: The intermittent or continuous loss of the normal muscle atonia DISEASE of REM sleep.
Reverse First Night Effect: A propensity to sleep better than usual on the first night in the sleep laboratory.
Sleep Attacks: Inappropriate falling asleep with few or no prodromal symptoms of sleepiness DISEASE .
Sleep Diary (sleep log): An instrument used by individuals to keep records of their nightly sleep duration and quality over a period of days to weeks.
Sleep Drunkenness DISEASE (prolonged sleep inertia): Prolonged difficulty waking up after a night’s sleep or a nap with repeated returns to sleep, irritability DISEASE , automatic behavior and confusion DISEASE .
Sleep Homeostasis: A process which describes the propensity for sleep driven by duration of prior time awake and sleep history.
Sleep Hygiene: A set of rules/instructions about lifestyle ( caffeine CHEMICAL intake, alcohol CHEMICAL and tobacco use, diet, etc.)
and environmental factors (light, noise, temperature) that affect overall sleep duration and quality.
Sleep Onset REM Period ( SOREMP DISEASE ): REM sleep occurring within 15 minutes of sleep onset on a multiple sleep latency test or overnight polysomnogram.
Sleep Related Abnormal Sexual Behaviors: Any of a spectrum of sexualized behaviors DISEASE which arise from sleep, typically NREM sleep.
Sleep Related Violence: Violent behavior DISEASE which is associated with a NREM parasomnia DISEASE when the affected individual is accidentally provoked by another person in close proximity – usually a family member.
Suggested Immobilization Test: A procedure for evaluation of periodic leg movements and related sensory components of RLS DISEASE during resting wakefulness.
A standard polysomnogram recording without respiratory measures is used for one hour while the subject sits quietly awake and upright in bed with the legs outstretched.
